To recap: average food, bad service, a loud (at least on Monday night) and rundown restaurant.

A dear friend started a no repeat bar and dinner pledge for 2013, so we've been hitting the town hard and venturing outside of our comfort zone for libations with cool atmosphere's. Hotel bars usually aren't our go to unless its on the other side of Broad and we're feeling fancy. We stopped in here Friday night and enjoyed a few cocktails. The lounge itself is busy (obviously with hotel guests, tourists and the like) We created our own "table" and hung out for a bit before deciding to move on to greener pastures. I did enjoy my Philly Love cocktail with vodka, and passionfruit served up in a Champagne flute. Im always slightly annoyed with a bubble-less cocktail comes this way ( presentation is everything). One person ordered food and seemed to enjoy it I would come back its been scratched off the list, but i would recommend it to out of town guests who we're staying near the Lowes.

Great place to stop for some good food, good beer, and good conversation.

I have to echo what my friend, Kristi S., wrote in her review. I completely agree that I'm open to giving this place five stars because I have the feeling this place will wow me. Maybe one day I'll look back at this review and think, I was an idiot, but my visit here was a solid four stars, which still makes me a fan!

It was a 30 minute wait for indoor seating on a Saturday night. They definitely double downed on the outside seating, since I would say the size of the indoor seating is the same as the size of the outdoor. I have a huge fear of mosquitos (hey we live in Florida!) so the day I decide I'm ok with getting Zika is the day I'll sit outside in the summer. (If I know I will have to sit outside I will bathe in bug spray and everyone dining with me has to deal with the smell.) Luckily, there is a long communal table that is first come first serve, so I didn't have to sit outside (which is also first come first serve) or wait the thirty minutes. 

My friend and I both went with the flight of four beers, deciding to share. This means we got to try a total of eight beers. We're dark beer drinkers, so this means we tried every porter/stout/brown ale they had on their menu (and then had to pull a couple non-dark beers to hit our eight). Honestly, I enjoyed them all. Some of the beers are seasonal and tbh, when I do beer flights unless the beer name is written down in front of me, I can't keep them straight. You'll have to come and try them yourself.

I got the Beer B Q Turkey Burger. Maybe this is my fault, since it is in the name, but I wasn't a fan of the beer b q sauce. I found it overwhelming. It also came with fried jalapenos which I picked out (I am not a spice person). The bun was perfectly buttered. I honestly planned to just pick at the bun, but I ate the whole thing! If you're on a diet and think you have willpower, you're wrong and should just order it without the bun. I got the cheesy mashed potatoes as my side and man they were cheesy! I loved it. 

I had serious food envy as I watched other plates pass by me. The calzones were ginormous! Seriously, that could feed a family. The pretzels looked huge as well! That's an entree size and then some. They don't skimp on portions here.

I definitely enjoyed this place. I'm a fan!

Apparently this is the most expensive subway in Edmonton. Why not though, the line is always half way across SUB. When all my other options have run out, I will purchase food from subway, although I'm probably not very happy about it. They are quick, as with all subways and they don't engage with their customers, but you can't really expect anything more from a fast food chain.

Good place to catch a drink in the city.  Great beer selection (hello craft beer!), and their cocktails are a good concoction.  This was my first time here since they expanded the space, so everything looks new, bright and clean!  And they have tons of TVs, and not all broadcasting the same thing. Staff was very attentive, and the happy hour drink specials featured beer, wine and cocktails!  Definitely good if your group all have a different drink preference.

I had the fries and chicken fingers.  Both were good; the fingers were very crispy.  Seems like Mac and Cheese is their speciality, so I'll give a variation of it a try next time!

OK, I'm not an expert on Mexican food.  Is it authentic?  I've no clue.

Is it good?  Yes, it is.  Each and every time, the food has been good.

I knocked a star off because the service is hit and miss.  I've been in there and had absolutely stellar service, and I've been in there and it's just been "ok".  The service is consistently inconsistent.  You never know how the service will be!

But the food, for me, makes up for the chance you take on the service.

The salsa is wonderful, and the Acapulco Cheese Steak is stuff dreams are made of.  Try it.  You won't be sorry.

I would have liked to rate Trenasse 3.5 stars, but because of the service and atmosphere, I think this place is better than 3 stars. I visited Trenasse for a group brunch on a Saturday afternoon. Our server was excellent! I ordered the Boudin Hash and Eggs. When it arrived, it was visually appealing. The hash had good flavor, but they were super stingy with the potatoes. It was also just barely warm. My syrup was the hottest thing on my plate. The eggs were bland even with the cheese added. The bacon was delicious. The menu said it was sweet bacon, but it tasted more like a peppery bacon. Either way, I loved it! The biscuit was weird. It had the potential to be good, but was a bit too salty and the bottom half was dry. Overall, it was a decent breakfast and I would probably get it again.

I am a firm believer that a donut is like sex: even if it's bad you're still glad you had it.  Luckily, the donuts here are AMAZING!  

This review is just for the donuts, I have never had their cakes or pastries.  Make sure you have cash because this place doesn't accept credit cards.  There is an ATM in the gas station across the street, but it's just best to make sure you have a few bucks.  

Be prepared to wait.  I have never been to Long's and not waited in a line.  Luckily, you're waiting inside a bakery so it smells delicious.  They have a good variety of donuts (glazed and blueberry cake are my personal faves) at really great prices.  I don't think I have ever paid more than 5 bucks for my haul.  

Everyone knows and loves Long's donuts.  Last month I brought donuts to my co-workers and they all asked me "LONG'S????"  Unfortunately since I moved up to Broad Ripple, they weren't from Long's, and I had some sad faces in the conference room .

All in all:  Worth the wait and the hassle to bring cash!

We were a party of 4 stopping in for dinner during a day in Santa Barbara. The atmosphere was a bit strange, as we first noticed the outdoor patio area, which had a nicely dressed young lady playing classical piano. The inside also looked elegant. But then there were large TV's everywhere with sports on. It was as if a sports bar and a fine dining restaurant had a baby - but a strange one.

The staff, although friendly, seemed very young, unprofessional, and poorly trained. They were good kids, just didn't really fit the establishment. For instance, when someone in our party asked about the fish of the day, the server told us it was an Atlantic Sea Bass - which we ordered. We waited a while for our food, and about the time I was expecting it would be coming out, the server returned only to tell us that the fish of the day was actually a Cod. What? It was strange that A) he didn't know the fish of the day, B) he waited so long to tell us there was a mistake, and C) he didn't apologize for the error. Something else was ordered in its place, but it was then delivered later than the other entrees which came out. It was poor execution. Also, when we initially sat down and were poured waters, the water was warm - no even room temperature, but actually warm. When they refilled them, it was cold water with ice in it, but it seems like the initial pitcher must have been sitting out for a long time.

I had ordered the salmon salad, which was much smaller than what I had imagined an entree salad to be. The salmon was mediocre, and the small salad was missing one of the key ingredients the menu mentioned it included. I'm not sure if they were just out of the ingredient and they didn't want to tell me, or if it was just another mistake. The food was definitely overpriced for what it was.

In conclusion, the restaurant seemed confused on whether they were a classical piano playing fine dining restaurant or a sports bar. The staff was nice, but very young and seemingly very inexperienced. The food is nothing special and portion sizes are small and lacking quality. There are plenty of dining establishments in Santa Barbara, and I would recommend going elsewhere.

The ice cream at Creole Creamery is really rich and creamy. For me, almost overwhelmingly so. I consider myself to be an ice cream lover, but I find it difficult to finish one scoop here (not a bad thing, since I probably shouldn't consume more than one big scoop anyway).

I've had the red velvet and the black and gold. Both were deeelicious. I appreciate the creativity in flavor choices and also the patience of the folks behind the counter as we customers try various flavors.

I think next time I'm going to try a sorbet.

A bunch of folks have said it already, but yeah, it's cash only.

Hilda knows exactly what she's doing. Every day she has about 10 rotating flavors of Italian ice and 8 or so ice cream/Gelato flavors as well as vanilla custard. Her gelati treats are wonderfully unique. I prefer root beer Italian ice with vanilla custard. I went 3 times the first week I discovered this.

I'm no Cajun/Creole expert, but I really liked this place. We went on the recommendation of a local for crawfish etoufee, and it was excellent. They're pretty conservative as far as spicy goes, but they have their house pepper and hot sauces on the tables to compensate. They also take pride in their gumbo, which they start cooking early in the morning. Their French Quarter building is apparently 200 years old, and it's been a restaurant for a long time. They have an open-air courtyard and an inside decorated with murals that evoke New Orleans' past.

Oh how art thou Drago's?!?! Amazing!!! Every time I visit Drago's Seafood Restaurant I'm satisfied. The wait is usually long for a table but it's to be expected of a place with great food. We sat in the bartender area because a table was available right away. Our server was friendly and also funny. I ordered the dozen of chargrilled oysters and a side of rosemary potatoes. All my food was delicious. If you're in New Orleans Drago's is a must try.

Meh...maybe I ordered the wrong menu items but I didn't think it was all that great. 

I met a friend for lunch and ordered the half sandwich soup combo.  The soup sounded tasty, beer cheese, but it didn't live up to my expectations. It was too thick (almost velveeta like) and not very flavorful. 

For my half sandwich I ordered the chicken salad on toasted German rye.  Now I think I made the mistake of ordering it toasted, but I could tell the chicken salad was on par for being quite flavorful just the way it should be ordered.

The ambiance is cute and very German. They have a wide selection of beers which is nice for those not having to get back to work.

I love Dominican food and was excited to discover this affordable Dominican restaurant on 12th and Callowhill.  Friendly staff made for a good start but the lack of air conditioning made for a stifling and uncomfortable meal.  There were a variety of dishes to choose from.  I had the tres gulpes and was underwhelmed.  The fried cheese and salami were good but the base of the meal was mushy and not flavorful.  My friend had the Tilapia which came out black.  I did;t ask her how it tasted but it looked severely If I were to go back again I would order the chicken lunch special - half a chicken with rice and beans for $7.50.  Also getting it to go would prevent from having to eat in an un-airconditioned room.  This place has potential unfortunately I didn't feel like it was quite met.

Bland. The menu reads good but the finished product is just boring. This place could use some spice to it. Sure it's nice to get a vegetarian option but not when it tastes like a bowl of steamed vegis. It's supposed to be mexican , you know spicy and flavorful, not old people food.

Creole creamery rescued the day. After a couple of salty tacos I was looking for something sweet, and I'm so glad I stumbled upon the sampler. Your pick of 4 or 6 mini scoops of ice cream. A flight of ice cream? Yes, please! I asked for a couple of recommendations and ended up with King's cake, praline, molasses, and coconut. I couldn't pick my favorite. They were all my favorites. Great flavor combinations, fresh ingredients. Yum.
Absolutely the best ice cream and service ever! I can not say enough about this delicious place! My review will be short and sweet because you have to just do it and know you won't be disappointed!

I think it's the adorable sign that brings in the customers. Pretty small but cozy restaurant. We never have to wait but there's a strict no outside food or drink policy. The rest room is one and gender neutral. Always have to wait to wash your hands and it's usually dirty. 
But the restaurant has some good food. I come here for the soup dumplings and scallion pancakes. I love scallion pancakes! The dumplings are fine. Nothing to die for but tasty. They are a bit too doughy for my liking. My friend said they were too oily. But they come at a good price and you still leave with a warm feeling in your tummy.

A visit to St. Louis is not complete without a concrete from the famous Ted Drewes. Today the temp was 98 and it was definitely a day to get something cool. We drove in and as expected the lines were long but, were moving. We checked the menu on the side of the building and I decided on the "Cardinal Sin" concrete. Chocolate and cherries. My wife loves a "Hot Fudge Sundae". So we walked over to the walk up window and ordered. Within a minute we had a delicious treats and we were on our way. We are only visitors and it is too bad we don't have one of these locations where we live. I would visit a couple of times a week. If you are visiting the city make sure you try one of their 3 locations.

This was our first dinner on our trip to New Orleans.  We were tired and very hungry from our travels and the staff was incredibly welcoming and quick.   I really appreciated that they asked for our vaccination card as soon as we stated we wanted to eat here.  They sat us a table in the courtyard which was quiet and peaceful.  The service was fast which we appreciated being so hungry.  I loved the selection of wines and we ordered one from France to share and it was delicious.   We started with the baked brie with roasted garlic cream sauce & coulis & balsamic reduction and it was delicious.  We could have used a bit more bread though so some of our brie did go uneaten but that's ok.  My sister ordered the Mushroom De Vin with chicken, I got the angus medallions and my friend ordered the Boudin Sausage link.  It was all tasty but I think the angus medallions were a favorite.  The courtyard here is such a nice of breath of fresh air near the wilds of Bourbon St. and with little places to find good wine, this is a must-go to spot!

Came here Sunday for brunch and had a decent time! I would give 3.5 stars if I could!

We got seated right away and our waitress was very friendly. We started with a pitcher of mimosa for $25, not bad. I got the bacon appetizer which was very good, I liked the tomato jam. I got the waffle bendict which was just okay. I think it needed some syrup on the side and the eggs were a bit over done, no running yolk :( I also thought the waffles were super soggy, not really what I was expecting. The home fries though were cooked perfectly, very crispy.

Also on Alan Richman's list of 10 Best Cheesesteaks in Philadelphia, I stopped into Sonny's toward the end of my trip. Ironically, it's a few doors down from Campo's (which I didn't actually get to try). Very soft rolls, big savory coarsely chopped juicy (not oily) beef, Whiz with. Great balance of cheese/meat/onion/roll. Didn't have a chance to return, but it was quite a satisfying meal.

Oh boy. Normally I'm a fan of Ross's, but this particular store seemed tired and low stocked. It was during but not quite around Black Friday, so perhaps that's why.

A few of the items I picked up looked already damaged. Thumbs down.  For example, furniture was chipped.  Dog beds that were on the floor with footprints on them.

Interestingly, this is one of the few Ross's I've been to lately that didn't have a security guard right at the front door.  Just an observation.

How we came to be looking for pasta is a long story... suffice to say...we considered many places and of course we consulted yelp. 
We chose this chianti for these reasons: tons of parking, has a patio, half price wine Wednesday, and has pasta. So away we went....
We were there before 6:00 so found ourselves with a choice of seating on the patio. 
We selected a $75.00 bottle of wine (for 3 of us ) and at half price...you can do the math...it was exquisite.  
The bread is fresh and crusty. The salad was crisp and the dressing tart and tasty. 
I halved my pasta dish and added a starter salad, it was all just the right amount.  
We had a lovely server who was sweetly attentive.
 In the midst pf our dining experience one of my companions said "I'm having a really good experience, the right amount of sun and shade and the good wine and service. We have to come back."

This place is awesome! I initially heard about it from one of the chefs I was serving a farm dinner with.  I was lucky to try some of their off-menu creations at this event.

I finally made it to their location recently and it met my expectations and then some. To start with, parking was very easy as I was able to find a spot right in front of the house-looking restaurant.  I made a reservation for three. We started with 18 oysters and cocktails. The oysters were very fresh, delicious, and without rocks or sand.  The strawberry sauce was a delight and it was my first time having such a sauce with oysters.  The sangria cocktail had a bit too much for my liking, but the cavan mule  I had next made up for that.  For the main course, I had the tacos, which were light and scrumptious.  There were four tortillas, nicely seasoned chorizo, and guacamole rice with sides of sour cream and green sauce. Next time I would have ordered something more like the burger since I was not too full after my taco brunch entree. Service is great and attentive and the place is noisy, so be prepared for that. You will also see people nstagramming and taking pictures in front of Cavan and inside.  

I'll be back!

I ordered the pulled pork, brisket, and ribs with the platter. The premier side of mashed potatoes with bacon and cheese was to die for! Excellent quality for the price. I will definitely be visiting again. :)

Of the 4 family-owned Thai restaurants in this 4-block span of the U. City Loop, Thai Country Cafe is my favorite.  The menu doesn't really vary much from Thai Cafe or Thai Gai-Yang, but the execution, I think, is above the rest.

This was the place that I discovered my love of Thai food, so I try to come back whenever I'm back in St. Louis for a visit.  The prices are so cheap, it makes me do a double-take every time.

I always go for the Thai egg rolls and the corn cakes as appetizers.  They can't be beat.  And the pad thai here is probably the best I've ever had.  And it's the standard that I compare all other pad thai to whenever I have it around the country.

The only time I've ever had to wait for a table was when a whole dorm of Wash U freshman decided they all wanted to eat Thai food.  Aside from that, there's always room at Thai Country Cafe.  I've turned a bunch of friends on to the delicious food that it brings & they drive in from West County to eat here.  And it's definitely worth it!

First of all, I've never been to a Jimmy John's before.  I wish that I had started coming here a long time ago!  This location is on the south side of Gulf to Bay just east of US19 in Clearwater.  It's between Newk's and Tires Plus.  It has a quite nice dining area with lots of booths.

I ordered the Big Italian 8" with chips and a small soda.  The sandwich was just awesome! (see pics)  It had more than an ample amount of meat and cheese.  I got it on their regular bread which was great.  Their chips were OK.  They have an all-you-can-drink soda dispenser.  My lunch was just over $10 for all that food!!!

I was pleasantly surprised on how good my sandwich was.  The Jimmy John's crew was friendly and the surroundings were relaxing.  I am definitely going back there real soon!

You mean to tell me I can grab groceries AND tasty, hot pierogis AND signature lemonade all at the same place...without leaving my car? Say whaaaaaaat?!

This place was a savior on a rainy day during covid with a pup along, and a hungry daughter when I didn't want to grab her junk food or sit down somewhere, and when I needed one ingredient to make dinner that night. Wow! This place is genius, serves such a purpose, and is sooooooo appreciate (says the crazy busy mom)! 

The groceries are a tad more expensive, think $6 for butter, but so worth it at times! 

Pierogis (maybe 8/9 to an order with fried onions) and a quart of lemonade ran $9 total. Not bad.

What a concept!!!! I LOVE it!! 
The young boys working were both so sweet too!

I'm all about this style of convenience!!!

I went here once a couple years ago and the food was good but the people eating inside were drunk and obnoxious and made the whole meal terrible. Went again and am SO HAPPY I did! We had incredible service from Michael Warren! He was attentive, helpful, knew answers to questions we asked, checked in on us and was all around incredible! The food was also fantastic and just what we were looking for! The Creole Combination platter was perfect! A little bit of everything and it was all so so good! Such great flavor and the perfect amount for splitting!!!

So I was hoping to be wowed by this pizza as I can't find a decent one within 5 miles of my house.  

The decor here is not inviting---red and black like a bad, bachelor pad--with a metal rail painted with splotches.

Service was fine and friendly enough but I like a bit more chew to my dough and to be honest the texture seemed like the dough was rolled out twice.   Again, it's not bad, it's just not fantastic.   The sauce was not too sweet and the cheese was fine.   The pepperoni was excellent and just started to crisp up on the pie.   I might try the Sicilian next time but for your typical round pie, I'll keep looking.

The food we had was pretty average overall. Some hits and some misses... While we really liked the roti and found the mango chicken to be decent, the short rib special was very tough and chewy, and the pad thai seemed below par for other Thai places in the area. And our server had the personality of a piece of cardboard.

Five stars for the lovely Brittney who made our Bananas Foster this weekend. Yeah, we arrived at 9:15 and even though the doors were locked, we finagled our way inside because the sign out front said they closed at 10pm and Yelp said 10pm but a smile and a "Please" and we were shown to a table.

We'd already had a huge dinner and really, we just wanted this famous dessert at the place that invented it. So that's what we did.

Brittney took our orders, brought over the cart, and whipped up a pair of fresh Bananas Foster. As she did so, she told us the story of the restaurant and the provenance of this particular dessert. It was interesting and fun and even though I have no doubt that she's told the story a million times, it was fresh and fun.

As for the dessert? It was excellent and delicious and SWEET. This is about as "not keto" as you can get and I enjoyed every single bite.

[Review 14062 overall, 1384 of 2020, number 6 in Louisiana.]

For a hotel restaurant, this place has a very nice feel. The service was very, very good and it was a very nice place to sit down in. We really had gone out for breakfast, but by the time we lobbed at Trenasse, it was lunchtime.

My wife ordered boudin balls and a shrimp salad. Both were excellent. I ordered crab bisque and a po'boy. The latter was very good, the former, the crab bisque, was well past it's use by date. It had to be returned and left me with a bit of a stomach problem for the rest of the day. It was replaced by a quite nice bowl of gumbo.

I would say Trenasse would normally have been worth four or five stars, but serving me with last week's crab soup is unforgiveable, and I am reviewing my experience on the day, not expectations.

I reiterate the wait staff were the best I have experienced in New Orleans and one of the two who served us so very well, should walk slowly into the kitchen, look the chef squarely in the eye, then kick him in the nuts as hard as she possibly can. Y'all cain't fail so badly and expect anything else from those who should be supporting you.

When you're on your way home from work, the holidays have come and gone and you're looking for some good takeout. Chipotle comes to mind. Whether ordering off the app or in person, they've continued to keep up the slogan with their fresh ingredients and fast food timely service with it not being so fast food like as other big chains. The price difference is worth it in ingredients alone.

Tender.  Moist.  Lightly-breaded.  Yes, please! Joella's delivers on all of that and more!  

We chose this restaurant because I've had it bookmarked on Yelp for a little while.  When you arrive, it appears that this place is a fast food joint.  Don't let the looks deceive you.  Everything is cooked to order here.  Therefore, it does take some time for your order to come out.  Be patient, my friend.  It will be worth it.

When our order arrived (they bring it to your table), I could see that this was going to be good.  The waffles were just a tad bit dense, which I believe is a perfect attribute to a good Belgian waffle.  I opted to get the maple syrup (there was another choice, I just forget what it was).  I poured it all over my waffles, and what I didn't use on them I dipped my chicken in.

Speaking of that chicken, wow.  I got it without hotness (I am hot enough on my own!).  Like I said earlier, it was tender, moist, and lightly-breaded.  I was glad I went with the tenders rather than getting a bone-in piece of chicken.  I liked the fact that I had a nice, dippable product for my maple syrup.

Even though this is a pretty hands-off restaurant as far as the employees go, we were still asked how our meal was by one of the managers, and all of the employees we encountered were friendly.  They seemed to enjoy working there.  That's always a bonus.

Come try this place.  You won't be sorry!

Out of all my cheesesteaks during my visit to Philadelphia, this last meal in the airport was the best.

Located in the middle of terminal F, Tony Luke's serves a huge cheesesteak full of meat, cheese, and onions (optional). It was also the least messy cheesesteak I had in Philly, which I definitely appreciated. Most other ones I'd tried were super sloppy and saucy, but the Tony Luke's one held together without running all over the place. The staff here were also friendly, and the made-to-order sandwich only took 5 minutes. I actually didn't eat it until an hour later on the plane, but it stayed warm and tasty despite the delay.

So if you're hungry and need a tasty and filling choice (and if you have enough time to hike over to terminal F), visit Tony Luke's for your airport grub.

3.5 stars.

So the quest to find good KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) continues...

This establishment is split into two: a sit-down Korean restaurant and a bar/karaoke place. I ordered the KFC at the bar for take out- it is $20 for 20 wings, and $27 for 30 wings. There are 3 kinds: plain fried, spicy marinade, and soy marinade, and our family opted for the spicy. They also have whole fried chickens.

The wings were of decent size, and the marinade was good, though not as spicy as I would've liked. Seems like the standard for KFC is Soho, and Koko's wings have a nice marinade, but lacks the all-around crunchy layer on the outside. It comes pretty close, though. The deal is better here: $27 for 30 wings of larger size. The pickled radishes are crunchy, but a tad on the vinegary side (I think I tasted come celery in there as well).

One of my biggest pet peeves: when I smell cigarette smoke inside an establishment. Please go outside!

Well, I gotta do it now.  I gotta dock a star. 

You see, the definition of two stars in Yelp is "Meh. I've experienced better." 

At first, I really thought this place had a shot to win us over.  I liked my first visit there two days into it being opened.  I really did.  

I've been back twice since then.  Both times, I've been let down a bit.  

The first time back, I was with a group of 8 people.  And the general consensus that night was a big "Meh."  

I went back again last night.  And I'm just noticing that there are certain dishes that just aren't tasting right.  

For instance, the sushi really isn't supposed to taste a little bit fishy.  Yesterday, that's what I was getting.  It was subpar.  

There are still some scattered good dishes.  Last night, they had some Korean style steak that wasn't too bad.  But I came to get a cheap sushi fix mainly, and that's exactly what I got.  Cheap sushi.  

Granted, what are you supposed to expect from the sushi at places like this?  Well, I can now say that places like Sun Buffet do this better.  And it's as simple as getting some decent sushi grade fish.  I'm getting the feeling after two straight trips here to Ichiban that's not happening here, at least not consistently.  

The first time I had sushi here, it was fine.  Granted, that was the second day, and I'm sure everything was fresh on the second day.  Inconsistency seems to be slipping in now, and if there is one area you don't want to be inconsistent in, it's the sushi.  

This isn't just the sushi.  Several of the Chinese dishes served just seem to be off on the flavoring.  Plus, my wife had the macaroni and cheese and hated it.  I tasted it, and... well, let's just say that I can't believe they screwed up macaroni and cheese.  Zero flavor.  

I try not to be this harsh in my reviews.  But Ichiban... you gotta do better than this.  Really, you're screwing up some of the basics.  

I've definitely experienced better Chinese buffets.

Back and better than ever. On my latest trip to St. Louis I came here not once, but twice. The first time was with a group for late-night wine and bites. The service was attentive but not overbearing, as we waited for other members of our party to arrive. The food came out quickly yet was not rushed or slapdash, even given the lateness of the hour. 

The second time was for an early happy hour after a movie and shopping at Plaza Frontenac. The drink selection (and prices) couldn't be beat and the appetizers were elevated small plates. The shrimp with eggplant was delicious and maybe even better than some main dish entrees that I've had. Definitely a must-go for anyone looking for a quality dining option in this area.

I now come here expecting to possibly get sick. The process is messy, the food scraps are everywhere, the food is just kind of thrown around like I am at a food truck in New York City. The outcome is always yummy but I can't help but wonder if their food counter looks like that when the health inspector comes through. 

Every time..., I repeat, every time I come in the whole counter where the cheese, lettuce, meats, etc is horrendous! The toppings are mixed in with other toppings, serving dishes are stacked everywhere, not in the ice, and most recently the young gentleman at the grill was literally throwing my food on the grill and in the tin like he was angry. He was put out / or just carelessly over. I can maybe see this behavior if the line is out the door but I was the only person in line. 

Once my tacos were thrown into a tin I had to wait at the register while five teens got done goofing off. They didn't even see me... right there..., three feet from their face. 

Another strange thing, there were like 15 employees just goofing off. I swear employees outnumbered guests. The most amazing thing is even with 15 teeny boppers working, all areas were still in chaos and unstocked. The specialty drinks were clearly tapped out, crap was all over the drink section, the hot sauces were grossly messy, the tables were grimey, and the tray/trash section was horrendous.

I literally think there were 10 health code violations just from the perspective of being a customer, makes me nervous what is happening behind the counter. Their food is always delicious but the overshadow of food poising rang so loudly in my head this time around, I can't bring myself to eat at this location again. I hope I can give another franchise a chance after this experience.

Gross!

GREAT VALUE: $6.95 LUNCH SPECIAL
Little Chinatown is my lunch partner's favorite spot for Chinese in Jeff Parish. I have to admit the flavors are clean and not heavy in sauces. See pic - the garlic chicken was cooked perfectly. The onions were carmelized but the celery and peppers remained crisp. The lunch special at $6.95 which includes a spring roll, fried rice and egg drop,soup is a huge meal and one of the best values in the city.

SERVICE IS A MESS THOUGH
For some reason today, my standard off-the lunch menu meal was forgotten in the kitchen. Two tables arrived after I ordered and they were both finishing entrÃ©es before my soup was served. Next, I was incorrectly charged for an extra soup and tea so that had to be sorted. And they didn't wipe our table clean until after several requests.

Krispy Kreme Donuts sent me a coupon for a free donut and small drink for my birthday for being in their Eclub..so I took advantage of it. 
I went through their drive thru window and I ordered a lemon filled donut and small coca cola (not much of a coffee drinker) and gave her the coupon...she wished me a happy birthday and I took the food to work with me for a breakfast before I started my shift.

The donut was very fresh and it was so good. I highly recommend this for a quick pick me up or a small breakfast...I stop there once a month and get two dozen to take to my co-workers as a gift..They love this place too!!! and the drive thru is so convenient !!!

The prices you see on the yelp menu are not up to date.

Very tasty tofu.  Their tofu are in large generous chunks and  served in a tasty broth. I got mild as in little spicy, and it wasn't spicy at all so I think it's safe to go on the spicier side.  We got the beef soft tofu and the mushroom soft tofu.  It tastes the same, just different topping.  For mushroom, I think they use black mushrooms which I am not a fan.  Nonetheless, I love the flavor and tofu. This may be my new comfort food.  It's like chicken noodle soup. I could curl up in a blanket on the couch all day and have this.  Not sure if it says on the menu, but it comes with rice :-)

I didn't give it 5 because the BBQ squid was an utter disappointment.  It came in large pieces and was not sliced. It's also just topped with kimchi like something. I don't recommend the BBQ squid.

Every time I come here I like it more.  Perhaps because I may be getting used to its proletarian atmosphere, but perhaps more because every time I come inside, there is either a new improvement or a noticeable thorough cleaning.  And you can't beat the immediate service and the made-to-order food in the way that the customer wants it.  The earlier the better for seating and food and ambiance.  We were there about 9:30 AM and it was a quiet crowd with normal attire...  As we were leaving, it seemed like the line to the Jerry Springer show, with cooky people coming in with their tattooes and piercings...  On the other hand, maybe we should have come later....  :-)  

Cash only.  No outside seating, but free Wi-Fi...

Great place to have enchiladas! Forget about the complicated stuff that the only way you can have is by going to Mexico. Don't try the Pansita or the Barbacoa or even the tacos, this things are far more complex and difficult that one my think and you really really need to be in Mexico to get ALL of the necessary ingredients to pull it off. 

Try the quesadillas, quesofundido with mushrooms, tacos dorados, but above all try every kind of enchilada that have. You will thank me! :)

Going to a Mexican restaurant on Cinco de Mayo is like going to the concession stand at halftime at a football game.
You are bound to hit crowds.
It was not the smartest idea, but I thought we would beat the crowds by arriving at 2pm.
No such luck, a half hour wait.
We have been in Reno for 22 years  and never ate here, so a half hour was doable.
After a short wait, we were seated and drink orders were taken.
The restaurant is like walking into a outdoor patio setting in Mexico.
Our waitress was great, she was so busy with Cinco de Mayo.
I ordered two shrimp enchiladas, with Verde sauce and a rellano on the side.
Both were very good, full of flavor and generous portions.
My enchiladas came with Verde sauce, just the right amount of spice.
I am looking forward to returning.

I noticed this place the first time I went all the way up to this area to check out Cafe Soho as it's only about a minute away from it.  I love tofu and Korean food, and after reading the good Yelp reviews, I knew it was a place I had to check out especially now with Miga in downtown Philly being closed.  

The decor is all wooden and what I assume is old traditional Korean style.  We were seated immediately and given menus.  In less than a minute we were brought a pitcher of water and the waiter was ready to take our order.  However, I wasn't that familiar with the menu, so we weren't ready yet.  I decided on the pa-jun (Korean pancake), that I seem to order at every Korean restaurant I go to because I like it so much, and an order of the vegetarian mushroom soft tofu stew.  The waiter asked us if we were sure we didn't want seafood and not the vegetarian pajun.  I will eat seafood, but I'm not too fond of the octopus and squid that usually end up in Korean food.  I told him I preferred the vegetable one.

About 6 Banchan (Korean side dishes) were brought out including:  Kimchi, beansprout salad, seaweed salad, and a few other things that I'm not sure exactly what they were.  They were okay, but I've had better at other places. We were also brought a raw egg, which I assumed was for our stew.   Our food came out within five minutes, and then the waiter was never to be seen again until we flagged him down for a check.  

The pajun was okay, but only had scallions in it.  At other restaurants when I order the vegetarian one, other veggies like kimchi, peppers, mushrooms, or carrots are usually included as well, so that was a bit disappointing.  The tofu stew was good and boiling hot in temperature and spice, but I didn't think it was superior to ones at other restaurants.  I did like the rice in the stone bowl, but it was really hard to get it off the sides and no one came around and poured the warm water/tea in our stone bowl at the end of the meal like others had written about.  We also were not instructed what to do with the egg (I wasn't sure if it was for the rice in the stone bowl or the stew), and the server dropped off the food so quickly and ran off that I couldn't even ask.  I wasn't getting any 3G on my phone, so I couldn't check back here on Yelp, so I guessed and put it in the stew.  It tasted good though.

The best part of the meal was the low price.  We only paid a little over $20 for the whole meal for the two of us and we left feeling full.  I would go back if I was in the area for the stew again, but I don't think I'm going to drive out of the way for it since the service was a little lackluster and I can get similar dishes at other places.

I felt like doing some food exploring today so I "dragged" a friend with me to Kelp for lunch. We had never been there before but had heard good things. And if you read my reviews you know that I love to try new places. 

We had no problems finding it. It is in a plaza on Bay to Bay. It is the same plaza that Feet First (running store), Pilot Bank, Massage Studio, Starbucks, Soleil Tanning, and Taco Fusion are all in. 

When we arrived we were able to park right up front. They have some spots reserved just for Kelp customers. We were also pretty happy to see the outdoor seating because it was a gorgeous day out. A couple actually had their puppy with them at their table outside :) Note that there is also indoor seating. It's a small place and I'm not sure how busy they get but between the indoor and outdoor seating, you should be good.

Their lunch options are great. For $12 you get 2 full rolls, a miso soup and a ginger salad. I went with that option. My friend got 2 rolls (see my pictures) and she really enjoyed them both. And their lunch, all the way until 4pm!

Service was very nice. Everyone was very friendly. They were attentive and the service was nice and fast.

Basically, I'll be back for more :)

I haven't really gotten into ramen. I know, I know. 

But I also stalk Mike Solomonov's favorite places and Neighborhood Ramen was one of them. So after a not so fun comedy show last night, this was a top choice at 10 PM. 

The first lady at the counter seemed super disinterested for some reason and after taking the order of the person in front of me (we were the only two parties at that moment), went to one of the tables and started having her meal. No eye contact, no verbal communication. Maybe she was having a bad day. Or maybe...

Another lady came out from the back, the polar opposite of Lady One. Super friendly, welcomed me on my first time there and was super sweet throughout. She even got us chopsticks/forks/bowls despite this being a mostly self-service restaurant . Thank you for making up for Lady One's coldness. 

She started us off with complimentary marinated spicy cucumbers, which were delicious and had a little kick. We ordered gyoza - their take ontheir was super interesting. Pan fried with a lot of filling, and served in tangy liquid (vinegar?) which was delicious compared to their commonly dry counterparts.

The Tantan seemed like the most popular choice and the two of us ordered one, extra spicy (which is an additional $1). It was kind of like their take on the Dan Dan noodles which I love. The sesame paste made it a thicker broth which we lapped up ravenously. The (miso?) marinated egg was boiled to perfection, with a soft yet firm yolk that we were a little sad to have to share. Definitely a hearty portion. 

Definitely see myself returning here, especially for late night cravings (open till midnight).

Coming in from a Bellvue roadtrip we stopped in here at around 3.00 pm on a Tuesday.  There were still a few stragglers from lunch - the vibe is dark and soothing, gentle Moby tracks were wafting and the lighting low.  Service prompt and attentive, panko fried avocado appy was delicious with hot mayo.  The Wasabi roll was beautifully presented and tasty but devoid of wasabi, no matter plenty to dip into on the other plates.  The Maguro and Saba were both delicious and generously cut.  A ginger Martini thingy was quite lovely.  We split all this for $55, it seemed a little pricey and it is far from home but definitely A-OK.  Private rooms and hibachi tables available.

This charming, traditionally decorated restaurant gets crowded, so arrive before or after the main dinner rush to take advantage of their parking lot. Pressing a red button on the table calls service. English isn't a strong point for some staff, but luckily for us, a friend spoke Korean and was able to communicate our complicated requests.

The kimchi version of their famous soon du bu ($9; soft tofu soup with beef and spiced cabbage) was damn good, sporting a decent kick and vibrant flavors. Served in a stone bowl with rice on the side, I cooked a raw egg in the light, but filling, soup to add texture. The kitchen go all out with the spices (I requested mine "Very Spicy"), but it was SO good I didn't care. (Next to me, my friend was dying - she can handle hot food, so maybe our bowls were switched?) Of the banchan, the cucumbers were a winner.

Jong Ja Jip has been recommended to me time and time again and I finally tasted firsthand why. It's an excellent value: our group of ten paid roughly $11/person. Highly recommended!

I can't believe I forgot to review this place. I came here for a bachelorette party, we were staying at an AirBnb nearby. As someone who doesn't eat meat, I was actually surprised at how accommodating the restaurant was. I had black bean burger tacos with a side of mac and cheese. I'm not really into the pimento mac and cheese, but if it's your thing, I'm sure you'd like it here. The tacos were great, and the server was lovely.

We have a great evening sitting in the outdoor nicely heated tent. We had a chance to chat with some of the workers and while their spirits are high, the fatigue of the ever changing rules is exhausting. My heart truly broke for them. 

We had been visiting a couple other local places that day, so we weren't starving. But I ordered the shrimp and filet skewers, while it's an appetizer, it could easily be a meal. The filet tips were so good, packed with flavor and very tender. The wild rice it was served over was perfectly cooked. We also ordered the arugula and prosciutto flatbread with a fig jam and topped with goat cheese. It was incredible. Loved the saltiness against the sweetness and the goat cheese added a great tang to it.

Great meal and look forward to going back soon!

Pretty disappointed after choosing Bourbon & Branch for brunch during my latest visit to Philly in Sept. I was upset with the lack of flavor the meals had. I chose this place for it's good reviews but I was not at all impressed. I ordered the buffalo chicken sandwich and fries. Not sure if it was the meals we ordered but I could have done without.

I think Juan's gets a lot of unnecessary flack. It is what it is. I hate that saying but it is true in Juan's case. This is not the restaurant you go to for Mexican food. But then again, it never says "Mexican restaurant" it says "Creole TaquerÃ­a"; whatever the heck that means. Their margaritas are delicious but small for the price. If you like your margaritas in a "big girl glass" and not a "sippie cup" go during happy hour, they're 2 for 1 (double for the price of one). If you care that the wait staff all has tattoo sleeves and not real sleeves, don't go to Juan's. 
I have to admit, I have a soft spot for Juan's. I've been coming here since I was a lowly tourist and it was a great place to grab a drink and some food when I first moved to the city and knew no one. I have numbers in my phone that say things like "Annie-Juan's". These were people I first met when eating at the bar by my lonesome and we had such a great time that we continued to hang out and exchange numbers. So cut Juan's some slack huh? Food wise: I love the pork and slaw tacos (usual), the Mardi Gras Indian tacos (veggie option), and the bacon azul quesadilla (when you want something that just might kill ya, but at least it's a happy death). Happy hour really is the best time to go, cheaper drinks and fewer crowds.

I lived in St. Louis for six years and whenever I go back, Ted Drewes tops my list of places I "have" to go.  And I'm not even an ice cream person.  Went back earlier this week and was not disappointed.  The long lines at all hours are a testament to the reputation of Ted Drewes.  No worries; it's the best-oiled ice cream operation ever, and the lines move quickly.

My favorite concrete ever is seasonal - the Big Apple.  It's a piece of apple pie mixed into vanilla ice cream.  

A must if you're in St. Louis.

Lee How Fook is a pleasant spot to dine with friends.  It's a BYOB and we sat around after dinner, finishing our wine without feeling rushed.  Service is good (by casual Chinese restaurant standards), but food is not so much.

THE GOOD NEWS:
Salt-baked squid is great.  Good texture, salty, tasty and fragrant.  4+ stars

Sauteed snow pea shoots (green leafy vegetables) are good.  I love snow pea leaves and there's nothing wrong with these! 3.5 stars

White rice: acceptable.  Not great, not fluffy, but edible and included with meal.

THE BAD NEWS:
Pan fried wide rice noodles (ho fun) with beef: so-so, mixed.  Noodles themselves are a good texture, and fried nicely, but beef is hard to eat: overcooked, hard pieces lacking in flavour.  I was surprised by how bad the beef was, since even the mediocre Chinese restaurants I'm used to will tenderize and season their beef adequately.  Lesson learned: Avoid the beef. 2 stars for the dish.

Szechuan eggplant is disappointing.  First of all, the flavour of this dish is not Szechuan at all.  Nor is it spicy.  Instead, it comes with something like a sweet and sour sauce -- and not a good one.  The texture of the eggplant was fine, tender and soft, but a disaster flavour-wise.  I normally love Chinese eggplant, but the flavour on this was such a turn-off that I didn't want to eat much of this dish.  To be avoided. 1 star.

Pork with mushrooms, bamboo shoots is again not something I'd want again.  Pork is overcooked, and lacked flavour.  The vegetable stuff in the dish is fine, nothing amazing, but nothing gone horribly wrong with it.  Avoid pork. 1.5 stars.

SUMMARY:
Could go back for salt-baked squid, snow pea leaves, and ho fun noodles, but I'd want to avoid anything with beef or pork.  Might need to avoid anything that requires flavouring (with sauces, slurries, etc.)  The simpler dishes seem to work best here, e.g. SQUID + SALT = yummy, GREENS + GARLIC = good.

I'm putting an optimistic spin on things -- partly because I had such a great time with friends here -- but frankly, it's pretty bad when a Chinese restaurant can neither manage a dish with more than 2 main ingredients, nor pull together an acceptable sauce when so many dishes depend on it.

General rating ends up around 2 stars: I've definitely had better.

Full disclosure: the owner is a friend of mine.

And he loves what he does. That dedication and passion for accessible cuisine really shines through here. 

I've probably had a third of the menu here so far - stand outs are the mac and cheese (it's not a side - share it), the banh mi sliders, the pulled pork nachos, and the homemade parmesan truffle chips. The bang bang chicken is also pretty good - be warned, however, because even though I can eat a spoonful of ghost pepper sauce and still remain coherent, the bang bang chicken made me sweat for a good 20 minutes. It's not so much a super sharp heat (6 out of 10 with ghost pepper at 9 in my opinion), but it's a sustained one. Good, but if you're not a lover of heat, you might wanna stay away.

Also, tons of beers. Ithaca beers. I'm always a bit disappointed at how many craft bars don't have Ithaca beers available, But the last few times I've been here, they had both Cascazilla and Flower Power IPA. Delicious.

Also, 5 dollars for a pour of whiskey? Seriously? Get a designated driver, and try 5 of them. 

It's also a beautiful space. My kind of ambience. They also play a lot of funk, R&B, classic rock, and other selections in the dining area. Not a lot of places stray from Buddha Bar or top 40, so this was welcome change for me. Put on some James Brown and you've made my night.

Also, check out their shows and movie nights and the like throughout the week. I saw a band there last Saturday that was actually quite good. Alt rock, local band, you know the deal. I'm pissed that I forgot their name, but hey - I was 6 deep and still drinking when I got there. 

Check the place out.

Came here with a group of 6 to celebrate my dad's birthday. We had reservations for 7:00pm on a Friday but wasn't nearly as crowded as the host (who was very pretentious) made it seem.

The menu is tapas style so it's perfect for large groups and sharing. Definitely more of a 'gastropub' vibe than a standard restaurant. We tried almost everything on the menu:
+ Olives - good
+ Tempura shrimp - delicious! a table favorite! 
+ Three Muses fries - delicious! 
+ Bacon wrapped bleu cheese stuff dates - good but very sweet (more like a dessert)
+ Lamb sliders - good!
+ Pork belly - delicious! a table favorite!
+ Bulgogi rice bowl - good! 
+ Fish tacos - delicious!
+ Mac n cheese - disappointing; we heard rave reviews about this one but it was pretty bland!
+ Kale bruschetta - delicious!
+ Cheese plate - ok, nothing special!

The meal was made even better by the good/attentive service and fun atmosphere. It was casual, fun and lively thanks to the music.

We had a really good dinner here. We made reservations as it was a Friday night. Very cute space and love the booths. Our waitress was amazing very attentive without being intrusive. Good beer selection and yummy margheritas. We had the queso as an appetizer and it was really good, best chips I've had in a Mexican restaurant in a long time. The tacos we had were delicious, chicken al caborne. We also had a side of beans that were yummy. They had meat in them and had a smokey flavor. We loved nada and will be back.

I have written a review for the CBD location of Jimmy John's on Poydras St. 

The menu is the same, the service is the same, the food is the same & the restaurant is just as clean.

My favorite grocery store in town. It's not the ideal place for getting good, necessarily or environmentally, but it is great to get 99 percent on my grocery list. Helpful staff, fresh produce, great fish and meat--what's there not to like? The downside is the price (though I contend it isn't MUCH more expensive than other store or Trader Joes--it really is "$$"), but you do get what you pay for. It's not perfect, but it is spacious, welcoming, and warm--I'm often less stressed when I leave than when I arrive. And yes, when they ask you if you found everything you are looking for, answer honestly, because they might discount an item to meet your needs.

I'm still on the search for the best Mexican food in New Orleans.  Unfortunately, I did not find it at Juan's Flying Burrito.  I was seated by an indifferent waitress.  I got the chips and salsa.  Chips were ok, salsa was very mediocre.  I ordered the flying burrito, which, according to the menu, consisted of chicken, shrimp, and steak.  There might have been two small pieces of steak in the entire burrito.  In addition, the whole thing was poorly wrapped, and came apart easily.  It was ok, but definitely not worth the $8.25 I paid for it.  

As other Yelpers mentioned, service is not great.  The waitress was very indifferent; I don't think she smiled once.  In addition, the whole restaurant feels kind of...cramped.  Bottom line: OK Mexican food, but not a good value.  I would recommend Felipe's Taqueria or Superior Grill over this place any day.

Gumbo is great. Red beans and rice is amazing. Everything else is relatively "average" (which is still very enjoyable) compared to the shops around. 

This is where the bf lost his "gumboginity" and lived to tell the tale. I could have sworn up and down he would hate gumbo since he hates risotto and anything else involving soupy rice, but y'all made him (and me) a believer. 

Summary: gumbo is 5 stars. Red beans and rice is 4-4.5 stars. Everything else is 3.5 stars.  

Service/ambience: good. 4 stars.

My friend and I had been craving dim sum for weeks! We finally caved today and went to TC Choy's for lunch. She had been there before but it was my first. 

When we arrived at noon we parked in the private lot. There is also street parking in the area but the private lot is much more convenient. When we walked in we were greeted and seated immediately. There were actually only 2 other people dining in the entire restaurant. Because it was lunch time we expected it to be busy but hey, no complaints there. 

We shared 5 small plates total. The food was pretty good but we paid $40 for 2 people for lunch for only 5 small plates that are like tapas. In my opinion it is overpriced. Who wants to spend $20 on lunch?

The most redeeming quality about this place is the decor. The Panang curry was watery and the pad Thai noodles were over cooked and way too moist. Thai spicy was a good level of spicy. I normally get drunken noodle or pad seyew but looking at the photos other yelpers posted - I knew it wasn't quite right. I wouldn't come back for either of those dishes.

I'm surprised I didn't review this place sooner!  I LOVE this place!  I love their selection of movies, love the comfortable seats, love that it's always just the right temperature in there, and love that I can have a muffin and herbal tea to eat while watching my movie!!!  You can't beat that!

Most of all, I like that I can go here and not have to worry about people talking and spoiling the movie! For some reason, people shut up and watch the movie here!

We came here as a large group after an event and they were extremely accommodating and helpful with our large order. The service here is superior to other fast food places as their employees were bringing out food to our table and checked in on our group as well! They even told us to leave our trays/trash. We were super thankful for that type of service from a fast food place. The food was hot and delicious. I ordered the chicken tenders and the honey mustard dipping sauce was great. The crinkle cut fries are crispy and fried to perfection. However, let's be honest, we came for the custard! Their flavor of the day was the Brownie Batter Explosion and it was so delicious. Chewy chunks of brownies mixed with their smooth and soft custard. I haven't had Culvers in over 3 years and didn't realize how much I missed it! My only regret was not getting a root beer float on top of it all!

Although the movie theater is dated it's clear time and money spent has kept it maintained and clean. There is ample seating for any type of movie or festival which one is usually  hosted by the Philadelphia Film Society in October. Often this is where you will find independent movies and other documentaries not otherwise seen on the big screen. I enjoy coming to Ritz East because it's so close to Penns Landing and a lot of restaurants. 

When you purchase a large drink or popcorn they offer free same day refills. The popcorn is fresh and tasty but don't look for popping kernels in a machine, it's not made in house. Almost every time I come to this theater I make a point to take in happy hour at a local pub or restaurant because the don't have 'food'. After the movie I may take a walk along Delaware Avenue to soak in the scenery.

It's been a while since I ate ice cream that I can rave about. Located in John's Pass right outside the main boardwalk. Has a variety of ice cream flavors ,softserve ice cream ,homemade fudge ,chocolates , and candy's to satisfy any sweet tooth. We got the cookies and cream and butter scotch ice cream which has soft fudge brownies ,heath , caramel, and mini Reesie's peanut butter cup swirled in. Every bite was different and joyful . If you notice the spoons are Color changing. I'm older, but I licked every bite of that spoon to see the color change.

Toppers Creamery is an ice cream shop shaped like a giant ice cream cone! And they have delicious yummy treats with lots of fun options here!

There are 3 basic soft-serve ice cream flavors: Vanilla, Chocolate and a Swirl of both combined. You can pick from a wealth of options that include:
Shakes and Malts
Floats and Sundaes
Hot Fudge Sundaes
Waffle cones, regular and fancy
Sugar Free Fat Free Ice Cream
Frozen Yogurt
...and MORE!!

The charm of Toppers is that the fun is trying just that - A WEALTH OF TOPPINGS:
Brownie Bites
Crushed Oreos
Waffle Bits
Chopped Peanuts
M & M's
PB Cups
Cookie Dough
Butterfingers
Heath Bars
Chocolate Chips
Gummy Worms & Bears
Popcorn
Rainbow & Chocolate Sprinkles
...and MORE!!

Then you can add a number of Sauces:
Hot Fudge
Butterscotch 
Hot Caramel
Marshmallow 
Chocolate Syrup 
Triple Berry
Peanut Butter
Strawberry
Pineapple
...and MORE!!

And...!!!
The price is so affordable! 

Have fun with different combinations and enjoy! Yummm!!


33/100

CVS is a loner ever since the Publix moved across the street.  It is easy to miss, but never busy or crowded so if you're in a rush this is a win.  It's in the old Publix plaza, off Gulf Blvd(22nd S) across from the Sweetbay.  
As I said, the place is never crowded, and always clean and fully stocked.  Parking lot is large and you can always get the number 1 or 2 parking spot.

WOW!! Great pancakes and great service. This was our first visit but won't be our last! The bacon was thick and chewy and the link sausage was zippy and perfectly cooked. I can't wait to sample some other menu items--and since I keep odd hours, the 24/7 hours works for me!!

I came here for an event so we had a set menu but they were dishes from the menu. I thought service far exceeded the food I tasted but the food was okay, nothing special.

The gumbo was decent, but nothing to write home about. The oysters which everyone ate seemed to be the best -- I'm allergic so I didn't eat any.

The chicken (looked like a chicken cordon bleu) was moist but again, nothing special. I liked the shrimp risotto I got, at least it was flavorful.

Dessert was bananas foster which was prepared tableside. Nice touch, but honestly, the bananas foster at Commander's Palace blew this one out of the water.

This CVS earns bonus points because it was open on Christmas! I think they are all open on Christmas, but this was is convenient for me, because it's near me.

This CVS is WAY better organized than other ones that I have been to and everything is really easy to find. The staff was super friendly, even though they were working on Christmas and I was able to get in, find what I needed and get out in a timely manner.

Very good Korean restaurant.  I liked the menu a lot.  We ordered the all you can eat BBQ.  $20 each and a great value. We tried the spicy pork and the spicy chicken.  It comes with steamed egg and your choice of a half dozen soups.  We chose kimchi soup.  Everything was good solid Korean food.  I've had better examples of just about everything we tried but it was still overall very good.  The service was terrific and we ordered extra pork and several extra helpings of some of the side dishes and they were all delivered cheerfully and without delay.  I had a really good time and would definitely come again when in St Louis.

DO NOT EAT HERE. I love IHOP just to be clear. We were craving some pancakes last night and went here against the advice of Yelp reviews. When we arrived we stood up front for a good ten minutes. No one was up there. People were lining up to pay, crowding the whole entrance and still no one. Waitresses and manager walking by without a word. Finally sat. Food tastes semi normal, not the best (eggs undercooked, toast arrived with a weird drizzle of butter like popcorn butter at the movies, and country fried steak gravy revolting) but maybe not the worst ever. What happened next however speaks differently. My husband and I were both up all night violently ill. We will never ever go back to this dirty, poor staffed location.

Sole Mio was supposed to close earlier in the year, and then didn't close. But when we were there most recently the waitress indicated that this was truly the last night they would be open.  Since you can no longer book on Open Table I assume this to now be the case. 

For what it's worth the food was very good and if it was still open I would come back.

1st visit here and must say, I really enjoyed it. Wednesday eve at 7p and not a huge crowd, but moderate. Food came out quickly! I settled on 2lbs of Snow Crab, Garlic Seasoning and No spice. Loved the flavor!!! I was pleased with the cook on the legs, very easy to pull out whole portions of crab for a great bite. I must admit, 2lbs ended up being about 5 claws and I was definitely full off that. I also ordered fries and garlic bread because I thought the crab wouldn't be enough and I was wrong. Fries were good, the basket is huge, enough to share with 3 or 4 folks. The garlic bread was meh, don't need that again.
Yes, it's market price on all of it. Prepare accordingly and ask questions.

So our 2nd stop on the Great Philly Cheese Steak tour is Sonny's.
The cheesesteaks were good.  But they forgot the Whiz.  But no worries, we got some.
I decided to try a cheeseburger as I heard they were good too.
The cheeseburger was hot and juicy.   Needed condiments.   Which you had to ask for.
Like Philly Hospitality.. my hubby asked for a Beer (any Philly kind) and he was kindly told "it's only 11:30 am sir, dont you think it's a little early for alcohol?"  But No we dont sell beer.  Kinda funny!!!

Had a great experience for my first time going today during lunch. Great lunch special for $6 and nice open, bright, and clean interior. Lots of tv's, great area in the back, and even an outdoor patio...btw, the pizza was GREAT and tasty. You will definitely see me here again!

This place is super hip, no doubt about it. Kind of a dinery feel with "Cash Only Bitches" written anywhere it can be, Loco Pez was a place I've been trying to get to forever. Is there any convenient way to get to Kensington?

Had three tacos and shared black beans and rice with the group. The fish was my favorite. Seitan and spinach and mushroom were tasty as well, but DAMN if those tacos weren't the tiniest tacos I've ever seen. Tacos for babies. And at $2~ each, it adds up. 

Black beans were pureed- I would have eaten it like soup if I wasn't sharing with the table. Rich flavor and a tiny kick, yum. Rice was rice. Chips were good, and even better with guac. 

Also, this place is CLEAN. The bucket that carried three squirt bottles of hot sauces was spotless. No crusty containers, no sticky fingers. Bravo. I'm looking forward to coming back for happy hour.

Great water ice, much better than Rita's.  The only thing I would say that is better that the water ice factory is the Polish ice on the Ocean City boardwalk.

The mango water ice is creamy, a crowd pleaser, and one of the best.  My personal favorite is the honeydew.  There are all sorts of flavors, a lot of fruit flavors, some traditionally ice cream water ice flavors, and even flavors like ice tea and root beer.

Cheap, you can get a small water ice for $1.

Friendly, and more important with how fast a line can form, efficient staff.

This place reminds me of when I was younger.  We used to go here after school at Triton, great times.

Their WIF (water ice and soft serve ice cream layered) is similar to Rita's gelati, but a little different.  The WIF has 2 parts water ice and 1 part ice cream, where a gelati is the reverse, 2 parts ice cream and 1 part water ice.

Last night was frigid and the streets were abandoned. It seemed everyone was wrapped in their snuggies at the precise moment when I was wandering the streets, looking for a warm bar to enjoy a neat bourbon. 

When my mate suggested Misconduct, I gave him a double-take. You mean the bar I've never really thought about patronizing? Since he's a man of fantastic taste, I obliged his suggestion and on we trudged. 

I ordered my Maker's, he went with Knob and after the kind bartender informed us of half price burgers, we got one of those too. I'm a total snob when it comes to burgers (there's a bun to meat ratio that needs to be adhered to) and theirs was fantastic. So good that I'd say it's one of the top 5 simple sandwiches I've had in the city. 

Next time I'm hanging out with a bar snob of a friend, I'll suggest this place, it's unexpectedly awesome.

Convenient, clean, and reasonably priced - what more could one ask for?  The employees were friendly and the aisles were well laid out, fully stocked, and not over-crowded.  We were staying at a hotel not far from the store so it was nice to be able to grab some snacks and drinks and not continue paying $3.25 for a bottle of water.

My mom and I had Christmas dinner here.  There was a set 6 course menu with a variety of choices.  Overall the food was good.  Lots of traditional Italian food with a bit of a twist.  Service was good. We had a young waitress but she knew her stuff. We were right by the bathroom and kitchen entrance so that was a bit annoying but overall it was a nice dinner.

First course:
Me - Half grapefruit stuffed with mixed greens baby shrimp and grapefruit.  Topped with a delicate grapefruit vinaigrette
Mom - Chef Samantha's vegetable minestrone - Vegetables pureed minestrone soup topped with extra virgin olive oil and shaved parmigiano reggiano

2nd course:
Mom - Porcini & Truffle ravioli - fresh pasta with porcini mushrooms topped with a creamy white wine sauce & a splash of extra vrigin white truffle olive oil
Me - Caprese - farfalle pasta with fresh cherry tomatoes, imported cherry mozzarella and basil

Third course:
Radicchio salad - imported radicchio tossed in with oranges, walnuts and topped with shaved parmigiano reggiano tossed in creamy lemon dressing

Fourth course:
Lemon vodka sorbetto

Fifth course:
Me - Veal osso buco - 16oz center cut veal shank sautÃ©ed and slowly over roasted in a delicate red sauce on a bed of soft polenta
Mom - Stinco di maile - 16oz pork shank braised and slow roasted in oven served over mashed potatoes

6th course:
Tiramusi

The portions were nice sized.  You certainly did not go hungry with all this food.

This Rouses is delightful! I wish I lived down here, but my sig. other does and I love to make groceries here.

Like it's been indicated: no lines ever, fresher feel than other groceries and, of course, with any Rouses; it's local! This Rouses is unique because it's got a TON of parking, they have huge single beers of all types, an aero phonic herb garden on the roof, a Red Box machine, a mini food court area...

If you already go to Rouses, you'll really love this one. The CBD is a little too quiet of a neighborhood for me, so I really like how bright and lively this Rouses is and tries to bring the community together for events. The view from the roof is quite nice too.

Let's start out with the good, our waitress was awesome she was very sweet n attentive to all our needs.
We started with fresh bread killer, homemade whipped butter,so good so far
My girlfriends fried shrimp came very good. Bad was the fries how do you mess up fries in a 5 Star restaurant?????
Now my steak n lobster came out,here we go bad things fixing to come to truth, I ordered the most expensive steak you could order,it was a bone in ribeye 53 bucks with a lobster tail 22 bucks.
The steak came n lobster I ordered medium, steak came out well done ugggggggg. The lobster came out it was cold.   Wtf
So she came and took my dinner back while my girlfriend was eating hers.
Finally the manager came to our table told us he was sorry for the delay.
My 2nd steak came after another 15 more minuets of waiting. What a disaster it came out way under cooked almost tar tar. I called manager over again told him I wasn't happy with this crap. He compt all my drinks and food.  I wouldn't ever think about coming here.  They can't cook a steak right. Geeezz

I give this place minus one star because you can't use your debit or credit card....this hasn't really been a problem for me because my credit union happens to have an atm right next door, but I can definitely see how this could be a problem.  

Other than that, this place is pretty freaking awesome.  The movies are late runs, so they have been out for quite a while.  But who gets to see all the decent movies while they are fresh out in the theater?  The movies are only $4 ($3 during the day), and the concessions are also cheap.  Sure, the sodas are not big enough to drown a small baby in, but it's still incredibly cheap for what you are getting.  My boyfriend and I managed to see a movie, get drinks and popcorn to share and we only spent $15...I challenge you to find a better movie deal anywhere in the St. Louis area.  The place is slightly out of date, but it's usually empty, so there's never any challenge to finding a seat or getting to the theater 1 minute before the movie starts.  

For example, we were the only people in the theater...which was hilarious in and of itself.  It's kind of nice to have a whole theater to yourself b/c you never feel guilty talking or laughing or getting up to go to the bathroom.  I now understand why so many celebrities put them in their homes.

Verde sits on Main Street in Carmel with street parking or lot parking behind the building. The restaurant is very warm and cozy with dark wood tables and booths plus an attractive, but humongous, chandelier in the main dining area. The bar area is comfortable as well with high and low top tables and several televisions. A small patio is available for outdoor dining weather permitting.

The menu has several appetizers from pork or chicken tamales, 3 types of cerviche, empandas trio and dips. I love their chips and the salsa is thicker at a mild heat level. The Indiana Street Corn is served on or off the cob and  slow-poached in butter then  smothered in cotija cheese, aioli and sprinkled with tajin spice. Messy if you order on the cob but worth it. One of my other favorites is the Chicken Tortilla Soup with a rich broth and veggies. The Street Tacos are very popular and you can mix and match your favorite 3 fillings out of 14 fillings plus add one side dish. For the unexpected, you'll find dehydrated, real Grasshopper tacos that are high in protein or try the butternut squash or octopus tacos. For those who can't have the traditional corn tortillas try the Taco De Nopal where they substitute a grilled slice of cactus, add steak or chorizo and topped with all the garnishes.

I had the 3 Enchiladas De Mole but substituted shredded pork for the chicken and topped with a generous amount of tasty Mole sauce. My husband had the steak Burrito Fajita with a side of black beans. He really enjoyed the flavor and presentation of the  large burrito with the red and green sauces. He cleaned his plate and even told the Manager how much he enjoyed his meal. As we were leaving he said he'd be happy to return in the future.

Our server was friendly and gave us time to check out the menu. Our food arrived, fresh, hot and timely plus our drinks were refilled.

On my next trip I'd like to try the Paella or the Red Snapper with saffron rice. So many choices look good it's hard to decide! Lunch was delicious and relaxing.

This 5 Guys location is massive! The food was mostly up to par, but I have to agree with a previous commenter that the fries were a bit undercooked (not as crisp). They had Mr. Pibb (Pibb Xtra) in the fountain... I can't remember the last time I've had Mr. Pibb... pre-millenium?

What I like most about this place is that the floor isn't slippery! @15th I can be standing still and I just slowly start heading off in a direction. I especially hate it when I'm sitting down and I keep sliding. Overall, this is a better area. There are almost no bums and very few obnoxious kids.

Other than that, I've been getting the same exact thing since 5 Guys opened on 15th and in this 4-5 year period the price has gone up about $1.50. For a regular drink, fries, and a cheeseburger it's $10.99. Where do you draw the line 5 Guys? If it weren't for this latest price hike, I'd give 4 stars. I repeat, WHERE DO YOU DRAW THE LINE!? For $11 there are much better options around.

Lastly, dining on walnut 11th-broad is better than dining on chestnut 15th-18th (liberty place included).

Great spot for decent Thai food. Lunchtime was busy but it was worth the wait. $8.95 for soup, a spring roll and pad thai and all of them were yummy. I would go back here to try more of their noodle dishes, even w/out the lunch deal.

The Shake Seafood have become my favorite spot for crab legs and sweet potatoe fries in the NE Philly area. Its' convenient location on Cottman Avenue and lots of parking is definitely a plus too.

Me and my family went during Saturday night. Upon walking in, there is a notice on the door that state they are no longer taking dine in patrons bc it is late. We was gonna get take out so that wasn't a problem. At around 10:30pm, The Shake Seafood is jammed packed, like woah that's alot of folks dinning in and taking outs. That's a good sign!!

We order fried shrimp platter, 2 pound of crawfish, 1 pound of king crab legs, 1 pound of snow crab legs, and sweet potato fries. Hubby really likes the fried shrimp platter with the cajun seasoning fries. I love the king and snow crab legs in the Shake sauce along with the sweet potato fries. As for the crawfish, I didn't like them at all. Wasn't season very well maybe bc it is huge, but I won't get them again. Btw it is a bit pricey for the amount of food, for the items listed above, our bill is $96. I don't mind as long as the food is good, but I can't not go as often as I like, don't wanna be broke afterward lol.

P.S. If you like  food that is heavy on the seasonings, then try The Shake Seafood, you won't regret!!

Welcome back, Brennan's!
I was there re-opening day. We certainly expected snags, but had far fewer than anticipated, which was great!
The table wasn't ready at our reservation time, so we were invited into the cocktail room (just like a bar, but fancier) to have a drink while waiting. We sat down, unsure if we were to order from the bar or if there was table service. None of the employees knew either. Staff were asking each other - and by the time someone came by, our table was ready.
From there, everything was PERFECT and flawless!
Our drinks included perfectly strong coffee, a Caribbean Milk Punch and a great Bloody Mary.
There are three prix-fixe meals on the menu - but I ruled them out, as none had the bananas foster as a dessert. :)
For appetizers, we had the seafood gumbo and the roasted oysters with smoked chili butter and Manchego.
My friend had the escargot omelette and I opted for the Croque Madame Royal. (Instead of ham and swiss, it's proscuitto, truffle, and gruyere), topped with a sunny side up duck egg and bechamel sauce. Both were rich, obscenely decadent and delicious! 
While not really a huge fan of bananas, I couldn't be at Brennan's and not have the Bananas Foster. For the show more than the dish itself. What can I say, I am a sucker for a nice flambe!
The staff timed service perfectly. Water glasses never empty, all plates presented simultaneously. Always at the ready, but not intrusive.
Truly, welcome back - and may this institution enjoy many more generations of legendary New Orleans quality and decadence!
I worked nearby and ordered every weekend for months. I love this place! They fresh delicious salads, great sandwiches, and tasty meals! Great delivery service!

I love Publix and I love that this Publix is close by so I can get there easily. It's located on a busier road so it definitely piles up during peak hours, but like all other Publixes, it's simply the best.
