This Publix has a hot foods section and a salad bar and some of the nicest ladies working in the deli. I've ordered sandwiches and catering food from here and it's always made on time. 

The staff is really friendly and welcoming and is always there if you need any help with anything. 

I have noticed that a lot of their items don't get restocked so you have to request it, something I find unusual for Publix. But when everything is there, this is a great grocery store!

A Taco Tuesday tradition, Mardi Gras Indian tacos are a win. Delicious veggie tacos with pinto beans, corn, red cabbage slaw, and a double corn shell, yum! I'm usually full after one but I can't stop eating them. Start off with the chips, salsa, guac, and queso because all the dips are worth trying. Juan's also offers 2 secret sauces, of the red and green variety, that the server brings out on request.

In the beverage category, their house margaritas are okay. I like them well enough but they are not my favorite ever. Juan's, however, does have a good strawberry lemonade. Also, they do have a large beer and tequila selection so their is no lack in libations. Overall a great option for a weeknight dinner!

Las Fuentes is fairly new. I stopped in with a party of three on a Monday night. Excellent chips and salsa! Very attentive service! Our waitress was filling my friends little personal bowl of salsa immediately after she took the last bite! Orders included shrimp fajitas, a shrimp quesadilla, and my order, the tacos al pastor (no cilantro). It was served on corn tortillas with white onion and small chunks of canned pineapple. This was actually very good considering they're not selling enough of it to be cooking that meat on a spit constantly. I get to this neighborhood less and less these days but this was very good albeit slightly Americanized Mexican food. If you're in the area this is worth your time!

I am not at all interested in upsetting the algorithm. I'm more than happy to add a star. My apologies for the mistake in identifying Sichuan/Szechuan. I got that information from google, so not sure if there is a way to change it (Google, I mean). It also states it under the restaurant's title on this Yelp page, so maybe a change in that might be helpful as well. In addition,  thanks for explaining the composition of the dish and my misunderstanding of how much chicken should be included. That was actually helpful. My rating may have been written in haste and misunderstanding. The title "elite" doesn't at all make me believe I know more than most about food. To me, it simply means I eat out a lot (well, I used to pre-covid) and the most satisfying part of leaving a review is to help hard working people get customers to their business. No sauce for the potstickers was a bummer, but like I said, the cucumbers were great. I'll just make sure I have sauce on hand next time.

I love a good authentic Korean restaurant! It's in a nice cozy location to have a good plate or pot of comfort food from South Korea. My favorite so far are the bibimbap and their spicy Korean style sweet and spicy wings. From the moment I walked in, they were very sweet and making sure that the menu was understood. They told me that the kimchi will periodically change based on the season and that the ingredients are purchased regularly and locally. Everything on the menu looks so good that it's hard to make a solid decision at first without drooling over the next thing you see. They seem to have a real nice relationship with local visitors from the surrounding neighborhood. All of their food are best eaten fresh at the restaurant. I'm always down for some tasty spiced foods!

Wash your hands and stay safe!

I'll keep this one short. The oysters are amazing. Their charbroiled oysters are very tasty. The fresh ones are very fresh tasting. No complaints whatsoever with the oysters. I tried the seafood pasta and shrimp and corn bisque as well. The seafood pasta was good and the serving was large. The shrimp and corn bisque was okay. Would order just the oysters next time.

I'm on a New Orleans oyster quest. Came here for their charred oysters that everyone raved about online. Got it for take out bc I'm right upstairs and we just woke up from a nap. Compared to the oysters I had in the French quarter, these were ok, good. I just didn't like how their bread was super hard to eat, like what is this? Cardboard?? The 1/2 dozen is $14, they raised the price from what I saw on the picture menus here. I would not come back again also because while all the oysters I've eaten have been truly truly salty....I like to eat the plain bread with them to lessen the saltiness and I had a terrible time trying to bite their baguette. Other breads I've eaten during my oyster quest were a lot softer, garlic-ier, yummier. 

Also had the shrimp corn bisque. That was very good!
Omg! I have been meaning to visit this new restaurant Food is so good here. I enjoyed the dan dan noodles and chicken. The food is really spicy but definitely worth it. I heard the crawfish was good.

After a delightful dinner and a long walk, my wife and I decided to swing by this little froyo spot to satiate our sweet tooth. As many of the froyo spots are, this place does not give you the sample cups, but the staff will have to walk over and pour it out. As a consumer, I prefer the self-serve, but didn't mind the service. Unfortunately, the young lady behind the desk gave us the most unwelcoming, tired, and judgmental glares, as she rolled her eyes with two sample request, making me feel terrible for trying out froyo. I was not a super big fan of the sugary froyo flavors, but her glares made it that much more intolerable. We threw in a dollar in the tip jar and will never return unless further management training will tailor to a customer-centered environment.
The food here was really good. I had a Gyro and it was fantastic. It was only 6 dollars. I will be back!

Stopped by here for a recent dinner with friends.  The overall service was excellent and our server made sure to ensure all members of our party had all of their questions answered and even gave some great menu advice.  The steak that I ordered was cooked to perfection and I highly recommend the black pepper encrusted option as it magnifies the flavors that much more and makes it worthy of what you will end up paying.  Sides are a la carte and not included like some other steakhouses in the area.  The green beans were my favorite as they were cooked and flavored perfectly.  As I mentioned before, make sure to pack your wallet heavy as it will leave a lot lighter if you indulge in a meal and drinks in the main dining room.

I remember shopping at this Kmart 15+ years ago and not much has changed. All of the complaints about the service here ring hollow to me: if you want five-star service, then go downtown to Nordstrom or Saks and pay for a personal shopper. Can't afford that? Well, then don't order champagne when all you have is a beer budget. 

Most recently, my wife and I quickly found the household items we were looking for and checkout only took a few minutes, which is basically the same experience I've had here for years. Although the store isn't the cleanest and its "cheap" prices are only inexpensive in the context of living in Santa Barbara, Kmart is decent option for locals and students trying to save a few bucks.

After a lackluster experience at the less-than-average Camellia grill, we needed a pick-me-up! The Creole Creamery was just the ticket! We've got a place in Kansas City called Syla's and Maddy's - I'm sure everyone's got their own one and the same: a college-town creamery, rich with hope and an aloof grassroots sensibility of purpose. Chalkboards abound, flavors are fun, and the prices are considerate. This place is precisely that. 

I think we walked out of there filled with homemade ice cream, sans $5 and change - a real deal. In places such as this, you cannot go wrong with any of their wonderful flavor profiles atop a waffle cone. Something new that I hadn't seen before was the venerable "TCHOUPITOULAS!" It's $30 worth of bad decisions, eight scoops and a whole mess of stuff. If you eat it all you get your name on a placard or something. While we were there, a boy was trying to impress a bunch of friend-zone girls to little avail - but he impressed me. Anyone with the sensibilities - or lack thereof - to take on I believe I heard 5 pounds of ice cream for a placard and some attention has wholeheartedly gotten mine undivided whilst I remain with a solitary cone and intrigue of what comes next. He gave up, looked sick, and lost the gaze of us all. Failure. 

Still, it's a nice little shop, good art, good feel, and better ice cream. If you're happening by, have a scoop of something worth the sin of indulgence.

Call me a heretic but I'd rather go to Qdoba.....sorry!!!!  Every time I go to Chipotle I get to the cash register and think, 'how the heck did I just spend $12 on lunch???'  I ordered a salad and an Izze's soda.  It tastes good, don't get me wrong but that price is crazytown to me!  Maybe it's because I'm not used to paying a lot for Mexican food, but no, it'll be another month until I forget the incident, go back in and like deja vu, 'how the heck did I end up spending $12 on lunch?'

The theme is minimalism and the space is clean.  They have a patio to boot!  The place is usually packed during lunch but even so the staff is super efficient and I am in and out in a decent time.  If you don't mind the price I say go for it!  

FYI, they don't have quesadillas.
The best yeast donuts in the world! Worth paying with cash, waiting in line, whatever. Happiness is a warm Long's donut.

I don't know if it's just me, or if others share this sentiment, but it seems the exponentially growing brewery scene in just about every city is starting to feel a little crowded and redundant. Sure, everyone has an exceptional seasonal beer every now and then, but for the most part it's the same stuff with a different witty name over and over again on everybody's tap lists. I still love going to as many new breweries as I can, but it's just starting to feel like it's getting a little difficult to find places that actually set themselves apart with something unique and memorable. Alpha Brewing has done just that, and they have done it very well. 

Located in a little downtown neighborhood with some other options to eat and drink in the nearby vicinity (I recommend trying some of the crazy pizzas at The Sliced Pint), this brewery certainly doesn't leave any doubt about what it is when you walk up to the place. Behind their nice outdoor patio area is a storefront that is almost all windows, and behind those windows are stacks of barrels, 3 high and 2 deep, aging a whole bunch of beers that are probably nothing you will see at any other brewery in the entire city. 

I love barrel aged beers, and I love sour beers (done properly, none of that kettle souring), and alpha had more options than I could try in one sitting. Our fairly large group found a few tables to push together in the taproom that had a bar with a dozen or so seats, and maybe 6 or 7 smaller tables. There were a few people set up with some board games, and some regulars at the bar, but it wasn't too crowded for a Saturday night. It's a bright taproom that is on the quieter side of things. You can see their brewing operation through a window, which if I am remembering correctly consists of 2.5 barrel brew kettles and 5 gallon fermenters, so they are definitely a small batch place.

The tap list consisted of maybe 5 or 6 of their "Beta Brews" on tap, and a few more in bottles. These were the things out of their barrel aging program, and were all really unique beers. If those weren't up your alley, they also had about 6 or 7 "Alpha Brews", which is more normal stuff that wasn't barrel aged, but still included quite a few really cool beers. If you ended up getting dragged along to a brewery as a non-beer drinker, I believe I at least saw some wine being served. It's not often I find beers that I haven't had at least one similar iteration of at some point in the past, but Alpha had plenty of them, especially their barrel soured beers.

Their prices, although higher than normal beers, were actually pretty decent for their barrel aged and sour beers. They had flights available as well, but those were from preset lists that you couldn't mix and match. I was surprised to see howler and growler fill pricing for their Beta stuff as well. I ended up taking home quite a few bottles from here, and a lot of them were available already chilled if you were taking it somewhere to drink immediately. The bartender working when we were here was great. She was outgoing and talkative, and knew plenty about the beers and the brewery. 

I will definitely be back here the next time I am in St. Louis.

The happy hour margaritas and nachos are awesome. The nachos! The calories are all worth it. The chips are not thick cut, but stay crispy even under the cheese-salsa-guac-meat blanket. 

The $1 tacos are not every day, but announced on Twitter, which sucks for me because I don't Twitter/tweet.

My favorite taco was the Carne Asada out of the Pez, Al Pastor, Chorizo/Potato. The tacos themselves were small, with a decent amount of meat. Tasty, those were.

Seriously, GET THE NACHOS!

Delightful happy hour! Great cocktail choices and appetizers from 5-7pm Monday through Friday. The menu changes so be sure to call ahead if you are not sure of what you are looking for. Tonight (Friday), I enjoyed a lovely night out with Miss Tina K for a happy hour endeavor! We enjoyed Emerald Isle cocktails ($6), some wine and I also had the Debonair Martini ($8) with bleu cheese olives. The burgers are $8 and we tried the Burrata ($6) which came with roasted grape tomatoes, arugula and crostini. Very tasty! The interior of the restaurant is very beautiful with dark oak and wine inspired wood floors. Happy Hour specials are only available in the bar area which is bustling, but not impossible to find seating. Crystal was our server and she was phenomenal!! Very attentive and courteous, ensuring we were set on drinks and gave us time to ponder our menu choices. I will definitely be back for another evening at Flemings! Great atmosphere!

Tourist Alert: If you are staying nearby don't miss this authentic treasure!
 The feminine offspring who is now working nearby was in the mood for a decent cheesesteak so she chose Sonny's and I am glad she did. It's located right on Market Street and has outdoor seating so on this warm October day we chose to seat outside.  When we chose one of the aluminum tables we were rewarded with all the sounds of the city and some great people watching.  I'll be honest, I have passed Sonny's hundreds of times never giving it a thought. Shame on me because the proprietors serve great steaks with smiles. Peruse their website and see they value their commitment to the city in which they were born and they take pride in having been awarded GQ's best Philly cheesesteak.

We both ordered cheesesteaks with a shared order of fries. My palate was happy with the nicely chopped ribeye and perfect amount of cheese. What impressed me was how good it was minus the grease of other cheesesteaks I've had elsewhere. My daughter said it was the best meal she had all week.
When my expat Philly friends are in town, I will now be taking them only to Sonny's to satisfy their cheesesteak fix.

Whaddup, Celiacs?

Since my diagnosis, I've felt a lot of feelings. Anger, denial, withdrawal. But at Monsu, I felt none of those things. In fact, I felt pure joy as I enjoyed a fantastic 4-course gluten free meal (for $40!) with my non-celiac friends.

Imagine this as a tweet with the hand-clap emoji between each word:

Every. Thing. On. The. Menu. Can. Be. Prepared. GF.

(Aside from like two things). And the pasta? Tastes REAL. Like real wheat pasta. I could've cried right into my vodka sauce. They even brought me toasted GF bread to dip.

Among our group of 10, we also had 1 vegetarian and 1 lactose-intolerant person. Our server was extremely accommodating to us all, and didn't make anyone feel like they were an inconvenience (something I'm currently struggling with on the daily). When it came to shared dessert plates, I was given my own lil panna cotta. Ain't that sweet?

Like all of Peter McAndrew's restaurants, the food is happily prepared with quite a bit of salt. It's delicious, and I love it, I'm just warning you. In case you don't like salt.
Good and what you'd expect from this chain.  Don't expect be blown away.  If you live on the mainline you cannot beat the convenience of Fleming's.

Dear Owners of Berry Sweet;
Why must you attract me with bright colors and cute designs like your store is? Do you know that I'm Asian and it's in my blood to squeal like a giddy girl and walk in there?! 

WELL, it worked. Hmph.

The yoghurt was/is delicious and the staff is so, so friendly. I love the toppings and if you eat a lot like me (I work it off. I swear.) you would know the different taste of ice cream and frozen yoghurt and this store is clearly serving frozen yoghurt (Hence the title, duh..?) 

It's on South Street and that makes it so much better to hang out with your lads and mates. (..If I had any friends. Don't judge me!)

I'll be going back here all the time now. Yay for yummy foods.

This is my second attempt to love Fiveguys! Burger was ok... nothing special. Cheeseburger all the way. Not really fond of the mayo they use... too sweet! Patties were done more than I like. Fries were good... but I prefer my fries a little crispy, not mushy. They did taste good (but hey, potatoes and grease, of course they taste good! But I have had better!). Still baffled about why Five Guys is so popular!  :) So A-OK... three stars.

Not bad.... I'm not a real fan of Mexican food, (it doesn't fill me up!!)  but this was one is okay. I've gone there twice and had soft chicken tacos. The place is clean enough, but I will never forget how unhelpful the staff was the first time I went in there.

I went the week they opened, and I guess they just assumed that everyone knows how the place "works". (Which they shouldn't have, since it was new to the area!)

This is an ok spot for lunch, I guess.

Best. Ice cream. Ever. You haven't had the true St. Louis experience without seeing the Arch, Busch Stadium, eating some toasted ravs, and getting some Ted Drews frozen custard. Order from the menu or create your own. I personally love the Fox Treat sundae (light on the hot fudge) or a mint oreo concrete or even a tried and true vanilla cone. Don't be intimidated by the lines, they move very quickly and are a part of the experience. And after you've ordered find a spot to sit and enjoy--preferably the tailgate or trunk of your car. If you get it to-go don't forget the dry ice--even as an adult I still get a kick out of making a witches brew in the kitchen sink.

great thick flavorful broth, better than any I've had in pennsylvania so far. very comparable to the ones I had in pal park new jersey. Until now, I've been disappointed with the offerings in philadelphia for soondubu. 

They also give you a full stone pot full of rice, egg, and tea to put in the pot after you are done with the egg. I'm not a fan of it, but i hear koreans love it.

I ate here 5 hours ago and I'm considering making the 25 minute drive to eat here again right now. 

Lots of vegetarian options, so you're good there if you have a ton of vegetable eating friends like I do.

Drago's is known for oysters and I will admit, they were okay not great. Once you've had ACME, you can't really to top it that easily. 

It's located in the bottom floor of the Hilton hotel. That itself was iffy. but sure, I'm down to try anything once. Wandered in, ordered a dozen char'd. For what ever reason, just not the same as ACME I don't think they use the same kind of cheese like ACME does. It was good, not great. 16.95 for a dozen. Some of the oysters were tiny compared to the others...

For entree, the combo platter is quite good. A mix of shimp fish, oysters... Normally comes out fried, but you can ask it blackened. 

It was okay, but not at the top of my highlights in NO. try acme first.

Mr. Dunderbaks is da Bombenstimmung!!  (fantastic atmosphere)!  

I loved it here.  Great German grub.  Fantastic selection of beers, 50 on tap alone.   The HB Maibock was my fave for the day.... ooooh yes.  And you can order beer in Liters.  mmmmmmmmmMaibock!

The spicy goulash was mighty tasty, though not really all that spicy-hot.  It was spicy in the sense of having multiple spices and not being bland.  Definitely spicy like that.

If I lived closer, I'd be a regular.  Without a doubt.

Why not full 5 stars?  I've only been once, and I didn't get a chance to sample dessert.  So read this as 4.5!

It was an interesting place, very tiny, but interesting. 

We chanced upon it while looking for food on a Monday night after the convention and then remembered it's historic nature as well. 

They had a "vegetarian dish of the day," which was very thoughtful of them. But the food wasn't stellar, the portions were okay, and the appetizers/desserts were somewhat disappointing. 

The red beans and rice as well as the white beans and rice were doable, especially in a city where being vegetarian you can't quite be very picky or selective.

Juan's offers great food at very reasonable prices.

I have been to Juan's several times, but my last trip was by far the best. A buddy and I were looking for a lunch place and decided to go to Juan's at the last minute. Even though it was prime lunch time (12:00), the restaurant was busy, but not packed. We were promptly seated and our server immediately arrived to take our drink orders.

This level of service continued throughout our meal. Our server was attentive, but not overbearing.

On this trip I ordered the western burrito with steak. Imagine fajitas wrapped into a large burrito and you get the picture of what this entailed. It was wonderful. the steak, onions, peppers and cheese all combined to make a juicy and filling burrito. Fellow Yelper Shannon S.'s suggested I ask for the habanero hot sauce when ordering. i did, and I am glad. The sauce was hot, but flavorful. It really made the burrito even better. In fact, this may have been the best burrito I have had in the city so far.

I really enjoy Juan's. If you're in the Garden District and looking for reasonable, good food, give Juan's a try.

Our last meal in NOLA, on a recent "girls weekend" and it didn't disappoint! 

Our server was new, and really did a great job of juggling all the dishes we selected and keeping us hydrated with ample water pours, with a white wine here and there.

Our group tried the following: oysters on the half shell (5 star), boiled sausage, corn and potatoes (4.5 star and a great price!), a cup of crawfish bisque with lump crap added on (5 star decadent bliss), and a grilled fish (don't recall what kind) with asparagus.

Why no 5th star on this review? Because I asked for a diet coke to go, and was told by a server that it would be "no charge" and I think it was 2.00-ish. No biggie, it's the Big Easy and this is the French Quarter.

Clean restrooms, attentive servers, a slice of French Quarter history and a convenient location when checking the area out - Do try French Market. Bon appetit!

A local and organic goods market on the other side of the river.  You know the side of the river most people in STL try to say they don't know about. 

I like the fresh salad and sushi bar. I saw the hot food but did not try any. Unlike, Whole foods the hot food is not just sitting out. Right know the prices are good. I am sure after the grand opening the prices will be comparable to Whole Foods. 

I found the employees friendly and to be pretty nice and helpful. 

i don't see it being a place i will go for regular grocery shopping. I think I do like Whole foods better still. Fresh Thyme is a comparable alternative.

all-you-can-eat kalbi!!! 'nuf said...

$25 per person after tax and tip!

the servers will quickly detect if you're a korean bbq newbie and quickly rush over with their shears and tongs and start cooking away for you.

it's byob.  and if it's close to closing time, offer the ladies a beer.  they may not speak english but they get all excited and will remember you the next time you are there.

the english name of the place is seoul garden and if you've never been, it's on the first floor of a high rise apartment and blocked by bushes.

You can't come to New Orleans and not try some gumbo. I usually steer clear away from this dish at home in the D.C. area because I've had some truly awful gumbo, but I knew NOLA would not let me down. After grabbing some coffee across the street, we headed over to Gumbo Shop to try a few things. 

It's a fairly large restaurant, with both indoor and outdoor seating. Our server was very friendly and engaged us with lively discussion about everything under the sun. It seemed, at first impression, a place that encapsulates the New Orleans spirit - both in terms of food and people.

Our first order was an appetizer of chicken andouille gumbo. I was hooked on the first taste. The boneless chicken, andouille, okra, and all the right seasonings made my knees buckle. Our server told us that this dish is known for being the best gumbo in the city. 

We then ordered entrees of red beans and rice with smoked sausage and the crawfish etouffee. Unfortunately, our server thought we chose the crawfish and pasta (penne pasta with crawfish tails and tasso in a reduced cream sauce). I didn't mind too much about the mix-up, although I would have liked to try the etouffee since it's a local favorite here. However since our server insisted that we ordered this dish (and it didn't seem likely that we were able to convince him otherwise) and it was already out on the table, I dug in. It was good, so no harm no foul. The red and beans with sausage was also very delicious. 

It was the perfect first meal in New Orleans. I'm so glad we were able to have some classic gumbo while we were here.

I eat here on a semi regular basis as it's close to where I work and they do take out. That said I've run into my fair share of problems. Well, actually, most every time (with one exception) I've had problems.

1. My coworkers and I ordered some food and we got the wrong rolls, but didn't realize until we got back to the office. We phoned them back and they literally said there was absolutely nothing they could for us and hung up. Bad experience. Poor customer service. Even so I continue to go back.

2. We did a birthday party on our lunch break for 12 of us. We told the server from the start we were in a bit of a crunch so we all ordered right away. And then it was a bunch of hurry up and wait. It took 45 minutes for the food and another 25 minutes to run our cards. What the hell? That's just ridiculous. He was upset he had a large party at lunch, I understand that, but come on now.

There were other things, but I guess I'll keep going. The food is good enough and the Mr. likes it so... there you have it. :)

I could not find a pelican there today. At least not the rusty pelican. But if I sit long enough and I will become one since the view is nice and make you feel relax and still. I can be one. 

This water front property has the killer bay view for the people who dine there. I would said it has nice sunset view. Price range is at high side for the food. The interior is well decorated. The dinning hall has the bay view. They have ball room can easily fit 200 people with bay east view. 

I was here for a society meeting. We was done in this ballroom that is beautiful for wedding. Our entrÃ©e is not in the regular menu. It is shell pasta with stuff cheese in side. It accompanied with green beans and carrots. The food is good. This place is good with seafood and steak. 

The service is good and attentive. Overall the welcoming host and restaurant do a good job.

I love Jimmy John's. Close to work and often my choice when I can't decide what I want amongst all the crazy options in this part of town. The bread is soooo good. I mean, chewy and soft, and holds up to the sandwich. I live for the JJBLT and the Club Lulu, but I've had others that are amazing also. (Those 2 sandwiches have bacon on them and always plenty of it!) 

You can order online even just for ONE sandwich! I've done that before. It doesn't matter if you are in store or getting delivery. It's always fast. Now this location has Apple & Google Pay so it makes the trip even faster! 

I also appreciate that there's an unwich option which is a lettuce wrap rather than bread for anyone watching their carb intake. I usually get that, but sometimes I can't live without the bread. You can also purchase day old bread from them for your own creations at home. 

Keep rocking it, Jimmy John's!

I was excited to try EATS! since I've driven by a million times but have never thought to stop in. The restaurant has a kind of "divey" feel to it. They had a solid bloody mary, which I always appreciate on a Sunday afternoon. 

Our server brought us over a complimentary basket of chips with some amazing dipping sauce. I think this was my favorite part of the meal. 

We both ordered the San Francisco Burger with garlic fries. The bread on the bottom of the burger was completely soggy by the time it was delivered to our table. The burger itself didn't have much flavor to it so I only managed to eat half. The garlic fries were pretty good as well. 

I'm glad I got to experience EATS! but I probably won't be dining there again.

This may sound ridiculous, but I have been in Creole Creamery five times and sampled their ice creams before taking the dive into actually buying a scoop. This weekend I went ahead and bought two! 

The first thing you notice when you walk in here is the cheery decor and the smell. The smell almost overwhelms you. It is sugary sweet and, honestly, I would come in here just to have a whiff. 

Then you catch a glimpse of the first ice cream area. An entire section devoted to chocolate creations. The Mexican Hot Chocolate is a favorite of mine because it combines sweet dark chocolate with spices like cayenne pepper. But, I ordered up a serving of Chockwork Orange- dark chocolate ice cream with specks of chocolate and an orange flavor. It reminded me of those orange chocolate balls that you smash on the table and they open up into orange segments. 
The boyfriend, of course, asks the staff if they have plain chocolate. They're confused for a second about why anyone would want plain chocolate when they've created all of these other amazing concoctions, but then serve him some with a smile. 
To compliment my chockwork orange I add on some pumpkin cheesecake. Creole Creamery does make a plain cheesecake flavor but it was the first day of October so I had to go with the pumpkin. It was creamy and just the right blend of the two flavors. 
Other flavors like the oatmeal cookie with molasses is heavenly. If you're looking for something original try the lavender honey- at first it's a little like soap- floral and not something your palate is used to- but it really is good. Try it! They will be happy to oblige with tastings (trust me). The only problem there is that they use tiny wooden spoons so you get the wood flavor that overpowers any ice cream. 

The prices, I must add, are just right. I actually was taken back when she rang up my order. Creole Creamery is much cheaper than my favorite ice cream in Boston. NOTE: cash only!!

I'm putting it in writing that one day I will do the Tchoupitoulas challenge- 15 scoops plus toppings that you have to finish all by yourself to get your name on a plaque on the wall. I will do it.

Came here for a Zumba training a couple weeks ago and was very impressed with the facility and staff. The room where we did the training was very large, clean, and cozy for a group of 60 women! Also, when we needed to use the restroom/locker room I was impressed with how large and cleaning everything was. I don't plan on becoming a member, but I appreciate the cleanliness and friendliness of the center.

I'd heard about King Dragon for a long time, about two years, and I finally got up the non-lazies to go there. Small eating area, typical Chinese menu, 

BUT WAIT. 

Hidden in the appetizer section are the Vegetable Dumplings. 8 Dumplings for $4.50. Wrapped inside a green noodle are some of the most delicious dumplings I've ever eaten. There's ACTUALLY different veggies in here! Cabbage, mushrooms, carrots, bok choy = yum. My friend told me to wait for the "withdrawal-like cravings" to hit. I got mine steamed, but I'm sure fried dumpling would be out of this world, because frying makes almost everything taste better. That's one lesson I've learned from Indiana.

I usually get Kung Pao, but I decided to get curry chicken this time and break out of my Kung Pao box. It was pretty flavorful, not hot like the pepper on the menu suggests. The pint is a perfect dinner portion. Only problem? It was less curry chicken and more like WOW HERE ARE EIGHT ONIONS. 98% of the vegetable in the dish was white onion, with about six pieces of chicken.

In one month we've been to Blue Giant 3 times and it's ONLY because we need to restrain ourselves from spending all of our money in one place. We've learned a couple things from our steady attendance, here's what:

- The spice level of the Dan Dan Noodles has come down significantly. Maybe the chef had an accidental heavy hand the first time or maybe they decided not to light our mouths on fire anymore, I don't know. Not a complaint or reason to rejoice, just an observation. If you came here previously and it was too spicy, give it another shot. 
- The spice level of the shrimp wontons might be dependent on whoever is cooking them. The first time we had them they were spicy, the second time we had them they were mild, and the third time was nearing Dan Dan level. Again, not a complaint, just an observation. 
- The specials, y'all. Whatever they are, just get them. We were lucky enough to catch the Duck Lo Mein after an undersold Peking Duck night and it was incredible. Same wheat noodles as the Dan Dan but covered in oily, slippery duck fat- we could've easily eaten 3 of these. 
- The Scallop Egg Foo Young is still my favorite main on the menu, but I have 3 others left to try (Mapo Tofu, Peking Duck, Salt and Pepper Catfish). The other things are great but the SEFY is probably the most unique taste.
- The folks at the door are incredibly nice, friendly, and patient. If you're running late for your reservation just keep them informed and they'll likely hold your table. 

Every friend we've brought here has loved it and will probably add to the reservation time but anything to keep these guys in business, even if they have to be shared with the rest of the city.

Great Cajun/Creole food - they have one of the best selections of it in the city, and it seems like all of their dishes are consistently good. My friend got the jambalaya, which was great, I got the Seafood/Okra Gumbo, and my other friends got Chicken Andouille Gumbo and the catfish. Be warned - the entrees aren't that large, and if you order an appetizer and a side thinking that it's the same size as an entree, you are mistaken! The desserts all seemed AMAZING - we had the hardest time deciding between the pecan pie w/ice cream, the whiskey bread pudding, or the praline sundae..finally decided on the pecan pie with ice cream, and in the end our waiter gave it to us for free :) What a nice guy..also the decor was so adorable and old school New Orleans.

I enjoyed dinner Brennan's - mostly.  The restaurant is stunningly beautiful and we loved being seating in the Havana Room.  Hospitality is warm and gracious at every turn from the host to the waiters.  The dress code seems to be minimal; we changed out of our jeans into something nicer but there were people in shorts and t-shirts so I guess you can come as you are.  Social distancing was very effective with extra spacing in the dining rooms.

During the COVID-era the menu is pared down and we were a bit concerned when the waiter only recommended 2 of the 8 entrees.  I started with delectable turtle soup and for my main had a nice smoky dish of stewed rabbit and beans.  My partner had a beef tenderloin with dauphine potato.  Food was very good but not an earth-shattering-knock-out.  My main issue was the undersized portions.  My rabbit was about the size of a chicken wing and maybe 3 oz. of protein.  The steak was quite small, too.  The prices weren't too bad ($25-$30 entrees) but I would have gladly paid a few bucks more for a more reasonable portion size.  Also there were no sides for order on the menu which would have helped round out our meal.  What's odd is the portions in the Yelp pictures all look a bit more bountiful than what we were served.

Dessert: I love bananas foster and this is the place to have it, complete with the excitement of a tableside flambÃ©.  The bread pudding was excellent as well.  We had plenty of room for dessert since our mains were small which suited my sweet tooth rather nicely.

I've eaten at most of New Orleans' fine dining establishments, and don't get me wrong, Brennan's was nice, but it was our most expensive meal on our recent trip and while the food was a-okay (albeit on the small size), I didn't walk out raving about any of the dishes.  It was an enjoyable meal and experience but for fine dining I have other favorite spots.

Craft Manayunk was a pretty cool spot to catch up with a friend over some brews and burgers!
The ambiance is typical gastropub, very cool, very good beer list, etc. I dig it. The beer list was very extensive and I found a great IPA to enjoy. 
Food was pretty good. Nothing earth shattering but it worked. It seems most people go with a burger or sandwich situation here, which is what my two friends and I did. I got the fried chicken sandwich which was really good...I loved the pickles. My friend ordered the lamb burger which seemed interesting. 
I would not recommend the mixed drinks unfortunately. My friend ordered a margarita which a) came in the wrong glass (maybe I'm picky, but why not put it in a margarita glass?) and b) was mainly sour mix. Whenever a margarita is like neon green my suspicions are raised, as was the case here. But all that aside, for beer and a burger I'm in!

great restaurant on the upper-end of restaurants here on clearwater beach. 

came one night with my roommate and her uncle. pretty good drinks, and pretty good entrees. if you're looking for a fancier place to eat, this is your spot!  

steak sandwich: i would avoid. its good (and good quality pieces of steak); however, the sandwich is mostly 60% bread, 20% arugula, and 20% steak strips. just a pet peeve of mine when the sandwich bread is the majority of the sandwich. 

make sure to ask for the break basket. our lady didnt bring ours, but it ended up being delicious when she did bring it over.

So.  You are reading a review of Chipotle?  Ok.  Well then, let me welcome you to the modern world.  I hope your slumber under that rock was peaceful.   We have internet now, and cell phones and Facebook!   We also have build your own assembly line food places.  

Chips toe is one of the best chains at doing the assembly line food.  It claims healthy and fresh and conscientious practices.   and it delivers some really great simple and reasonably priced quick serve Mexican food. 

This particular location isn't as big as others I have been in, but the outside patio is sizable and they have a good sized parking lot outside.  And if you are feeding a picky family this might be a good choice because of a number of other quick serves in the same center.  

Everything was band new, clean and the service was quick and efficient.   

And it's walking distance.  Well to my house at least.  I have no idea where your rock is located.

This place is a hole in the wall... Quite literally. No sign graces the outer facade... It is a bar and in the very back thru the swinging saloon doors is a hole in the wall behind which killer po boys resides... 
I ordered my pork belly PoBoy and waited at the bar which is a separate business. 
I really wanted to like it... It was well constructed... Very generous with the swine... However it was all fat...  
I do love pork... And bacon of course.. However this was just too much fat... I am sure the classic shrimp would have been a better option...

Charbroiled oysters!! Do I need to say more? I have a texture issue so I usually avoid oysters adr all costs,  but my goodness.  The garlic,  parmesan butter sauce that's put on top is AMAZING!! I used the crusty bread to soak up every drop if that goodness. 

The alligator tacos were ok. The floor tortillas were hard in the edges,  I'm not sure if this is because they were old or different too much time under the light awaiting pick up.  

I had 2 corn dishes,  but they weren't very good.  I can't even remember what they were. There was also a shrimp dish that would have been very if the sauce had been served on the side.

This is a great spot for Creole food. It is even recommended by locals. There is a line outside, but it moves quickly.  The staff is very friendly and welcoming.  I ordered the platter with gumbo, roast chicken, corn, and bread pudding. The chicken had multiple pieces and was served with a brown gravy with mushrooms. They give you a loaf of warm french bread to dip in your gumbo.  All the food is fresh and made with quality ingredients. The restaurant has indoor and outdoor seating.  There is no bar to sit at.
We stopped in here recently to get subs. The service was lightning fast as usual and we were very happy with the sandwiches. It is easy to stop in here on the way to the beach.

Three words: HAPPY HOUR NACHOS

Just go during happy hour, 5-7 M-F or 1-3 Sat/ Sun, and order yourself the nachos (splurge the extra $1 for a huge scoop of guac). For $6, you'll get a beautiful mound of melty , gooey, crunchy, salty, satisfying chips with no skimping on the toppings. Best paired with 1-2 friends and a draft IPA. My vegetarian friend and I had no qualms about splitting this meat-free dish, and we hardly made a dent before my stomach finally screamed at me to stop binge eating. I probably looked like an animal, shoveling food with my hands - NO SHAME. Best nachos I may have ever eaten.

I also ordered a Chilorio taco (a spicy pulled pork) and a Chorizo & potato taco - both banging, but the Chorizo definitely won. The tacos were small, like smaller than the palm of my hand, and I have little hands (I'm Donald Trump LOL). I was a little disappointed that they cost $2+ each. I'd definitely come back on $1 taco night though.

Beer selection is alright, about 6 on draft and a variety of bottles/ cans, and the bar is full of any liquor you could want. The vibe is very chill - a little dim, a little tight at the bar. Hipster, but not overly; divey but clean.

Bartender was a little harsh. I arrived a little before 5 and I wasn't about to buy a beer when it wasn't on happy hour. When I stated I'd sip on water until 5, she rolled her eyes and kind of gave me 'tude. She was fine otherwise, average bartendery service. 

I'll definitely be back. This is the perfect weekday happy hour.
Love and miss their smoothies.  Always hit up the one in IV and if I went downtown to run errands I'd usually have one of these in my hand.   Enjoy Blenders more than Jamba.  Sorry JJ.

This is an awesome po-boy shop tucked away in the back of a bar called Erin Rose. We ordered the shrimp po boy, which was delicious. The shrimps were huge and they were definitely generous with them - however, they were way too salty! The cucumber/carrot slaw was a nice addition, different from the lettuce I usually associate with po-boys. It was sooo good, could've definitely eaten that by itself. A little pricey at $15 but the sandwich is super fat and yummy

First, a shout out to GRoupon, because without that I would never had known about this place.  It's definitely off the beaten path. Honestly, the place doesn't look like much at all viewing it from the street, but once you venture inside, you'll be glad you did. 

I would give this a 3.5 stars because (1) the food was very good (2) the ambiance was what I would call European romance.

Was this "real french" cuisine? Heck if I know. I'm an American. I do know  what ever european cuisine it was, it was deliciously prepared.  Everything from the salad dressing, to the bread, to the entree down to the traditional creme brulee was thoroughly enjoyable.

I don't understand giving this a low rating because someone doesn't like the wine. Huh? Yes, the restaurant name is wine house, but I'm there to eat. It is a restaurant, after all.

Inside looks like an adorable elderly french  (or European) wealthy grandmother decorated. I'm in to old fashioned antique-looking  decor, so this was right up my alley.  It really does look like another world in there. Ladies and gents, this is a somewhat dressy place. Yes, believe it or not. Don't judge this book by its cover. Some girls were in prom dresses. Guys, no shorts here; long pants and a button down.

We will definitely return.

Stopped while walking Nashville upon a recommendation and scoping Yelp. Ordered a couple of appetizers and a burger. Appetizers were tot fondue and MD crab dip. Burger I ordered was the 'buy the farm burger.'

ATMOSPHERE: set in a restaurant neighborhood in the outskirts of downtown, there is outside seating as well as indoor seating that offers large booths and trendy music. The music could be loud if you're not into that sort of thing, but in terms of overall settings - it is very accommodating to a variety of tastes and needs for groups, etc. 

FOOD: The food was overall very good. The MD crab dip was good and creamy. The chips they come with were good- crispy and salty. As for the tot fondue- I don't know why I was expecting more than what it was. Kind of like the tots you get in high school with some jazzed up fondue. Wasn't a fan but it hit the spot. 

Burger was prepared very well. My other buds said the same- ordered it medium well and came out as ordered. 

SERVICE: Our waiter was on the odd side. Very attentive but not very talkative. Kept the drinks filled and did his duties. Also appreciated his willingness to only have half of his shirt buttoned. Man had a chest pelt that would make the most sterile woman blush. He also pointed where we should go to get the full Nashville experience. 

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Price wasn't bad either. $21.58 for a burger, drink and one appetizer.

Ok. I found it shocking that this is a chain. Cause the food is truly special. Melt in your mouth goodness... the stuffed chicken breast, the wine, the steak quality, the creamy mash potatoes, the various dessert cups that give you a shot of heaven... and SO reasonably priced. ($2 a cup)  They have a zillion choices of creme brule', and rather large starter salads that are almost a meal in themselves.  We took our family here and were all around impressed. Only downfall was the slowness of service... we were definitely salivating before the food came, and ate WAY too much bread.

I lived in Edmonton a couple of years before someone introduced me to Route 99. As an ex-Torontonian, I was surprised that at least some  E-towners enjoy the dive diner experience. The walls are covered with license plates and photos of movie stars. It's perfect, as far a greasy spoons go. There are lots of windows, like any decent road-side diner should have, and lots of cushy booths to stick to. The waitresses rule this joint.They've got systems for making sure everyone gets what they need fast and efficiently. The girls breeze around the diner, and around each other, with practiced grace, taking orders, refilling coffee and delivering bills. They know what you need before you do. And they're perky 'cause they've been up since six and already had 5 cups of Joe. It's always busy here on the weekend, but it doesn't take long to get seated if there's a wait. They've got yer pancakes, eggs, sausages, bacon, waffles, omelettes, steak 'n' eggs - you name it. This is the perfect way to spend a lazy Saturday afternoon before hitting Whyte for a stroll or shopping.

This place is so yummy and fun! I can't believe that I had not been here before. I love that they offer such an extensive menu and that everything ordered can be customized. They also offer a very extensive vegan menu which is a wonderful option for plant-based eaters. Our server was attentive and our food came out quickly. I thought about taking one star off  the review since I received the wrong menu item, but the server was so apologetic about it and sought to immediately correct it that I didn't let it phase me.  Apparently the cook was new and put buffalo sauce on the chicken sandwich that I ordered that was not supposed to have BBQ sauce. I opted to keep the sandwich since even it was not what I ordered it was super delicious! Well done bareburger.

Its like a subway with less choices.  
-only one size sandwich(white loaf or wheat thick sliced)
-no low fat condiments
-basic sandwich toppings only plus avocado spread
-the bread isnt crunchy like french bread but isnt as soft as subway breads 
-3 types of chips
-2 different types of cookie
-no kids meals
-very small interior, one 6 person booth, 4 4 person booths and 2 2 person booths.  if you go during a busy time plan on taking it to go or go thru the drive thru.  
-they do have 15 people working at the same time so it will be FAST

Unique stuff from a neighborhood store.  I went here every week when I lived in the area, and I shopped without breaking the bank.  I have my standard list of groceries that I buy every week, as I think most people do, but Straub's is a great way to break the cycle and try something new.

The reviews here have been mixed but seem to be improving.  I love to OD on MSG every once and a while so I stopped in to check this place out.  

This used to be the Old Country Buffet and the new folks didn't change it much.  Like most Chinese buffets the atmosphere is nothing special.  Of course you didn't come here to admire the dÃ©cor but to eat yourself into a stupor! 

I stopped by for a weekday lunch and the tab was $8.59 + $1.99 for an unlimited soft drink for a total with tax of $11.21.  That is very typical buffet  pricing for this area.

I was impressed by the cleanliness here.  The restaurant itself was spotless and the men's restroom was immaculate.  Sorry ladies but I didn't check the women's bathroom.  I wasn't in the mood for all the yelling and screaming that was likely to ensue!

The wait staff was fine.  My soda was refilled and my plates were whisked away with no problems.  I even received a nice smile and a thank you as I prepared to leave.

So what about the food? You need to know that I don't eat sushi.  I'd rather have a root canal with no pain meds that eat raw fish!  I'll leave the sushi review to someone else.  The Chinese food here is solid.  Every selection was full and kept that way while I was there.  All the temperatures were proper.  Won-ton soup was great.  The dumplings were very good.  One of the most popular buffet entrees is chicken with broccoli.  Here it was tasty but they need to use more care with the broccoli.  There were quite a few substandard pieces.  The hibachi station was excellent.

Nobody expects gourmet cuisine at a Chinese buffet but here you will get solid fresh-tasting A-OK food at a decent price and friendly service.  I'll be back.

The Quick-n-Dirty:
Location: Good
Ambiance: Good
Price: Pretty good
Food: Average

The Long & Drawn Out:
Our hotel front desk staff recommended Ellendale's as a great place to eat. The location was convenient as it was right behind our hotel. So, with coworkers in tow, we headed up the hill. The restaurant itself is an old house - as it was told to us by the hotel van driver, it used to be an old dairy house back in the day. 

As soon as we got in the front door, we were promptly seated in the main area near the bar. The service was good overall but the bar lagged a bit getting wine out to the table. Surprisingly, we were serenaded by a overtly loud singer/songwriter, which forced us to try and hold a business conversation a few decibels louder than what was comfortable.

I ordered the vegetarian Quinoa Stir Fry. I really appreciate having a vegetarian option on the menu. The quantity was really good for the price point; however, the taste was pretty bland. I was expecting something really flavorful and plenty of vegetables but it turned out to be the opposite. Don't get me wrong, it was OK but not the best.

I would probably go back the next time I'm in Nashville to see if there is something else on the menu.

Didn't care for atmosphere or food at all, mom n SIS food was okay. I like spicy food but my dish was Wayyyyy too hot. I had sczhewan bean curds, SIS had eggplant with garlic sauce, n mom had shrimp/chicken n broccoli

Be still my beating heart. I may have found a new love. I've discovered a restaurant that has three of my favorites and they do them all well. I'm besides myself with excitement and can't wait to tell you about it. 

My inaugural  visit here was with the ISC (International Super Club). As my usual, I arrived early. This gives me an opportunity to relax at the bar before all the members arrive. Tonight I started out with one of their signature adult beverages.  One of my favorites is a Manhattan,  which we will talk about later.  However, their Heartbreak and Setbacks is kinda similar, so that is where I begun. The. Bonded Rye was smooth and being served on the rocks made a refreshing cocktail. 

 As I enjoyed my cocktail,  I munched on their Crab Avacado.  Once you have enjoyed this appetizer, it will be hard to go back to regular guacamole.  It's a smooth blend of avocado,tomato,onion and cilantro.   Then it is topped with shredded crab meat and served with lotus root chips. It's the perfect nosh while sipping a cocktail. 

Somehow my H&S was gone before the appetizer and I needed a second adult beverage. For my next cocktail, I went with my favorite, a Manhattan. To test the masterfully skills of a barkeep, I take mine up. She nailed it. Happy boozer, here. 

As our members arrived, we moved to our tables. Here I started out with another of my favorites, chicken wings. They were served crispy and the mix of lemongrass and Thai Chili, was a delicious mix of tangy and heat.

Before I could order my entree, Stevie needed another cocktail. #3 would be an Old Fasioned. Again, the young barkeep nailed it. It's good to see that in addition to being creative in mixing and creating new cocktails, they are still mastering the classics.  

 Finally, the piece of resistance of the whole night was the Bao Soft Shell Crab.  Soft shell crab is not only one of my favorites it is one of my weaknessess.  Whenever I see it on the menu it is a must have.  This is the first time I have had it on a bao  and I can honestly say it will not be the last.  I was expecting the softshell crab to be in pieces, but to my surprise it was one entire crab placed between the bao. I first enjoyed eating my way around the bao, experiencing the delicious soft shell crab. Then I ate the bao getting the full experience of the; eel sauce, masago, kaware and mayo. That is when I said, be still my beating heart. I was in love. 

 The ambience is extremely comfortable and modern. Their service is detailed, friendly and professional.  A combination that provides you a relaxing and enjoyable dining experience. 

I'll be back? - Hell, yes.  They've got three of my favorites.

When - June 21, 2018
Why - International Supper Club

I was a little wary to try Chipotle because McDonald's had a hand in its development. But since it seems like a pretty decent company and everyone seems to love it, I gave it a try.

I am the type of person who goes on the website and looks up nutritional information. As usual, it was a horrifying experience. 

Luckily I was able to cobble together a salad that was reasonably healthy. I picked chicken, black beans, hot salsa and guac to go on top. I'm glad the dressing was on the side because the salad honestly did not need any. 

Over all, it was okay, not fantastic. I would eat here again, but for mexican cravings I'll stick with taquerias.

Hassan is definitely one of the most deserving businessowners I have ever encountered, and I'm extremely proud to keep going back to support Mood Cafe whenever I'm in the area or want to bring a friend to try out someplace they've probably haven't ventured to. 

I stop by probably at least once a month when business brings me to the West Philly (as in, past 44th street) area, and each time Hassan is extremely friendly and willing to explain new things. He even gives large samples of his famous lassis, and I think the first time I came here he gave mine to me free! Definitely made me come back again and again. By now, I just end up getting the mango lassi because it's one of my favorite drinks (not too sugarly, but sweet enough to satisfy me and cold enough to refresh me). I usually bring a gluten free chaat back for my boyfriend, and while I'm not a big fan of chaat in general because of its spices I do enjoy nibbling a few bites off his plate, since all the ingredients are crispy and fresh. The only reason this didn't get 5 stars is that it's slow sometimes to get your order when there's a line, because there is only one employee and he painstakingly makes each order by hand (and with a smile!), so it sometimes gets me a bit impatient..but I would not compromise the fantastic service for all the quickness in the world, because that's what makes this place so great!

Sadly, it wasn't as good as the Chipotle's I've had in Boston. 

First, they were out of tortillas.  How can you be out? Thats the main thing you sell! Then, the taste was overwhelmingly lime. Yes, I know the rice is lime, but once topped with pico, thats all you could taste. The chicken had some nasty pieces in it and I had a huge chunk of pork fat on my carnitas plate.  

Besides the fact that their menu is limited and they dont have margaritas, I'm going to vote Felipe's holds King of burrito joints.

3.5 stars! The Hook is a cute little place that is best described as the seafood version of Edley's. You order at cashier and food is brought to you. Atmosphere is really cute, with beach like theme, and great patio with cornhole! We went for lunch, a bit early at 11:30, right before lunch crowd. I ordered the shrimp tacos and a side of BBQ broccoli. It was just average, not bad, but nothing amazing either. I'd love to give it another try as it is such a cute place.

Please note that this review is for the Pharmacy only

I became violently ill within the last couple of weeks and was tested by my doctor. I needed special and so called 'rare' anti-parasitic medicine.  My usual pharmacy is at Rosauers and I love them dearly but unfortunately they did not have what I needed. They did call around and found that this Walgreens had what I needed.  They worked with Dan, the pharmacy manager,  to ensure that the paperwork and insurance check marks were all cleared. I drove out to the location on Apple and Parkcenter and found Dan working busily helping a slew of customers.  He asked me for my name and knew instantly as to the reason why I was there.  He was very polite and professional.  I felt at ease even though I was not feeling my best.  He explained the nature of the medicine and we exchanged some pleasantries.  For those who live in this area, you are in very good hands. Well done Dan!!!!!!!

I didn't find the prices here that inexpensive.  I waited in line for a long time to get a key copied.  It was the same line as the returns, so you can imagine how long the wait was.  Only to find out that they don't copy auto keys.  

Bought two pairs of shoes.  Looked very closely at the sale signs.  Seemed very clear that it was a buy one, get one at half off.  Got to the cash register and the register rang up the shoes as one was for sale at $5 off and no get one half off.  No way.  Absolutely no signage to that effect.  

What a mess.  At least the dude at the cash register was cool.

We went here for a going away dinner due to the LaBan review.  I had to get the mole, and went with the enchilada version.  It was very good, although a tiny bit spicier than I would have preferred.  It was a huge portion and I took most of it home.  The leftovers were of course delicious.  We also shared some guacamole and some nachos.  There was a lot of jalapeno going on in everything.  I like spicy food, but it was a little much.  Overall though, everything was really good, and very cheap.

If Mexican food is your comfort food, this is your place. I've been here a few times, and gotten food to go too. The food that they provide is a good satisfying meal. I'm just not in love with it. I don't crave going here. Strangely, when I do bite into my food, it hits the spot that I didn't even know that I had. I've never been disappointed with with anything I've ever had, and the food and drinks do come out promptly.

btw, when you do get take out from here, you're going to be just as happy elsewhere as you are in the restaurant eating it.

The true definition of a local family owned restaurant !

Ok ill admit I really wanted to go because they had Schnitzel on the menu and we were in the Gulfport area due to the chef's competition at the casino. Once you step inside, immedieatly you feel the nostalagia of the restaurant. Inside it feels like as if I stepped into my grandparents home in which I was about to be served a great home cooked dinner! 

The waiters there were very attentive to us and asked us if we had been there before to which we had not. They explained that it was a family run business and has been in the area for generations serving the local community. Shortly after, we were served a loaf of bread with house made honey butter - we must have killed 3 loafs between the 3 of us !

They had a great brunch menu and I was so happy that they had the schnitzel on the menu. The misses orderd the liver & onions and my mom ordered the beef brigninon. Her dish was a little salty but the schnitzel I ordered was quickly finished as it too me back to the schnitzel dinner I had during my last trip to Austria!
 
If your looking for a nice place to take the relatives for a quiet intimate location, come check this place out!

Had multiple drinks here... no idea on the food, but i've heard from multiple sources (and visually confirmed), it looks amazing!

the view is awesome, i love downtown Nashville.  
The bar gives you a great view of the restaurant and downtown while providing stellar service and a great option of beverages. 

The bourbon.... huge selection of bourbon including many hard to find. IE George T Stagg, OFC and a bunch of vintage bourbons. 
Be prepared to open up your checkbook.. most bars try to make up the cost of the bottle with 3ish drinks, this place does the same... with the bourbon being poured by the ounce in most cases

Either way... its a big city, fancy restaurant, we can all agree it wont be cheap. 

Great selection... good service... Good view.  I'll be back!

Fantastic new store! Huge and bright, and so much great stuff! There's a deli with freshly made meal options to go (lasagna, salads, sides, etc), gorgeous desserts, a meat department with meat already marinating, and so many more aisles filled with other food.  Bulk bins as well with lots of beans/lentils. They have frozen meat and fish, and the prices looked reasonable to me.

The produce section seemed kind of small when you take into account how big this store is, and the actually didn't have something I was looking for.

This is overall a great organic grocery store!

I have been curious to check out this place and since it's an hour drive for me, the opportunity presented itself last minute and I got to check it out with friends. I ordered elote( corn, lime, aioli and cheese) and Las Favoritas( chorizo stuffed dates wrapped in bacon) to start. The elote was with clear winner between these two dishes. I also had the opportunity to try Bombas Contigo( fried potato with bacon with brava sauce); I love potatoes and I loved theses as they were formed with potato shreds and not fried mashed potato.
I enjoyed shared carafe of red sangria followed with a Pisco Punch and they were standard for me. Just OK cocktails. My husband and I shared the Parillada platter which is described as: Ribeye, chorizo, morcilla, lamb chop, roast marrow, salsa verde, chimichurri, and seasonal vegetables. So basically it was a plate of meat, which is what we were expecting but no real side to the dish. My husband and I loved the morcilla (blood sausage); who knew blood sausage could be so tasty? All this was finished off with one surprisingly great dessert called the Capirotada( bread pudding with figs and goat cheese?), that was rich without being heavy.

It was a very busy night and so initially our service was attentive and then it went down hill.
In the midst of conversation, the waiter handed us our bill.  So I asked him, he aren't you going to tell us about your great desserts?  However, it took so long to arrive that I regretted ordering dessert; a line had crossed. My husband wanted to leave as the place was getting increasingly crowded but we were in limbo waiting for my dessert while sitting outside in a breezy evening on the patio at 8pm, with an hour drive home in our future.
Love the happy hour menu and bar scene here.  The specials for happy hour are reasonably priced the steak is good,  Mac and cheese is can't miss.

Joella's Hot Chicken is the first Indiana location of a small Kentucky-based chain of "hot chicken" restaurants with Ohio soon to join the crowd. 

Hot Chicken, for the uninitiated, is a "tradition" that is said to have started in Nashville, TN and basically takes your traditional Southern fried chicken and gives it a kick. In the case of Joella's, that "kick" comes in varying degrees ranging from "no heat" (which really is pointless if you're actually coming here) to spiked honey (sweet mild), Ella's Favorite (a sort of mid-range option), Tweener (medium heat), Hot (spicy fire!), and Fire-in-Da-Hole (the hottest, indeed). They have six chicken plate options including, yes, an actual vegan option. I ordered a 3 Jumbo Tenders Plate that comes with one of several dipping sauce options along with one of several sides. You can get the tenders grilled upon request. 

The drink is not included in the plate and my entire meal, including drink, came in at just over $11, a fairly standard price for this Indy/Fishers border area. 

Joella's also offers "Sammies," Salads, a handful of dessert options, and they do serve beer, soft drinks, bottled craft/flavored sodas, and both sweet/unsweet iced tea. 

In case you don't realize it, Joella's took over the spot vacated by 96th Street Steakburgers. The interior is in more of a Southern/Americana theme and it appears that they are working on adding an outside dining area. They do not offer drive-thru - worth noting since the drive-thru in the building is still present. 

They have a couple of accessible parking spots and you should note that the only curb cut is on the east side of the restaurant (the same side as the accessible parking - for once, logic prevails!). 

As you enter, you are immediately surrounded by the dining area and the ordering counter is straight ahead. You order, they give you a number and you get your own drinks from a fountain to the left. The fountain is not particularly wheelchair friendly, though I was able to make it work. 
I thought the cups were a tad small - not sure of their size, maybe 16 or 20 oz, but for a place that emphasizes hot food I definitely found myself wishing I didn't have to go back up to get a refill. 

The food? The chicken is hormone free and you can definitely taste the difference. As I get older, preservatives kick my booty and my body did fine with this chicken. The jumbo? Definitely not jumbo. I found myself looking at it and thinking of at least a half dozen local restaurants with bigger tenders, though certainly I would consider them jumbo compared to most chains. The fries, which I chose as my side, were of a shoestring variety and were served in a nice serving size. 

If I could, I'd likely lean toward a 3.5 star rating. However, I really liked the friendly service and felt like that hospitality factor allows me to up the rating rather than lower it. I wouldn't say this is my favorite chicken, or even chicken tenders, in Indy but it's a place I wouldn't hesitate to eat while in the neighborhood.

This review is specific to Meijer Pickup. Pre-COVID, I shopped in-store and enjoyed the experience. Meijer is generally clean and well-stocked and I can find what I need.

I recently did a Meijer Pickup order. Note: this was the weekend before Thanksgiving, so I'm curious if my experience was atypical due to the upcoming holiday. 

Long story short: I arrived at the pickup area outside the Starbucks entrance and texted the number provided, and it took a grand total of 30 minutes for an employee to bring out my order. There were four other cars waiting alongside me. It's clear they were understaffed, as the poor employee was the only one bringing out groceries. 

It was also odd because earlier that afternoon, a Meijer employee called me to go through the substitutions and out-of-stock items, and to let me know my order was ready early and I could come pick it up.

Overall, I found Meijer's pickup experience to be inefficient, especially compared to Kroger. With Kroger, everything is done within the app, including accepting/declining substitutions and letting the store know I'm on my way or I've arrived. I never wait more than five minutes tops at Kroger. 

Meijer would benefit to have the pickup area be separate from the busy main entrance. Kroger's system works well because their pick-up is on the side of the building so the employees don't have to walk far to get to customers.

Prime rib carpaccio is outrageously yummy. The staff here is so friendly and down-to-earth that I pick 'em over a slightly better steak down the road. Now if they'd just reconsider those slightly scary black commodes...

Fleming's Happy Hour is one of the best in town. $7 burger with fries (burgers come with bacon and choice of cheese) - one of the best burgers I've had. The service has always been good as well. Only downside is that there is no outdoor seating! I know they are doing renovations, but I'm so bummed that it doesn't look like it will include outdoor seating. I haven't been for a "real" meal, but I can't say enough good things about happy hour - but I can't give 5 stars solely on happy hour, so I'm leaving it at 4.

If you know anything about me you know that I don't enjoy waiting in line for food. Gumbo Shop is one of the many places in New Orleans where a line may form to dine. 

It's tough picking a place to eat for a group of six people. We decided to wait it out for some Yelp approved gumbo. Gumbo Shop is a restaurant where the line spills out onto the street around the front where you can peer in at those who are already dining. Don't drool on the window as that is rude to those trying to enjoy their food. Wait and wait until you are in a dark hallway like alleyway that is feet away from the entrance to the restaurant. 

Staff here is organized and do no seat any parties that don't have all persons in the group present. No exceptions. 

You're seated and greeted by friendly staff who serve you your cajun/creole traditional dish. I had the gumbo and the crawfish etouffee. The etouffee was the better of the two and I would highly recommend it.

Located in Downtown Tampa, this park is wonderful!  Thank  you City of Tampa for the investment that was put in for this park! The events held here are amazing and the view is great! Very family friendly and there is so much to do here.  A great playground for your little ones as well!

Juan's Flying Burrito, fell flat on its face.
I had the enchiladas, and have had much better.
My wife had the Quesadillas, and they were BAD.
First, who cooks the lettuce INSIDE of the quesadilla?
You end up with wilted, slimy lettuce.
Second, who charges for the sour cream?
This is not supposed to be cafeteria fare.
The only thing holding this place together was the 
great service.
Go a few blocks down the road to Nacho Mammas..
Where the chips and salsa are not only, but the food actually tastes good.

I must say I was a little worried when I entered a BBQ joint with a full bar.

I was raised on BBQ in places that had little lighting, where side dishes were a luxury, and Wonderbread and sauce are the only distractions one needed from the main event.  I myself also love making BBQ, which I adhere to as a religion, rubbing meats and brining birds days in advance, and slow smoking tough animal protiens until they become cookie dough over the span of half a day or more.

The shrimp corn dogs with avocado sauce were good, as was the Pig Burger.  A nice, fatty, flavorful burger with Benton's and a fried green tomato on a potato roll.  I got it with 'Pate of the South' and they didn't flinch at making it medium-rare, as per my request.  I had some greens on the side, which were good, but not exceptional.  

The brisket on Texas brioche was quite good too.

I am headed back there to take my CEO and our executive team there tomorrow night - I plan on diving in more to their BBQ specifically and I will update as soon as I do.  Assuming I still have a job.

UPDATE:
I went back there with the CEO and the rest of the bosses and it was a great meal.  Shame on me for not getting BBQ my first time there.  I got the STL Spare Ribs (I'm a bad, bad Jew) and sampled the brisket.  Everyone there loved it and we had a pretty good mix as the home office is in TX, and we had people who hailed from STL as well in our party.  I am still employed, so it was a success.  Also had the onion rings, greens, sorghum beans, guacamole - all of which hit the spot.

Finished off with the John Daniels (we go way back) banana pudding - perfect comfort food, and sampled the peanut butter cup which was also fabulous while it lasted.

The service was also excellent.  I still feel guilty eating in a BBQ joint that is so clean and has so many sides, but smoked meats dissolving in your mouth is worth it.  The only thing pretentious are the prices.  Upgrade to 4 stars!

One more note, watch out for the cocktail prices - TEN DOLLARS PER!  I think someone has themselves confused with The Patterson House.

The trick to getting a table besides luck is to come here 10-15 minutes before the live music begins...it gets quite crowded thereafter.

This time, we tried:
Edamame - $4 - good snack
bruschetta - $8 - ok
falafel sliders - $6 - pretty good
pork belly - $9 - disappointing
strawberry basil ice-cream - $5 - SO GOOD!

I had 5 Guys in California and it was just ok there and knowing it's an East Coast thing, I thought maybe it would be better here and honestly, it's just ok out here too.

The burgers are of a decent size and there's good flavor in the burger itself but it came across to me as a bit too greasy and honestly, I'm not a huge fan of the fries at 5 Guys. In my opinion, the best fries are served at In-N-Out, the waffle fries at Chick-fil-a, and Burger Bar, Las Vegas (sweet potato fries). If you're into the thick cut fries then this might be for you. I'm more into skinny fries but fries that are a bit more crispy than their thicker brethren.

Service here is ok. The at the counter was not very helpful as he had not tried more than half of the menu (at least he was honest about it) and the place is clean. Maybe a bit too clean as some parts of the restaurant smelled of clorox.

There's plenty of parking as it's a huge shared lot with the other stores in the plaza.

Honestly, nothing to write home about but definitely a step up (in quality and price) from the other fast food chains (i.e. McDonald's, Hardy's, etc)

Parking: Plenty
Wait: 5-10 mins after ordering
Price: $9+ per person

It was my very first visit to New Orleans (as a tourist,and a couple years later became a local), and when I visited Gumbo Shop, I thought it was the best thing since sliced bread.  

Hindsight is 20/20 right, yea.  This place actually is not the best.  

You have seriously got to experience your first bowl of gumbo from a mom and pop shop. Someplace authentic, a what you would call "hole-in-the-wall," that's where you are going to find what you traveled all the way to New Orleans to eat.   Although the cooks are local, they are not using their mama's or mau mau's (New Orleans version of saying grandma) gumbo recipe.  

But I get if you are just checking in to your hotel, and hungry, I can definitely see why visiting this place ranks #1.  But again, the soup isn't, but its a decent runner-up.

This is a review from July 2019. They have recently changed their menu, so now their tacos are served on corn tortillas, the way God intended. You have to buy guacamole if you want to add that to anything. I recommend the new steak taco --really good, the cauliflower taco and the chicken taco--all different flavors and awesome. They have great fresh brewed iced tea. The guacamole was really good. The chips are a little on the salty side but you can scrape some of that off. It wasn't very busy for lunch on Saturday which was fantastic. Great service. Love the decor throughout the restaurant and in the bathrooms!

I am like...89% sure everyone who waits tables here is stoned most of the time. And really, that's okay. 

The service can get weird sometimes, but I never feel too weird being here. I recognize all the trappings of crust punks and bike punks, despite the gutter punk decor. (Hot tip: gutter punks don't like having jobs. It gets in the way of harassing tourists on Frenchmen St.) Then again, this is probably not the place to bring your sweet church-going mother unless she's okay with a server who has been around the block a few times...on a fixie. (Hot tip: hipsters aren't the only ones with fixies.) 

I should probably talk about the food and not just the servers, amirite? Okay. There is a lot of food. I know this sounds simple and stupid, but bear with me. The food comes in large quantities. Larger than average. Larger than New Orleans typically spews forth. So get your tum ready or take a box home. (I double-fisted a burrito one night, and I still brought some home for later.) 

And there are vegetarian options. Like, real ones. Granted, they read like a stoner dreamt them up in a haze of really good purple kush (that's a type of pot, right?); but darn if they aren't tasty. I recommend the Mardi Gras Indians if you're feeling tacos. 

Here is your super-pro tip about hot sauce: There are multiple bottles of spicy liquid available for your consumption. If you think you have what it takes to go toe-to-toe with the big boys (and girls) of hot sauce, ask your server for the really spicy one. They'll usually say, "Oh, I brought you the hot sauce." That's when you look at them calmly and request, again, the REALLY spicy one. This will usually get you what you want. 

Also, for the confused: this is a Creole TaquerÃ­a. That means it's not any real sort of food; this place is a mash-up. A good one.
