If I were about to make a musical comparison, I might compare Juan's to the Grey Album by DJ Danger Mouse: smooth, splendid, not to everyone's taste. Sometimes, you just need the classics. (Oh god, this review reads like I'm stoned.) 

Accessibility notes: Half of the restaurant is accessible for mobility devices. The men's restroom is not accessible because it is up a step. Ditto for the bar. No braille signage or menus. Can get super loud at peak hours. Most of the booths are narrow and difficult to get into.

Our work team took Sunday afternoon off and decided to wander around the French Quarter. The group consensus favoured a place where we could sit outside and enjoy some live jazz and an adult beverage. And that's what we got! Service was friendly, but we had to come to them at either the bar or the coffee shop area. The music was quite good (the name of the band escapes me) and the expected free will donation at the end was a small price to pay for such a pleasant and relaxing part of our afternoon.

In the mood for some really good pizza and you not wanting the ordinary go to Little Rocco's Chicago, it's great pizza delicious salads and their wings are definitely ones that you might want to try. Being located centrally on Broadway it's pretty easy to find the parking isn't so great and the actual size of the building is kind of small but they do have booths and outdoor seating, The waitresses are very friendly and quick and attentive, one of the best salads I've had in town always really fresh greens and dressings are very tasteful. Now the pizza is excellent always made fresh to order, it's a little crispy but yet still soft enough for you to enjoy, fresh ingredients always make for the best, and if you're lucky enough to go during lunch hours they have an excellent lunch menu you could order a slice and a salad or a slice and wings all for under nine dollars, I was pleased to find out that they sell the sauce that they use on the wings. By far one of the best deep dish pizzas I've had in town.

I was intrigued when I saw that a ramen place was opening in New Tampa. I feel bad for any business that had to open during a pandemic, but Michi Ramen has pivoted to handle it better than any other business I've seen. I personally will only do curbside and delivery right now. The setup they have for curbside pickup is fantastic. You walk up and speak into an intercom. There's a slot in the window for you to put your card into. There's a tiny box with doors on each end they can put your receipt in and another similar large box where they can put your food.  You never have to get close to another person and they always have taken care of us quickly!

To be honest I liked, but didn't love their ramen.  What really has intrigued me is their tea bar. They have several green tea drinks, a few milk teas (with no boba), but also have *yogurt* drinks. I see that even though they have 40+ reviews I'm the first person to mention this. I really had no idea what to expect with a yogurt drink. I thought that "yogurt" could possibly mean that it had a thick consistency, but that's not the case. The yogurt apparently just gives it a more powerful flavor. So far my favorite is the grape yogurt drink. It's really refreshing unlike anything I've ever tasted. Thanks for bringing something new to the area Michi Ramen.

Their flat bread sandwiches were better than I expected. 

Rockfire grill seems like your average college town pub/bar + restaurant. The place is filled with students grabbing drinks or a late night bite. My first impression of the menu was that it was a bit unusual, in that they used their flat bread for seemingly all bread substrates. Flatbread pizzas, sure, but also no buns, just flat bread sandwiches and flatbread burgers. I must admit it worked because the food was tasty and made well. The flatbreads were fresh, hot, and enjoyably soft. Both the spicy chicken sandwich and the burger were good. My order took a bit longer than I expected to come out, but it was worth it. 

Good food must be recognized, and Rockfire delivered.

Dinner with old friends at the Roadhouse. Started out great fast service from Michelle, good drinks all is well. Weds night and there was no wait for a table. Plenty of sweet rolls and peanuts to go with our drinks. We ordered the best option on the menu. Steak and rib combos with a cup of chili and the green beans with bacon. 

The sirloin and ribs for me the filet and ribs for my friend. Chili came out quick. The cup with cheese and onions was overflowing, however the cup without cheeses and onions was 2/3's full. Where is the quality control. Well not in this kitchen. The steaks came out both over cooked. What else could be wrong. The filet was not filet it was sirloin. We pointed out the mistake to our server who promised to return ASAP with a filet. 

10 mins later the manager arrived with a perfectly cooked sirloin steak. We again pointed out the fact that we ordered a filet. She apologized and offered to bring another filet. We said no an decided to eat the sirloin since it was cooked correctly.  We were not offered anything more than an apology. No discount off the meal no discount to return, nothing. Our server was very nice but her. The manager and the kitchen staff need some steak education.

Tourist trap with frozen seafood in gumbo. Honestly - if you are pondering wasting your time, appetite and money - do yourself a favor and go elsewhere. Dooky's Chase (and a block away from Willie Mae's Scotch house) is a not as conveniently located but the make a trip out there if you want to taste real authentic gumbo.

The courtyard its in was really cute, and they have live music for what it seemed all day long! It was pretty crowded, all though not as much as Cafe Du Monde, and the coffees were overpriced. 

While the beignets were good, no way did they compare to Cafe du Monde's. So don't substitute your beignet fix with this place, but go ahead and supplement with it ;)

I've been seeing a few of the seafood boil pictures from The Mad Crab over the last few weeks on Yelp. On Monday evening I got to have a rare just the two of us dinner with my Father and since we are both always looking for the newest thing I mentioned The Mad Crab and we headed to U. City. It's a large place (formerly Kim Son) and it's decorated with a nautical theme. When the hostess seats you they cover your table in white butcher paper. We went for the largest combo, The Hangry Combo ($76.99.) We chose King Crab Legs, Shrimp, Mussels, and clams. They boil this with corn on the cob, red potatoes, and sausage. For flavoring we chose the Whole Sha-Bang (mild.) We got a side order of garlic bread to dip in the sauce/boil. They give you a plastic bib, plastic gloves, a seafood cracker, and a seafood sheller and dump the bag of boiled seafood onto the paper covered table for you to figure out. It was so great! We cracked the crab legs, scooped out the clams and mussels, and peeled the shrimp. It was savory and spicy even with the mild seasoning and I like spice. Loved the sausage and potatoes too! The spice and boil made a kind of broth/sauce and it was delicious dipping the garlic bread in it. Next time I'll try the French fries for dipping purposes. This was way too much food for two people and we lugged home a hefty to-go box but we have big eyes and wanted to try EVERYTHING! I can't wait to go back. The service isn't the best and they don't have a liquor license yet but who cares? Believe me when I tell you there is absolutely nothing else like this in St. Louis or anywhere close! Get here immediately before the critics get in here and start writing it up and it gets too busy!

A surprisingly GOOD experience with Dorjee (our Teppan chef) and our server.
Excellent Sunday-lunchtime service for our table of 10, celebrating a birthday.

The lunch menu is a good value - the "Lunch Boat" - I chose salmon - a teeny piece of salmon - comes with sashimi, edamame, tempura (all in small portions - perfect) and soup/salad.

My daughter (age 12) devoured the tuna tataki app. and a plate of nigiri.

We enjoyed the food and service, while watching the onion volcano.
Nostalgic.

No wait for a table for breakfast. My husband and I had the lobster appetizer which was amazing! He had the Benedict with shrimp boudin. I had the Benedict that had the wine sauce! We split a side of potatoes. We would come back for dinner sometime!

pretty standard fast chinese food at an airport.  

My experience wasn't as bad as others, but it wasn't exactly great.  Panda Express would be better suited here

Someone told me the other day that my Yelp reviews are "too nice". I'll admit that unless service is horrible and I really hate the food, I will be pretty generous with my ratings. However, my four stars for Juan's were totally well earned.

Juan's is a New Orleans classic for Mexican food. I headed over here for dinner, and since I was in a "burrito" mood, I got the "wet burrito". This is a burrito packed with beans, rice, lettuce and salsa and topped with red chile sauce, melted cheese, sour cream and jalapeÃ±os. The burrito is HUGE and was so good. I was going to snap a picture, but before I could, that burrito got ate.

The service was friendly and I like that the restaurant itself is dim and kind of cozy. Juan's is small, so there is going to be a bit of a wait for a table, if you go during busy lunch and dinner hours, but I waited less than 10 minutes at 8:00.
just a grocery store chain.  actually, the most use I got outta this place was parking in their lot after hours if I couldn't find an easy spot in the CWE.

Seems like an odd location at first, but it really is not that far from Westchase and all those other restaurants and hotels to the south and west on Tampa Road are not far away either.

No doubt I like this location significantly more than the one in Centro Ybor in every possible way.

Parking is more plentiful than it looks from the road although all those signs posted about not parking on the grass suggests they may not have enough when they attract a capacity crowd.

The interior is much larger than it appears from outside as well, and the design is very modern and comfortable.

Bar runs long, high-top table runs just as long right next to that and table seating fills the rest of the room.

Outside offers a modest size tiki bar with lounge/patio seating surrounding it.

As you would expect, there is plenty of craft beer to choose from and something they call a Mug Club to save regular visitors some money. There's also a bartender named Olivia who is good at making customers happy.

While I'm not a regular wine drinker, the fact that eight wines are offered "on tap" was a new and interesting thing to me.

From a menu standpoint, this TBBC features a good selection of apps, salads, burgers, pizzas, calzones and dinner plates. Portion sizes do justify the price.

As a soft pretzel snob, I am extremely impressed by the Moosekiller Barleywine mustard dip that accompanies this item. 

If they ever sold this by the growler, I might buy that to take home in bulk.

Stopped in on a Saturday night, sat at the bar
Great bar tender
No free chips :(
Caliente margarita: really good
House margarita: really good
Badass bacon bean dip: lived up to the name: solid
Hawaii 504 nachos: big plate full of all the ingredients and went together really well: great 
Luau quesadillas: full of bacon, shrimp, super tasty

Pretty legit place for Korean food. 

I am not an expert on Korean food by any means....but I am at least looking to try new things provided they aren't spicy to avoid subsequent heartburn & certain colon-rape the following day.

I can't remember the name of what I ordered here but it basically translated into Ox Bone Soup. It sounded like it would be really rich but it was actually quite bland. I actually preferred the item that Sean H. ordered which was some type of garlic-y chicken stuff. I would DEFINITELY order it again. It had far less gristle than the chicken from JooJoo's.

Service was alright but nothing to write home about. Overall cost of food was quite expensive for just two people (with one beer and a soda too, no dessert.)

Would I come back? Maybe for the chicken stuff. I also enjoyed some of those little dishes they bring out right after you order. As soon as she set the plates down I had to separate the things that looked spicy away from the "safe" looking items. I would have asked her to explain what things were and the names so I could write down the stuff I liked, but we got there pretty late and they were going to close within the hour so everyone was busy trying to clean up in preparation for closure, so I didn't want to bother her while she was busy cleaning.

But yeah, next time for sure, I need to learn the names of the stuff I like so I can order with ease at the next Korean place I go to. (And hopefully pronounce things correctly.) I'd love to learn how to speak Korean so I could talk to the waitstaff.

Also a plus - this place isn't too far from my house & workplace.

We've never really needed extra assistance as we're pretty good at navigating the store and finding what we need but when we do need help, it can take a while to find an employee to ask questions. I do love that when we do find an employee, they are more than helpful with useful suggestions and recommendations. I also love that it's dog friendly and our dog is always greeted and pet and sometimes the employees have dog treats as well. They have a good selection of plants and outdoor improvements that we love. We love to DIY and can find almost everything here. I will admit the prices can be a bit high here as we've been able to find the same item for lower prices at competitors/other Lowe's stores, or online (other retailers and lowes.com). This location can be quite busy since it's located around Broad Ripple.

I'm only rating Martine's based on a recent late night visit...
What a lovely spot! I can't believe in all the many years we have been coming to this area F and I have never been here.
We ended up at Martine's after a fundraiser for the William Trent House in Trenton NJ. We only stopped in for a after dinner cocktail. The friend who brought us here is a regular and apparently many of the local restaurant workers end up here after their shifts. You can tell it's a friendly neighborhood hang out, very welcoming and laid back at this time ( after 11) on a Saturday night. There was plenty of seats at the bar as well as tables inside and out.

The barman made me a delicious Jamison cocktail, which I nursed the rest of the night.

I'm really looking forward to coming back again and trying the food. I loved the cozy ambience and would like to experience it at an earlier time of day. Can't wait!

This may be the slowest service for subpar cuisine around.

My most recent trip to NOLA landed me here for the 2nd time, both visits were because I was with people that wanted the grilled oysters, which apparently are quite good. I'll never know, I'm allergic. 

Both instances of my dining at Drago's offered the same slow and inefficient service, overpriced menu, and overall MEH feeling. Too many cons to make up for the one pro (oysters), even per those who were there for the pro. There are far too many amazing restaurants to patronize in the Big Easy to waste time here.

Chipotle is the TargÃ©t of the Mexican fast food game. 

What's not to love about Chipotle?  Burritos (or tacos/ bowls) made your way. Quick. Hot. Fresh. Generally great service at this Cherry Hill location.  They also have a really good soundtrack playing whenever I go in. 

My go to is the carnitas burrito but you can't really go wrong with anything.  Good rice, fresh salsa and guacamole.  

And yes, we are aware the guacamole is extra. 

As for the price, it's a bit more expensive than your normal fast food joint, but then again the quality and freshness is a step up.

I expected to go there, try the veggie burger and leave without giving it that much thought.

It turns out a place that sells a lot of beef might become the new vegan hot spot of Philadelphia.

They label their menu which shows they are attuned to the concerns of vegans. So they meet the bare minimum. Good thing they surpass it.

For starters, get the pickles and slaw "bare snack". Two kinds of vegan slaw. The whole thing is fantastic. It made the perfect sharing item for a party of three.

They also have so many toppings and sides that are vegan. The vegan sandwiches they offer can be modified to add these items such as chickpea onions and stout onions. 

My wife and I split two vegan sandwiches, Guadalupe burger and the Mazuma tempeh sandwich. Both were great. I especially appreciate that they make their own veggie burger. No Morningstar Farms here.

For dessert we had the vegan carrot cake. The only item we ate that we didn't love. I would skip it net time.

Seriously, the meal I just had there compares very favorable to the many great all-vegan restaurants in Philadelphia. I am very very impressed.

Came to Little Nonna's last month for a birthday lunch with my mom and sister. It was a really nice day and we sat outside in the garden, which is green and beautiful and overall really lovely. We got a few dishes to share and most of the food was incredible, as was the service. 

---Garlic bread: I LOVED the fresh head of garlic to spread on the already prepped garlic bread. 
---Eggplant parm: Delicious. Light and tender with a sort of nutty flavor. All three of us absolutely  loved it and I'd definitely get it again.
---Pan seared gnocchi: I don't normally like gnocchi but this was really wondeful. The gnocchi had a great consistency and the dish overall was really fresh and warming. I loved the cherry tomatoes and mushroom! I would absolutely recommend this dish.
---Nonni's spaghetti and meatballs: I found this dish to be the least exciting of the three. The spaghetti is pretty standard and the meatballs, while good, are nothing that blew me away. It's a huge portion which I imagine would be a huge draw to some, but I'd rather a smaller portion of something more flavorful. 
---Apple crostini: good, but not that special or interesting. Next time I'd try one of their other desserts.

Since I come from NY with lots of Chinese food, I thought that the food quality in Philly was not that great. But I got impressed my the quality of this place. I ordered: 

- String beans. Well done. Great spice to salt concentration
- Beef dish. Not too salty and not bland. Well done
- Shanghai Xiao Long Bao. Well done. Great soup taste. 

Definitely a great place to come for Asian food!

I was only in LA  for a few days over the weekend and I wanted to do something I can't get at home or anywhere else I'm bound to be traveling, we didn't have much time to plan, we found a pamphlet for this Swamp Tour in our hotel lobby and booked it the night before with no problems.
We were picked up in front of our hotel right on time, along the way to the tour the bus driver told us about some spots we were passing along the way.
At the tour depot there is one bathroom for men and one for women, so do that first, the line gets long. I used the guys room, since there were no men waiting.
You can pick between a  covered or uncovered boat, we went for uncovered since the weather was beautiful and we had hats to wear, good choice! Our tour guide was Ted, he was awesome, he grew up in the swamp and loves what he does. He had so many great stories to tell us. We found out the gators are just coming out of hibernation so they weren't  very active, we got to see a few though, along with many snakes, birds, squirrels, and a turtle. Who knew  a swamp could be so beautiful. I could've stayed all day.
What a fun little yogurt shop surprise in Clearwater! Great varieties of flavors and toppings!

My Yelp friends in Westchase have been raving about Siam Thai Restaurant, and I was anxious to give it a try. Thai cuisine is still new to me, and I wanted to have something different rather than the typical noodle bowl or dish of curry.

This restaurant is located along Linebaugh Avenue and directly across the street from Westchase Elementary, in a little two-block stretch of restaurants and retail establishments. It's in the same little shopping area as Tijuana Flats, World of Beer, and Burger 21.

The interior is decorated simply, yet elegantly with artwork and antiques, and there is a sense of peace and calm despite the busy nature of the restaurant. When I was there for dinner, every table was filled, but you never sensed that they were trying to rush you out of the door. Families were coming in and out to pick up carryout orders, and the restaurant stayed busy the entire time we were there.

We started with Tom Yum soup which is one of the most popular soups in Thailand. Tom Yum Soup has many health benefits, due its potent combination of herbs and spices, and in fact, this Thai soup is currently under scientific study as it appears to have immune-boosting power as a natural remedy for cold and flu viruses. Mom always said that soup is good for you!

The soup is made with chicken broth, minced lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, a variety of chilies, straw mushrooms, onions, tomatoes, and all kinds of spices and herbs. To that they add your choice of seafood or meat, and you end up with a delicious hot and sour soup. It had a bit of a peppery kick, which will clear your sinuses without causing you pain.

For the main course we shared Siam Scallop and Shrimp which was pan-seared seafood with broccoli florets, sliced carrots and cabbage in a delicious chicken stock / garlic broth with a bowl of sticky white rice.

Delicious dinner that was reasonably priced. I'll definitely be back to try some other dishes.

It's not every day that we city folk can see live gators, wild boars, and a bald eagle in its natural habitat. Really enjoyed this tour, don't think I'd go visit this park of Louisiana if they didn't provide the means to do so.  They pick you up in a van at your hotel (for an additional fee of course), drive you to the swamp, load you on the boat for the 2 hour tour, and drive you back to your hotel.  It takes up about 4 hours of your day, but it's worth it in my opinion.  

How much wildlife you see depends a lot on the weather and the season. I went in October, so it was right before the gators begin to hibernate. I think in the colder months you don't see any gators at all (Nov-Jan) so be warned.  They don't guarantee anything.  Also during the hot, muggy summer it gets really hot and humid and the bugs are out.  We got to see about 10 gators, 3 good sized ones up close.  A lot of them had been poached due to aggressive hunters during hunting season though, which is a very sad thing.  Usually hunters leave these ones alone or aren't so aggressive, but for some reason this season was extremely brutal to the local natural area.

You also get to see wild boar who are running around in packs.  They aren't afraid of the swamp tours and actually actively pursue them, because it means food, i.e. marshmallows!  Wildlife, including gators, apparently love sugar just as much as humans.  Our captain, who is hilarious and told jokes all through the tour, was very adept at chucking the marshmallows to bring the animals closer to us.  He knew several of the animals by name, which makes sense since he probably sees them 2 or 3 times a day.

Make sure you bring plenty of water as you're sitting in a boat the whole time.  If it's hot outside, you'll want to bring a hat as well.  Also, make sure you go to the bathroom before you get on the boat at the Cajun Encounters building.  It would be an uncomfortable 2 hours if you don't.  

A great way to see nature without getting yourself dirty.

This is such a beautiful and unique place to eat. The service is spot on and the food is delicious. The prices are also really reasonable. The downstairs is a more traditional restaurant but still has a bar in the back that feels private. The upstairs has a more hipster bar vibe, but still does full service at the tables around it. The bar tender was attentive and helpful. She also let me sample wine before I purchased it! +

The Tuna carpaccio and roast tomato toast with bacon marmalade were amazingly full of flavor and fresh ingredients. The pork-chop and apple cranberry cobbler missed the mark for me but the sauce on the clams and honey cream cheese layer cake more then made up for it. They make all there cakes in house daily which is a another plus for me! ++

I would definitely go again and I look forward to trying Ben Thibodeaux's FQ restaurant Meauxbar.
Haven't been in years but i remember really liking their sushi! Great decor. Themed perfectly for a sushi restaurant. Fun place and great sushi!

Soooo I am confused. Is this the Korean Noodle House or the Cheltenham Seafood Noodle Shop? I went to the place in the picture (Korean Noodle House) at this address and it was really good. 

This is a tiny little place (small parking lot) and I lucked into a table almost right away. The place was packed and there was togo building up in the window. 

Good times were had as no one spoke English and the menu is only sporadically translated. As I said, they were just about full with 6 four tops and one large party to only one waitress so I had time to guesstimate a dish. Did I ever pick wisely! 

A mound of noodles and seafood in a "special brown sauce" hit the table with Kim Chee, an intense almost black sauce with a faint tobacco quality (but in a good way), and a few other sides. 

The place is pretty no frills, but for around $10 I got lunch, dinner, and lunch! Now if I could only figure out the name....

Go here now!  Get some bao!  That's really all you need to know!

More details?  Sure.

We went here for the first time with the International Supper Club - an ad-hoc group of Yelpers who enjoy trying cuisines from other countries.  

Bao are buns.  We had a discussion at the table about what makes them unique but we never got to the bottom of it.  I did a little research before sitting down to write this review and the answer is that it is a relatively standard dough that is steamed instead of baked.  When the restaurant griddles them lightly they pick up an even more unique combination of flavors and textures.

I ordered a couple of appetizers: dumplings and wings.  Both were quite good but the wings were the more unique of the two.  Think of wings that are coated in a bunch of less common ingredients like lemongrass and rice powder and you're on the right track.

I chose the three little bao for dinner and they came out on a small wooden cutting board.  The first one I grabbed turned out to be my favorite - it was stuffed with tempura-fried slices of tofu and yam then topped with a house-made sauce and a few leaves of cilantro.  Next up was the pork belly, followed by the waygu beef.  Odd as it seems, the first one remained my favorite by a long shot.  I also snagged a bite of the kids' char siu bao and they were something I could see myself ordering on a future visit.

My GAWD I miss Ted Drewes, I know this review is a couple of months late, but forgive me....

This Ted Drewes is still my preferred location over South Grand. South Grand is nice and was convenient to where I lived, but you just can't beat the one on Chippewa. You can't.

What do I love about Ted Drewes you ask? 

- I love their flavors. Granted you can only get vanilla custard, but who cares! It is so orgasmic good! 

- Though slightly pricey, you definitely get bang for your buck. Quality and enjoyment out of a cup of happiness. You couldn't ask for better.

- They offer amazing seasonal flavors. Just to name a few I am in love with -- apple pie, strawberry shortcake (mmmmmmmmm, or is that year round?), pumpkin pie, apple caramel, and the list is endless.

Hands down the best frozen custard in St. Louis... not to be confused or categorized as ice cream. 

I love you, Teddy! If only you had a location in Washington DC would my sugary goodness heart be fulfilled.

So we found this place on Bourbon St which was a nice surprise!  Great outdoor patio with live music.  The first time on a Friday afternoon, we grabbed 2 drinks and sat and listened to some great music!!  

Service is a little slow but your on vaca so nothing to lose.   We had great weather during our trip so that was nice!  Iced coffee and sweet tea was both refreshing. 

We enjoyed it so much, we came back on a Sunday morning.  Great music again and had beignets for breakfast with the cafe au lait.  Wish the beignets were warm but we did enjoyed them a little more than CafÃ© Du Monde.  It was a little lighter & fluffier.   

Definitely a clean, fun, music location.  

Note: no outside drinks allowed after 7pm.

Cajun Encounters runs like a well oiled machine. Not being one to follow the herd, I was a bit perturbed when I encountered a crammed parking lot and a line out the door. This time being the last in line worked in our favor. We had the smallest (and most hilarious) group and our tour guide was none other than Mr. June from the 2011 Baton Rouge Fire Department calendar. My 12 year old daughter suddenly found the stamina to beat the heat. 

During the tour, gators of all ages snacked on marshmallows and hot dogs. If it weren't for the stifling temperature ("We REALLY need a wind going through here," my daughter proclaimed.), I would have bet the price of admission that there would be a pirate sitting atop a cannon and swigging from a whiskey bottle. I'm still not convinced that Cajun Encounters didn't plant the Texas socialite with the six inch pouf on board our boat...the one who swore she was going to breastfeed Fluffy the baby gator.

Jennie M and I headed over to The Marc optimistic that they may be open on Remembrance Day... We wandered inside only to learn that they were not open for lunch.  But they were going to be open for dinner that night!

So, we headed elsewhere for lunch but ventured back later that night (post elite-event).  Our party had grown into to three and we called ahead to make sure they could accommodate us.  Luckily, the answer was yes!  We strolled in around 9pm and were greeted warmly by the staff.  

As I'd noted earlier, The Marc is one large open room, but it's tastefully decorated and has a cozy feeling to it.  The dinner menu is limited, but there's likely something for everyone on it...

We started out with some olives to munch on in addition to some fresh bread...
It did take awhile to order and get our food, but it was well worth the wait, and we weren't in a rush.  I had Manhattan Clam Chowder and a Caesar Salad and cleaned both my bowl and my plate!  I also did some damage to the side of frites we ordered for the table. My dining companions seemed to enjoy their meals as well... 

Needless to say, I think we were all pretty full after our meals, but our waitress talked us into sharing dessert - a chocolate turtle pie of sorts that was the perfect sweet ending to a wonderful day!  The Marc is definitely a dining experience to remember and visit again in the future.

It's very very bare-bone and low key with regards to ambiance and seating BUT the food is solid and portions are reasonable.  It's popular for takeout but the service is very friendly and attentive if you dine in, as well.

Some highlights:
1. Pumpkin curry with chicken: Solid red curry broth with tender pieces of sliced chicken breast and plenty of kombucha squash and a pepper and carrot medley.  This was tasty and the curry was great mixed with the rice.
2. Pas See Yew: Solid with plenty of fried egg (loved that!).  The seasoning was very good and flavorful without being overly salty.
3. Pad Thai: This version has a creamier sauce with a heap of ground peanuts on the side, topped with shredded cabbage and chopped scallions.  The noodles themselves are thinner than average, which made them a bit on the dry side.  The flavor was solid, though, and there was plenty of fried egg, which I loved.  That's actually my favorite part of any stir-fried noodle dish!
4. Pineapple fried rice with chicken: Decent with chunks of pineapple, cashews, and plenty of peas.  This has a stronger curry flavor than other versions but it was tasty and the raisins gave it a nice flavor twist.
5. Spicy house noodle; Wide rice noodles stir-fried in a red curry sauce.  This was very good and I loved the concept of sauteing noodles in a curry broth.  I'm definitely a noodle fan vs. rice and this was the perfect combination.

If you don't mind eating in a takeout-like setting and are just coming for solid food, then it's a good dinner option.  Otherwise, get the takeout.  It's not the most authentic Thai and not Asiana or Thai Orchid but the dishes are tasty and they are open until 10 pm everyday.

Although I don't know much about gaming, I stopped by this shop across Meridian from Circle Centre Mall to see what kind of games they had.  The shop is long and narrow with the displays of games up front by the check out counter and entrance.  The back half of the store is set up with lots of tables for groups of players to be able to enjoy their purchases.  I can't tell you if the arrangement of the tables is conducive to playing all types of games or not, but I'm sure the staff can help meet your needs.

I was also glad to see that they did carry some more "old fashioned" board games that are self contained and suitable for most levels of family to play.  They also had puzzles and a selection of Monopoly games that had unique themes I hadn't seen before.

Oh, and don't let the downtown location make you think you are paying too much.  I checked some pricing compared to that certain online giant that delivers to your home and this place was within 10% of the online giant.  I like supporting local businesses, so when I can, I buy from actual stores and save the online for things that I just can't find elsewhere.

Overall, I came away with a favorable impression of this store.

Review #1968

Ok, so my friends introduced me to this place and I hate that I know about it now because it's so good! I like that you can customize your order or choose something pre-made off of the menu. The ingredients taste fresh, for the most part - I have to point out that one time I got take out from here and the special sauce had gone bad but they still gave it to me... it's like who ever put it in the bag wasn't looking at it even though it was not the right color. The service is always great and despite it being a made-to-order place it's usually pretty quick! There is one other thing besides my bad take out experience that caused me to dock this place to three stars. Price... for what it is, a burger joint, it's expensive and, yes, I understand the concept of fresh ingredients but let's be real, you're overpriced. I could see myself coming back for a treat but when there are many other cheaper or healthier options in the neighborhood it's not at the top of my list.

I like this place.... Nothing mind-blowing going on with what's on the menu. But I like what's served and the atmosphere anyway. One of the things that caught my eye on the way in was an extremely nice bar. It gave me an idea of where I could possibly stop in for happy hour in the future. But since it was late, I took a seat inside the restaurant. Nicely decorated interior, and somewhat loud inside. But it was a nice crowd and festive type of environment. 
I never had the ribs with Jack Daniel's sauce. After ordering them, I realized that I'll be ordering something else next time. The ribs and sauce could use some tweeking. Not a deal breaker since there wasn't high expectations as far as the food goes. 
I'll be back because I like the atmosphere. I'll just keep my food ordering to a tapas type of minimum until I find something that I might eventually enjoy.

I LOVE Big Lots! 

Yeah, they have lots of cheap Asian junk, but you can also find BARGAINS GALORE on tools and household goods.

But what keeps me going back are the CLOSE-OUTS of brand-name or equivalent-to-brand-name-quality FOOD ITEMS.  If something doesn't sell well at major chain stores, the manufacturer still has to dump their warehouse full of stuff that the major chain stores don't want anymore. And that's where Big Lots comes in.  

Granted, there is often a reason why something doesn't sell at the big name chain stores and it ends up in a close-out store.  But sometimes the reason is not quality, it's just the taste of the average buyer.  And if you happen to be "odd" or a "discriminating consumer" (like me) and like something that the majority  doesn' t like (which happens all the time to those of us who really do have good taste, snort, snort,  :-), then you can sometimes find it at Big Lots for a GREAT PRICE!  OY VEY! SUCH A DEAL!

So here's my strategy: I shop the food aisles every week,  try a little of something I might like, and if I like it, go back the next time and buy a LOT of it, because when it's gone, it's gone.

The employees at this store are pretty helpful and friendly too. They'll help you look for something.

Are you a fan of Tuesday Morning?  If so, Big Lots is the lower-priced version of Tuesday Morning.  I've sometimes seen the same things on sale for cheaper at Big Lots.

Caveats:  #1:  Check the expiration date of all food items before you put them in your cart. They are notorious for having out-dated food. Most everything is fine, but every once in a while they have out-dated product.  #2:  The store is not the cleanest.  #3: This ain't Carmel, and not even Glendale.  Think PeopleOfWalmart.com 

Note: I do not work at Big Lots, never have, and do not own stock in them. I just luuuuuuuuuuuuuv saving money!

"What kinda cheese?" I need to know that first!"

Maybe snotty service is their schtick. If it's not, it's a good thing that they have good food to help make up for the ray of sunshine we encountered on our visit.

We popped into Sonny's for a late lunch, the two meat eaters in the group wanting to compare it to Tommy DiNic's. My friend went first, she followed the sign* ordering a beef with onions and was just about to get to the Whiz when the lady barked that she was doing it wrong. When it was my turn, I ordered a grilled cheese and was met with a sneer telling me it would take 10 minutes and asking if I still wanted it. Yes, yes I did. I got a disgusted look when she clearly didn't approve of my american and bleu cheese combo.

My friends quite enjoyed their cheeseteaks. Not as much as Tommy DiNic's, but better than Campo's. My grilled cheese was good, although the thick broche bread was a little stiff after the sandwich press. Still a decent showing for a place specializing in beef. We also got fries, I would file these under skippable; very thin, they reminded me of McDonald's fries.

Would I go back? Depends. On my own, no. With some cheesesteak seekers, yes. I'd probably would give this place a 3.5 or 4, if it weren't for the assholery that we encountered.

* In case you're wondering, here's how they ask you to order:
http://goo.gl/0pTZzr

It was the one snowy/rainy eve this season. The wife, yes we got married about a month and 5 days ago, found herself with a migraine, incapacitated on the couch. Clearly she was in no mood to create something delicious, and we both needed to eat. So what were we to do?

Option 1 was to unleash me on the kitchen to cook...which would have resulted in a mountain of dirty dishes that would certainly  survived for at least a few days. NOPE!

Option 2 was to dine on something delivered...which sounds great in theory until you realize Reno is really remiss in this regard. GUESS NOT!

Option 3 was easily the least desirable decision we could make...which I was not so willing to welcome. See, since the food wouldn't come to us, I had to fetch the food. Worse than that, we couldn't come to a consensus on what we wanted when we did finally decide to do the deed! 

And then, out of nowhere, one of us suggested Indian, and all at once the world was one again. It was the answer to all our desires, the only thing strong enough to motivate even me to leave my perch on the couch to brave the roads, to retrieve dinner for us.

We ordered our food through the Yelp app! Rich and creamy Saag Paneer, rich, velvety sweet and savory chicken korma, and an eggplant dish, all ordered hot and spicy, along with garlic naan and  onion kulcha, rice, chutneys, and naturally two mango lassis were bagged up and ready to go when I arrived. It was so easy! You can pay with a credit card before picking your food up, which made it super fast too!

I returned home and was instantly a hero! My skills as a great husband were spread far and wide across the internets and, for an instant, I was famous!

So for this update I'm going to up it a star because of the seamless process, absolutely delicious food, and friendly service, and for making me worthy of worship!!' 

Thanks India Kabab!

This is the best Indian in town!

Walk to the back of the narrow Erin Rose Bar and you'll find a small room hidden in the back. On the left is a small counter and an even smaller menu. But it's quality not quantity here.

We tried the BEER BRAISED BEEF DEBRIS PO BOY, which was juicy and will prepared. The bread had a satisfying crunch but was not dry.

This is a great late night stop if you're in the area. Just don't expect to sit down and eat your food... There are a couple of small counters and one table, so you may not be able to get a seat.

Actually, it's probably worth it just to use the bathroom. It's in the Erin Rose and is the smallest bathroom I've ever used. If you accidentally pee on the floor it will run straight to the bar.

Annabella was our server she was great or should I say excellent, she changed my experience from when we walked in the door and having to wait with no crowd and about 6 open booths.

She was very attentive and paid attention to even when the drinks were low.

Over all she mad the experience great, it was not crowded being it was a Wednesday night. 

Over all the food came very fast and everything went up from there.

Rockfire Grill rocks everything out with their artisan flat breads. Everything is well flavored and balanced that you can't go wrong with what you order. Seriously, I've had the burger, the pizza, the flat bread, and haven't once left unsatisfied.

The owners are also very carrying in greeting customers and getting feedback.

The battle for supremecy in the "Best Cheesesteak" in Philly is and has been an ongoing battle. Everyone has their favorite, their "ole reliable" for that "go to" spot. A fierce compititon to be number 1 and I am more than willing to accept this kind of challange.  A 1200 plus calorie induced challange types of deliciousness, and Sonny's you have made my top 3!

Holy goodness as I entered Sonny's , I was greeted with an inviting aroma of angus and ribeye on the grill doing its thing.(Angus for the burgers, Ribeye for the steaks) We all know that hum of meat being cooked, that sizzle that just makes you do a little shimmy. Best part about Sonny's they always start off with a clean slate. Meaning once one steak is made they clean it off and start with the next one.  They don't keep a heaping mound of meat on the grill like other places do.  From what I have seen at least , that my friends of Yelp makes for a great feast to be had.

So what does Nando go with? The options they offer , the combinations of a mouthwatering taste buds going into shock kind of pleasures. I decided to go with Sonny's  Bacon (Apple wood is used) cheesesteak with American cheese, compliment it with wiz and fried onions for the win. Basically a Wiz and American Wit if you want to know the lingo, without looking like a tourist. (That was for you out of town noobs) 

I place my order and already I start to do the happy dance ! (my inner self was feeling the flow)  I get my masterpiece as I give the all knowing "nod" to the man wheeling that spatula. I must say before I get this they lightly toasted my roll and dressed the bottom of the roll with Wiz. After that they then added the goods with a layer of good ole Americana on top sealing everything in. A blanket you might say to keep it snug with the meat cut just right . It wasn't chopped up into little bits and it wasn't slices laying in there. It was just right, and we should all know what just right is

 I take my first bite , the juices from the meat and cheese mixed with that  Apple wood smoked bacon was amazing. The meat , not a single dry section, a great flavorful rush to it.  The way the Wiz and American held everything  in with the onions mixed all in there , this bad boy was phenomenal ! I didn't need ketchup , I wanted to enjoy all the flavors this had to offer. 

So as I am in a "Nom nom " mode , my taste buds were getting a well deserved treat I am looking around this fine establishment. A nice old school dÃ©cor to Sonny's showing pictures along the wall of how they did things back in the day. Great spot with plenty of seating in the back and along the wall. Clean with a great crew working their magic , with that said these guys are also open till 3 am. So get in there and get involved in something you'll be sure to come back again and again.  

Review over, go there now! Immediately , stop reading and GO !

Once again I have no clue why I am writing a review for a chain restaurant because not much varies unless the management is really terrible or really awesome. Well in this case, it's really awesome. Or at least above average. I've been here about 2-3 times total mostly after hitting up Gateway Convention Center and I've had a pretty good time every single visit. Those cheddar biscuits might not be exactly the same as Red Lobster but at least they're lower in calories! (80 cal per biscuit.) The lobster tails are really good too and I like that you can order just one if that's all your feeling. Their drink menu is really what hit home for me...lots of different drink options plus "skinny" cocktail options. (God, I hate that term, "skinny"...what if you're limiting your calories because of a health reason, not because you want to be skinny? LOL.) But yeah they also have many non alcoholic drink options like the delicious strawberry lemonade with fizz.
Also I will mention while food generally comes out fast here, there have been one or two times when it did take a little while longer so don't come here if you're in a hurry, or if you are, call ahead and get it to go!

Another one of my "good eats" tourist pitstops for several reasons:

1) it's centrally located on St Peter's.  Let's face it, you're a tourist, you're going to be hitting up the French Quarter and it's right there!  Give your tired feet a rest and come in and grab lunch!

2) No matter how busy they are, you will be seated within 10 minutes.  It's like magic.  Really.

3) The restaurant itself is cute, mildly romantic (without being saccrine or precious), and the service is generally great.

4) The food isn't going to get any Michelin stars, but it's solid, basic, traditional Creole cuisine...and that's why you're visiting NOLA right?  To sample the Creole and Cajun cuisines!

5) The Whiskey Bread Pudding.  I lied in #3...they MAY get a Michelin star for this.  I absolutely dislike sweets...and I want to make sweet sweet love to this dish.  My husband looooves sweets, and he wants to make sweet sweet love to this dish.

Now a few key things -

Have a bloody mary with your meal!  They make faaaaaabulous bloody marys here!  It doesn't matter that it's only 11am...you're in NOLA.  It's OK to drink before 5 :)

If you are a tourist, please try to be "adventurous" and put yourself in your server's hands.  Unless you have an honest to god food allergy (and a REAL allergy, not a fake allergy where it really is that you don't want to try something different), don't quiz the poor server for 30 minutes asking what all the ingredients in each dish is.

If the weather permits, ask to get a table in the courtyard (it's really pretty), or barring that, get a window seat and people watch!

Personally, I looove the gumbos here (hey it's called Gumbo Shop for a reason!), but my husband is a fan of their etouffees.  Either way, the food is solidly good and very reasonable price wise!

Be nice to your server.  Everytime I've come (and I've come every time I visit NOLA - too numerous to count), I've had great service.  The servers have always been attentive and prompt (even when they are clearly overworked and tired), just be nice and you'll have a great time with great recommends (and on occasion, a few free refills on those delicious bloody marys)!

And definitely have the bread pudding!  It's really amazing!

I LOVED this place. 

I visited Nashville just over a week ago and wish I could get back sooner than is likely to happen because I am still dreaming of their fish sandwich.

I am a seafood aficionado. I have eaten quite a few fried fish sandwiches in my day and this was the absolute best I've ever had! It wasn't very hot (spicy) and I don't care if it's not authentic a la "hot chicken." This fillet was amazingly crispy on the outside, flaky and moist on the inside. It was a sizable piece of fish--the fish itself was clearly the star of the show: the balance of flavors considering the sauces and accoutrements was spot-on. I hate when the bun overshadows the fish due to proportions of the components, but this was not even close to being an issue at The Hook. I also take issue with a fish sandwich that deteriorates and gets mushy--NOT a problem at The Hook! The breading remained crispy and intact until it had been completely demolished.

We tried the Po Mi as well and while interesting and tasty, it isn't something I'd come back for. Chips and fries are top notch though, and I'd also order the slushy Pimms over and over.

Loved the ambience. Loved the cocktails. Loved the fried fish.

The pizza better be good here. I didn't have any but will be back to try it due to the positive reviews. 

But this place is gross. And the wait staff was curt and rude. I know, sometimes that can be charming in a Carla from Cheers kind of way. But it wasn't like that. The drinks were fine, and the games were fun, but when I do get Black Thorn, I will get takeout.

I guess this place is great if you are a typical penn kid who never eats in the dining hall or ramen in the dorm. 

I was up near Penn and excited that chipotle had opened up shop, but I will stick to el fuego.

Delicious! Very tasty Caribbean food. The ox meat is ridiculously tender, juicy, and delicious. They close a little early, so don't plan to go if after 7 or else you'll feel rushed. The staff is really nice and courteous. Tables have white table clothes and it's beautifully decorated. Only beer and wine is sold. However they do have liquor flavored wine. Weird but delicious! They sell tequila, vodka, and rum flavored wine shots. Never had those before but they are great! It's in the back of the Walgreens on Platt. If their location was closer to SoHo, this place would be packed every night!

Somehow we ended up going for custard while it was 29Â°F outside, which is probably not the optimal time to visit an outdoor frozen dessert stand.  But it was worth it to introduce a newbie to Ted Drewes and the world of midwestern custard.

I always try to find out what foods/restaurants are special to locals in an area, and my MO friends swear by Ted Drewes.  So when a new colleague came with us on a business trip and said she didn't know the difference between ice cream and custard... we knew what needed to be done.

There's something about their custard that is the right combination of rich and creamy and flavorful.  I'm a sucker for a concrete (let's face it, plain custard is pretty boring), and they've got so many flavors to choose from!  It's all vanilla custard, but you barely notice once it's been mixed up with all sorts of toppings.  This time I got the Dutchman, because I love pecans and butterscotch.  It was soooo good, I almost forgot I was freezing (almost).

A few things keep me from giving them the last star.  One: I really wish they also had chocolate.  I'm a chocoholic and some concretes would just be better with chocolate as the base.  Two:  I know the walk-up model is popular and classic, but I'd love more places to keep warm if they're going to serve custard in sub-freezing temps.  Three:  the smallest size concrete is still a lot of custard.  I'm not a cheapskate, I just don't want to eat an entire meal of custard.  Calling a size "micro" that's still like 12oz is laughable.  I threw out half of it and would rather have just not wasted that food.  

The lines move fast, and they've got lots of menus and signs posted so you can think about what you're going to order in advance.  They make everything pretty fast, too.

Very mediocre experience. Our server was friendly but no one came to our table for quite some time. As usual I go at off times because I don't like waiting for a table or waiting for food. Husband ordered ghost burger w fries I got cowboy ranch burger w salad. My salad was sizable but they short portioned his fries. He barely got any. When he Re-ordered a 2nd helping he barely got any the 2nd time and although the restaurant was 80% empty it took forever to get a refill on fries.

Red Robin is falling out favor w me. Not sure I'll be going back.

Amerigo Italian Restaurant in Midtown is a casual dining experience with a comfortable and nice ambiance. They have a few locations in Tennessee and a couple in Mississippi as well although this is the only location I have visited. 

I've been here twice and both experiences have been good. Most recently I came here for a work lunch so they put us in a private room since there were so many of us. I'm always sympathetic for servers which have to take care of a large group but I think that our servers did a great job. They were quick to take our drink orders and get us situated. 

Through my workplace they had arranged for each one of us to pick a salad, entree and dessert. I got a Cesar salad, the chicken acuto and the pecan butter crunch cake. I enjoyed everything that I ordered. If I had to pick a favorite it might be the pecan butter crunch cake. If you are going to get a dessert get this one! It is sinfully rich and decadent and almost tastes like a cheesecake. The Cesar salad didn't have an overwhelming amount of dressing like some places do which I was happy about and the croutons were tasty. The chicken acuto was actually a perfect serving of a grilled chicken breast with a side of black bean salsa and spicy olive oil. It's served with a grilled artichoke and green beans. Everything on the plate was delicious and other people at my table who ordered it agreed that it was a great dish. Most other people at my table got the lasagna which seemed to be a crowd pleaser as well. 

Overall I enjoy Amerigo and have had good meals and service here. It is a perfect place for us to go for work functions so I always look forward to us coming here.

We came here 5 years ago and actually didn't go inside cause the outside was a little iffy.  Tonight we went in because we got a take out/delivery menu at home and liked the looks of it so we thought we'd try going in person first.  We ordered a salad, a soup and four sushi rolls for dinner.  Two of the rolls were labeled as 'special' but they were rather uninspired compared to other sushi we've had in the area (and around the world).  

The decor was kind of boring, and the restaurant was empty for a Friday night (just us an one other couple).  

I asked for tea but the food arrived before I asked again and they brought us lukewarm tea.  As for the regular sushi rolls, we had a spicy tuna with no spice and another roll that was a bit bland.

Overall I think it's great to have a place that will deliver sushi to us when we don't want to go out, but if we're going out I think we'll stick to another place in town with a bit more creativity, ambiance and customers.

I got 2 bowls, $14.85, left a tip for a flat $20 fee.  The Brazilian and the Sedona bowl I think, one of which was full of granola and fruit, the other Acai and fruit with barely any granola.  I got there at 9pm, they close at ten so I don't get the trash service.  It's like they only blended enough for one bowl and then just said fck it.  They didn't even make it look appealing!  I called and Caleb the manager who was standing right there when the order was taken and made took my name down so I can get a free bowl if I return but I won't be because it didn't even taste good.

First time visiting this store,.

I've never really shopped at Save Mart, only a few times in Galt, Ca.

I guess because it was a competitor to the kids dad's family store in town.

I was really impressed how organized and  how clean it was.

I like how the isles are semi big, and it wasn't crowded.

If I ever need anything, I will stop here  when in the area.

A plus that I found my multicolored tortilla chips!!!

So I'll give it to them that the chicken is indeed hot.  I got the hottest level chicken strips, which were followed by a 5-minute panic attack before the heat subsided.

Unfortunately, I don't think they fried the chicken fresh.  Maybe they just reheated it, because it came out suspiciously fast and was soggy, even though we ate it immediately.  Also, they were extremely stingy on the sauce, and they charged $3 for "bottled water" that was actually just tap water in a disposable cup. 

I would go back if I were dying for something spicy, because I just don't know where else I could go in this town.

The newly opened Driftlight Lounge Bar & Restaurant is on the 1st floor of the JW Marriott Water Street Resort in Downtown Tampa. The Driftlight Lounge Bar is in the lobby of the JW while the Driftlight Restaurant is in an adjacent large room. Currently, the Driftlight Restaurant is only open for breakfast or brunch from 5am to 11am and remains closed for the rest of the day. Both Driftlight venues offer upscale elegant decor with modern lighting and high ceilings. Both Driftlight venues have large glass floor to ceiling windows which offer a nice view of the sunset, the park, the convention center, the Marriot Water Street, the Sail Pavilion, and tons of tropical palm trees. Driftlight serves food and drinks on the 1st floor outdoor patio as well to guests seeking fresh air. 

The Driftlight Lounge Bar serves small plates of bar bites for lunch and dinner and a full array of cocktails in the lobby area of the JW Marriott. For a greater variety, staff recommends visiting The Six Bistro & Rooftop Bar on the 6th floor of the JW Marriott Resort. The Driftlight Lounge Bar serves jumbo shrimp cocktail, house chips & dip, deviled eggs, ham gruyere hush puppies, rosemary sea salt fries, Joyce Farms Organic chicken wings, Grouper tacos, 4 types of salad with 3 types of protein, salsaccia pizza, fig & goat pizza, margarita pizza, pastrami sandwiches, blackened Grouper sandwiches, and burgers. 

The Not Ya Colada Cocktail came with Bacardi Cuatro, brown butter washed Maison, Rouge vsop, pineapple, lime, & coconut milk. 10/10 

The Seis Cocktail came with Corazon Reposado, Vida Mezcal, Champagne vinegar, prickly pear, Habanero foam. 9/10 

The Winter Spiced Old Fashion cocktail came with High West double rye, spiced brown sugar, simple syrup, angostura, trinity bitters. 8/10 

The Irish Goodbye cocktail came with cold brew coffee, Jameson Cold Brew, Montenegro Amaro, Oat milk, & coconut cream. 9/10 

Our server was very friendly and knowledgeable in helping explain items on the menu. It only took a minute to get a hello after sitting at the bar and we got our drinks in less than 5 minutes. The bar had only about 6 patrons at the time and there were 2 bartenders. I look forward to coming back again soon to try more off the menu!

Their cheeseburgers are good, could be thicker,  big selection of frozen treats(custards,ice creams,shakes,etc..) service is friendly, you are not waiting for your food. they don't accept c/c they have an atm and you gotta pay to use it.

All three of the Ritz's are awesome. I love this one especially because of the old school brick street and its choice Olde City location. 

The Ritzes are the only place to see great indie films in the city. My only qualm is that there isn't one around Market East. That would be a great way to kill some time there.

3 1/2 rating but ultimately bumped it up to 4 stars because of their Au Lait and they have a good sized menu for breakfast (served all day) and lunch options.

Cafe Beignet will always have a special place in my heart. This was the very first thing we ate right after we landed in the wonderful city of NOLA.

Located right in the heart of Bourbon St and Bienville St, semi tucked away behind Musical Legends Park, came here for a late lunch. I order the Jambalaya and boyfriend ordered the Shrimp Bo'Boy sandwich. 

Whoever said the jambalaya portion was small must have a big appetite. The bowl was filled with never ending portions of Andouille sausages, chicken and rice. Poured some hot sauce in and it was a simple, yet great lunch! Portion is enough for two females to share. 
Boyfriend's shrimp bo'boy left a lot to be desired though. Bare minimum of shrimp....that was disappointing. He did like the horseradish sauce and his baguette was warm and soft.

The iced vanilla Au Lait was DELICIOUS!!!!!!! Great flavor and perfect amount of caffeine. Wish we had the chance to come back again, but only being here for a few days, I wanted to try as much restaurants and different local coffee shops as much as possible.

A must visit if you're in New Orleans. 

We came here dinner on NYE and were so delighted with our experience. They have so many options and my veg friends were also pleased with the options.

We ordered the alligator sausage appetizer which came with a jam like sauce. Both were scrumptious! For the entree I ordered the catfish and shrimp creole with garlic mashed potatoes. Ugh wishing we had eaten here for every meal.

I used Legendary Tours on my recent visit to New Orleans to go to the Whitney Plantation. The tour was easily booked in advance on their website and great customer service was provided after booking. A couple of days after purchase one of the representatives called to to let us know that our tour day would be free admission and self guided tours. They would still provide the transportation if we were open to the self guided tour and would refund the entry fee which was issued promptly. 

The bus was clean and comfortable and the driver was on time for pickup and very knowledgeable.

I was happy to support this local Black owned business and highly recommend them for your tour consideration.

So this place is a solid real deal chicken place. I had the Tweener which is kinda spicy white meat. The chicken is so moist that it just falls right off. The heat was just right. The kale salad is delicious. The mashed potatoes were alright I just got full. 

We both got a beer and they did not fill them up all the way so when the foam settled it was a disappointment. 

Other than that come here eat!  I am going for the chicken and waffles next time.

One of the many virtues of the Mandarin Garden is its full bar that offers a few beers from Asia and a bartender with a willingness to make old school cocktails, like the Mai Tai.   After a long work day, cocktail in a tiki glass (with a parasol and maraschino cherry) is hard to beat! 

The service here is quick, efficient and attentive.   No matter how many times we have visited (scores), we are always charmed by the apparent custom of having a waitperson who immediately greets a diner at his/her table.   The greeting is promptly followed by water and tea service.   No request required.

The food is consistently good quality.  Mandarin's wonton soup always is a crowd-pleaser.  The broth is light, full of chicken flavor and not over-salted.   All of the chicken dishes in white sauces (Moo Goo Gai Pan, chicken with mango, etc) and the moo-shoo are excellent.  My husband has been equally thrilled with pepper steak, General Tso's Chicken and the sizzling dishes.

I have to get back to the gym this week. It has been a month of over indulgence and fattening food. With that being said, cold stone is pretty good. :) Docking a star due to value. Docking a star due to taste. Again. Pretty good. Definitely not excellent, but sweet enough for me to recognize that I need some gym time in my life.

This place really impressed me! The food and service was great!  Located inside the Intercontinental Hotel. Our server name was Kevin. 
You order your menu by courses. They had four courses. Now you don't have to order all four courses. You can pick and choose and also share. The five stars is for the taste and Quality of the food. Just keep in mind it is a little on the pricey side but the menu is very impressive and the food and service speaks for itself. I enjoyed everything and would not hesitate to return.
Holy smokes- the grilled oysters totally live up to the hype. Everything else was sub par. But the grilled oysters!!!

OK, the hype about having Hatch chili in your burger is overrated. It's OK. I do like the kick. But it's an average burger. Good bun. Good fries. I rather go to In-N-Out or Freddy's. But you try it and see if it is your cup of tea.

5* = A top favorite. Mind-blowing good. I will definitely return and I will go out of my way to go here. Worth every dime of my money.

4* = Outstanding. Tucson-top-tier. Some elements not quite as good as it gets, but it still is worthy of my regular business.

3* = Good experience. I might do repeat business if it is convenient, the only option, the only one in its category, or on a whim, but would not be among the first thing to come to mind. Would definitely recommend you trying it to get your own take on it.

2* = Not so good. Would not recommend at all. Waste of money.

1* = How are they still in business? Stay away at all costs!

We didn't know there was a TBBC location in Westchase/Oldsmar, but our friends suggested we meet here and I pulled it up on Google maps. It is right off Tampa Rd. on Racetrack Rd. across from the flea market. It has a Westchase address but to me it is more Oldsmar.

It was pretty busy at 7pm on a Saturday night so we opted to sit outside instead of wait 45 min for a table. It was hot, but at least we had shade so we didn't mind.

I've eaten at the location in Ybor before so I am familiar with their menu. My husband and I split an order of wings, our friends split some fish spread and then for dinner I ordered the salad with ahi tuna, my husband ordered more wings, and our friends ordered the ahi tuna and the burger with the fried egg on it. Everyone's food was very good. For beers, I had their seasonal cucumber lime, one friend had the chocolate/oatmeal stout and the other had the hefeweizen.

This is a great place for beer lovers in upper Tampa Bay. I think we will be meeting up at this place more often.

We had a great time here.  We were in Indian River Beach for several days and tried several local places with some success and some less-than-successful experiences.

This was a success.  We ate out on the front porch which had plenty of room for social distancing.  Like many places just before Omicron started getting crazy again... most people had completely disregarded COVID protocols again.  IRB was no exception.  "COVID? What's that?" was the motto of our days in IRB.  We were quite often the only people other than UberEATS and DoorDash drivers to be wearing them.

That didn't stop us!  We enjoy eating alfresco and TJ's was very much prepared for that.  They have a great porch.

There bread was fresh & delicious.  The salads were well made and not just some iceberg with carrots on top.  I had chicken fettuccine Alfredo and  my wife had chicken parm.  I'll say mine had a bit too much sauce on the sauce to noodles ratio, but that was easily fixed with my spoon.

We had extremely good service and had a very nice dinner.

2 stars? o god here we go. Yup. its because of the service. The service left a very bad taste in myself and my friends mouth. First off, they ran out of a few things while we were there. At first, there was only 1 person serving everyone. when we entered there was only 1 table, and as we were there maybe another 2 or 3 tables came. id like to state we only ordered water and juice to drink, along with an app each. as we were waiting awhile for our drinks, the 2 new tables came. lets just say after 45 mins of waiting, the 2 new tables received their food..and then a 3rd starting getting their food. something was up and i didnt get it. our original server seemed to be ignoring us and not giving me any eye contact. I know i can be a bitch, but even my friend who is way more passive than me noticed the odd behavior. 

eventually a new server entered the game, i brought up our issues to him. he was confused about what we ordered. we ordered crawfish rangoons and buns. everyone elses table fulled entrees came out. well he eventually had to put our orders in, it seemed the first server never did.

back to the drinks, i ordered a drink and it was supposed to be housemade ginger soda. my first thought upon dirnking it was, wow this tastes like straight up lime! the second server asked me if i wanted another, then told me that they dont have ginger soda today, he offered a lime soda... said ahh thats why she gave me a random drink. i assumed she didnt even ask just gave it to me. he defended the original server and said, no the ginger beer has lime it it. im not crazy, i know my first drink was some type of lime soda..it just didnt have lime in it  - it was lime! anyway i didnt get the 2nd drink. the 2nd server probably heard me and my friend talking shit to eachother, he came over to us and apologized for the mix ups with the ordering process and thanked us for being patient. kudos to him. i appreciated that. there really seemed to be something up the first servers ass, not gonna lie, she seemed to be miserable and had an attitude. i think it was clear me and my friend were unhappy and i guess she eventually didnt wanna deal with us. 

maybe we came on an off day, but it was odd...rude..and very confusing as to why all of this went down. 

so onto the good...

the place smelled amazing! these chefs know what theyre doing! you can see the kitchen and check out the spices and seasonings they use! my crawfish rangoon were amazing! i highly suggest getting them. to be honest, they dont need the amount of sauce it came with. my friends buns were to die for also.

Another great review.  Loved it.  Very subtle flavors, more sophisticated spice profile than the run-of-the-mill North Indian restaurants in the Northeast.

Owners are very pleasant, and they are happy to accommodate even vegan requests.

I had chana saag sans oil or cream at a high spice level, which was absolutely delicious.  

The roti and naan were good, as was the basmati rice, which had some saffron rice, as well.

The chicken tandoori was extremely tender, and juicy.  You could really taste the yogurt, for once.

Palak paneer, I was told by my DP, was very good, although I did not try it.  I did not see the cubes of cheese, and cannot vouch whether or not they make it in house.  That'd be sweet if they did.

Pappadam was crisp and seedy, for lack of a better descriptor!

Another positive point was that they had our take-out order ready within 20 minutes, which is very fast.  They even do delivery, although we did not try that.

The only downside, and this is probably a function of their newness, is that the restaurant still has glimmers of the faux Mexican faire that used to occupy that same spot.  Garish yellows and turquoise tiles probably need to be removed.

Good, reasonably priced food, although you should be prepared for a bit of a wait.  Everything is prepared fresh, so you might be waiting 15 minutes or more for a chicken parm sandwich, depending on how busy they are.  Just grab a seat nearby & wait for your number to be called & then enjoy (until you notice that the city of Philadelphia has put a surcharge on fountain drinks).

Located in the rear part of Erin Rose bar, it a hidden gem for poboys.

Reading several of my fellow Yelp reviews, decided to go with the Dark & Stormy pork belly poboy.  It did not disappoint!  The pork belly was tender and glazed with an Asian sweet sauce.

Like others have mentioned, it's smaller than most poboys, but hey, I'll sacrifice a couple inches for taste any day.

Since it's located within a bar, looks to be 21+ only.  So kids will need to wait outside.

Very nice old school vibe with excellent service by Milton. We came in at the end of the evening just for bananas foster, bread pudding and milk punch. They put a table together for us in the lounge and milton gave us the quintessential experience with all of the history of the restaurant, the Brennan's and their other endeavors. Milton was awesome and the milk punch and desserts were to die for... Made table side!!

Simple execution of the highest quality ingredients seamlessly blended with outstanding craftsmanship behind the bar and live jazz.

We were seated right on time and greeted with a smile by our server who provided a quick overview of the menu and a gentle reminder that we should pace our food selections. We settled in to our seats to enjoy the music and awesome vibe the space offers.

Food highlights were the scallops, the pork belly and the fresh gulf fish crudo with honorable mention for the meat and cheese charcuterie (the roasted red onion was awesome). The winner libation of the night was The Flying Squirrel (served up), the layering of favors was delicious!!

Three Muses was everything we hoped for and more, bravo! Making reservations is highly recommended.

Cheers!

Nice, clean, and courteous.  Plus, I used the new mobile app for the first time with this store and it worked great.  It's down the road from Nashville International Airport, and around a lot of hotels.  Oh Yeah, the baked goods are dangerous.

A very large variety of ice cream, cones and a mixture of tasty treats. The guy behind the counter was very helpful and answered any question that I had for him.

You can't go wrong with any flavor combination. My only complaint is that it is cash only. Besides that its a great place to cool of and relax with made on the premise ice cream.

Also take a gander at the walls, there is a lot of local flavor here and I dont' just mean the ice cream. What is also neat is you can look through the window in the back and watch the ice cream chef in action. 

This place is a real treat in more ways than one!

I've been to New Orleans many times and it took approximately six years to finally try the food here.  It was recommended to me by a few people and decided to give it a try on my next visit. 

It smells so good coming in! That buttery, garlicky, smoky seafood awesome smell! This restaurant is located at the waterfront Hilton at the edge of the French quarter and business district. The restaurant itself is a lot larger than I would expect as it occupies almost the entire floor it's located on. There is a maze of seating everywhere! Now I can see why they didn't require reservations. We had the shrimp and grits and the charbroiled oysters which were amazing. 

They have a relatively efficient wait-staff system, so the wait is not too long. They have probably gotten their flow of work mastered after being around for a few years. Our waiter was very helpful and friendly with us. Now that I have finally eaten here, I can definitely recommend this place to others. It's worth a stop by if you love seafood.

This review is for the Thursday late night happy hour only. Dollar drinks are the titz. If you get there early, you can get a nice table for your group- otherwise, you are standing and getting bumped into. The wait for drinks get -1 star, but its understandable, I know I am not the only one who likes dollar drinks and therefore I must share.

My friend and I were visiting New Orleans and really wanted to try some gumbo. We stumbled upon this shop and have not looked back. The gumbo is delicious and hearty, we both had the chicken gumbo and the seafood gumbo! The service was amazing !

If I could give this place negative stars I would. My friends and I have the most horrendous experience here. After searching high and low for a good brunch place to end my trip to NOLA to see my friends, we found this place. It was close by and had good prices. We called to make a reservation for 10:30 am. Upon arriving we were asked to wait while they cleared our table, 45 min later we asked what the problem was since other tables without reservations were getting seated, the girl looked blankly at me and said "oh you had a reservatio?" noooooo, we just said that for giggles. Another 15 min later we were given a table. 

We ordered a round of mimosas while we looked the menu over. After asking for our waitress a few times, she finally came over and took our orders. My friends had the eggs benedict, while I had the waffle with egg whites and turkey bacon. Our food got to the table COLD. Its disgusting, who likes cold eggs and waffles? We kindly asked the waitress if she could take it back to at least be put in a microwave and she gave us attitude saying "we're packed, but ill see" 

The cook then came out to speak to us, he apologized and we said we understood they were slammed we just want hot food. He took back our food and gave us all papers to fill out to send us gift certificates which we found nice. That was until the manager, also his wife came and gave us an earful. Last time I checked, its not my fault your food is cold and you can't handle the crowd. We stayed to enjoy our mimosas when they sat a table of guys next to us who began talking to us. The manager comes over and tells us to STOP SOCIALIZING AND FINISH BC THEY NEED THE TABLE! I hav never been so mad and disrespected at a restaurant. Needless to say, I said a few choice words and left. 

If you want a good dining experience and food go somewhere else. This place sucks.

I have been wanting to come here for awhile. When my daughter said she wanted pizza and wings, I knew where to go.
Located on Neil rd, off peckham, this little pizza place is a diamond in the rough.
Parking was not an issue, they have there own parking lot.
There are quite a few tables inside, both picnic benches and booths.
They have quite a few special combos to choose from, we chose number two. A medium two topping pizza and a pound of wings.
The pizza was good. We ordered sausage and pepperoni. Both my daughter and I agreed it could have been cooked just a bit longer to brown up the crust and bottom. 
The wings were delicious. Cooked just right , moist not dry, and not oily.
The sauce was delicious, we ordered mild. Next time we will order medium, because mild has no kick.
Definitely will be back.

My husband loves Boston Market. Me lately not so much until I came to this one. The set up is nice and wide open, very clean, and the service and everything there is exceptionally friendly. My food was great had the 1/2 chicken with sweet potatoes and squash casserole with corn bread. So tasty and so quick. I really like this place even more again, and will be coming more.

When did Walmart groceries become the most popular activity on a Sunday morning?? BOTH self checkout lines nearly meet at the center of the store.
