There are several cashiers on duty but their lines are all filled with full carts 7 to 10 deep! How long can Walmart survive half empty shelves and 30 minute checkouts? Gave me time to write this  review!!??!!??!! I feel like we can do better. It will take longer to check out than it took to fill the cart

I'm so sick of watching Sonic commercials In Hawaii and not being able to try their food, so when I visited my uncle in Delanco I definitely wanted to stop by. It was snowy and icy outside so it was nice that we didn't have to get out of the car. I ordered a Chicago dog meal with tots and a cherry vanilla coke. The dog was pretty good, perfect amount of condiments and I enjoyed the coke...subtle hints of flavors. The tots were too salty and I passed them to my hubby. Took a bite of his burger and it was pretty standard...not mind blowing or anything. I also got a butterfinger chocolate freeze (milkshake like thing) it was yummy but it seemed like they skimped on the butterfinger mix in. Can't say I'll be back (since I live in Hawaii) but my curiosity has been satiated.

Capdeville, you are working it. 

I promised I'd be back to give things another shot. I have a better idea of what the Capdeville concept is now, too: a laid-back pub-style place with a slamming kitchen and minimal table service. I think the point is to stretch out and relax instead of trying to wham, bam, thank you ma'am. 

Since my last visit, the kitchen is even more on-point. They were putting out dish after dish of fantastic looking food in a very reasonable amount of time. Everything I saw come out looked like it must enter my mouth NOW, even though it wasn't mine. I feel like the chef and his staff have really settled into their menu and know how to play. Of note is the artichoke bruschetta, which is always good. It's a little bit different from the rest of the city, with cubes of artichoke heart and shaved parmesan...but it works so well. 

The noise level is still really out of control, but that's what happens when you have WOOD CEILINGS and drunk people. I have accepted that it will never change. (But really, some thick drapes on the windows would be so sexy, Capdeville! Get your girlfriend to arrange them artfully and admire how plush your space looks. Mmmmrawr!)

My main beef and the only reason this review crept up one star instead of two is the staffing complaint. No, it wasn't White Linen Night this time. It was Thursday. Our server took frequent smoke/sex/something breaks so we sat and sat and sat before we were greeted. Then we sat and sat and sat between courses. Then our food sat and sat and sat in the window. (This is the downside of making the transfer point visible.) Part of the problem was our server (who was clearly a magician); the other part seemed to be very rigid roles. The other server on the floor was rushed off his poor, hip little feet the entire night so he couldn't jump in...but the bartender spent a lot of time crossing his arms and looking moody. We were seated in the bar area so it would have been mighty convenient for the bartender to drop our food off instead of perfecting his perfect moody pout ...but none doing. And more than once, the servers ended up behind the bar, making drinks while the bartender "worked the crowd." It's not comforting to see a server make a mixed drink when the bartender can't bother to deliver a plate. 

I'll give Capdeville a few more chances because the kitchen is so right on, and the atmosphere is fun; but the service has the potential to turn me off from an otherwise lovely place. 

Accessibility notes: Fully accessible for mobility devices of all sorts. Very dim and no braille signage or menu. Extremely loud for hard-of-hearing customers. Outdoor tables may solve problems of light and sound.

I have loved Dim Sum throughout my childhood and continues to be one of my all-time favorite meals. So when I moved to Tampa almost 2 years ago I went on a search to find the city's best Dim Sum... sadly, it's not here. After reading great reviews, I decided to give it a try and to say that I was unimpressed is a huge understatement. I even ate here twice to be sure.

The best thing about the restaurant was not the food. The decor was classy, the atmosphere was welcoming, and service was good, but the focus should most certainly be the food. The food was bland and seemed to be the furthest thing from fresh. It was an absolute disappointment. Not to mention that they only had 2 carts, which is no where near sufficient for the kind of spread a proper Dim Sum restaurant should have. In a nutshell- it's over-priced and poor quality with a lacking menu.

They say "Third time's a charm" but I'll never know because I don't intend on wasting my time or money on another disappointing meal. If I'm going to waste my time and money, I'd rather do it driving around the entire Tampa Bay area to find a better Dim Sum place.

We came for happy hour. I don't think Maggie's knows what "happy hour" means, because one Stella Artois and one small serving of fries cost us $12. In fact, this was the most unpleasant hour we spent in Santa Barbara that day. 

We were seated at the patio, the only area one can participate in happy hour, apparently. All was still good as we perused the limited menu. Heck, all was still good when we got our beer. But when the parmesan truffle fries arrived--with, as requested, parmesan on the side--we were just annoyed. Six dollars for just a handful of fries?! On top of that, the fries weren't even anything special--I'd much rather have McDonalds or In N Out's. Further, the parmesan tasted disgustingly stale. I thought it'd be the snow-flakey parmesan one gently sprinkles on top of pasta, but nope. This was small chunks of pale yellow staleness. Yuck.

The only good thing about my experience was the cleanliness of the restroom...

I am so happy I got sides of the Seafood Gumbo, red beans and rice and the Crawfish etoufee!  I got a little of everything and it was all super delicious.  The line moved along (just stand in line; no need to give your name) and we were seated in the busy main section.  Hubby got a chicken dish which was good and just what he wanted, and I got GUMBO to my heart's content.  And that bread pudding... holy moly. Super delicious!

We grabbed cocktails at the bar before our table was ready. I had the Low Hanging Fruit (vodka, St. Germain, Pear, Lemon, Grapefruit, and Cremant). It was refreshing and tasty without being too sweet. Later, I had a glass of the Malvira Arneis, which lived up to the description of fresh and mineral. I checked out the space, which is very open with exposed brick and a modern but intentionally worn feel. They definitely hit the mark with the aesthetic.

For food, we started with the kohlrabi (spiraled) with Caesar dressing, croutons, sheep cheese, and trout roe. I made sure to eat every last fish egg, they were so delicious. This was actually my favorite dish of the night. It was unique; I've never have kohlrabi prepared this way, and the pairing of the roe was exquisite. 

For our main, we shared the Heritage pork shoulder. I was expecting a much more substantial serving of meat, considering this was $23 without any sides. We were somewhat disappointed when two slices of meat came out- there weren't many bites to be had. That said, it was really good. Cooked perfectly, tasty sauce. 

We also shared the tomato, mozzarella, basil, and parmesan pizza. They have a brick oven to fire up the pizzas, so the crust was crisp and had that mildly charred flavor that takes pizza to the next level. They have other pizzas with more interesting toppings, but my husband isn't a fan of white pizzas, so we went basic here. We enjoyed it very much. 

In short, the fare is fantastic, though a bit on the expensive side for the portions. I recommend this place for a special treat when you want to celebrate.

I had lunch here on Friday with a friend, and we were generally pleased with our meal.  Except that it took FOR-EV-ER.  But first, the food.  I had the gator-stuffed chicken.  It was two rings of chicken breast wrapped in bacon and stuffed with alligator sausage.  It was served with a berry chutney and corn maque choux type thing.  And I chose the side salad with charred onion vinaigrette.  All of it was delicious!  My friend ordered a fried green tomato and shrimp po-boy with the side salad. 
Also, I had a voucher for a free dessert, so we had the chocolate peanut butter ice box pie.

Ok, not that much, right??  We were there for an hour.  An hour!!  No idea how or why it takes that long.  It was good though, and the waitress was friendly.  So 4 stars.

Sorry to bust up the love fest, but our meal here was a solid 3 stars, no more.  It wasn't the best Indian food I've ever had, it wasn't even the third best, not that I'm some kind of a super expert in this cuisine.  Some of the sauces were oddly sweet and really threw us off.  Sweet raita?  Weird and not in a good way.

However, the meal was enjoyable on the whole & I'm not knocking the place.  I was just a little disappointed after reading the reviews is all.  The veggie Korma was pretty tasty, but the other entree was forgettable.   I literally forget what the name was & the sauce was bland.  The rice & naan were good.  The service was very friendly & the price was certainly right.

Overall, a nice affordable ethnic option in downtown New Hope.  Considering the price point at most places around here, it was definitely a good find.  Just not the most complex flavors is all.

08/10/2011 - 03:47 pm

I came back out from hiding after an intense morning of carbo-loading and radiation treatment from natural sources.  I believe a visit to FQ was in order as I pass by street Jazz music performers, police sectioning off pedestrian paths and some miscellaneous bums shouting randomness out as if they were Wall street dealers with a bluetooth headset.

I was pretty sure I was going in circles at one point which is how I came across Gumbo Shop Creole Cuisine which seemed like fly-swatting time of day with handful of customers which was less than the staff on duty.  I really don't know what to make of this environment, speechless.  Sticky table, waterspot utensils, but at least they sat me on some weird historic church-like seat facing a mural.

Staff made an attempt to be Tourist friendly although you can see it in his eyes that he wants nothing to do with you.  No worries, I grew up on this serving style and almost felt like home.  There was an instinctive feeling I wanted to get out asap, so I told him a Bowl of Gumbo to start and I'll go from there.

Waiter arrived with warm French Bread.

Seafood Okra Gumbo($7.99)

Okra, Onions, Bell Peppers, Celery and a tiny bit of Tomato sauteed and blended with Shrimp and Crabs into a thick, brown Creole soup-served over Rice.

Soups up, I sipped the soup and it reminds me of my dorm years.  I recognize that flavour anywhere because I grew up from it, the taste of Campbell's Chunky brand Beef base.  At least I know there's Okra in it because of the slimey consistency in every spoonful.  Shrimps were like tasting rehydrated Dried Shrimps while the Blue Crab had similar characteristics.

It's one of those dishes that makes you want to stop.  Needless to say, I didn't order anything else.  It didn't help there was New Orlean-style Flies freely helping themselves with my Meal, and I was sitted indoors rather than the back Patio.

Memorable but not a good way, at least for this one-visit customer.
Search for tasty, flavourful, Gumbo continues....

Its Juans, so it kicks ass! 
The jerk chicken nachos would beat down any other nachos anywhere else, if chicken could wrestle.  Because I'm a vegetarian, they always politely offer and agree to put the chicken on the side.
The drinks rock, great prices and even better tasting!  
The decor is fun, and just simply awesome, like the music and location!
Plenty of carnivore, vegetarian, and vegan options!
The only reason for four stars?  I have an undying loyalty to the Mid-City location. The service really is better, I dont feel like I'm asking for a favor by placing an order.  Sometimes I feel almost intimidated by the servers at Magazine, which is tolerable, only because the food/drinks rock so much, but I'd prefer Mid-City!!!
This place is always loud at dinner.  You can barely hear someone across from you.  Has a perpetually crowded bar.  Food is chain-like but not bad.

There's not much to do in Tampa.  Mr. Dunderbak's a great place to hit up if you happen to be spending some time in Tampa. Mr. Dunderbak's has a variety of delicious brews on tap and an adequate food menu.  Additionally, there's a wall of chocolate close to the counter.  

While I appreciated the variety of craft brews, one of my favorite beers was not up to par the day I ordered it.  The Brooklyn Brewery Cuvee de Cardoz was not carbonated correctly.  It could have happened for a variety of reasons (keg tapped too long, bad keg to begin with, or under carbonated at the Brewery), which is not to be blamed on Mr. Dunderbak's.  

I also ordered the lox (smoked salmon with cream cheese on a bagel), which was just okay.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't wonderful.  It was just okay.  The hot German potato salad was also a little more sour and soupy than I would have preferred.  The Matterhorn on the other hand was quite tasty and rather large for the price.  Piled high with meat on a toasty bread, it is perfect for soaking up heavy beers. 

Despite the semi-flat beer, I really like this place.  Five stars for the beer variety and big sammiches!

Came here on a Tuesday for lunch around 1 o'clock. The line was still out the door, but luckily it moved fast. I got my usual, which is veggie burrito bowl. 

Everything was ok but it was super SALTY today. I drank like three glasses of water while I ate my lunch. It may have just been an off day. Their guacamole is delicious and the only reason why I come here.  

I chipotle more than qdoba because of the flavor. Chipotle is usually pretty spicy, but in a good way.

I have found my new go-to place in Chinatown. With delicious traditional Taiwanese and Shanghainese food, fast and friendly service, and great prices, what's not to love? I came here on a busy Saturday for lunch with my family; the place was packed, but we were able to be seated right away. We ordered the beef scallion pancake, pork soup dumplings, Taiwanese beef noodle soup, and crispy salted chicken. The dishes came quickly and were all delicious. The soup dumplings in particular had a thin, delicate skin and plenty of hot flavorful soup inside. Definitely the best in Chinatown! I love that this place also accepts credit cards on checks over $15, so no cash needed. Will definitely be back for more!

I have to say that Zeppoli was very good and I would like to come back and try a few more things.  We arrived a bit early for a Monday night reservation and we were sat immediately.  We started by ordering the salad and the app special which were lamb chops.  The lamb chops were perfectly cooked and came with a slice of cooked eggplant and the 2 went very well together.  Moving on we ordered the Gnocchi which were good but they didn't really wow us so next time I would like to branch out and try another pasta.  For dinner, we ordered the Marinated Rib-Eye which was bone in but they cut the bone out for you and place it on a separate plate and the Fisherman's Stew.  The Fisherman's Stew was just fantastic, everything went extremely well together and the broth wasn't too acidic which does happen sometimes.  I was gnawing on that steak bone for a while as well.  We did order some sorbet and ice cream for dessert and it was very good.  Overall besides the misstep that was the gnocchi this was a solid meal and I look forward to returning and seeing what they have in the future.

I've been a frequent shopper at straub's for a very long time! Since chicken salad was $5.99 a pound. Now it's $10.99! Speaking of chicken salad!!! That's the best this small grocery store has to offer! I absolutely love their chicken salad! It's one of the best ever! Seriously, if you're a chicken salad fan, this is a must have when you're in STL! My mom which is very critical when it comes to food loves it too! Only downfall is that it's a little pricy! 

I also love their Thai pasta salad! It taste so good! Has water chestnuts and celery for the crunch! Something about this pasta salad makes me come back for more and I'm not a pasta person at all! Everything that is in the pasta is very flavorful. Looks so simple to mimic the recipe but I just rather purchase from straub's. 

The curry chicken salad is also great! Made just like the original but curry style! A little sweeter but still prefer the original. 

This little grocery store also sells a lot of small business goodies such as Ann & Allen's gooey butter cake. labonne bouchee goodies, sia's Italian ice and much more. Since this is a privately own grocery store it can be a little pricy but it gets plenty of business regardless!

we heard that the shrimp poboy here was out of this world.  we made sure we tried this bad boy during our trip.

VERDICT:  we thought it was just ok.  since everyone was saying that this sandwich was freaking amazing, we were expecting some sort of flavor explosion (nope) and amazing bread (not really).  the sandwich came with 3 jumbo shrimp, which we thought were rather bland.  the bread was meh.  not soft (like fresh bread) but not crunchy either (like a toasted baguette).  if anything, it was kind of reminded me of stale baguette?  ouch.  for $15 a sandwich, we find this pretty expensive.  call us crazy but we have had better. way better.

AMBIENCE: killer poboys is tucked in the back of the erin rose bar (yep, where you get the frozen irish coffee).  super dark.  grungy looking. two high tables (we took our sandwiches to go).

SERVICE:  just ok.  don't expect a happy, friendly conversation.  they are busy making your sandwich (which takes them awhile).

OVERALL:  we really wanted to love this place but thought the sandwiches were just okay.  nothing mindblowing. with that said, we understand why many people do (our friend mark is a huge fan). this place could've been such a gem.  i) location behind a bar...hole in the wall (literally).  ii) small, focused menu. iii) twist on a classic (banh mi)  too bad we didn't fall in love.

tip: bring yo cash.  this place will not accept cards.

Rouses market is a staple in the French quarter that always has something you need. The employees are really nice considering, they deal with the worst of the visitors that come in looking for God knows what at God knows when. They have a full selection of king cakes including stuffed and playing varieties. Is security guard even help me find the flavors I was looking for. One of the other employees and I worked together to rig up a bag big enough to carry 2 cakes at the same time (talk about great customer service)!  They also have pretty much any type of food item or alcoholic beverage that you may need. It's a bonus that they stay open late. They were in full swing during last night's inaugural parade for Krewe Boheme and they didn't miss a beat. Glad to see that they're still the same.

Finally, someone decided that it would be a good idea to combine beer and grocery shopping!

I went to the new Tap Room last week and was extremely pleased. Great beers on tap, Steve Earle music playing, and a good vibe among the people there. I loved that they even had a "pub menu," and you were also able to bring in lunch from the store to eat in there.

My husband and I ended up doing a few beer flights, which was the perfect way to sample all of the beers we wanted to try. My husband fell in love with one and brought it home in a Growler, which I had never heard of before, but doesn't make as much noise as one may think.

I think the new Tap Room is a great addition to the Reno community. It's not as much of a happy hour vibe as some of the newer Midtown bars, but the staff is friendly, knowledgeable, and it's a great place to relax while you're writing down your grocery list. And after a few drinks, that list may have evolved into something like potato chips, hot dogs, guacamole, and chocolate bars. Thank goodness you're at Whole Foods, where you can get the best caliber of all 4 of those items.

Enjoy!
Yelp wait list for this joint doesn't work, hostess is the rudest person, will not spend any more $$ here

Well, we were LITERALLY one of the first people in the store for their Grand Opening today at 7am.  :)  That's how excited we are to have this fantastic store in our neighborhood.  Seems like we have been waiting forever, but it is finally open...whew.  
Anyway, the store itself has a really great layout with large displays over each section to let you know what's there....like the Seafood section, the Butcher etc....a lot like Whole Foods.
There are many choices from local farmers and a lot of various organic options.  
We bought salmon and a round roast and the butchers were extremely helpful.  As a matter of fact....everyone who was working there that we encountered was oooooozing with friendliness.  They seem to have a good team working there. 
There is also a Sushi Bar of some kind where you can get sushi made for you while you wait....I will be taking advantage of that soon. :)
I will not that they do not carry Edy's Ice Cream but maybe I can do without that one for awhile....hmmmm.

Portions: Huge! 
Service: Ok. 
Food: Delicious. (I've tried the linguine with bolognese, chicken Marsala, a slice of pepperoni pizza, caesar salad, the bruschetta & garlic knots they give every table in the beginning are tasty)

There's the main dining room once you walk in, small. And to the left is more of the party room where I've witnessed baby showers and wedding showers going on.
Excellent pizza and some of the best chicken wings in town!

Tucked away as part of the La Paloma Resort, Contigo isn't the most convenient place to get to. But, there are some pretty slammin' views if you score a table by the window or dine on the patio. 

The atmosphere is semi-fancy (or maybe everyone was just dressed a little fancier for New Years), with a nice open space and a cool bar. Service was pretty good; everyone was really nice and welcoming, with just a slight snafu with our waiter not being completely sure what a gluten allergy entails. 

We came here for New Years Eve dinner, which had a pre fixe menu with an optional wine pairing addition. It started with a Manchego plate, that came with marcona almonds (my favorite), bread, and amazing local honey that I now want to slather on all of my meals. Next, we had the ibÃ©rico mixto and piquillos rellenos. The iberico plate was good, but nothing mind-blowing. The piquillos rellenos were pretty disappointing; I love shrimp but they tasted heavily of cream cheese, and the random small chunks of shrimp had kind of a weird texture. For the main course, we elected the cabrillo and the lomo. The cabrillo was really good, but the lomo was far and away my favorite thing of the night. It was melt-in-your-mouth tender, and the potato puree and broccolini paired perfectly with the tenderloin. 

All in all, I think Contigo was pretty good. I don't know that I'd go far out of my way to revisit necessarily, but sure wouldn't mind if I was already in the area. Though those Paella Tuesdays are pretty tempting...

I really really wanted to love this place. Aside from the outstanding reviews, this place has all the characteristics of gem. It's literally at the back of a bar through a space that looks like you're entering a bathroom. Its a very small space where the air is filled with the smell of deliciousness and there are only a few seats. I was pretty pumped for this...

I got the Dark & Stormy Po boy which is Pork Belly with Rum Ginger Glaze with Lime Slaw, Garlic Aioli. After about 20 minutes the sandwich came out and it looks delicious. Upon taking a bite the problem was immediately evident. There was practically no meat in the sandwich. The meat that was actually in there was good, but it was literally buried in the slaw, glaze and aioli. With eat bite, I tasted only bread and toppings with the occasional small piece of meat. It was to the point decided to put all the meat on half a piece of bread and eat it that way just so I could get a real feel for it. Once i did this, it tasted good, but was still overkill on the toppings.

This is a bit of a weird situation. Everything about this place screams classic, but the way my sandwich was constructed made it impossible to really enjoy. Based on the reviews, maybe my sandwich was a one off situation. Either way, I only ended up eating a little over 1/4 of the sandwich because of the lack of meat... Which was obviously frustrating.

I don't even like ice cream but their vanilla is delicious!! It not too overly sweet and seems to has bits of vanilla bean in it and just the right creaminess. I don't know their secret, but it's mighty delicious. 

I've tried the strawberry and I didn't care much for it. Tasted too artificial to me. The vanilla just blew it out of the water. 

They also have awesome pup cups for $1! That's a sweet deal for a treat for your little friend. 

Definitely a fun place to stop for for a quick sweet frozen treat for you and your pup!

I came stumbling in at 2 in the morning after a night out in Philadelphia and Penrose Diner provided all I needed to end my night. First off the staff was wonderful, they treated a group of loud, buzzed fools with nothing but class and respect. The waitress was helpful, friendly and more than accommodating.

Food was good, standard diner menu, ranging from classic breakfast items to steaks and burgers. I kept it simple a nice order of eggs sunny side up, potatoes and corned beef hash. All cooked to perfection and so tasty.

Worth a visit at the end of a long night especially if you're staying in the hotel across the street. Buzzed comfort food at its best.

Please make sure you check your receipts. Especially in the dark!

I have been here on two occasions and on both occasions they  managed to get the bill AND food order wrong. 

The first time, I gave them a PASS since the movie was packed with patrons and it seems everyone was ordering a drink or food. The second time, however, no excuses. There were a total of 6 (yes, six people) in the entire theatre since it was a matinee. They forgot our dessert then proceeded to overcharge for a few items.

Great concept, terrible execution.

They have salad options and stir-fry options. Toppings are extremely expensive for the amount they give you I.e if you order mushroom, you'll get 3 pieces of mushroom max. Have never truly understood Honeygrow as a chain because I think the stir-fry is extremely oily. The salad, I haven't tried, so I can't quite say anything about that. 

I do appreciate this place because it's a fast-casual lunch spot that I don't feel cherry hill has a lot of. The ordering is pretty intuitive, you use a screen and pay at the screen. It's very fast. Orders also take like 5 minutes to make - not sure how they do it, but they do. 

I've researched the calories online, but when I'm in the store I don't see the calories as I order - maybe they have it somewhere else, but I wish they would give you the total calorie count since they do have a "health" branding aspect to their company.

Healthy, fresh, reliable.  In a nice, unpretentious atmosphere. 

In all the years I've lived in or visited Philly, this place has been slightly empty, with eager, charming waitstaff, plentiful mint tea and fresh food at bargain prices. I used to get the meat platters, but the sandwiches, falafel and baba are delicious too. Every time I visit, I'm afraid the restaurant will have disappeared. But no.

Great little Korean cafÃ© in North Philly. They had a variety of Gim bap ranging form beef to curry chicken, veggie, tuna etc. They also had a few ramen dishes and a KILLER version of donkatsu. I had the beef Gim Bap and Naeng Myun , which were both awesome. The Naeng Myun had a great sauce to it with tons of veggies. The gim bap was exactly how I grew up eating it, having several Korean friends. One of my buddies had the Donkatsu, and it was HUGE and cooked to perfection. All in all, a great little spot to get some different Korean food.

This place is pretty tasty. The noodle bowls are delicious! The rice bowls are HUGE and cheap for a quick lunch and fairly comparable to Hana Kitchen (although I'd say I prefer Lao Wang rice bowls to Hana Kitchen). 

The service is always fast and they also have a great beer selection on tap! 

I'd say the the noodle bowls are the best part about this place. Spicy is SPICY but everything else is flavorful and delicious!! 

They have a little area with some sauces which is always welcome.

If you want to experience one of the nation's great urban parks, try the perimeter bike path, which is a bit more than five miles in length, I believe. Along the way, you'll find a world-class zoo and art museum, Missouri history museum, "Muny" outdoor theater, ponds, pools, fountains, gardens, golf course, and tennis courts. West of the park is Wash U. and the Delmar Loop, and east is the Central West End (CWE).  Be careful that you don't crash on a downhill; but if you do, you're within sight of Barnes-Jewish Medical Center, one of the best in the nation.  Bikes and "Segways" are available for rental (inquire at Lindell Pavilion, where you'll find coffee and public restrooms). Suburbanites like me can just load up the bikerack on the SUV, and park north-central, or many places around the interior. Sadly, I can share stories, one personal, of "smash-and-grab" car burglaries in parking areas. It's best to take all electronics and valuables with you.

A very nice public park that has been getting increasing traffic and varied events.   One of the major outdoor concert venues with plenty of nearby paid parking options.  View is great across the river from the signature minarets at University of Tampa.  The playground and water-spray park is popular with the kids and convenient to the Children's Museum.  Kids and parents are frequent visitors, mixing with local street folks charging their cells on the free outdoor electrical outlets.  Well patrolled by law enforcement so  trouble is unlikely. Very attentive maintenance crew.

Most of the space is wide open but conducive to tents, so it can accommodate lots of events, including some connected with the Republican National Convention, Movies on the Lawn, ice skating, and the annual St. Vincent de Paul "Walk for the Poor" complete with the Starship Yacht docked at the seawall to serve as food and beverage source.

Cheesy classic Philly steak sammie time!  Not the best I have had on a Philly, but made it a meal when in Philly downtown!  Convenient spot to grab and munch on. 

I liked the onion rings as a side order a lot!  They batter it up well and fried it to a perfect crispiness, that was delicious.  It was the crunch that was overly satisfying with my mustard dip. 

Cherry hot pickled peppers, complimented the sammie!  I had a bite of that with every bite of the sammie!  I was indulging.  The pleasures of simplicity on grub local food with travel, was what this spot reminded me of in that moment.  It was treasurable and marked a satisfactory spot in my soul. 

Classic Philly sammie that one can't go wrong on when ordering up here! Add the onion rings while at it!  Win!

Korean Food near the St. Louis Airport? I've been wanting to check this place out for a long time during my many Business trips to St. Louis! Seoul Garden Korean Restaurant exceeded my expectations! 

The Kalbi (BBQ short ribs) were cooked great & Japchae (stir fried noodles with vegetables) were yummy! All the Banchan (Side dishes) were super good! We had a really nice waiter who provided Awesome service!   

I will definitely try the All You Can Eat next time!

My Coworker and I were so happy after Dinner! We are definitely going to come back the next time were are in town!

Who would have thought there was good Korean Food in St. Louis!? :D

Inventive, well-crafted sushi rolls and a cozy little nook to enjoy them in. I've tried quite a few maki here but the Hurricane Roll stands out among them. Saki and fried ice cream were highly satisfying. The specials are worth taking advantage of, but these magnitude 9.0 rolls are worth the price either way.

Please read my last review!!     I went on and on about all the previous five star and one star reviews and whether or not they were sincere.   I had a lot of messages and comments some supporting my views and others challenging them (to say it nicely)   

My friend Lily had a higher opinion of it than I did and we thought it would be fun to revisit the restaurant together.    Lily is my expert in Chinese cuisine and she ordered off of the Chinese menu.    Things I would never even know exist!!   

I have to say that I was quite impressed by the food!   The portions were generous for the money, very different than my first experience.   The taste was very, very good and while it isn't Lily's favorite Chinese restaurant in the area, I think she enjoyed it as well.    

That said, the restaurant has SO much farther that it needs to go.  It was complete amateur hour when we were there.   The ordering was awkward and slow, two of the four dishes that we ordered were wrong and had to be sent back.   It was a meal of explanations,  arguments and apologies.    

I want to say that it is OK that the place has no atmosphere whatsoever because it is in I.V.  But why shouldn't it be a more visually pleasant dining experience.   As I mentioned in my first review Wok had an almost entirely Chinese clientele which I think says volumes about the authenticity of the food.    

Ok there you have it, my previous one star review is now a two star.   Come on Wok, it won't take too much to get me up to three stars!   The food is already there!

I really like the value & the convenient location.  (I am not a sushi exchange expert, but know bad can tell bad fish.)

As others stated, it is in a strip mall behind Walgreens.  The inside decor would be just OK for West County, but good to great for South County.

Hot tea was nice.
Miso soup seemed slightly bland, but good.
Kani Salad was a imitation crab meat interesting starter.
We also tried the pot stickers (Gyoza) that were tasty.
I had both 2 orders of sashimi salmon & spicy tuna.  Both seemed to be very fresh.  I really liked the balance of flavors on the spicy tuna.

I work with a lot of guys who used to work at Sewell Cadillac. It was before my time, but I felt like I knew the place because of all of the stories I've heard. Thus, even though it's a little out of my way (I live on the Westbank), I decided to stop by and check out the new Rouses located in the old Sewell building.

I wondered how they would transform it from a car dealership to a supermarket. The place looks fabulous, and the parking garage is really convenient. Be sure to drive to the top for a nice view of the Crescent City Connection bridge. 

Also, it might be a good idea to grab a map when you first walk in the door. I saw the maps, but neglected to do so. Really, who needs a map for a grocery store? You'll think this, like I did, but then you'll freak out when you can't find the produce section. It's more than a little confusing. 

Once you manage to navigate the store, though, you'll find a good selection of great products. Everything is high quality, like you would expect at Rouses. I need to come back here at least once more, on an empty stomach, and check out the prepared foods. I almost gave in and got a cup of King Cake Gelato on my way out... but resisted. This time. Next time I think I'll go for it :)

I've been twice, once before their grand opening with a group of 6 and once last week with a slightly smaller party. My friends were more impressed than I was (I would say really more like 3.5 stars).

The atmosphere is nice, albeit a little bit more upscale and a little bit less fun/cool than my main restaurants of comparison (Bakersfield, primarily). All of the light fixtures are super lovely. The bathrooms are actually the prettiest bathrooms I've ever seen. That wallpaper (*insert heart eye emoji here*)! I don't like the half circle tables for larger groups. I could barely hear the people who weren't sitting next to me because we were basically sitting in a line.

I've had the guacamole (with crudite, jicama, etc.), queso (with black bean puree at the bottom), fried avocado tacos, and fish tacos. Mix up your queso, it's great with the crispy, warm chips. Fish tacos were too fishy for my liking. The fried avocados are crispy and flavorful, but the amount of food in the tortillas were a little sparse my second time there. I would say this is probably inventive food for Indianapolis, but coming from Houston, it's pretty standard (except maybe the taco with mashed potatoes!).  (Side note: If you love Nada's avocado tacos, you will FLIP for Torchy's in Texas.) Prices are decent for food. I had two of the draft cocktails - not impressed by the margarita (Bakersfield's is WAY better, gotta say), but the Mexican Mule was pretty tasty. It was the perfect amount of sweet and refreshing.

Service improved for the second visit. The first visit, our waters only got refilled after multiple requests. They brought my friend the wrong drink. They brought my friend's pork belly tacos without egg (even after a long discussion about it with the waiter!). They gave us the wrong leftovers (pork to the vegetarian, kind of a bummer).

My friend took me here one night for some late night noshing and it was pretty good.  The service was fantastic!  Our waitress was super nice and very attentive.  I got the grilled cheese with fries and a slice of cherry pie for dessert.  Good, traditional diner food and the place was large and clean. Can't complain...and would definitely go back if I'm in the area.

Best homemade pasta in Nashville; several different types of noodles made fresh each day. Their menu offers many succulent sauces like the Mama Rosa (pesto sauce with a hint of ricotta, cream, and fresh tomato sauce blended), VTC (homemade pomodoro with a touch of vodka and cream), or Sorrentino (pomodoro sauce tossed with mozzarella and fresh basil leaves). They also have great desserts, but my favorite is the Tiramisu. 

Their old location had a terrific view of the city skyline, but their new location (a short walk to the Schermerhorn Symphony Hall) is more integrated into downtown.

GOOD A** BURGERS!!!

I ventured to this location with a classmate who has been here several times but it was my first. Ordered a jr. burger and small fry....THE JR. BURGER LOOKS LIKE A REGULAR SIZE BURGER!! and Mann was it good! Fries were hot and customer service was outstanding..

Cons: Didn't care for the parking that's behind the restaurant its kind of a inconvenience but due to its location they really don't have a choice!

WILL DEFIANTLY RETURN!

To visit St. Louis and not have frozen custard from Ted Drewes would be a traveling faux pas.  For over 70 years, they have been putting smiles on faces on both kids and adults.  Their custard base is not overly sweetened, resulting in a smooth and fresh frozen custard.  They only serve Vanilla, so if you want other flavors, you'll have to get them mixed in via a Concrete, Milkshake or through a Sundae.  There are over 12 Frozen Custard Shops in the St. Louis area, but before you try the rest, you have to try the acclaimed best!

What a great way to spend a Tuesday!

We did the HandleBar with a group of volunteers on our week off from volunteering and it was the perfect activity to enjoy each other's company but still be doing something active. We all brought our own drinks and our driver (Donovan) was great about checking on us and making sure we were always filled up! 

I'd be excited to give the Handlebar a go on the weekend, but going during the week was a nice break from the madness of the work week and a good way to have a fun time with great friends!

I used to eat at Semenza when it was on Kings Row, my memory was it was delicious. The last thing I remember eating there was years ago (after it moved to Neil Rd) and it was the garlic cheese bread, which I remember being SO BOM! 

Me and my uncle, who BACHING it, while my aunt is on a trip, decided to get dinner, he said pizza, and I thought heck, let's do Semenza's, it's got good reviews, and I keep hearing about the amazing chicken wings, and I always think about that cheese bread, so we went a two days ago on Thursday night. 

As you know it's on Neil Road, which when I was growing up, was the gang street, not sure if it still has that rep, but, upon arriving, I felt very unwelcomed. A guy was at the register taking an order and it was taking a while, me and uncle had decided on a medium special which was a 2 topping pizza and 1 1/2LBs of wings for mid $20 range. 

After taking the ladies order, he just walks away, no greeting, no communication, I was going to walk out and would have if Todd South didn't tell me a personal story about the owner, I figured this guy wasn't him, and that was the only saving grace. Another guy comes over, and he takes our order, so we ordered, even after the blatant customer disrespect, I asked if he was the owner, which he confirmed. 

I then ordered a pitcher of Bud Light beer (no Coors Light) and the famous cheese bread. He said they ran out of bread, so I didn't get the one thing I really wanted! 

Our food comes out in a reasonable amount of time, and I can say it was not impressive, neither the pizza or the wings. The wings were not super big either. I thought everything was okay that night, but I don't ever see myself eating pizza or wings there again. I had high expectations from Yelp, so I really expected them to deliver something memorable on the pizza and wings, this was just okay food, not horrible, not exciting, hence my 2 stars. 

The pluses were an employee there, not the owner, was a good friendly personality, I appreciated him, and the pitcher was a good size for $12. Last, but not lease, I ordered my pizza well done, and this pizza was a far cry from well done when the nice guy dropped the pizza, I did confirm, if this was well done which he said it was, it was definitely not!

I really liked it here.  My BF and I got the Creole Combination Platter which has Shrimp Creole, Jambalaya and Red Beans and Rice.  My favorite was the Jambalaya.  It was full of flavor (as the rest of the dishes were) and had a good amount of meat.  

Thankfully the wait here wasn't too long because we came at peak dinner time.

Ah, this place will have a special place in my heart forever. 

This was the location of our rehearsal dinner. They did a nice job accommodating 23 people in a cozy environment. We ordered roughly about 36 small dishes, salads, and salmon/steak for everyone. At the end of the day, food was amazing, and all of our guests were pretty happy - but they were TIRED from how late into the night we had to wait for our food. I would have hoped that if they were anticipating a group of ~25 people that they would have had staff to accommodate. Service, although courteous, was incredibly and painstakingly slow. 

My husband and I also came here for the morning after our wedding - our first breakfast together as a married couple! Food again was great, servers were kind, but again, very slow to refill our drinks/take our check/etc. 

Overall, this place is great. Ambiance, decor, and food are amazing. Maybe they don't usually have a high turnover rate so the restaurant is not staffed that way, but service tends to slow down immensely with large numbers of people. Hopefully you will get the chance to come on a less popular day to experience this place!

Tons of flavors! You can not come to this Rita's and not expect to find over 15 flavors. From the fresh ice, to extra soft pretzels, and to the awesome toppings they provide for sundaes. OMG!! I can go on and on about Rita's. Lol.

Here are a few of my favorites - 
Mint choco chip gelati with vanilla custard - Mmmmm! I love the lil mini chips and the ice is so refreshing. Not sure how healthy it is, but a lil splurge here and there can never hurt anyone.

Vanilla custard with peanut butter sauce. Sometimes I throw other things into it, but I tend to just stick with the basics.

Pretzel - I dunno where this place gets their pretzels, but it's always taste soooo fresh (like hot out of the oven fresh), even when you come near closing time. Pretzels tend to get hard as it sits long, but not here!

Cherry pie blendini - it's cherry water ice, custard, and nilla wafers. HEAVEN!

Nothing really stood out.

The BF and I placed an order via telephone to go. The lady on the other line said our order would be ready in 10 mins. I thought, "wow, that's fast! Great!"

10 mins later, we make our way to the restaurant to pick up our order and the lady I spoke with said sh would submit our order. What??

We awkwardly stand by the register before another hostess tells us to move and stand by the bathroom.

...


Ate food at home and it was okay. When people say this place won awards for having the best gumbo, I think that there will be intense flavors, but it was just mediocre. Nothing good, nothing bad. To say I was disappointed is an understatement.

Stopped here with my husband after a night out recently. The staff was extremely quick and officiant! I'm a little bias as I truly believe their is no such thing as a bad Philadelphia cheesesteak, but I really loved Sonny's. The rolls were fresh and they definitely didn't skimp out on a very filling portion. It was around $25 for the two of us, but we ordered cheese fries as well. 

I can imagine Sonny's can get crazy during the late night hours after bars let out, but it was super quiet in there around 10PM on a Saturday. We will definitely be back the next time we are near Market St.!

I was able to ride in style to the Yelp White Night on the HandleBar this year and it was the perfect compliment to an already stellar event.  We boarded the HandleBar at Tow Yard Brewing which was nice because we could leave our cars and grab a pint for the road!  The HandleBar allows you to play the music of your choosing and offers a fun and unique way to travel around downtown while having a blast with your friends!  Our driver was friendly and professional and ensured we all had a safe and enjoyable evening.  I would love to organize another event on the HandleBar soon!

Great event for dog owners and lovers alike!  Great smells, romps, and woods!!  My dogs loves the event and the free info, swag doggie bags, swimming pools, and eats.  It was a fun event with and for us humans as they were treats and food trucks available plenty of dog watering holes and snacks.  Free food samples, Pwt cate info, magnets,dog treats and lots of doggie wears to shop.  Also got to visit with some of the rescue groups and adoption agencies in the Tampa Bay all supporting rehoming and animal rights. Great cause good exposure for everyone can't wait to do it next year.

Unpopular opinion clearly, but we didn't enjoy this place as much as the rest of the yelpers. The service was slow and our food was meh.

We started with the guacamole San Miguel. Which was basically guacamole before you smash the avocados. Decent but not great. Same can be said about the complimentary salsa. 

My husband ordered the fajitas which came with beans and rice as well. Everything was SO SALTY. Hopefully this was just an accident and not the norm of how they serve their food. 

I ordered the flautas. The meat inside was good but they were boring. The tortilla was way overcooked and flavorless. I was also surprised that the meal didn't come with sides. 

I got a sangria and hubby got a margarita. Neither of them were good enough to have us wanting more. 

Yes, the decor is cute but that's not enough to keep us coming back unfortunately.

So my wife and I tried to come here two Friday's ago at 4:15 pm before a benefit to grab some grub and were told at the side door that they don't open until 5 pm. Really? Five o'clock on a Friday...whatever. So we went back this past Friday at 5. I've go to say that they have a great happy hour, $3 drafts, $4 house margaritas, and $4 nachos. We sat at the bar and my wife had a margarita and I a PBC Harvest From the Hood. Her drink was tasty and seemed like it was the real deal and not a premade mix. Atmosphere was cool and the bathrooms were bright, clean and the Spanish comic book wallpaper with the buxom women was totally fun. Perused the menu and started with the Nachos de Kezo. Carne Asada, Pulled Chicken and Chorizo and Potatoes loaded on to delicious chips with melted cheese, Crema and Guacamole. Holy cow they were awesome. The bartender told us they also make them as Nachos De K & A but use waffle fries instead of chips. We will definitely try them next time. Then onto the tacos. We ordered the fish and the shrimp tacos. Yes they were small but they are only $2-$2.50. The ingredients were well prepared but it seemed like they needed some seasoning somewhere along the line. Both were a little bland but coked perfectly. A little salt can go a long way. Maybe that's why they give you 4 to 5 different sauces in a little bucket with your order. Overall we enjoyed the chill vibe and the nachos but thought the tacos were a little lacking in the flavor department. We will give this one another try.

The only Chipotle location in the New Orleans area and its just like the rest around the country. Like the others this location features excellent tex-mex that I prefer in the bowl rather than burrito. Unlike the others they don't nickel and dime you to death with ad-ons. Unfortunately its quite a ways from downtown New Orleans so I won't be eating here to often but when in the area there is probably no better option in Elmwood.

Saigon Bay is generally my Viet go-to on Fowler when I'm in Tampa - but we were here between Christmas 2018 and Jan 4 2019 and it turns out that Saigon Bay was closed for the holidays.  Good for them!  They deserved the break.

That said, it was thanks to their closing that I discovered my NEW go-to Viet joint around these parts.  Cozy dining area, comprehensive menu and great prices.

Yesterday we came for breakfast - today; for lunch.  We were five and while I was tempted to go with the clams in oyster sauce (chef specialties menu) our server recommended the filet and vegetables.  Who am I to argue with a good recommendation.

Two house special Pho, one Shrimp fried rice, on Bo Kho and my filet/veg thingy.  The Pho broth was sublime.

All quite tasty.

Regardless, next time I'll put my foot down and definitely order the clam dish.  It just sounds good, and what's more - I've had my fill of Bo Kho over the past month!

Strongly recommend anyone who tends towards viet cuisine to check this out.  No disappointment anticipated.

I like Chipotle!  Yes, I know it is a chain, and yes, I always prefer to support local businesses, but I have to say, for a large chain, this place does a pretty damn good job!  I really appreciate that all of their meats are hormone and antibiotic free.  I also think it is awesome that you can get a full and nutritious meal (for me, it made 2 meals) for $6.50.  WAY better than any other fast food chains.  Nice job, Chipotle!  Plus I love your guacamole!

This is literally the most disgusting Whole Foods Market I have ever been to in the United States after paying for my groceries I went into the bathroom even though there is a bathroom checklist there was no soap there was urine all over the seat and splashed water all over the floor


Very disappointing sorry but I had to give a one star

I have to say it. 
HANDS DOWN BEST BEIGNETS.....EVER
Doughy, good size, and about a half pound of powdered sugar dumped on top. It took awhile for my order to come up - but no biggie. Due to where it's located in the musical legends park, there's always some nice music playing. Or just grab yourself a quick drink at the bar next to it. Plus, for only $3.99 it was awesomely priced. 
Highly recommend stopping by. 
Glad I don't live in NoLa or else I would be eating these every damn day. Seriously. For reals. #FatKidForLife

Love love love
Only had uber eats from here but yum the noodle bowl is so good, topping:s, egg, noodles and thick delicious pork belly.
Short review, but y'all, other have detailed the deliciousness, I'm just here to concur with my fellow yelpers!!!!

I've always liked TBBC, but it's a bit of a hassle driving into Ybor (coming from Clearwater), so I'm glad they opened another location. The drive isn't much closer for me, but avoiding driving through "malfunction junction" is always a plus.

This new location is spacious and brighter. I love the bar that's made out of a trunk of a tree; the natural curves it has. There's a very spacious patio area, but not with much shades so it can be very sunny and hot. We've always chosen to sit at the inside bar. Bar = faster access to drinks & more drinking than eating. Don't judge.

I've enjoyed several brews by TBBC and they all have been good (barleywine, hefeweizen, blonde ale and kumquat fruit ale). There is also a full liquor bar, which I haven't taken advantage of. The servers at the bar have always been great. They're so attentive; never let your glass go empty.

As for the food, I've only had 2 dishes so far: Cantonese Calamari and Calzone. The calamari was soooo good the first time, but not so great the 2nd due to the fried coating being mushy in the sauce. But this dish is so good, it's definitely worth more tries. The calzone looked impressive, but it wasn't as good as I had thought. I guess it's a TBBC signature thing because the side that's up is really puffed up. It looks huge, but it's all air inside. We got pepperoni and banana peppers toppings, but I can barely see either. Once you crack the plate size calzone open, there's just mostly air and lots and lots of cheese.

Just last week TBBC changed its menu slightly and I noticed a pork belly appetizer was added. Can't wait to go back next week to try it.

The only reason Dierbergs will not get 5 stars out of me is the price. Oh my goodness, is this place expensive! I absolutely adore their selection of gluten free and vegetarian options, but only around payday. They have one of the best varieties of nutrition bars on this side of the river. I'll frequently find myself with no time for dinner, so I'll throw a Larabar of Luna bar in my purse in case I get hungry. They have flavors and brands I cannot find at Target or the Commissary...their produce is also a million times tastier. Not just their organic selection, but all of it! If you're made of money, you really can't go wrong here.

Phenomenal brunch Nola food in a classy restaurant with wonderful service! I was a guest of a large group and we had brunch upstairs. The gumbo appetizer was a delicious savory combination of meats and gravy style sauce with rice. Their brunch breads of banana bread with butter was yummy! Then I had shrimp and goat cheese grits, which was excellent with creamy grits and savory sauce for the shrimp. It's a different dish from the Charleston style but still delicious. They also had bread pudding in a more custard style. It was a sugary custard with a little bit of bread and crumbled toffee candy on top.  The service was amazing and the decor was lovely! Fabulous brunch and one I will always remember!

Fabulous little smoothie shop.  I stopped in here with a girlfriend looking for an ATM (we found one!) and figured what the heck, while we're here we'll order a little pick-me-up before heading to the Farmer's Market.  I ordered "The Cranberry" fearing that it might be too tart, but it came out perfect!  I got a great little boost in my day knowing that the smoothie was filled with antioxidants and good things.

I've lived within close proximity to the Maple Shade Custard Stand my whole life, and just recently I learned it's real name. Before I would refer to it as the Drive In, which comes from the big red letters on it roof. 

But regardless of what you call it, its a local favorite. The ice cream is delicious, the prices fair, and the portions generous. Overall the place has a great home town vibe with a friendly staff. 

The custard stand has a small parking lot where people will park and enjoy their ice cream on their tail gates. There are also two wooden benches where you can enjoy your ice cream. If the lot gets too crowded, it is typical practice to park along the street.

This stuff is pretty good.  I particularly like the level of customization you can bestow (or inflict) on your ice cream.  Parking is a squeeze, but doable, and free.  The atmosphere is lively, the wait isn't too bad, and there's something to be said for a place that makes your sit outside on whatever open parking block you can find.  Portion control is the name of the game here.  Obviously it's all bad for you, so just order what you can reasonably eat.

A solid lunch option, the specials are on the last page of the menu. 2 rolls for $9, or 3 for $13, and it comes with soup OR salad (not and). It's pretty easy to show up for lunch with a group, which is a definitely rarity for a sit-down lunch in Rittenhouse.

I can't speak to the food as much (vegan at a sushi place!) but as for vegetarian/vegan options, there's a good number of veggie rolls. Another person at my table got the tofu terayaki, which I wouldn't recommend as it was literally large slabs of tofu. You're better off with rolls (I had the inari roll -- it was actually a roll, not inari! and mango+avocado. Would recommend!).

Yep! Already can't wait to come back. Julia R brought me here for a little date night last night and Indo, you did not disappoint. 

When you first walk in, the front section of the restaurant highlights their open kitchen. From what I understand, you can sit at the counter tops in the front to experience their tasting menu. For a couple I believe the tasting menu is around $150. I look forward to trying this out sometime!

You walk down the hallway to the more intimate section in the back. This is where we sat yesterday for our reservation. We both decided to share everything, the whole meal. We kicked it off with "a plastic chair in the rose garden" and "the art of eight limbs." Both were delicious, but I was feeling partial to gin last night, so I enjoyed the rose garden a little more. You come here to eat, though. The freaking food! We started out with the gyoza, which was plated in the most vibrant way and they were phenomenal. Then we shared the issan himachi, it was approachable and filling. We finished with the shrimp toast, which was so balanced and then had a little flare with its kick. So good. There were so many more things to try, but no more room in our bellies. 

Last note, don't miss the restrooms and their fun whimsical art. 

Until next time!

We just dined here for dim sum and I must say this is the only dim sum place I'd return to.  The restaurant is clean!  I've been to some dim sum places in Bradenton and even Chinatown NYC, and it makes a difference when the restaurants and carts are presentable.  We were seated in the cool green room in the back and were greeted immediately by servers and carts full of delectable treats to taste.  The spicy sauce is good on everything, chinese broccoli is fresh and tasty, beef/noodle entree was especially good, all of the dim sum was prepared well; no complaints.

Meijer has the vaccine figured out! My husband and I registered early online with Meijer pharmacy. What they do is call you when you are eligible and they have vaccine available. My husband and I both got the text from Meijer only 2 days after we became eligible. You can pick your appt time. My husband got his shot on the same day he got the text. I got mine next day. So easy. I had no line or wait and they immediately schedule my second vaccine appt. I am so grateful. 

This Meijer is large and I like to shop veggies here. The fruit is always fresh and the prices are good. I can find hard to find things like oyster mushrooms here. The store carries almost anything you need, including alcohol. Today, I picked up BOGO ribs and rotisserie chicken. Shelves are well stocked. 

The staff wears masks and hand sanitizer is available. Most of the patrons wear masks but not all and mask wearing is not enforced. Good news is that they offer curbside pickup, too, which I have not used. 

There is a full service pharmacy on site as well. They carry a full range of household goods and decor. Prices are reasonable. 

The parking lot is large and sprawling and can be hard to maneuver during peak hours.

My favorites of the night: Masu Nigiri $12, Issan Hamachi (most popular dish) $20, and Japanese Pumpkin $14.

The $28 Laksa was good, mussels and shirmp + roe in curry sauce.  I might have been curried out from the Japanese Pumpkin appetizer.

The $28 Sake Yaki was a little disappointing.  There was nothing outstanding about this dish.  It was basically fried salmon on a bed of mashed potatoes.

The cocktails were not very appealing to my taste buds.  I tried the Kinboshi, A Day in the Temple and the Python's Pearl.

The hostess informs you up front about the automatic 20% tip that is added to the bill.  Service was good, so we would have tipped at least 20% anyhow.

For the upscale pricing, I was expecting more from the main dishes.  Where they really shine is with the nigiri and I would rather stick with those than venture more into the top portion of the menu.

The restaurant is small with outdoor/enclosed-addition-to-the-restaurant seating available.  Reservations recommended.

.|\---/|
| o_o |
.\_^_/..2021

I'm really hoping this Chipotle will iron out their kinks because it has only been here for a few months. This first time I was here a few months ago the lady argued with me and my boyfriend because he called the corn salsa "corn." 

This time, THEY WERE OUT OF CHIPS! How does a Chipotle run out of chips?! One of the main reasons I come here is for the fresh guacamole and chips so I was highly disappointed. I don't know how it can get any worse....but it did, my brown rice that was in the bowl was slightly undercooked. It had that hard underlying taste.

I was looking for a good gumbo restaurant while in NOLA, and my friend delivered. I ran into him at the conference we were both attending; small world. 

Gumbo Shop is a little restaurant in the French Quarter with nice retro interiors. I ubered here, but I figured parking here would have been tough. 

Prices seemed pretty reasonable. I got the Seafood Okra Gumbo (about $10, I believe.) My friend and his girlfriend loved their dishes too. I'd totally recommend this place and will definitely come back.

I love the feel of this place. So chill right in the middle of Bourbon street! This is a great place to come and just hang out. Grab a drink at the bar and listen to some good music. I've had cafe au lait and beignets here. Pretty good for Nola! I've also stopped through a few times while on Bourbon Street to grab a table in the patio area to listen to a song or two. I love the statues of the music greats at the entrance! Super cool charm and history here.

West Co's 24/7 breakfast/drunk @3am place.

The only reason I go here is because it's 30 sec from my ex-bf's place. This is always where we go the "morning after". Some FWB couples smoke a cig, we get pancakes.

It's legit. I do like the atmosphere. It's clean. It's a "down home cookin'" looking sort of place. It kind of looks like some of the places you'd find out in Colorado. Lodge looking, ya know? I like it. The waitresses are pretty meh. Hit or miss. There's one waitress I ADORE who has to be like, 70, and she dyes her hair blond and wears big obnoxious pink bows but she is sweet as cherry pie and incredibly quick and efficient. And actually seems to care about her customers. A couple others aren't bad. The rest couldn't give two craps about you. They have attitude. Look tired and can't be arsed to be there. Ex-bf explained it best: "I think the waitresses here are in a prison work program." Yeah...looking around I could totally see some of these chicks having spent time in the slammer, and this is their first job since entering the halfway house. You really have to be there to know what I'm talking about. You'd be able to pick them out. But who knows.

All I know is that service is typically slow and apathetic for us. Eh. 

Food is pretty good, but I've only really ever gotten pancakes, and my biggest gripe is that they only have maple syrup. So if you get the strawberry pancakes, there is some strawberry glaze on it, so that's okay. But my apple pancakes this morning were full of apple chunks but not enough glaze, and I wasn't about to taint them with the wrong flavored syrup, so they were kinda dry. Hate to say it, Uncle Bills, but take a hint from IHOP. If you're gonna have multiple flavored pancakes, follow through with the syrup. Jus' sayin'.

If you're out in West Co and craving breakfast food at an odd hour and don't want to go somewhere commercial, go here

(There is also one 2 minutes from me, but I've only been there once. The Kingshighway one actually doesn't seem to have as much on its menu. But it's fine. Gets the job done. Maybe I have to start hosting the booty calls at my place so I can have an excuse to go to the KH one and write a review =])

We decided to try Taj Mahal in Metairie for a birthday dinner. We arrived for the opening time of 5:30pm but they did not open the door until 5:40. They promptly seated us and took a beverage order. They returned with one of the drinks wrong, and then returned again with a hot drink that was supposed to be cold. The sprite and coke tasted weird to us....

There were 6 of us from age 3-53 and we each found things on the menu that we wanted to try. We had Naan as an appetizer, it came with 2 sauces and everyone agreed that it was tasty.
The little ones ordered white rice, and the garden salad. The salad was supposed to be tomatoes, carrots and cucumbers....they substituted cabbage for the cucumbers. I asked about the cucumbers and they said they were out but there would be no charge for salad. 
The rest of the dishes were delicious! We had lamb and chicken dishes. All dishes were spicy but we expected that. The mango chicken is mild if you are looking for something less spicy. I wanted a vegi dish so I tried the Gobi Manchurian and let me tell you, my mouth was on fire!!!
For dessert we wanted Kulfi (Indian style icecream) but they were out. We tried the Kheer (rice pudding) and it was ok. We also tried Gulab Jamun (milk balls in rose syrup) they are not something we would order again but it was fun to try new things.

As I started to step down off of the bus at the corner of 19th & Chestnut, I pondered where I might be able to catch a quick bite of food before meeting a friend to see a play at Plays and Players. I don't have much time, so something quick would be awesome. I don't feel like anything too fancy, so something casual and cheap would be nice. Perhaps the deity of your choosing would send me a sign and guide me to a place that satisfies these requirements. I look up as the bus doors close behind me and hear a cherubic swell of harmony as a beam of light from the heavens illuminates the sign of none other than Qdoba.

Turns out I was being guided by the Greek god of mediocrity. My steak burrito was was adequate, not a hecatomb (in the most classical sense) of meat, but enough. Not the ambrosia of the gods, but worth the $6 dollars I paid for it.

My main issue, the factor that decreases my rating from a kingly 3 stars to a meager 2, is the fact that they sell a number of drinks in plastic bottles yet have no recycling bin. For shame, Qdoba.

People know that I love QDOBA and I'm thrilled to have them so close to my house.  The crew are always friendly and helpful...  Maybe too helpful?  They give my wife whatever she wants, but it's just so challenging to close that tortilla...  The newer pricing model from when they reopened a few years ago is one set price for all toppings.  Maybe my wife should specify she'll want one of everything...   I dunno...  I don't know if I've ever eaten here though, it's usually just a quick pickup and I'm back home.

After being turned away from brunch at Luke, which we were told was completely booked, we stumbled across the street here to find that the restaurant was barely a third full for brunch, quite strange because the brunch menu and regular lunch menu looked great! Not to mention, the service was spectacular. Our waiter was very attentive without being bothersome.

I had the Benny! Benny! Benny! - essentially a sampler for eggs benedicts. This is a HUGE portion so definitely only order if you have the appetite. My favorite Benny was definitely the one with the ham. If I could order again, I would just get the regular ham Benedict rather than this sampler.

We were driving back to Washington DC from Manhattan. Although we've had a great lunch, I was dying for something sweet. This place was directly on our route home so worked out perfectly that way. I couldn't believe that we had found a place that offered such a unique and fun menu! My husband was initially drawn to the ice cream nachos and all the spiked flavors. Whereas I was excited just to have some good flavors to try.

Upon arrival, we were surprised to see that this window service ice cream shop, was actually part of a larger bar and Grill called splitz, I believe. Pretty cool! Also, it was huge! It even had a nice looking covered patio. If we stopped again, I totally be game to grab lunch before hand!

Back to the ice cream. My husband loved the bourbon butter pecan. I did a flight of four flavors and one of my very favorites was one of their seasonal flavors, French toast! It had awesome flavor and I really loved the chunks of French toast in it? I also really enjoyed the peanut butter flavor!

I noticed that they had a sale on their pints as well, so we grabbed one to go. It was the perfect thing to bring home to my dad who had been watching the kids all weekend. The flavor was caramel popcorn. Fingers crossed he lets me try a bite! LOL

Every beach needs a proper ice cream shop. 

And I wouldn't be me if I were not coffee hunting at the beach, so I was happy to learn this place will serve me a latte.

I really like the casualness of the shop.
The reggae vibe.
Music themed ice cream + coffee shop.

Latte was perfect, and yes the staff was fun.

Will certainly return, and may even try the ice cream.

omg the capitol pork is out of this world  and!!! they have fresh homemade crispy noodles.

sorry, im in boston land of bread with chinese?! WTH?

anyway, this is one dish ive never seen anywhere, and although ive been here dozens of times, i only get the capital pork.


yummmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm

I like Pollo Tropical a lot. It's a good alternative for fast food that's actually healthier than typical fast food. I love their 1/2 chicken with a large selection of dipping sauces with corn and rice & beans on the side. When I really want to eat healthier, then it's time to go with the skinless chicken breast. Very tasty. If chickens not your thing, Pollo Tropical also offers ribs and pulled pork as well. They are pretty good as well.

The first time I ate there, I paid for my soup and waited 25 minutes while watching others who had arrived after me, recieve their food almost immediately.  I then politely asked if my soup would be ready soon. The man yelled to me with an annoyed look in his face. "It'll BE ready in a few minutes!"  Five minutes later he hands it to me, and it was 50% frozen. I politely sent it back, pointing out the problem, and he flipped out on me.  He yelled at me in front of everyone, giving others the impression that I was the one at fault and eventually he refunded my money.

Two months later I was walking by, didn't see the unfriendly man in the kitchen so i decided to order chicken soup, which I ate and even gave a piece to my small dog that was with me.  30 minutes later, at home, my dog and I both commenced a three day long food poisoning illness.  

I won't be returning to this place that doesn't even know how to correctly spell 'Boss' in Spanish. PATHETIC.

It's that 'yeah!'

Just because i'm into this Yelp life, does not mean i know of everything there is to know about whats happening in my city, and in that quest to acquire more knowledge, even my friends, at times, end up putting me on game.

Celebrating a good friend's birthday, we were invited to join in on a 'family-style' feast at Red's Chinese, which we did make reservations for. Never hearing of it before, i was a bit skeptical when Chinese was brought up for dinner, but coming from this gal, i should've known better. I am ashamed to have even had a spec of doubt about it. That little concern quickly vanished. As soon as you hit the door, it hits you. The aromas had me tasting the air because i was convinced something would come of it.

They've got the fully open kitchen space, which i really like to see in restaurants. I marvel at the mechanics of how some kitchens are ran at times. Plus an open kitchen typically means a very clean one, especially in newer joints. The lighting is really dim in here, like a click or two too dim. It took a minute for my eyes to adjust, but once my eyes and i were in agreement, the brain had to jump in and demonstrate some restraint because everything on the menu looked like a winner.

We were in a group of seven and top to bottom we ordered: 

The South Lake Porridge which tasted better than it smelled, i added a little Sriracha and it was cool. But my least favorite of everything.

(2) Craw Ragoon, which were very tasty, especially used in the mustard sauce.

The ginger scallion noodles which were also really good, i'd go for those again. 

General lee's chicken, which was my favorite but a strong second is the Kung Pao Pastrami, trust me, get both of those dishes when you come here you will be in amazement at how good they are.

The Bywater eggplant which we were worried would be too spicy because of the reviews, but they were perfect.

A couple rounds of drinks and the Chinese donut for dessert, and between seven people we were all full and the tab was only $170!

But let me get back to that chicken tho. My god, you can see the flavor in it once the dish hits your table, it has this glow, almost like that perfect plate of food on commercials, except in real life. Peanuts are a part of this dish, so if you have allergies, you may want to ask them to hold off on those, but for real goodness's sake, i hope you don't and can experience this dish as it is intended.

I am going back, second night in a row for that chicken. The menu changes daily so be sure to check the website or call before ordering if you're unsure as to what they're offering. Pick up and Delivery available, but do note they add .25 per dish for pickup and delivery.

Nicely done, i'm with it.

Classy grocery store. Wide selection of chips, salsa, snacks, beverages, chocolate and specialty items. 

I stumbled upon the aisle with a surprisingly impressive number of jarred marinara sauces! The neat part is that a lot of them are made in St. Louis. 

The fruit and veggie section is fairly undersized, but nice for a market of its stature. 

There's always a special treat near the registers. Last time, I grabbed a few amazingly delicious chocolate caramel squares.
Very Informative, took us to haunted places (that we were planning to see anyways) and gave us funfilled stories behind each place. Kept us listening all night!

I didn't try the sandwiches right after I purchased them, so my review may not be the most accurate. Since I had a few hours layover before my next flight, I decided to pull a crazy stunt and take the bus to Terminal F and check out Tony Luke's. The least amount of time it'll take to go back and forth between Terminal F is probably an hour- the bus ride over takes 10-15 minutes each way, then you have to order and wait for your food, and catch the next bus that comes. Also, it'll take 10-15 minutes to get your sandwich at Tony Luke's, even though the line isn't that long. I decided to try:

-Junior Italian Roast Pork (w/Sharp Provolone, Broccoli Rabe, $7.59, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tony-lukes-philadelphia-6?select=GB5t3XxaxRhk0IGYfW12TQ#GB5t3XxaxRhk0IGYfW12TQ): Eh, just ok. The pork was really salty, and it got a little soggy from the broccoli rabe, so not even popping it in the toasted oven helped. If you order this, I don't think provolone is the way to go. I would give this another try but eat it right away.
-Traditional Cheesesteak (w/Mild Provolone, $8.49, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tony-lukes-philadelphia-6?select=GB5t3XxaxRhk0IGYfW12TQ#5wQKfJkavtj6wcFMPFsyFA): I opted for provolone vs. whiz so it wouldn't get soggy, and I think I would've enjoyed this much more with the whiz. However, the bread was good, as was the steak, and I would order this again.

I didn't think that the cheesesteak or roast pork from Tony Luke's was amazing, and better than other cheesesteaks I've had in Philly. However, since I didn't eat the sandwiches right away, I'll have to hold off on my final opinion until then.

I thought this tour was phenomenal!!! We had originally booked our swamp tour with Dr. something or other and they were horrible so we jumped ship (no pun intended) and booked with Cajun Encounters. I am so glad that we did! 

We opted to take the bus from NOLA and was glad that we did. Our driver was so-so and he attempted to give us a tour from town out to the dock but sadly it was lacking (this is why I am deducting half a star...you will see why the other half star deduction...just keep reading). I think there was a language barrier and that kind of sucked. Oh, and he was 30 minutes late. That was a little frustrating. We took the first tour so this meant I could have spent an extra 30 minutes sleeping. Boo!

Once we got there we checked in and it was rather chaotic (the other half star deduction). You walk in and see a long line for tickets. The bad thing was that it is in the center of the gift shop. That made shopping rather difficult. This is probably not a good thing for revenue. The dumb this was that there was a register in the back...which was closed! 

The tour itself was great! Our guide was friendly and very knowledgeable. I really enjoyed him. He gave us a history of the swamp and offered tons of info about the elusive gators of the bayou. We saw a number of them and even got to hold a baby. How awesome is that? Let me tell you, it was pretty darn awesome! I highly recommend that you request a covered boat. The poor people with the open boat were sweating like you couldn't believe. I thought it was very interesting that we did not encounter one mosquito! Amazing! 

Overall, I highly recommend this tour! If we travel back to NOLA we will definitely be back!

Lee How Fook is a great old school school restaurant in Chinatown near Vine st.,
They Has been around for as long as I can remember, serving up great traditional chinese food. L.H.F. is a small spot with a quaint dining room and a friendly,  experienced wait staff. I've been a longtime customer and they even reckonize my voice over the phone.
