My favorite dishes are the salt baked spare ribs,  the fried chicken,  Clams in black bean sauce and the kung pao chicken. 
 Over the years I have never had a bad meal, or a bad dining experience or felt like I was overcharged. They do however have a loyal following and sometimes it is hard to get a seat.
 If you're looking for a good old traditional Chinese food this is your go to the spot.

I've been wanting to try The BAO since it opened. They did a nice job on the remodel and the space is dimly lit, sparse, and kind of sexy. There was a single TV behind the bar and I think it was intentionally black & white. During my time there the movies on the screen were Little Shop of Horrors and Ferris Bueller's Day Off. These are two movies I could sit and watch in black & white with no sound forever. I met a friend for an early weekday dinner and neither of us were that hungry so we decided to share the Taiwanese Dumplings and the Soft Shell Crab Bao. The Taiwanese Dumplings are filled with chicken and vegetables and come with a soy scallion dipping sauce. They were very well cooked and had lots of nice crispy edges. My dinner date isn't an Asiaphile, as I am, and doesn't eat quite as many dumplings as I do. She thought they were the best she'd ever had and I thought they were just the best I had this week. The bao was actually a clever concept to make into an expensive designer sandwich. The bun has a slight sweetness and a good chew from being steamed and really holds up as a sandwich bun. The soft shell crab was good albeit slightly heavy on the breading. They do not include any kind of side dish with the bao. I felt they could at least put something a little colorful on the plate even as an afterthought but that was just my opinion. The cocktail menu was quite inventive and intricate but I'm not much of a drinker. All in all The BAO is clever and pretty well executed for a designer sandwich restaurant with an Asian twist in Clayton.

Our dinner was great! I had only heard good reviews and now I know why. The restaurant itself was very nice and the live piano music added nice ambiance.

The prime rib roast did not disappoint and the fall savings prix fixe was just right. I would definitely go back and this time order off the regular menu to enjoy MORE of the delicious prime rib.

I think the only disappointment was the tiny "family style" side portions. We had a table of 10 and ordered 4 sides and each person only had about 3 green beans, 2 fries, a tablespoon of mashed potatoes and creamed spinach. I would suggest ordering more sides or for the restaurant to tailor their sides to the size of the table.

Cajun Encounters ... matching tourists with gators since 19somethingsomething

They have a pickup route in NoLa so if one misses it, one can still get to a later stop and get on. Its a pretty comfortable ride to the swamp. You'll get to see (while in the shuttle bus) the abandoned Six Flags along the way.

Fair warning - BYOB. There is a little convenience shop where you pay fully for your ticket, but no booze. And the food gave some people stomach pains. But you can find various gator jerky. 

There are modular bathrooms that flush and have running water.

The swamp tour is pretty cool, you get to go under one of the lift bridges (?, they don't draw up in the middle, but lift straight up via four gears). You'll see grass lands, swamp lands, old trees, houses on stilts, and maybe some swamp folk. If you're lucky, you'll see some animals and stuff. We saw a baby gator, a big gator, a tiny raccoon, an angry raccoon, an egret, and a heron. 

It might drag on for a while so don't drink too much - you'll be dying for the bathroom. Fun! Definitely don't need to do it again.

Good place to get a donut but it is a little bit annoying that it requires staff assistance to do so.  Also, the layout of the store is a little strange.  The vegetables are towards the back of the store and not arranged in a way that makes it easy to shop.  Unlike other Schnuck's stores, the pharmacy is beyond the registers so you can't really have them ring up a couple of items from elsewhere in the store if you're combining errands.

Always a great experience at Culvers! The custard is excellent, the burgers are some of the best around, and the prices are right. The staff here is friendly but this place can get busy and they can get overwhelmed. The parking lot is usually full and there are usually cars lined up around the drive through so plan ahead.

I hate to call this fast food because that would put Culver's in the category with McD, BK, and Taco Bell... and those don't even compare to Culver's. Rather, this is an Quickly Prepared Eating Experience.

Come grab a burger or get your kiddos some frozen custard (ITS NOT ICE CREAM) on the way home. Oh, and the root beer is incredible, best as a root beer float!

If you haven't been to a Culver's yet, definitely put this on your list!

The ambiance and live music here is fantastic. The band was pleasant and not overbearingly loud.

However the whole "you have to be out in 1.5 hours" is a major turn off. I could understand if people were sitting around not ordering but if you're ordering food and drink that makes no sense.

The food was decent but nothing to write home about. The service however was terrible. Since everything is served tapas style the food comes out as it's ready. Unfortunately my tacos took so long that everyone was finished eating and I still didn't have my food. 

Then I saw the table next to me (which arrived 30 min after us) served not one but two taco plates. When I asked the server what's going on, she gave me a really bitchy attitude and acted as though she was talking to a child. She goes "yeah like I said the kitchen is backed up." To which I said yes but not enough She did take them off the bill but her attitude was so off putting and condescending I didn't even care at that point. 

The tacos still took another 15 min after that. 

Also they have 2 different websites with different menus which is confusing. I went there based on one menu and got something different. Annoying.

I thought about writing something witty and entertaining but then I read what Scott S. wrote and his review was such a slam dunk, I figure why bother? 

My one word contribution: Amazeballs.

I have come in to this Save-On Foods several times now. The thing is it is a little bit more of a walk on cold days from my hotel than other stores.
However, Once you get there it is worth the walk.
 This is a large Grocery store,complete with everything you could ever want.

It even has a lovely little cafe inside for food and drink.
The thing that I have found the best is the cosmetic section.
Which of course is the shampoo and lotions and such.
I needed some important items and every where else was so high priced.
I do not have a Save-on card(which gives discounts) but, the lovely lady in front of me in line allowed me to use hers.
That was so very good of her!

They have a pharmacy ,as well as a huge cheese and deli selection and bakery.
They do not charge you for your bags so that is awesome as well.
I could of gone crazy buying all sorts of things.
But, then you have to carry them all back your hotel.
Great place to come to for your needs when you are downtown ED.

Brennan's is known for their service and for the creative Chef Slade and team. I sat at the bar while my table was being prepared and stuck up a conversation with the amazing bartender Lou. She was so hospitable and showed me different jazz places. 

Once I was seated for dinner I felt like I had stepped back into an older time of dining without any rush. The waiters there took care of everyone attentively. There was never a moment where I was waiting on them to come back. I also didn't feel like they didn't allow me Space. There was a nice balance to it all. 

I started off with their fresh hot bread and a Vietnamese soup dumpling they served complimentary. The duck was just delicious and for dessert I had to get the bananas fosters since it was created there and is a table side dessert. Worth it!

It's a Walgreens...but with a deceptively large parking lot so that's pretty helpful since this is a really crowded section of Magazine.  

The staff seems competent and no one cursed me out so that's a plus. (Yes, this has happened at other Walgreens in the city)  The store is clean and well-stocked...

If it was closer, I'd probably stop in more often

Get the basil lemonade!

What a great happy hour place!!! This place is like a more spacious version of Alpha/Devils Alley. And they actually have semi healthy and cheap appz! Also, the specialty cocktails are just $5...and the basil lemonade one was amazing!!! Also, the avocado fries were sooo good, never had them before, but can't wait to try them again. Plus the chicken tenders were some of the lightest and moistest...ever! They were not super greasy or covered in yucky bread coating. Loved them. Although the french and honey mustard dipping sauces were pretty terrible, the BBQ was great. Wasn't too much of a fan of the edamame because it was swimming in beer juice, so it wasn't as dry and salty as I like. The place got PACKED around 5:30-6 so make sure to get there early to grab a table. Plus, a great crowd of younger professionals, and they have big TVs for the sports liking people.

PS. There is also a row of unisex bathrooms which is kinda unqiue!

What an amazing meal! I'm so glad I stopped in here. The retro decor was nice to see, the tables were clean, the service was fast, and my waitress was AMAZING! 

The eggs weren't cooked with anything on them, yet were the best scrambled eggs I think I've ever had in my life! The grilled butter biscuit, was to die for, and my sausage was cooked to perfection!

You won't be disappointed if you stop in! I love that they're open 24/7!

I've been involved at several events at I House and have always had a good experience.  I House is SUCH a cool environment.  It attracts academics and lovers of the arts from all over the world.  As a result events at I House are wide a varied.  The facility is a bit out of date, but adequate.  They have a auditorium that provides an intimate environment for shows.  They also have a large patio and several common areas and rooms that can be used for various purposes.  I've really enjoyed the occasions I've had to go  there.  The only drag is parking, which is horrible in University City.  You've pretty much GOT to park in a parking garage.  Suck it up and pay the price.

I loved the Grape & Strawberry Phosphate, it was very good.  And, they had a great selection of jelly beans----I didn't try any of their ice cream sundaes, but it would be a fun place to take a group and eat sundaes/milkshakes I imagine.

Came here with my colleague for dinner after a nice OTF workout! It was pretty quiet for a Wednesday night but we didn't complain. 

Our server was pretty awesome recommended many dishes on the menu. They came out with some bread and olive oil with pesto. 

My colleague had the house taco plate and she thought it was average, rice and beans were bland. I had the seafood dish with shrimp, white fish, mussels, sweet potato, rice all in an awesome coconut broth topped with chopped almonds. Let me tell you this dish was phenomenal and is a must try! Loved every single ingredient in it! If you like seafood you will appreciate this dish!! Highly recommended! It has a Latin name that I couldn't recall but look at the picture and judge for yourself!!

Enjoy!!

Adorable. Sensual. Funky. Classy.

This gastropub in the heart of Frenchmen street is the perfect getaway from the ruckus and debauchery of Bourbon street. They do not serve pizza nor daiquiris here (thank god)...

Tourists: If you are looking for a real New Orleans Jazz experience...this is your place. The drinks are reasonably priced, stiff, and tasty.

This is an intimate (small space, compact seating) venue - small but mighty.  I understand why they require dinner reservations and a limited seating time frame; there's likely always a wait for folks to get in.  But once we were there, we didn't feel rushed at all by our server.  In fact, the pacing of our drinks/food arriving was relaxed. 

Given that a food order is required for seating, I was worried about the food quality, but we really enjoyed all the items we tried.  In fact, my two companions said it was their favorite meal while in New Orleans.  The atmosphere is lively and the musicians (Royal Street Windin' Boys) were outstanding; in general our 1.5 hours here was an awesome start to a great evening enjoying the music on Frenchmen Street.

The Food:
- The mac & cheese: do yourself a favor and just get it.  Creamy goodness, with a perfect bread crumb topping.
- Tofu Rice Bowl: a surprising delight.  You MUST order extra kimchee when getting this dish.
- Fries: crispy and flavorful with feta cheese.
- Fish Tacos: good, but not their specialty.
- Pork Belly: I personally don't eat pork belly, but my companion said it was tasty.

Drinks:
- The Muse is a lovely cocktail (I'm a gin and St. Germain lover).
- The Spagetti Western was fabulous....and boozy.

I mean...what is there to say about BDubs that hasn't been said already? Once you've been to one, you've been to them all.  However, this location had a RIDICULOUS AMOUNT OF PARKING! Considering how packed it gets in here...that's definitely a bonus.   I came here to watch the 2015 National Champions BEAT ALABAMA!!!!  *GOOOO BUCKEYES...ROLL TEARS!!! *It was so crowded without a table in sight.  There's tons of TV'S, The service was EXCELLENT!  My food came fast, my drink never got dry and I left full, happy and buzzed.  That makes for a pleasant Bdubs experience!  The END!

I've been to Brio many times for cocktails, dinner parties and dates. They've never failed to deliver good food, service and great drinks. Brio is located in the Plaza Frontenac complex. Very spacious offering a ton of outdoor seating options, a full bar area with cocktail tables and of course their large open dining room. Service is pleasant. 

Brio is perfect for large parties, meetings and happy hour. They serve a delicious array of seafood, pastas, salads and wines. Dessert and cognac selections are just so-so. I highly recommend the Salmon, Tilapia and Shrimp & Crab Cakes dishes...all are real crowd pleasers.

Thank me later,
~Christy

I'm a fan of Fare, but my last visit is causing me to reevaluate how much I like Fare. Don't get me wrong, I love the concept of a restaurant that serves organic, local food. The food is fine, the beer list is good and the mimosas were mostly champagne with a splash of orange juice. My last visit was just a little off-putting. 

For one, I just found myself struggling to pick something off the brunch menu on my most recent visit. I was feeling an omelet but neither the meat or veggie special of the day did anything for me. The meat omelet consisted of salmon and lox, and the veggie omelet consisted of mushrooms. I ended up going with the breakfast burrito even though I didn't want that massive of a meal. 

The southwest burrito was stuffed with eggs, pulled pork, black beans, cheddar, pico de gallo and topped with chili. The burrito itself was tasty and very enjoyable. I just remembered it being bigger and coming with a side salad. I know I just said I didn't want a massive meal, but it's never a good thing when portions get smaller and sides are removed. 

My second issue was the service. I was there with a large group after the Hot Chocolate Run. Everyone has certain expectations of large group dining scenarios, and I always enter them with an extra drop of patience. While our food came within 30 minutes of ordering, it was hard to get a server to even stop by our table to take our drink orders. Some beverages were forgotten, some extra beverages were added to the bill and some food items just came out wrong. With the number of races scheduled each year in the Fairmount area, one would think Fare would be prepared and thriving with large group brunches. Although my group dining service expectations are never high, I was fairly disappointed with the service we actually got. 

I still like Fare and would absolutely go back, I just need to bump them down on my Fairmount priority list.

I reviewed my previous review when I saw one of friends visited and was surprised at my score being only 3 star here. Not ready to go 5 star yet but after a few more visits after my first review I certainly can say with certainty we got us a winner here. Son loved the burgers, even for breakfast and I stick with eggs. 

We got in the habit of paying it forward here, especially around the holidays to continue a  Waffle House tradition. 

Will stop in again sometime when we hit the area.

Dots hits the spot. So stop at Dots. Pick it up and trot.

Best frozen custard evah!!!!! (Yes that is my Oprah imitation) I am saying this as someone who has frequented Wisconsin's famed custard stands and as a non native of St Louis so there.

My sister intro-ed me shortly after moving to St Lou. For those of you not in the know, Ted Drewes is the famous home of the concrete aka crete, a custard mixture so thick they serve it to you upside down.

She is a fan of the cretes where they stick in a whole piece of pie (her fave is pumpkin) into your creation and mix it into bliss. I am a devotee of the fox treat crete with hot fudge, raspberries and macadamia nuts. I also like the Hawaiian crete with pineapple, banana, coconut and macadamia nuts. A plain chocolate chip crete or a chocolate shake will do in a pinch. 

I know her kids are all born and bred Ted Drewes addicts and frankly it makes me proud. 

Whenever I am in town this is a must stop. You are crazy if you live nearby and never stop in.
It's all about crabs soft shell blue and rock I had a fried softshel sandwich very good they fry the whole crab    Hush puppies where so good I also had a cup of crab chowder soup delis.

Had dinner with a few friends tonight at Capdeville. I love the atmosphere here. I always run into people I know and we just have a great time here talking. Its truly a cool spot.  I love the burgers here! I had the Capdeville Burger tonight. Au Poivre Sauce, Crispy Onions, Bibb Lettuce, Gruyere Cheese, Roasted Garlic Aioli = Yummy goodness. I absolutely enjoyed this sandwich along with their tasty well seasoned fries that I could sit there and eat for hours. 

Staff was friendly and great! I love this place.

The owner/bartender could not have been more friendly, sweeter, or more welcoming. She made the experience what it was. It's obvious she works hard to make sure her patrons feel at home and come back. It's a place to go when you want to strike up a conversation after a lonely day. The beer selection was great - both bottles and draft. We did chicken and kimchi fries. The fries were delicious - would recommend. The wings were also good but not the very best (or most flavorful) Korean fried chicken I've had. The wings were large and juicy and portion was generous though! The sauce maybe just didn't live up to some of our Atlanta expectations, which are very high. That being said, we certainly didn't leave disappointed. 
There's also a huge sauce bar with everything from ranch to an array of sweet and savory asian sauces, spicy mayo, eel sauce, ketchup,  you name it!! That was pretty cool :) Overall, great vibes. Wonderful neighborhood bar/restaurant.

I've been wanting to try Indo for a long time and I was so happy I've been able to stop by for takeout during quarantine. The pickup experience was really easy and the food did not disappoint! I ordered the short rib khao soi which was so full of flavor! The tenderness of the short rib and the complexity of the curry was so delicious. There's so many things on the menu I'm wanting to try. Will definitely be back soon!

I'm sure there's a battle of the beignets and I wasn't as big of a fan of the ones here. They are denser and slightly crispy on the edges, which may be exactly why some people prefer them. I enjoyed that the breakfast came with french bread and it satisfied our appetites. However, the real pull of this place is the courtyard. 

The courtyard has plenty of seating and live jazz music which is great ambiance when in New Orleans or anytime really. There's also a small daiquiri bar right next door in the same courtyard, in case you want to be boozy at breakfast. The food was ok but the area made me happy and started our trip out on the right foot.

When I first moved here back in 2010, we'd come to Mafiaoza's about every other month. They had a two for one special on Tuesday night that we would go to. The pizzas are huge and pretty good. The price can be more than a regular pizza place, but the quality is there. After about a 3ish year hiatus, we stopped by there on a Thursday night to meet a friend from out of town.

It's crazy how much 12 South has grown over the past couple years. I remember when this was about it on the strip. They can still hold their own against the new places. We parked out back and entered through the rear and saw the hostess for a seat on the patio because the summer temperature was tolerable. Our server greeted us and got our drink orders.

We also decided on ordering some apps to share for dinner, the bruschetta, there homemade seasoned focaccia bread topped with gorgonzola cheese & Italian diced tomato relish ($8.50). We ordered the fried cheese ravioli sticks, seasoned ravioli stuffed with an assortment of cheeses and fried, served with marinara sauce ($9.75). Lastly we got the cheese fries, steak fries with melted provolone, mozzarella, & bacon ($8.50). 

My favorite from this was the loaded fries with ranch. The portions on the appetizers are huge. I liked the bruschetta, but with it being focaccia bread, it can be a lot bread. I like with its more on a toast point. The mushrooms in the toppings had a very hard, almost chewy skin. The fried cheese was yummy. Three came to an order and you could make a meal out of two of them. I've missed this place and will have to keep it in mind the next time we are in the area.

My sister's friend wanted us to come here since she had a gift card she wanted to use up, so after months of crazy schedules, we were finally able to make it happen.

We called ahead to make sure we could sit in the bar area since it was a holiday weekend and it turns out it actually wasn't super busy for a Saturday night. Our server was attentive and checked in with us often. Drinks were between $13-$15/each and appetizers were like $10-$15/$17 I think.
 
3 of us ordered the slider trio app and 1 got the filet flatbread. I personally enjoyed the filet mignon slider but wasn't a fan of the crab cake one. As for drinks, they didn't have any on their signature menu that struck our fancy but they were very accommodating and made us drinks we wanted.

Price wise, 4 drinks and 4 appetizers ran about $115 (before tip). I'd come back again but I'd probably stick to the steak vs the seafood; the steak is where they really shine (it is a steakhouse after all!)

My French may be la horrible, but my love of French food just keeps getting stronger and stronger. So when Edmonton's newest French restaurant, The Marc, opened it doors downtown I was one of the first to grace its doors. A spacious, simplistic and clean decor, allows the marvelous food that exits the tiny kitchen to be the real star of this space. The menu is small but each item reads like a work of art. From the scrumptious steak tartar, the awe inspiring duck confit to the perfectly seared skin on the arctic char, this place impresses. The Marc has now been around for over a year and I have been there 5 or 6 times, each time I am truly delighted by my meal. If you ever are in need of some serious cheering up, nothing says comfort food like the foie gras truffle frites with a glass of pinot nior, followed by the to-die-for beignets. Pi de resistance!
So with a big Merci to the Marc, I invite all to don its doors. 

Oh, and seriously. Get the Beignets!

Great way to get a little NOLA culture.

So I went on this tour expecting to see alligators in a swap, but got so much more out of it. The tour started as soon as we got picked up from our hotel and hit the highway. Instead of just being our bus driver he actually was pointing out different sites on the way to the swap, showing us some of the devastation from Katrina first hand.

Once we got on the tour we were given a tour of the swap by would you could say is a "Swamp Person" which made it pretty interesting since he lived on the swamp for his whole life.

If you all you are are looking for alligators I do not recommend this tour but a great chance to check out some NOLA culture.

When you first walk in to the restaurant you're greeted by a grand display of wines in the wine room. The restaurant is well lit and decorated in shades of red, yellow and orange, making it feel warm and inviting. On arrival we were greeted promptly and seated in a location of our choice in the restaurant. Although we were the first patrons to arrive for dinner at 5:30 PM, the dining room quickly filled up within the half hour for a busy dinner service. 

After some brief explanations from our server we decided to start our meal with the Samaki Harrah ($16): catch of the day in a red pepper coriander sauce. That night the restaurant was featuring cod and it was cooked soft and flaky. The red pepper sauce was flavourful without overpowering the dish and the size was just right to prepare us for our entrees. 

My boyfriend ordered the Lahem Mishwee Platter ($26), which features two skewers of AAA Alberta Spring Creek Ranch grilled beef tenderloin. All the meat entrees at Parkallen are served with your choice of two sides, and he decided on the Lebanese fattoush salad and sauteed fresh vegetables. The skewers of beef were well seasoned and tender, but the star of the plate happened to be the fattoush salad. The tangy dressing over the salad mixed with the salty, crunchy pita crisps made it both refreshing and full of flavour. To this day my boyfriend always reminds me that the fattoush at Parkallen is the best salad he has ever had. Now if only I could get my hands on the recipe...

For myself I chose to go with the Spring Rack of Lamb ($45) with tabbouleh salad and Lebanese rice. When I'm out for dinner and lamb is on the menu, I will always order it. Parkallen grilled these ribs beautifully as they came out juicy, tender, and the light seasoning allowed for the flavour of the lamb to come through. Of the two sides I really enjoyed the tabbouleh salad, as it was crunchy, tangy, and full of flavour. The rice wasn't anything to write home about, but it was subtly sweet with thinly sliced almonds and hints of cinnamon. 

Our dinner ended with some cheesecake ($10) and caramel pecan flan ($10), both of which were a nice way to end the meal. The desserts at Parkallen are brought in from elsewhere, but I wish they had something available that they make in house. 

Throughout the dinner we were very well taken care of by our server, and other staff were equally as attentive. Our glasses of water never reached half empty but the servers weren't overbearing either. As Parkallen describes themselves as a Lebanese and Mediterranean fine dining restaurant, it is definitely reflected in their service and pricing. This is not a restaurant you'll be frequenting often, but I would recommend it for celebrations and special occasions. On the other hand, a portion of the menu is dedicated to pizzas made in house. Perhaps it is time for another visit, as I'm curious to see what they have to offer!

I wanted to love Palace of Asia, but I can only give three stars since I either loved or really didn't care for the dishes that we ate.

We started with the Mixed Appetizer for Two, which I didn't love at all. Everything on the plate was battered and fried. The only thing I really liked from this appetizer was the Harabhara Kabab (spinach ball). Yes, that was deep fried as well, but it wasn't coated like a McDonald's chicken nugget, like the rest of the things on the plate. I mean, really, you take a potato slice and deep fry it? That's it? No, thanks.

For our entrees we got the Tandoori Mixed Grill and the Panir Masala (note that I actually ORDERED the Palak Panir, which is a spinach-based dish, but what came out was the Panir Masala, a tomato-based dish). We also got some garlic naan.

I didn't love the Tandoori Mixed Grill as much as my husband did. I really liked the chicken, but I couldn't get on board with the lamb (it was ground lamb, and to me, it looked like sausage). The shrimp was also pretty tough to chew.

I have to say that my favorite part of the entire meal was dipping the garlic naan into the Panir Masala. While I wasn't super fond of the cheese cubes in the sauce (because of the texture), they were OK in moderation. The flavors, though, with the garlic naan and the tomato sauce...mmmm, that was good.

So, in the end, dinner was OK overall, with three components combining to make two stand-out dishes (the spinach balls and the tomato based cheese cube dish/garlic naan). I don't know if I'll be making any desperate attempts to return, but I don't regret going.

Also - this place is f'ing GIGANTIC.

The end!
Checking out is sooooo sloooooow.  Everytime I go, there is one person at the check out, and even if there is only one person ahead of me, it take forever.

We are so glad we found this cute little place! I absolutely love the decor - it's so comfy and calming, I wish my house looked like this. It's such a relaxing atmosphere, even though it was quite busy on a Sunday afternoon. Kava, coffee, and tea are all available. I'm looking forward to coming here again one evening for some kava and lounging on one of the couches. 
I ordered a small cold brew coffee ($3) instead of kava since I needed to focus on studying. I was pleased with it, but my boyfriend ordered a large hemp tea lemonade ($5) and felt it was rather bitter. Anyhow, they have some desk areas with charging stations and desk lamps, so if you want to study this is a great place. 
We'll be back here again soon, I'm sure of it. Great place in Seminole Heights!

My husband and I had dinner here Saturday night and loved it.  We had the General Lee's Chicken, which was sticky, sweet, and crunchy, Kung Pao Pastrami which was savory and spicy and the Mu Shu Pork which was tender, juicy and perfect rolled up in light, yummy pancakes.  

It was all absolutely delicious! 

There was an off the menu app - Tuna Poke which was also crazy good.  There were fried lotus flowers in the dish - those things are addictive!

The portions are large so we had plenty of food to take home.   We definitely over ordered but everything sounded so delicious that we couldn't decide.  Not to worry though, we snacked on leftovers yesterday and I finished off the chicken for lunch today.

I also had some sort of tea daiquiri that was sweet but also refreshing.  I'm not normally much of a daiquiri fan, but this was very different.  

And the service was great. Our waiter was super attentive and was able to describe every dish in great detail. 

We'll definitely be going back as I am looking forward to trying the rest of the menu.

The Korean food here is pure awesomeness. 

Must order the sundubu jjigae (Korean stew) here! It's a hot and spicy soup made with uncurdled dubu (tofu), vegetables, mushrooms, onion, scallions, various combination of tasty seafood and gochujang (chili powder). The soup is made and eaten right in the serving bowl, which is typically made of solid stone. Served with a raw egg to be cracked into the soup. It comes out still bubbling vigorously. You are also given a bowl of cooked white rice and several banchan (side dishes). The banchan are so addicting that you'll ask for seconds! A true Korean meal is never complete without banchan. And the ones here are crazy delicious. Also highly recommend their bbq meats. 

I worship this eatery greatly. You might as well stop reading this review and ask me about it in person. Because chances are that if you go here now, I will be there eating my sundubu and banchan!

I ate an early dinner at Brio on a Saturday evening.  I ordered the Pasta Alla Vodka (Ricotta-filled pasta, spicy tomato Parmesan cream sauce, crispy pancetta, basil.) My dinner date ordered the Tuscan Grilled Pork Chops with Mashed Potatoes on the side. The service was friendly and speedy. My water glass was kept filled and the bread here is always fresh and good. The pork chops were very well liked as was my pasta. The only thing I will say though is I felt the portion was extremely small for a $20 plate of pasta. They are always busy though. Clearly I'm in the minority. Be careful in that bar. A cougar might get you.

Oh yelp, you've steered me awry this time. When I went to El Rey, yelp had given this place 4.5 stars.  I was blown away by the stars, but not by the food.

The food isn't bad. The chips as a starter was actually really good. Tastes fresh, yet not oily at all. And when dipped into the green sauce on the table, it had the perfect amount of crunch and spice.

The rest of the food was just average. The menu was all over the place - I was looking for a Tinga burrito - not offered. However, there's Tinga fries! Wifey wanted a shrimp taco - not on the menu. But they did have shrimp fajitas! The waiter said the chef would be able to make it, but it's weird that it's not on the menu. So wife did the shrimp fajitas.

The fajitas came out quick, but came out incorrect. Wife requested her entree have the salad's sour cream on the side. They brought it out with sour cream on top, and an additional side of sour cream. No big deal, but later I was charged for the additional side. And they took her plate back to just take off the pieces of lettuce with sour cream. And yes, I said plate. Aren't fajitas usually served on skillets? Not here. Came out on a plate, already cooked. She noted her shrimp was grilled very well, but there wasn't too many pieces of shrimp. Lots of onions though.

My carnitas burrito came out ginormous, but it seemed short on carnitas too. And there's no sour cream on the burrito - I used my paid-for sour cream for that.  I only ate half as I was full from the chips. No sauce on top of your burrito either as some other places do with mole, tomatillo, or verde.  Not offered here.

Service was really friendly, and the place isn't too big (in a somewhat busy plaza), but I think the food leaves a lil more to be desired than I'd like.  And the prices aren't THAT great. Because of that, I probably wouldn't try this place again. Too many places in the area that offer Mexican, so onto the next one!!

This is the best thing to ever happen on Washington Avenue. And the worst thing EVER for a diet. My gym membership is going to have to start pulling double-duty.

E and I drove over on their opening night and had no trouble finding parking on this deserted stretch of Washington Ave. The wait was considerable, but you could see everyone hustlin their hearts out back in the open kitchen, and everyone had a smile on their face. The longer you wait, the more time you get to deliberate over the pastry cases. If you don't get a butterscotch blondie, though, just slap yourself in the face right now. It is possibly the most delicious blondie I've ever had, and I would even rate it higher than a fudgey chocolatey brownie. So rich, moist and sweet. I'm ashamed to say I ate almost all of it even after binge-ing on pizza. E only got a few bites. We also got an oreo marshmallow (just what it sounds like, and it was great!), and a maple vanilla pecan fudge. That thing was ridiculously good, too.

As for the pizza, I can say they've got our  business on lock for quite some time. The gluten-free crust is house made, not a frozen pre-formed tragedy, and I really enjoyed its texture. Slightly fluffy in the middle with a great cornmeal crunch on the bottom. The pizza sauce is perfection and they use good pepperoni. We also got a regular large white mushroom pizza. I had 2 slices of that... Good God it was so good. Super garlicky, tons of exotic mushrooms, and an excellent crust. This place rules. Long live Kermit's!

While visiting my old home of Tampa Bay, we decided to drop into this Fijian kava bar and cafe! We were so presently surprised to step into our nostalgia from our Fijian honeymoon in 2018! 

Wes, was the barista and he made the day! He served us a little kava ceremony, made me a bomb cortado and had great conversations! 

The ambience was very Fijian and authentic and brought us back to the Fijian islands! Awesome lounge couches, great books to read, essential oils flowing and so much more! 

We love this place and will tell everyone about it! Cannot wait to visit here from Atlanta again soon and hopefully move back one day soon!

As most people know, this place will set you back but we're all adults (age or maturity) and we all know upon walking in and seeing the gorgeous flower choices and shiny, clean and yummy fruit/veggie displays that our wallet/bank acct are about to lose $$$.

I'm a multiple market shopper.  I don't go to just one place...I'll go to one for produce/fruit, another for meat/fish, another for imported cheese and yet another for bread or hard to find/specialty drinks...Mind you I'm not a walking wallet but Whole Foods definitely has items everyone else doesn't or has higher quality ones.

tip: always grab the circular when you walk in.  It's got coupons you might need.  If not? put it back.

Top buys for me?  Almond milk (they have the bigger refrigerated container and the chocolate one is good), coconut water (hard to find in large sizes), peanut butter (i forget the brand but it's soo good), olive bar (so many choices, pricey but YUM)

tip: bring your own bag, you'll either get a 5 cent discount off your purchase or you can get a wood token instead to donate to a charity on display (last visit it was american red cross for haiti)

The Cheese steak and fries are excellent, came here two times while connecting through philly, the staff however is the lack of 2 stars.

Look I'm from Texas I don't eat many Cheesesteaks, but when I ask what should I order, I don't expect *That you order something* is the right response. 

The food quality is excellent and the Maryland fries are delicious. If your having a quick layover in Philly, grub here, but don't expect any service or friendliness from the staff and please dont give me that "it's philly" bull$#4. We are humans are should be treated to a higher standard than the local level of intelligence. 

Also the tables that you sit at in the food court be sure to use your own hand sanitzer and wipe your own tables, the bus boys/girls just stand around on their cell phones while you look at a dirty table and then them and they just continue to text instead of offering to clean you table. Good luck.

So after our experience at Pizza Rock (see my previous review), we were still on a hunt for Pizza. We ended up going to Olde Town Pizzeria (OTP) and were not disappointed. Very classy look on the inside with some interesting wall decor. While this plaza always has too many great places and not enough parking spots, tonight we were able to get a spot right up front and was seated within 5 minutes. 

So two things I really liked. The separate pickup window is actually really nice and right thre when you first go in. Also, they have a really cool coloring sheet for kids that is more challenging than most other places. It kept my son occupied the whole evening. 

We order the stuffed breadsticks and the thin style meat-lovers. Both were great. The pizza was good cold and was exceptional when I warmed it up the next day in a cast-iron skillet. Perfectly crispy crust.

Since we were looking for a new "pizza home," it seems we have found it.

Apparently Philly's new hotspot. I'm willing to try any noodle bar. Since this was my first time in Philly, I let my friend (who has lived there on and off for the past 4 years) choose.

Eats:
black garlic wings
brisket ramen
caramelized onion rangoon
miso ramen
pork pizza dumplings

I would probably give all the appetizers 5/5 but the bowls themselves 4/5. Miso ramen broth was different than any other miso ramen broth I've ever had before. I don't say this in a bad way. It was just different.

Of course I ordered the brisket ramen because it came with Asian-style brisket, kimchi, and a matzo ball. Just Korean-Japanese-Jewish fusion nbd. Don't worry about it.

We were surprised to find a restaurant that serves sichuan food so close to home. At first we dismissed it thinking that it was one of those restaurants that claim to serve sichuan food but actually don't serve anything close to that. But when one of my colleagues who is from main land China said it was really good, we got curious. The cool tingling sensation caused by sichuan pepper corns needs a bit getting used to. We didn't really like it at first but after trying a few sichuan entrÃ©es over 1-2years, we developed a liking for it.  We have a few favorites like Chongqing chicken, Ma Po Tofu, Dan Dan noodles to name a few. Definitely worth going if you want to try good sichuan food.

This is a pizza joint with some of the most non-Italian ambiance around. It's owned by a Lebanese family, and along with the big menu of 'Za you can order an extensive menu of Lebanese cuisine, which is delicious stuff, but I've never had it here. The place is decorated with giant hukkas, which are big, ornate pipes for smoking flavoured tobacco.  It's kind of cool. The service is friendly and fairly fast and the food is really high quality. The pizza's on the expensive side, but they're using lots of fresh mozzarella, homemade sauce and quality toppings. Also, if you like toasted cheese, they broil it a bit so your mozza comes golden brown and delicious. Did I mention the sauce?! It's soooo good, and they put lots on, unlike some places that only brush on a thin coat. It's their signature sauce and they want to make it memorable. I remember.

We ordered take out from here the other night.  We were pretty excited about take out sushi in the area so we gave it a shot.  The menu wasn't that impressive, kind of a boring selection, but we ordered a few rolls and the staff was friendly and the delivery prompt.  The rolls themselves weren't anything exciting, but were tasty enough.  We'll probably order from here again when we're too lazy to go out and get sushi.

Winner!  This place is a hit.  I couldn't get a reservation the entire weekend, because they were booked.  I can see why.  The view, for one, is amazing.  Have you heard the term Nashvegas?  You will see why if you come to the 34th floor and eat here.  The nightlife you can view from the top is stunning.  I came here for a medical conference, conveniently at this hotel, so I didn't have to go anywhere.  My colleague and I enjoyed dinner here twice in a row, because it was too good to pass up.  We had to scour the area for seating, and were lucky enough to get seats both nights at the bar and lounge area. 

They actually have two bars here, one inside and one on the outskirts.   The outer tables are most desirable, because you have amazing views from the restaurant out onto the city lights.  The last night, we sat at the outer bar, and my only gripe is the TV sets.  They are so high up your neck starts to hurt.  It was like sitting in the front row at the movie theater.  No one wants that!  I don't know why they didn't engineer those better.

Now the drinks....delicious!  I had the French martini, and it was sooo good!  They served it with those super fancy cherries, too. They aren't big, and they are not cheap.  So for one Old fashioned and a martini, it was $39 and change.  The drinks were on point, though.

The food was hit or miss.  Some things were really good.  The fries were amazing!  Seriously the best fries I think I've ever had in my life.  They come out steaming hot, and they are served with three different condiments, a barbeque sauce, a fancy ketcup, and truffle sauce.  The truffle fries were definitely my fav.  The rest were really good, too.  No soggy fries either.  They were rich and satisfying.  So good I got them both nights.

They had a shellfish platter, which was really good. It came with the option of hot or cold.  We got the hot served with a miso butter.  Everything was really tasty. $85 though for not a ton of food.

The lobster tacos were a disappointment, just not enough flavor but I did like that the shell stayed crispy,  not soggy. 

The tuna roll was killer. Super fresh! Very good taste and the chef was so kind to make me a spicy mayo with sriracha. AMAZING! 

I'm actually glad I don't live here because I'm pretty sure that I would have clogged arteries because I cannot stay away from those fries. I'd also be broke. I feel kinda badly I didn't eat anywhere else on this trip, but man...the view, the food, the martinis...and right at my hotel was a win, win, win.  See you next year!

One of my sons loves this place, so I get to sample the wares.

Overall, I would say the quesadillas are much more quesadilla and much less filling. I prefer more filling, yet it's all still tasty.

The size of these quesadillas is monumental! I'd say one could serve at least two people!

I've sampled:

The St. Louis ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla.

The Texas ($7.49) -- Home-made smoky sweet barbeque sauce, red onions, grilled chicken, thick-cut bacon, cheddar and monterey jack cheeses on a flour tortilla.

The Italian ($7.49) --  Parmesan tomato sauce, red onions, red and green peppers, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla.

The Parma ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, grilled chicken, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a flour tortilla.

The Bleachers 'Chos ($6.99) are really the king! Yea, I know, it's just nachos. But the four-cheese queso is stupendously fabulous, and I could drink it by the gallon!

Also, as others have said: after 8 p.m., everything's $5.

Nick's Roast Beef was recently remodeled and it looks really great inside. There are a ton of TVs around the bar, making this a great spot to catch a game. On the other side of the restaurant, there are tables and booths for a more quiet, family oriented experience. There are always great specials and the food is reasonable.

I always opt for the roast beef sandwiches. They have a variety of tasty toppings. Fries don't come with the sandwich, but a side order will take care of 2-3 people with no problem. I recently tried the sweet potato fries and they were really tasty.

If you sit at the bar , as I always do, be wary the the crowd can get a little dicey sometimes. They are mostly harmless, but can be annoying. Some examples are a group of drunks screaming at the TV during a Phillies game, and a weird pill head who tried hitting on my sister in law but couldn't get the words out because he was slurring- we ignored him and he stumbled away. I think the staff of this establishment could do a better job of controlling the crowds for the benefit of their other patrons. I've seen people get tossed out of other establishments for less.

I will still continue to go to Nick's to watch games and eat their delicious roast beef sandwiches, but I will definitely never go alone.

Was dying from major lack of sleep and stomach was angry from all the alcohol the night before. So I stumbled upon this Starbucks, and it was really cute inside with photos of Reno in sepia all over the wall. Although the barista forgot my sugar free vanilla, after adding it, it was one of the best made iced coffees I've had in awhile from Starbucks. It was just what I needed to stay awake for more gambling!

Was looking for a different pizza spot to try near my house when I was browsing through the app called Slice and found this. I didn't know this pizza place existed or maybe it used to go by a different name- but I decided to try it cause I wanted a pizza special that they had. 

Surprised to say the food came quickly and was really tasty! Ordered a pizza special with a cheese steak and fries- and everything arrived hot and so good. Glad I tried this spot because I would order from here again soon.

Spent a long time walking around French  Quarter to find somewhere to eat. After over an hour I settled for Gumbo Shop and I'm very glad I did! The entrance is down a little alley and goes into the restaurant and a courtyard. We ate in the restaurant which was packed with lots of people. We were first given a simple loaf of bread, nothing special. Then I ordered the Creole Combination Platter. It came with shrimp creole, jambalaya and red beans and rice. My most favorite was the shrimp creole and I would order the larger size of just that if I ever came again. Very tasty and your basic flavorful food. For dessert we then got the bread pudding. Yum Yum but I was so full that i couldn't eat it all. I felt that the hostess was a bit rude the way she talked, but our waitress was super nice and friendly. The atmosphere is also very nice and cozy for a lunch or dinner.

We came here because Ruben C. Kept badgering us to try the gumbo here. Hubs was on an epic gumbo quest so we thought, "Why the hell not?" We were the first customers when they opened for the day and all the servers looked ready begin their shifts.  Our server was excellent and really nice. I loved hearing him pitch the daily special and make recommendations. 
I wasn't extremely hungry and wanted something small.  Hubs got the chicken and okra gumbo.  He did not like it at all.  He felt like it was more of a Creole style gumbo than a Cajun style like where he's from.  I thought it was fine, but I'm no expert on gumbo.
I got a side of chicken, sausage, and shrimp jambalaya. Holyyyyy shit. That little side was so filling and rich with flavor.  Not too salty and not too spicy.  
After checking out, we went across the street to a local coffee shop and soon after, one of the servers from Gumbo Shop came in and brought us a shopping bag that I had forgotten in the restaurant. 
I was going to give them a 3 star but I was so happy with my little meal and the service that I have to bump them up a star.

Cajun Encounters has all the signs of a tourist trap, because it is one, a really good one. There is no easier way to jump on a boat and explore the swamps of Georgia. Here are the main reasons why I'm grading this so highly:

-=-Easy-=- There's a shuttle to get here for a fee. I was feeling a bit more adventurous so, I rented a car to make the 40 mile drive out of New Orleans proper and into the marshlands. Shuttle for two was around 50 bucks, so my car rental was well worth the little extra.

-=-Fun-=- Boat rides are fun rides, but for this one hold on to your hats. You will go fast, you will go slow, you will go to a crawl with less than 1 foot clearance between trees. Animals are mostly unpredictable, but typically you'll see at least a couple alligators. There is potential to see wild boars, snakes, and turtles as well. 

-=-Captain Mike-=- "Where y'at where y'at!" "Livin da life!" "Awite!"...and more! Super laid back, highly informative, and those alligator calls were pretty cool. "Chikee chikee chikee!" I cannot recommend Captain Mike enough. Toss him a good tip afterwards too. Man's gotta eat.

What is there to say besides WOW!

Rising from the ashes and taking a chance by opening in the thick of COVID, Venus in Furs is an incredible addition and unexpected surprise.

If a tasting room for natural wines ONLY had a baby with a super sexy NYC cocktail lounge, it would be Venus in Furs.

Not only is it absolutely stunning on the inside, with one of the most breathtaking bar facades in town - the menu offers unique natural wines but best of all, cocktails with wine.

Truth be told, I wasn't expecting much from a wine cocktail but with descriptions that actually made me laugh out loud (shout out to the 'lingering notes of summer '08), I had to try at least one. I went with The Gentle Whip and it shot to the top of my ultimate favorite cocktails list FAST. Not only is it delicious - it is fresh and vibrant with notes of vanilla that will make you beg for more. 

If you're still reading this just stop what you're doing and GO already!

Another place where the music was amazing.  It's a nice quaint spot where you can have a bite to eat or get a drink and enjoy the jazz sounds of NOLA.  There are tables that are cafÃ©-like so it gives a comforting feeling to the place.  Drinks weren't too costly and had a fair amount of alcohol in it.

I guess this must be what it's like to be treated like a celebrity! From the moment my friend and I walked in, we received friendly, individualized attention, despite the fact that we were sweaty and dressed somewhat sloppily from our day outdoors.  We were treated like VIPs as the red carpet was rolled out (figuratively!) and sat down at a beautiful, white table.  The place was sparkling clean, elegant, yet not stuffy.  This would be a great place for a romantic date! Don't let the unassuming exterior fool you, because it's actually quite elegant inside! Andre, the sharply dressed man that greeted us, is actually the owner, and he does a great job as a host, making each person that walks in feel special.  His entire demeanor is very calm and pleasant, and I was caught off-guard, because I have become a hardened Miamian that does not experience this often, unless there is an ulterior motive.

The music was fun, and energetic, and Andre had such a peaceful, happy energy about him that it permeated throughout his restaurant.  You couldn't help but feel happy while you were in the establishment.  The food options were plentiful and all sounded delicious, but my friend and I stuck with the safe choice of jerk chicken, which came with a salad and rice and peas.  We each decided to get a large, dinner portion, but had no idea it would be so much food! It was certainly enough to share, though to be fair, we had also had some delicious jerk chicken wings to start.  I had a watermelon soda, which satisfied my sweet tooth, and was very refreshing.  The chicken was very tender and tasty, and the wings especially were hot and spicy, just as we had asked.  It's great to find food that is well-seasoned, and that does not mean that it is dripping in salt.  On the contrary -- it means other flavors and spices dominate, with salt taking a backseat.  We were also told the ingredients were all locally sourced, and organic. 

We were checked on constantly, to make sure we were happy.  Not too long after, Janise, the owner's wife, came over to personally ask if everything was satisfactory.  She also happens to be the chef, we found out, and is from St. Thomas, which means you're getting the real deal here -- authentic Caribbean cooking! Janise was as lovely and friendly as her husband.  I guess that is probably why the food was so full of flavor and love, because they genuinely enjoy making people happy and have pride in their business.  We were too full to get dessert, and I am sure we missed out on something great, judging by the Yelp pictures.  I am glad my friend and I did not go to the place that the staff from the Henry B. Plant Museum had recommended and that we came here, instead, because that place was not very well-received.  Thanks to my Yelp app, I found Yah Mon, read some of the reviews, and we were sold.  The food, and the reviews, did not disappoint. If you're anywhere near this restaurant, you must make it a point to dine here.  Great food, catchy name, clean space, and great service.  This is the standard by which all restaurants should be judged!

I've heard so much about this place but just now had the chance to try it out! 
Located downtown they have a unique wooden store front that sticks out in a good way.
The inside is awesome all of these fun lights, colors and the tables and booths are set up in a different way that I have not witnessed before.
Service is amazing! Quick, attentive but not annoying.
The menu has a lot of options, but it's laid out in a way that doesn't feel overwhelming.
I went with the eggs benicdio and I loved them, a ton of flavor the salsa, egg, Avocado and shrimp worked together so well.
The have a big drink menu as well, breakfast cocktails, cocktails Mexican beers and gringo beers.
I love bloody Mary's so I got the bloody Maria diablo style and it was perfect! 
I'll be back to try the dinner menu and more of the brunch menu!

Came here last Thursday.  Started off with some Rose.  Perfect!  We decided to get the BBQ shrimp.  They were huge and the sauce was amazing.  We then had the crab cakes.  They were very crabby and on point.  We also got the fried avocado with blackened crawfish tails.  I thought the fried avocado was weak.  Definitely needed more flavor salt another component of some kind.  The service was great and I am looking forward to going back!

Tl;dr great food but portions are quite small imo. great vibes. Great service. Price is ok. Wow. super excited to come back the next time I visit st petes. This is MUST VISIT everytime you come to st petes.





P A R K I N G 
Street parking. Pretty easy to find within a mile of the pier. There's also parking within the pier area but a lot of times the parking is full so you'll likely have to walk in.




E X P E R I E N C E 
Called in two days ahead of time on Friday, for a Sunday 815 res. They were completely booked for Fri and sat evening. If you're a walk in, expect to wait at least 1-2 hrs. Food came out relatively quickly given that the restaurant was soo busy.
  

The live music was a really nice touch. Music sounds good. Singer layers his music too which is exciting to hear him create it live.




I N T E R I O R / E X T E R I O R 
Well designed decor. Clean. Well kept. Open concept. Casual but you can def wear dressy casual. 

There's a lot of seating. Well placed. Seating ranges from 2-10+ people. Tables are generally social distanced. A few customers complained that it's a bit chilly outside so the employees turned on the patio heated lamps.




I N F E C T I O N    P R E V E N T I O N
No hand sanitizer stand available to customers. Employees were wearing masks. Most customers inside were wearing masks unless eating. Masks seem to be enforced. 




F O O D 
Old havana punch 9: soo strong. I'm def a lightweight but I drank 1/6 and it had me feeling a little woozy. V fruity. Basically a rum punch. Yum. 

Panko crusted grouper 22: pretty good. Fresh. Almost gave me a thai style feel. 

Crab cakes 14: omg unreal. So good. One of the best crab cakes I've ever had. Textured, fried well. Not mushy. Flavorful. Large. The salad thing that came w it, was soo good. Sweet. Not overly mayo-y. 

Oysters, fresh, dozen 19: shucked well. So fresh. Meaty. Uggh. Yesssss. Must get. 
 
Deep water mahi mahi 25: mahi mahi was so fresh. Grilled. Sooo tasty. Has some sweet tangy sauce. Rice gave me the æ²¹é£¯ feel. V flavorful. I don't usually eat more than a bite of the rice that comes w the meal but I almost finished all of it. 

Honestly, when I come back, bc I will, will def get mahi mahi, oysters and the crab cakes. They were a hit x1000. I'm already missing it and I haven't even left the restaurant yet. 


**This food had me and my friend filling 60% full. Not  large portions. Probably should get 1-2 appetizers + an entree per person. Or get 1 app, 1 entree and 1 dessert per person. 




S E R V I C E
Dustyy was a great waiter. He was friendly and open to give suggestions. He checked on us just enough. Available. Fantastic. 




B A T H R O O M S 
Relatively clean. out of paper towels tho. 4 stalls in the women's. 2 sinks. Space is small. Hard to social distance. 



P R I C E 
+ tax/tip = 120

Why oh why have I not been here sooner?
Have tried them at a few different Yelp events.....well.  One day, it just dawned on me and SO glad I could finally experience it.

First off, sitting at the bar, the bartend-ress was quite fun and nice.  She offered me a taste of the Lazy Magnolia brown ale.  Oh did I really like that.  So I had 2.

And she brought us some homemade chips with dipping sauce.  Yum.

For lunch I had the naked pineapple mahi.......salad turned sandwich!  On a fabulous bun.  It also came with a nice crisp fresh side salad.

The hubby had a classic cheese burger with bacon.  Oh, it looked really good. And he said it was even better than it looked.

Monday is $5 burger day!  Toppings extra.  Will have to return just for that, if nothing else.

Lots of tv's, nice bar, great staff, outdoor seating out back.  Parking is in the back.
Come to EATS!  I certainly will again.

I really love the Curtis Hixon Waterfront Park in Downtown Tampa. It is located across the water from the beautiful University of Tampa and is a great place to take photographs. An ideal place to spend an afternoon at the park and watch the sunset. The monthly Rock the Park concert is held here for free the first Thursday of every month with local bands playing. Plenty of local restaurants are within a few minutes from here. The park is right next to the Tampa Museum of Art and Glazer Children's Museum. There is a dog park and a playground for kids. It is the most family friendly place I have seen on this side of town and it's nice to see people outdoors here and active instead of crammed inside of a mall.

I have had BBH a few years back and they were delish then. I used to order the orange chicken that came fresh with a crunch with a spicy orange sauce that came on top with a orange slice to top it all off. It came with white rice which was always soft and ready to be devoured.

Jump to present day and I ordered during lunch, which can I say that businesses that offer lunch on the weekends... THANK YOU! Our bellies and hangry side love you. I ordered the Generals Tso chicken lunch that comes with chicken rice but I substituted mine for veggie rice which was perfect. And years later the food was still on point with it being fresh with a crunch and flavor on point. 

I ordered a side of the spring rolls and a crab ragoons and they were both delish coming with sweet and sour sauce for both which i never use but thank you for thinking of my taste buds.

There was enough food for 2 days if you have a small belly like mine (not meaning small on the outside ;) ) Which is always a plus.

I will be back in a few years when I have a craving. If I craved it more, I would be here weekly. Give them love if you're in the area or not.

5 stars all the way, This is the type of restaurant/ lounge that makes you rethink all your star ratings because Three Muses blows them all out of the water. I don't know what was better, the live awesome 1920's jazz music or the fabulous food. This place is a winner in my book. 

They have delicious old fashioned and freshly made cocktails here unbelievably in the $7/ $8 range. I tried the lavender lace and the fiance got the Pim's cup. Tell me where have you ever seen a Pim's cup on a menu? The only other place we had heard of it was on the show Boardwalk Empire. I swear I thought  I had fallen back into the 1920's here. I really couldn't stop saying how much fun I was having.

As for food, I highly recommended the scallops. They were the highlight of the evening. Super creamy and and the felafel crust on them worked so well. Who knew. I really don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu we had a few other small plates and they were all good. 

Now to add this review to my Best of the Best list.

Nothing fancy, which is great. This is an authentic-feeling Dominican restaurant. Most customers are speaking Spanish, the decor is very cute, and the food is great, though not made to order. The food is all ready to go, but it wasn't dried out at all, and it of course comes out in two minutes when you don't have to wait for it to be cooked. The guanabana juice was delicious, the sweet fried plantains were the real deal, and the stewed chicken was to die for. The rice and beans were perfect and in hearty portions. The prices were not bad for Center City. I got a ton of food and that yummy juice for $22.

While walking around Bourbon Street, it's a little frightening to see white powder riddled on the streets and plastered on peoples' noses.  Because of that, you might suspect people are sniffing cocaine due to their boisterous attitudes, but after eating beignet's at Cafe Beignet on Bourbon Street, I'm convinced that they are the reason for such things. Lol

Cafe Beignet offers better beignets than Cafe Du Monde and it's not even close.  They're far more fluffy, soft, well-sized, and deliciously powdered than any beignet I've had and it's only $3.99 for three!

Cafe Beignet has two locations--one being this one inside Musical Legends Park on Bourbon Street and the other on Royal.  I much rather prefer the one on Royal as it has a more clean and endearing environment.  This specific location on Bourbon is more fun and lively, but the distasteful smells of Bourbon Street creeps in from time to time.  I do love the live jazz music that is played though.  
----
Conclusion: Those who are looking for 5 star beignets and a lively, musical atmosphere, come to this outdoor location.  I, along with Mr. Alton Brown (famous food critic on the food channel) agree Cafe Beignet is much better than Cafe Du Monde.  Come here for food, alcohol, music, and the best beignets! can be found here too!  

Extra Notes:
-Accepts credit card
-Tables are available but be aggressive when trying to obtain one.  There are three tables upstairs near the restroom too
-Service can be better as they're not very friendly or helpful
-Restrooms are filthy

We stumbled upon Three Muses during our first few hours exploring Frenchmen Street. We put our names in for a table and had a long wait. But who cares! There's plenty to entertain you in the area while you wait. 

A late dinner at Three Muses was the perfect way to start our weekend in New Orleans: great food, local beers, wonderful live music, and friendly service. My group of four shared a bunch of tapas including: seared scallops, bacon wrapped dates, lamb sliders, swiss chard fritters (AMAZING), mac n' cheese, and feta fries. Almost everything we tried was great and we stayed for hours, listening to the music and ordering more tapas as the night went on. Definitely a gem on Frenchmen!

Didn't get to try the gumbo, but the jambalaya was everything that I had hoped for! 

Strangely enough, the best jambalaya I've ever had is from a little take-out place called NOTO (New Orleans To Go) in Madison, Wisconsin. Their jambalaya has the perfect amount of heat and southern spice, and I arrived in NOLA looking for jambalaya that would meet my criteria. 

After being disappointed by a few other restaurants, I decided to stop by Gumbo Shop on a whim after reading the Yelp reviews. I'm so glad I did!! I got my jambalaya to go because it was nearing closing time for the restaurant. Although the presentation in my to-go box was not super impressive, upon first taste, the age-old adage "do not judge a book by it's cover" rang true.

The jambalaya was exactly what I was craving - it was hearty and had all of the flavors that I was looking for. The portions were generous and they definitely did not skimp on any of the ingredients!

If you are in the area and looking for some great jambalaya to round out your NOLA trip, put Gumbo Shop on your list!

Great market in the Quarter conveniently located on Royal Street, stocked with your favorite drinks and snacks to take back to your hotel. It's much larger than you think, and they carry lots of local items, too. Get some to take back to your loved ones as souvenir tastes of New Orleans for far better prices than you'd pay in a souvenir store.

Nice employees, too.

Despite passing Culver's for 4 years on my way to Walmart, I've never gone in. I thought I'd remedy that.

Culver's is apparently a Wisconsin fast food chain that has spread to Florida. Among standard burgers and fries, they have cheese curds, and custard.
They have indoor dining as well as a drive thru.

Butter Burger - Tastes like a more "Home cooked" version of a MCDonalds burger. Less heavy. It's not spectacular .  3/5

Cheese Curds- These are small spheres of cheese covered with batter and fried. The cheese is melty and the breading complements it well.  3.5/5

Custard - I got the flavor of the day (Chocolate caramel) I would say the consistency is between traditional ice cream and frozen yogurt. The only custard I've eaten is flan once or twice. This is different from that. This was really good and worth going back for. 4/5

The place is clean and the employees are friendly. The food took about 8 minutes to come out.

There are covered seats outside to eat under.

Overall: This is a solid but unremarkable place. The custard is worth getting repeatedly though.

Great prices. Good food. Good service. Clean. 

Interior is nice. I think more could be done with the interior. 

Had the bacon wrapped chorizo stuffed dates 1st with a glass of red wine from Chili. The appetizer was wonderful. Came with four morsels to enjoy!  

So a platter called Parrillada (for two) $59
Ribeye, chorizo, morcilla, lamb chop, beef heart, roast marrow, salsa verde, chimichurri, seasonal vegetables. No beef heart so did a chicken skewer (wow so good). So...ribeye was amazing. Chorizo ok, morcilla-amazing, lamb chop cooked perfect and tender but lacked some flavor, chimichurri was fantastic and the veggies were good!  Does it sound like we enjoyed it all....YES!!!  The steak and chicken had a nice charred flavor. Tender and cooked perfectly. It was all so good.

It is always a shame when the service mars the efforts of the kitchen.

I visited Grille 39 for a business dinner on a corporate trip to Indy recently since the restaurant was located at The Renaissance in Carmel and - if nothing else - it is remarkably convenient location if you are staying at this or a neighboring hotel. The amenities are opulent, most notably the Bar area which boasts some fantastic bartenders. 

Sadly, the service the Bar offers is in deep contrast to the dining area and it is largely due to the leadership/management of Grille 39. Our group of 40 was served by a single server named Joel that deserved better. Drinks took ages to arrive. Plates arrived in haphazard fashion. There was zero balance to the timing because Joel was running for his life for two hours. This is inexplicable for a hotel of this size - get it together Renaissance.

It is a real shame too. The kitchen is among the best in the hotel industry. 

As a starter Salad, I when with the Classic Cesar which is a run of the mill rendition featuring chopped Romaine, shaved Parmesan flakes, Croutons, tossed in a classic Caesar Dressing. There was nothing to complain about as the ingredients were plenty fresh but there was no real pop to the combination.

The Filet Mignon, however, was splendid. Cooked to a precise medium-rare with the perfect amount of char on the outside and a juicy/succulent interior. Even the seasoning was applied expertly and I must admit that this may be the best Steak I have ever had at a mid-level hotel. Chef Erik Kemeny can take pride in his team's ability to put together one hell of a beefsteak. I was very impressed. 

Truth be told, both Joel and Erik deserve more than the 3 stars I can award considering the experience. Hopefully, adjustments will be made in the future in order for their considerable efforts to be fully realized.

I really wanted to like this Midwestern burger restaurant based upon all of their hype when they started opening locations in the Tampa Bay area, but after my visit I drove away thinking "mehhh".

Culver's started as a fast-casual food chain in Wisconsin in the mid-80's, and has quickly spread to over 500 franchised restaurants nationwide. They advertise "Welcome to Delicious", and promote their Butterburgers and frozen custard, among other menu items.

This particular location of Culver's can be found on Nebraska Avenue, just north of Bearss. I visited there on a weeknight, and stood in line with lots of families. The menu is quite large, and it takes a while to read through everything before finally making your selection.

I ordered a Mushroom Swiss Butterburger with a side of onion rings, and took my numbered placard over to a vacant table while they prepared my meal. According to the information I read, Culver's uses a freshly-ground mix of three cuts of beef: sirloin, chuck and plate. The patties are mashed down on the flat-top in order to cook more quickly, but that also means there is a loss of some of the juices. The buns are lightly-buttered on the crowns, and toasted, and then the whole thing is assembled and placed into your basket along with your sides. (I don't get the concept of buttering the top of the bun, but I wasn't a fan.)

What I ended up with was a bun that was greasy to the touch, and meat that was dry and lacking in flavor. Thankfully they had added the Swiss cheese and grilled mushrooms, but I had to get up and get some mustard and black pepper to put on the burger. Maybe I was supposed to ask them to add condiments and seasonings, but that certainly was not made clear during the ordering process.

The onion rings were OK, but they'd sat in the fry oil a bit too long and were bordering on being burned. Again, back to the condiments bar for more ketchup and mustard as a dipping sauce.

In the end I paid $10 for a meal which left me disappointed. I've certainly had much better burgers at other places, and so I'll have to plan a return trip to see if I just happened to catch them on a bad day.

My family and I was very fortunate to have Madison as my tour guide on our sugar cane plantation tour. Madison made our tour one of the best ones I've ever had. He was diligent in texting me when he was coming to pick up my family and was on time! Madison also had extensive knowledge of the New Orleans area and was very funny and witty telling jokes and relating with the guests on our tour. Through our conversations, we found out that Madison is a very educated man holding a degree in Physics from Tulane! How about that!!! He was able to explain some physics to my children as well as tell us about the realities of the people we were seeing as we were driving towards the Plantation. He explained to us about the history of the people around the area and that many were actually descendants of the slaves that were working on the fields. He also explained the history of the Creole movement which I found truly fascinating! When we reached the plantations, Madison was quick to grab our tickets and we were swiftly off learning all the rich historical history of the Laura plantation and Oak Alley Plantation! Simply marvelous!!! At the end of both tours, he simply just let us soak it all by playing some of his favorite blues music that really made the whole experience enjoyable and memorable! Some Chucky Berry, Elvis, Dixie Cups, and some local blues! Thank you Madison! I'll be back and I'll specifically ask for you!
Incredible response and handling of the virus issues. Happy to have them back again. The place is energized and dialed in. Staff and management are on point. Food is fast and tasty. Keep it up!!
Took 44 minutes to get our entrees after our oysters. All we ordered was shrimp and grits and shrimp ettoufe which were basically soups. Oysters were pretty good both raw and charbroiled.

Fabulous view sitting outside overlooking the Delaware.  My husband had a watermelon Fig Gazpacho soup which was out of this world. He also had the special petite filet with watermelon arugula and feta cheese salad which was cooked perfect.  I had a Portabella burger which was also just fine. Great place to visit before going to the Playhouse. The service was wonderful and they were very aware of being quick so that we could make Our play. Great little spot in New Hope don't miss it.

I went into this Five Guys location on a rainy, wet Thursday in desperate need of a burger fix. I am currently doing the whole30 diet which means I cannot have a multitude of things. But what I can have is a Five Guys burger patties with some toppings and make myself a little burger salad. 

Well Syvia K. made that ask not seem annoying (although I know it is). She even then went around the whole floor to ask people how their meals were. Knew that it was a couples first time and spoke to them in the kindest of manners and then told me that my meal had to be remade because they added cheese and apologized for the delay. It wan't even that long of a delay but the effort and true kindness was unmatched to an experienced i've had any time recently at a restaurant of any level. I will be back for sure and I hope Syvia is working. 

As for the Burger "Bowl" As I am calling it - I asked for the hamburger without the bun and no lettuce wrap. It came in a nice little aluminum container with lettuce, tomatoes, pickles on one side, grilled onions & the burger patty on the other and mustard on the side. It was exactly what I wanted. Even if the smell of the fries wafting around were ALMOST enough to tempt me to have one.

there are many things i like about lee how fook.

THE TEA

yes, there is hot tea provided BEFORE ice water. very important detail. a light chrysanthemum tea is the perfect complement to lunch.

THE FOOD

salt baked squid: a yelp declared favorite. so of course, i had to try it. and i agree, it's delicious! crispy and salty, but not overly done in either respect. this is like the much lighter (though unsure if it's much healthier) alternative to calamari.

mapo tofu: eh, less than standard. too much on the non-spicy side for my taste and a little too "westernized." but you really can't go wrong with tofu. heart.

lamb casserole: yummy!! stewed lamb with bean curd in a casserole dish has everything i love and nothing i don't. even the leftovers were so good the next day. and i never say that about chinese food leftovers.

what i didn't like?

THE RICE

the rice was terrible, though they give you a lot. how can i be picky about rice? because i eat it everyday so i know the difference between good and crap.

THE SERVINGS

dishes are really small for a chinese restaurant, especially at those menu prices. i'm a little begrudged by that because it goes against every fiber of my chinese (read: cheap) being.

conclusion? 3.5 STARS rounding up because groupon saved me money :D

I finally tried a bowl of noodle here, and it didn't live up to my expectation.  Good Sichuan cuisine can be so addictive with ample amount of numbing citrusy peppercorn and fragrant chili oil.  I admit the noodles were spicy and numbing.  There was also plenty of sodium, so it wasn't bland either.  What it greatly lacked was a good base made from simmering pork bones or chicken bones.  Imagine this without the spicy components, the broth is actually very watery.  I have nothing against MSG, I use it in my own cooking, but you can't rely only on MSG for umami.  The richness and savoriness of a well made stock can't be duplicated with a few sprinkles of MSG.  I also didn't like the beef being cut into perfectly square meat cubes.  The texture would be much better as thin slices.  If they can just make the stock better and tone down the MSG a little, the noodles here would be addictive.
