This a gorgeous, well-laid out park. My half-pint loved both the real playground and the turtle sculptures. We didn't hit the zoo, but the location is perfect for a fun full day in park. The park is huge - worth a drive through to take it all in.

Wow I haven't reviewed Nada yet? Well, that's crazy because I really do enjoy Nada. I haven't been in a little while, but they definitely are a staple establishment that I recommend for one to visit in downtown Indy all the time. 

Number one they have in a beautiful venue with gorgeous decor and plenty of seating. You can sit at the bar, but you can also be seated in the backspace is spacious and awesome with different kinds of seating for seating multiple numbers of guest. Then they also have a space that works well for smaller private parties (about 25). 

Drinks and tacos is thing to do here. I usually get pork tacos and stay away from any of the creative options that they have on their menu, but you really can't go too wrong here. I will say that they have improved on their service in the last year which I have appreciated.

Ok, here goes. My favorite cheesesteak in Philly? Yeah. Sonny's.

Contrary to popular (tourist) belief, a typical Philadelphian's breakfast, lunch, and dinner is -not- comprised of a cheesesteak. If it were, however, I suppose Sonny's is where I'd go. Not Pat's, not Geno's, not Jim's, but Sonny's. 

While the aformentioned hot spots cater to visitors, Sonny's feels a bit more local and genuine. There's no colloquially forced ordering procedure ("wit," "witout," "whiz" - I'm pretty sure Pat's/Geno's/Jim's does that to suggest local flavor) and they offer more sophisticated toppings. After all, a cheesesteak is just like any other sandwich, one that's not limited to just onions and cheese. 

So if you're in the neighborhood, hopping off your Olde City carriage ride or walking out of the Constitution Center, Sonny's is a sure bet. You won't find a line trailing around the corner and you won't find a bunch of tourists reciting the proper way to order their cheesesteak in line. No pretension, no bull, just good meat and cheese sandwiches. 

Holla.

Down a star from the last trip as something has changed. Not as delicious as before and the oysters were TINY!!! Unbelievably TINY! Kinda pissed but we had the Sweetest server who tried to recommend some other places to eat when we told her we were only there for the oysters. Otherwise, this would have been a 1-star review.

Axiom fitness is a real breath of fresh air as far as the 24 hour-ish gyms go. Now I have been a member of the Anytime fitness and Planet Fitness, as well as Snap but this one just is a few steps above in quality and atmosphere. 

From the moment I walked in and was greeted by the staff I was impressed. They have membership people and trainers who also give new members evaluations/assessments for free and of course those at the front desk who great you with a smile each visit. The locker room has been a little less than clean on occasion and the counters are always covered with water and there are no towels, paper or otherwise available for wiping down. This could use some improvement. The facilities seem to be clean at all times and if a piece of equipment seems to be broken, it's only for a day or so before it's back in service.

I don't think I've eaten this much in a really long time.  I think we ate almost everything on the menu.  Literally.  There were only three of us.  Fortunately, the tables are close together so we made friends with our neighbors, and ended up sharing our bounty with them.  Ha.  

Most things were really good- we were starving though and waited over an hour to get seated.  The meat and cheese plate stands out.  I'm a sucker for cheese.  Other notable menu items are:  fried pickles (actually, they were amazing), french fries (sooo good), the lamb sliders weren't that good in my opinion, but the masses seem to like them (read in other reviews).  Something with mustard sauce, maybe egg rolls, or shrimp tempura were good- obviously, the condiment was the one that stood out to me.  That boolgogi bowl was really good too.  I think we had the mac and cheese too.  

So aside from this being a testimonial to me being a total cow- the main thing you should draw from this review is that, aside from the great music here, the food and drinks are good.  I think I stuck to wine because the cocktails were a little strange to me.  I'd go back.
You have to try a legendary place like this.  Don't be scared of the lines.  They go fast!!  The concrete treats are MUCH better than DQ!!  My strawberry shake was excellent as well!

I enjoy this restaurant very much.  I feel I should lay some things out right away though.

1.  I know a lot of people walk in and are very shocked.  It's small inside and kind of almost shabby looking, but don't be fooled.  Plus I LOVE the chalkboard back wall.

2.  It can get crowded and loud in here in the weekends.  But it lends a fun vibe, just be aware that this happens.

3. This is a great place to go with a group of friends.  If you want to do a date here, I suggest a weeknight when its not as busy.

Now onto the food.  The pizzas, appetizers (the mushrooms are the best!), and salads (get them with green goddess dressing) are amazing and great to share with a group.  I love coming here on a Fridya after work with some girlfriends and partaking in several different pizzas (anything with the Benton's bacon on it is divine).  The pricing in reasonable and the service is good.  I've also eaten here on a weeknight, when its quieter and a litle more personable.  I had entrees on this occasion and really enjoyed their salmon special.

In planning our trip to New Orleans, my friend suggested we do a haunted voodoo tour. Misreading the email, and thinking I was signing up for a Vodka Tour, you can imagine my surprise when we got to Madame Laveau's and there was no distilling equipment in sight. Compounding this, when our tour guide started to describe the haunted background of New Orleans, I couldn't help but roll my eyes a bit (correction: a whole lot actually). 

However, once he started leading us through the French Quarter, my skepticism quickly faded away. Our tour guide Randy managed to give the backstory of New Orleans and its history as a colony, first of the Spanish, then the French, and finally the Americans. Throughout it all, the only constant was something unnatural and dare I say paranormal. Randy managed to keep our group of about 20 entertained, educated and slightly scared. Though perhaps I was the most scared, when I spontaneously started bleeding right as he began talking about vampires!! (Thankfully it was only a nosebleed brought by dry air and dehydration)

Throughout our vacation in NOLA, we kept running into other tour guides, yet Voodoo Bone Lady was the absolute best, hands down, namely due to Randy and the incredible tour he gave.

Wasn't bad. I liked riding in the nice air conditioned bus and got a somewhat decent tour of New Orleans on the way to the Swamp site. The part I didn't like is the part where we waited for about an hour at the Swamp Tour's gift shop  for another bus tour to arrive. Once I suppose everyone arrived they separated us according to the group package we selected and then we were led to a boat and led slowly through a swamp trying to beg baby alligators to give us attention by throwing marshmallows at them. Only we never saw any in that section of our extended tour package. From there we went in reverse and it was a nice ride when our tour guide was speeding through the open swamp because I got a breeze and felt like I was in a slightly exciting adventure but then it was back to lets throw something at that alligator and see if they want to play. 

They didnt.  

Bring Sunblock and a Hat.

Very good food!  Fusion Thai and Chinese dishes, with sushi.  Sushi is freshly rolled and the options are delicious...  My wife and I do at least 2 rolls every visit, and my favorite is the roll with mango.  Great location where you can find plenty of good food on the Southside.

I can't believe it's been a few months that I have been here. I feel like it was just yesterday. That's how vivid and tasty my dinner was here!

Initially I really wasn't feeling this place. It's very crowded here and service can take a bit of time.... But there's a good reason why, the Greek food here is amazing and I swear the tastiest and best I have had. I've been to a number of restaurants at the Sponge Docks and none this memorable.  

My hubby and I ordered the saganaki(flaming cheese) charbroiled octopus, and chicken Mykonos. This also comes with the Greek lemon soup and a simple apple honey dessert that is so good. Everything was cooked to perfection.

Our meal was extraordinary and this is my most favorite restaurant at the Sponge Docks. You gotta try it and be Patient if you wait a while. I hate waiting but this is worth it!

Updating for relevancy! 

I've been her a couple times in the past week and found myself likin' it a little bit more. Not like "4" stars more, but enough to say a word or two. The main change of heart? Well, besides supporting local I really dig their beer selection. It's pretty darn big and great for a grocery store. In fact, it's probably the best craft beer selection that's not a specialty liquor store. 

I recently got some really fancy cider's that were amazing. Not too sweet and very dry, just like I like it. They also have a pretty big sour beer collections which are hard to come by at a grocer. 

Anyways, if you're into unique brews than you should check out Fields.

Omg awesome delicious authentic German restaurant in simple strip mall on highway.  As recommended potato pancakes to live four. Enjoyed a schnitzel Reuben sandwich and bratkaetoffeln with cheese... still to come apple strudel!!

Sinfully good! That's why I will only come by with my Granddaughter occasionally. She hooked me on BLIZZARDS! Dang, I'm not running 10K distances for one of those addictive treats! I also love the Cherry Dip Cones, which were my original habit back at maximum density! There's your 3 Stars!
Their food is typical fast food and marginally better than ordinary. 
Their staff always seems to have one person I would fire on the spot for bad attitude and customer service. A manager asks you to do something, you don't say, "I really don't want to but..." in the customer's ear range. Then I asked for a ranch dressing packet and instead of just handing it to me in under 10 seconds, I have to wait 5 minutes for it! I really give leeway but here...I would have neutralized the situation immediately!

I generally hate Cosi - the bread is like hot cardboard - and the food is not my thing, but I stop in to this one every once in a while for iced coffee.  A good friend lives near this one so we'll meet here, grab some iced coffee and hang out with or without our kids in tow.

The restroom is abhorently filthy though.  Yick.

This is one of the best Italian restaurants I've been to in South Jersey in recent memory. It's a bit off the beaten path, you need to make a reservation and you shouldn't come expecting the likes of spaghetti and meatballs and chicken Parmesean to be gracing the menu; but that doesn't mean it's not worth a visit. 

The first thing I was taken aback by was the noise in the restaurant. I was hoping for a more intimate, quiet setting; however, it felt like you had to talk loudly even to the person right next to you. Not the worst thing, just not as quiet as I had hoped. 

After placing our order, we were served a variety of freshly baked bread. We started off with the grilled octopus which was a special of the day. We both agreed that the flavor of the octopus was delicious but felt that it could have been a tad bit crispier. 

Next we shared the pesto Trapanese - fusilli pasta with almond-pistachio pesto which is one of the best pasta dishes I've had in a long time. We were also served complimentary gnocchi alla' Argentiera - spinach and ricotta topped with Sicilian caciocavallo which was very good. 

As for the entrees, I ordered the Coniglio Pizzaiola - stewed rabbit with tomato and fresh oregano with rosemary oven roasted potatoes. I really enjoyed the sauce which was full of flavor as well as the crispy potatoes. The rabbit was super tender but also a bit under-seasoned. My dining partner ordered the lamb and we both agreed that although it was cooked perfectly, it too was lacking in seasoning. 

We rounded out our experience with Zeppoli Siciliano which even came with a lit candle for my birthday thanks to my companion. We both agreed that the zeppolis were by far the best thing we had eaten off the menu - not dense at all, so light, airy and sweet. I still think about them sometimes....

I really enjoyed my experience here and love that Zeppoli is not just any other NJ Italian restaurant. Four stars which can easily be five stars. Perhaps invest in some nice napkins (the dish towel on my lap is better suited for the kitchen), work on the noise, and add just a tad more seasoning. I look forward to returning.

Hold on to your hats people, Little Nonna's is AMAZING. 

Whenever I'm on the east coast, I go in search of meatballs. Meatballs are my favorite food. After checking out yelp for some direction, I headed to Little Nonna's and ordered a plate of meatballs with a glass of house red and the Kitchen Sink to share with the table. 

Everything was fantastic. Food, the restaurant itself, wine and service. 

This is definitely a Philly favorite of mine and I return everytime I'm in town.
Good fries... burger was nothing to write home about but I did steal my bf's fries .. yummy ...

First time here!!!!

Guys just go and try it. Simple. But I'll give you a little bit of my experience.

Came here for dinner at the recommendation of several NOLA natives to try the oysters. Man listen, I'm not an oyster eater AT ALL and I immediately fell in love with these chargrilled oysters. We legit spent about $100 on oysters alone. Seriously, just eat them and love them! We all also ordered entrees which did not really receive any negative remarks aside from the collard greens. Drago's ya'll are in the deep south honey, PLEASE upgrade the collards so we can enjoy those too! They just severely missed the mark. 

Our server Jamie was ready to go home and basically rushed us and appeared to get a little frustrated by us ordering more food. I'm sure had we come in a little earlier than an hr before closing he may have had a better attitude, so it is what it is. I will definitely be returning for a foodie weekend soon!

Tucked away in the back of a bar, with a line that wraps around a circular bar table, is a seemingly popular poboy spot in NOLA. After about a fifteen minute wait I was relocating myself to a more peaceful place to munch. Sadly, my $14 sandwich (which was really more of a banh mi than anything - I admit, it was a nice twist) was soggy after just a few minutes. Decent flavors, good bread, but overall way way way overpriced. I get it, we're in the FQ where you can get away with hiked up prices, but I rarely pay more than $4 for a banh mi. Actually, I think the whole wondrous magical spirit behind a banh mi is that you're getting this fat, amazing sandwich with pickled veggies and cilantro for a piggy-bank loving price. I don't care where we are, this shouldn't of been more than $8.

Over rated.I you are in the immediate vicinity and have to have mexican food (tex-mex) sure thing, go there; but, I would under no conditions exert effort to go here again. Kinda blah, kinda the same as so many other places.

It was my first time in this location, just after the restaurants are starting to open up again. 
The interior of the restaurant is nicely done, great atmosphere and decor.
The food and drink are of spectacular quality. Fresh and high quality foods all around. May I recommend the Fajitas 3-way... yeah the name makes me chuckle too and I grin as I order this dish. It is well worth it though as you get a large amount of steak, chicken and shrimp along with peppers and onions on a sizzling platter. A very nice plate of beans, rice, greens, pico, sour cream, guac and tortillas come alongside also. You will be eating on this for at least another day.
I also had a house margarita along with my meal and it was just spot on. Not too sweet, not too tart, not too weak, not too boozy... just right. 

So why not 5 stars? 
The service was seriously lacking. We received our appetizer halfway through the meal. The waitress seemed to have completely forgotten that we even existed... thank goodness for food runners and other staff, who picked up the slack... mind you, this is at 50% capacity (by the way, I don't think that means to cram all the guests into one corner and leave the rest empty)
Come here for the food only... if you want service also, I suggest you go to one of the other locations.

This is by far the number 1 metro city park In the United States!  It is actually larger than Central Park in NYC and has more to do!  No matter if your looking for a place to have a picnic or going for a hard work out you can do pretty much anything here!  Also this was home to the 1903 Worlds fair which helped put STL on the global map!

Things to do that are free!!! 
 -Zoo (voted the number 1 free attraction in the USA) SO much fun!  Go see the penguins!!! 
-Art Museum (attend an art and drinking event)
-Science Center (has an omniex theater which is amazing) 
-History Museum 
-Free seats at the Muny (amazing plays)
-Shakespeare in the park (summer months)
-Strinberg Ice Skating rink (free if you have your own skates other wise small fee) 
-tons of Festivals, my favorites are Ballon Glow, the Earth Day Festival, and the Beer Festivals.  

Also Forest Park is home to two golf courses, horse back riding, and archery area, and tons of ponds and lakes for boating!  

You will always find something to do at Forest Park!  I love playing Softball here as well as tennis!  

Go have a great time at a great, fun, interactive, relaxing gem of STL!!!

Very pleased with this buffet.  They do great for a solo trip, a couple, small group of friends or a hoard of hungry lacrosse players (my team's favorite team dinner spot)

Dinner is about 15 bucks but it's cheaper at lunch.  The Habachi is by far one of the best around.  The only place that comes to mind that may rival it is in Delaware.  They do a nice job of keeping your table cleaned off (be mindful to set your fork aside so they don't take it), and refilling your drink.  They have a couple of TV's playing (usually without sound) which can be cool to check out if you're afraid you'll miss out on some news or sports action.  

They have crawfish that were surprisingly tasty, the skewed chicken is great, beef with broccoli, and sweet and sour chicken is also solid choices.  I was pleased with the temperature of all the food but if you truly want to master the Ichiban experience... this is what you do.  
        Go to the hibachi part of the joint, load up your plate and have him cook it up they way you like, now walk away... trust me, walk away.  Grab a second plate and start filling it with already prepared food out on the buffet.  By they time you are done walk back over to the hibachi dude and wait a few more minutes. When he is done he will hand you a plate with your piping hot (about 600 degrees) food on it.  Walk over to your table and dig into your plate of buffet food while your hibachi cools to a reasonable temperature.  Repeat as necessary.  You are welcome.

Also available is some random American food, sushi, soups, desserts, and a salad bar.  If you leave here hungry its your own fault.

RICHER THAN ICE CREAM!  frozen custard by itself, topped or blended with my favorite extras into a thick (able to hold upside-down) concrete is the StL treat no matter what time of the year.

I admit this is not health food.  Custard is richer and softer with eggs and higher fat content than normal ice cream.  (Since I was raised on it I can taste the difference)  Then I order raspberries, nuts and chocolate "fox treat"  sundae or blend with whatever sounds good.  (I like deciding, with the concrete, what exactly I want in my own personal dessert- fruit, candy bar, nuts, pies, and/or chocolate fudge (I like the fudge to be added on top of the mix).  The list of stuff I can add is insane in length and variety, plus the ability to combine...)  I only live once so I will treat myself to my own personally created indulgence, even in the winter.

In the summer this place looks insane.  The lines does move FAST so just get ready to order (do not procrastinate on making a decision on what anyone in your group wants- I get everyones order and tell them to wait at the car).  This place is a hangout during summer nights for kids of all ages.

I worked across the street for 4 years and they always have a line.  In the middle of winter with snow on the ground, THERE IS A LINE.  The frozen custard is that good (something richer than standard ice cream).

If you want standard hard scoop ice cream that you can pick the extras like a concrete- GO to Cold Stone so we have less of a line.

=)

Orleans Grapevine is definitely one of the more pricy and upscale restaurants in the French Quarter. After a week of eating fried chicken and Creole fare, my boyfriend and I were looking for something different on our last night in NOLA and chose this place. We're definitely glad we did. 

We ordered two appetizers and split them - the Fried Goat Cheese Salad and Baked Brie in a garlic cream sauce. I'm a huge fan of Brie, and this one was absolutely phenomenal, although I wish it had been served with crackers. The salad was tasty as well, and the dressing almost tasted like a honey mustard vinaigrette. 

I ordered the Shrimp and Grits as an entree and enjoyed that very much as well. The portion size was very generous, but unfortunately after filling up on Brie, I couldn't finish my food and the grits hardened to the plate. 

Overall, this is a great spot for a date night or wine Wednesday with the girls. Highly recommend!

In love with their cajun fries and addicted to their burgers. I get mine with mushrooms, onions and BBQ (is that weird combo? lol). The first night we went the staff were amazing! They just had this flow going and the mood was very upbeat. It was fun watching them make the orders and interact with the customers. Awesome customer service! Restaurant is clean and food is good so two thumbs up for this location!

I read several reviews of this place. I tried to eat their for lunch one time, but was mislead. Now here's the scoop or poop. If you take route 70 west, you'll need to drive around the back of the America's Best Value Inn. The restaurant faces the Cooper River Park. I had read reviews and most of them were positive, however, I read a review from an Indian Restaurant Review web site that TOTALLY trashed this place. After going there, I'm convinced that the review I had read was either a competitor or a disgruntled employee. The place is classy with Excellent service. It's a BYOB. The staff is friendly and overly accommodating. The prices were competitive and the food was promptly served and fresh. This is an excellent place to take someone on a nice date or a business guest. The atmosphere was relaxing and the restrooms clean. For the price and ambiance, this place is a winner. The food was good. They boast about their daily luncheon buffet that I've yet to try but will be doing so soon. I've read raves on it and the price $ 10.95 seems to be a bargain. Will be back again soon. Enjoyed it.

This is a great, wholesome restaurant that you think of when you think "cajun". The gumbo was very tasty and had decent prices compared to some of NOLA's places! If you eat here, eat outside in the courtyard area-very neat!!

Ah, the late night food craving... It's so nice to find a place that is open late and is not fast food.
 
The restaurant is pretty bare bones and kind of reminds me of a cafeteria. The pictures of the menu items are discolored from being displayed for way too long, not that that has any reflection on the quality of food, it just really stood out to me for some reason. I guess basically what I am saying is this place majorly lacks in atmosphere, but I guess you're not really there for that.
 
We decided on the wet burrito to share. There are a couple of options for the type of meat; we chose carne asada. Along with the burrito, we got an order of chips and salsa.
 
Our food was ready to pick up pretty quickly. The serving of chips was huge. I wasn't a fan of the salsa, which is completely smooth, but this might just be a personal preference. Sharing the burrito was a good choice; it really is big enough to serve two people, especially with the side of chips. The red sauce that the burrito is topped with has a really tin-like flavor which was really off putting, but the fillings inside were much better.
 
Overall, a passable late night meal. I had no idea this place existed until recently, so I foresee some more trips here in the future, I just might stay away from the wet burritos and salsa...

This is a hotel restaraunt so it is kind of noisy and not very romantic. I mean from most seats you can look over your shoulder and see families waiting to check in at the front desk. The food however is pretty awesome. Also if you're just looking for a big clean convenient business place to have seafood this is a good spot.

Fried oysters were as fresh as possible.

Seafood Gumbo was the best gumbo I've had in years. A mix of oysters, shrimp, and crab.

Fried shrimp was well fried shrimp.

A quaint little authentic old world style Italian restaurant.  Small interior with quirky decorations, and an outdoor dining patio.

We sat indoors near the open kitchen.  There is some counter seating too. Service was good and efficient.  We ordered a bottle of red wine for three diners.  Most of the wine options are Italian and we got a Sangiovese.

I ordered some garlic bread that was simply delicious and full or garlicky taste, plus a grilled garlic on the side to fetch out pieces to add and smear if you like.

My entree was the linguine and clams.  The pasta was perfect, al dente, with slices of sausage and small whole tomatoes.  There was plenty infusion of garlic, but unfortunately I have to say I didn't detect any clams! One of dining companions had the same dish and remarked the same.

It was all in all a charming place for a cozy Italian meal in a relaxed atmosphere.

Huge thanks to Chris M for setting this up. 

I had no idea or preconceptions of this place. But we were going to be in the backyard at 1 pm for a food event. 
Chris set up an art tour of the hotel prior  to our food event. 

The Morrison Burner Hotel was started in 2013. It was remodeled by volunteers using as much original material and recycled furnishings. The hotel is also ran by volunteers. Their philosophy is based in the ten principles of burning man. Gemini escorted us thru the first and second floors, the saloon and backyard of the 1928 building.  

Steam Punk Saloon is a great space. And you can't knock the prices. 

The hotel hosts various events for fund raisers in the saloon and in the massive backyard, that is complete with a fabulous large stage. 

In the second floor there are hostel rooms and a few full rooms. Different artists have themed many of the rooms, making it hard to choose a place to stay.  The 3rd & 4th floors are for longer term residents. 

If you ever get a chance check the place out. Or if you have partied too hard downtown- stay for the night.
I totally dislike Marathon Grill - I only went back bc I had a groupon. The food is just not good. No wonder the whole Marathon establishment is falling apart.

This place has ads on the buses, voted best for the last twenty odd years or so, blah blah. We were pretty exhausted so we decided to order takeout from the bar. Their supposedly famous gumbo and an order of red beans and rice with andouille. There was a loaf of bread included but it was seriously a dry loofah sponge.  It was all just okay. Nothing too exciting, nothing horrible, basically just a bunch of uneventful nothing.

We came here on a Sat for dinner and got seated right away.  The place is clean but no frills.   The food is quite legit here.  Very good Taiwanese food.

1.  Spicy Beef Noodle soup- very good here, broth does have a nice kick, there was ample meat which was super tender
2.  Beef scallion pancakes- must get here.  Sweet and savory without being too greasy.  Only knock is I wish it was a bigger portion for the price
3.  Juicy Pork Dumplings- came out piping out and the dumpling soup very good.  Not as good as the ones I've had in LA but close 2nd

Overall excellent flavors and very authentic.  Bill came out to be $32 bucks for 3 persons which I thought was very reasonable.  Service was so so.  However for the taste and value, we will definitely come back here again and again.

While I've had the opportunity to try dishes from The Marc over the years at festivals and events, I've only once set foot in the actual dining establishment. And while I wasn't there for a full meal, I was impressed. Not only is the actual space nice, but the staff are fantastic! I was wowed by the fact that there is a Renoir print in one of the women's restrooms for example!

I doubt that I've ever had as good of a blueberry tea for such an inexpensive price as I had at this restaurant. The fries were top notch -- definitely one of my favourite places to eat fries in Edmonton... and oh my goodness the beignets were AMAZING! Definitely one of my absolute favourite places for beignets -- definitely the case for Edmonton! 

The dishes that my companions had that evening looked delicious as well. I was truly impressed with the caliber of service we had at the bar. I would definitely return given the right occasion.
The lemon ice here tasted like it was flavored with off-brand Kool-Aid.

Great! I tried to go to anotehr restaurant, but didn't feel like dealing with the whole BYOB thing as I was in town on business and unprepared for that. I passed by and caught this awesome noodle bar with great hip hop playing. Sign me up! I had the bacon, egg and cheese dumplings and this awesome duck Pho with Foie Gras meatballs. SUCH a good meal! I will for sure be back!

Okay, I feel I have never been steered wrong by Yelp until this moment. But it has happened, so we're going to talk about it, and then i'm going to send you all to your respective rooms. 

Awful food. I mean an awful, bland, flavorless, sorry excuse for seafood. I would feel so embarrassed if I owned this restaurant. I mean, if you're literally right on the water, your seafood should be AMAZING. 

We started with the fish dip, which was 2-3 stars. I've had much better fish dip elsewhere. I want delicious smoked fish flavor and I didn't get much of that at all. You know what I tasted? Weak fish flavor, no smoke, mayo, and the saltine crackers they serve it with. I had to drown it in lemon juice to make it taste like something. 

Then I got the grouper sandwich and my husband got the grouper wrap. EVEN. WORSE. Both of them. So, so, sooo bad. If I closed my eyes I literally wouldn't have been able to tell you I was eating seafood. It tasted like actual nothing. Cardboard and air. Again, drowned it in tartar sauce and lemon juice and still ended up leaving half of a piece of grouper in my basket. I'm sorry you had to die to become that sandwich, Mr. Grouper. That shit ain't right.

Not great! I picked this place because they seemed to have great reviews on Yelp... I'm sorry to say that my fellow Yelper's let me down this time. First of all, the lady on the phone had very poor English and a strong accent so we had an extremely hard time communicating and it was a struggle to even place my order. She had to pass the phone to someone else just to explain that I wanted to add mushrooms to my order. She abruptly hung up and I had to call back to ask about delivery time and cost of food. The food arrived pretty fast but wasn't great. My Shrimp in Garlic Sauce tasted strange... the whole dish had a fishy taste... we didn't enjoy it at all. The beef and broccoli was ok, so we only ate that. The fried rice was very bland and strange. It was yellowish rice with not one vegetable in sight. Not even an onion diced up in it. Very sub par Chinese food. So dissapointed! Order somewhere else if you want to enjoy your food. Sorry!

I just keep finding myself here over and over again... Amerigo is not crazy fancy, its more of a feel at home place. It is always a fun scene, busy bot not too loud. They have all Italian staple menu dishes you like to see there, at the same time they surprise you whit other fun stuff.
My favorite right now is the flatbread pizza with figs and balsamico reduction, feta cheese and ruccola. 
Service is always friendly and fast. Upon seating you are served really fresh, warm bread with fabulous Olive Oil and herbs to dip it in. 
A good Italian restaurant have to know how to serve you a great calamari and yes they do! 
Tip: If you have a bigger celebration coming up, book their room for private dining. You get a lot of great food for your money in a very classy setting.

3.5 stars.

I came to New Orleans with my family for a wedding.  This was our first time in the South, so it was going to be an interesting experience scouting for food and places to go.  Parents of the bride told us about this place, so we decided to check it out.  It's famous for charbroiled oysters.  The bride says it's the best thing ever.  

Additional to ordering a dozen of the charbroiled oysters, we also ordered a dozen oysters on the half shell, and an entree of our own.  I picked shrimp and grits because I had never tried it before, and I heard that it was a staple in New Orleans.  

The raw oysters were decent, but I prefer Seattle's.  The charbroiled were okay, but did not live up to the hype.  I think it was too salty and oily.  However, my shrimp and grits were AMAZING.  The waiter even said it was his favorite dish on the menu.  The grits were cooked perfectly, and the shrimp was too.  I loved the sauce so much...I'd come back just for that. =)  The next time I come to New Orleans, I plan on trying the other dishes...

For happy hour:  $3/$4 beers $0.75 raw oysters.  So good. 

I'm told we broke the record with 16 dozen. I highly recommend the gratin and Rockefeller.
I went to Culver's yesterday with my husband and my son the burgers,fries,cheese curds and frozen custards are so delicious great place to eat at nuff said

This was not bad at all for fast food. Reminds me of a Mexican version of Subway. And I was pleasantly surprised of the flavor of the ingredients of the bowl I selected. About average in price of its competitions. Clean enough. I try it again

If you are going here for drinks and a greasy snack-okay. If you want an actual meal, go elsewhere. Nicks is a local restaurant which is dated and gloomy. The waitresses are usually nice and they are always ready to fill you up with another drink. 

The drinks are cheap which is one of the reasons I drop in from time to time. The buffalo shrimp, and french fries are also notable.

I have a huge sweet tooth and have been to ice creameries/dessert places all around. The ice cream flavors and quality here didn't jump out at me, but it's an overall solid ice cream joint.

Flavors:
-Tried a shitload of things because I'm a greedy fatass. Ones I liked the most were the creole cream cheese and salted caramel (though their salted caramel mix is predominantly more sweet with the sweet cream base).

However, $4 for 4 not-so-mini scoops in the sampler boat is an unbeatable value, like, probably even better value than mcdonalds.

Service:
-Really nice and somewhat timid teenagers working at the counter instead of some airheads with hearing problems and dance to beyonce after scooping

Wasn't aware this place existed off Race Track! I was called to a Race Mgmt Meeting here and blown away when I got here.
I had been to the Ybor location but wasn't expecting what I saw! When I hit the Yelp page, I had to run around looking at all the facets of this jewel! 
I'm not going to rehash what others have already reviewed BUT; those carved tables were visions of beauty were stunning, the view of the brew room from the main dining room was very cool, and the patio bar looked so inviting. The pretzels with beer cheese and a  spicy mustard were perfect with my Redeye Ale! I was first intro'ed to TBBC with their Reef Donkey & True Blonde so I changed it up! I need to come back and hit their menu as it has great teasing offerings! Their taps provide great variety in brew tasting AND wines! I can't say enough about this beer heaven! This is coming from one who lives in Dunedin, home of the "6 Brewery Triangle!"
The best thing about this visit is our team is going to talk to management about holding a special event here! I know it will be a huge success!

As a reaident New Yorker, the closest I've been to encountering a gator was one of the fabled Sewer Alligators, baby gators that were flushed down the toilet once they started growing too big (that or Batmans nemisis Killer Croc, but that's a story for another issue of DC comics).  Looking for activities to do in vacation (we couldn't be drinking hurricanes all the time after all), Cajun Encounters swamp tour was highly recommended. After all, what better way to run into a gator for a city boy like myself?

As soon as we boarded the shaded swamp boat, Captian Emmett had us in great spirits, letting the boat rip right out of the dock and into the swampy bayou. No sooner than 5 minutes in and coming up to the side of the boat was a six foot long gator. Fearlessly dangling a hot dog off the edge of the boat, Captain Emmett had our new aquatic friend jumping straight out of the water trying to get a bite of the hot dog (and maybe some of the Captian's finger too). Driving deeper into the swamp, we stopped six or seven more times to watch alligators, each one seemingly larger than the next one, lunging, snapping and lurking around the boat. 

After seeing the gators, we went further into the swamp, passing by prime waterfront property partly decimated by Katrina. Finally the boat idled into a shallow glade of trees where we were introduced to one of the greatest scourges of the south - feral pigs. As the pigs ambled up to the boat they started ramming the sides for food - Babe this was not. Explaining the total amount of destruction these big fellows do, everyone inched closer into the boat. A huge thank you to the Cajun Encounters staff and Captian Emmett for giving us a fantastic day in the swamp

Great place to hang out on a beautiful day. Whether you're looking to shoot hoops, play baseball, tire your lil tykes out on the playground or let your pup roam free in the dog run area, there's plenty to keep you busy. It's all clean and well kept.

My energetic pup Milo is a big fan of the dog run. There are usually at least a handful of other dogs to run around with. There are a few trees to provide shade (mostly for the dogs) and benches to provide relief for the humans. Milo and I are especially thankful for the water system in place to keep all the dogs hydrated. 

*Dog Park Pro Tip: If your dog has a tendency to bite the heads off of others... stay at home.
*Dog Park Pro Tip 2: If you're an overprotective pup parent that doesn't like for your dog to interact with others of its kind... stay at home (and think about getting a cat instead).

Find the balance, people.

For $9-12, you will have one of the best Po Boys in NOLA, if you can find the place at the back of Erin Rose. The hosts in the kitchen were very friendly and helpful, and both of our po boys were outstanding. I had the pork belly, and my friend had the barbq lime shrimp. I would be hard pressed to choose between the two, so just go with what you most like or what seems good to you at the time.

One of the things I liked about Killer Po Boy is that the sandwiches are not huge, and I did not have an unhealthy or greasy feeling after eating this po boy. The shrimp are grilled, not fried, and the sandwiches were of reasonable size and include carrots or veggies. Grab a drink at the Erin Rose, bring it to the back and enjoy one of the city's finest sandwiches.

To think I didn't go to Tin Can Bar for so long because I was still lamenting the loss of Bait and Switch! While I do miss the prior iteration of this location, Tin Can bar is the next best thing. The same bartender who used to mix my schuylkill punches is now mixing my blood orange margaritas and they are equally kick ass. He is an amazing bartender and I'll follow him anywhere, but for my convenience I hope he stays there. 
The food was so good too! I wish the menu had a little more but what we tried was wonderful. We shared the Nashville wings which are the same as they were with Bait and Switch, delicious as ever. Some of my favorite wings around. My boyfriend got a burger which he really liked. I got the bbq pork platter which was a revelation. The fries are absolutely fantastic. I'd like to say I got collard greens as my other side but alas I got the macaroni and cheese but I regret nothing.  
We are also loving the vibe here. The decor is a little darker which we dig. The pin ball machines, though not functioning during my visit, would be pretty cool, and the outdoor area promises to be lots of fun in warmer weather. 
I can't express my unbridled joy at this place doing its predecessor justice. I encourage my fellow hoodrats to make this place a fixture on their neighborhood rotation, and anyone else to come give it a try.

3.5 stars

The foodie coupons brought hubs and I to the Wild Hare on a Thursday night.  In general, I enjoyed the experience, but I found the place a bit confused, both in decor and in menu.  We were seated in a back corner by the bar, and while I thought the tin signs and such fit right in, we also had one wall that looked like random pieces from someone's attic.  Or someone's grandma's attic.  I didn't really feel a theme there.  This also carried over to the menu...I feel like there were many random seeming international sorts of options.  Maybe stick to stellar pizza or sandwich combos and keep it at that.  I think this place could benefit from some streamlining.

On to the food-we ordered a couple of obscure beers (both delicious), the beer battered mushrooms with gouda sauce, a fig and prosciutto pizza, and a special that evening, veggie gouda stuffed chicken (sense a theme?).  I particularly enjoyed the mushrooms and the pizza.  I also liked the chicken, but I think that this place would really shine if it stuck to more basic fare.  I could totally see myself coming here to grab some apps and drinks or maybe pizza or a sandwich.  Honestly, maybe it's the atmosphere that makes me feel like I shouldn't spend over $15 on an entree.  

One definite bright point in the evening was our waitress.  I found her to be friendly and attentive, without being overly so.

I know...I know, really Five Guys??? 

You know those times when you're out running errands, and you want something good but fast. You know you shouldn't but what the heck, you know it'll taste great. Enter Five Guys.

My goto burger is the cheese burger, you know the double paddy burger with cheese. On this night I went healthy and didn't add the bacon, lol. My toppings (there are14) are grilled onions, lettuce, tomato, and ketchup. We split a large fries, these are truly delicious when cooked right. If they cook them a little too long.....not so good. Anyway, this juicy concoction gets very messy but so what. It is the best burger you can buy at a so called fast food joint IMHO.

BTW, other items on their limited menu are; Little cheese burgers ( only one patty) hotdogs, BLT, grilled cheese, and a veggie sandwich.

So go ahead, enjoy a Five Guy burger and all the free peanuts you can eat!

I ordered take out from Lee How Fook and it was good. It's sooooo hard, let me repeat, soooo hard to find a good Chinese restaurant spot in the city. I HAVE NO IDEA WHY HONESTLY. sigh. Anyways, the take out order consisted of: kung pao chicken, chicken and broccoli, a side of pork fried rice, two egg rolls, and a ribs entree. It wasn't the best Chinese food I've had, but it was fine for what I wanted. 

Easy location to pick up the food too. I just parked right around the corner (double parked for .252 seconds) and went right in (since its located at the corner). The food was not expensive and I'd order from here again.

Pretty good, i got the beef and chicken burrito. Taste wise it really reminds me of Izzo's. There menu os pretty limited but thats good if your indecisive like me, but if you like options and choices it wouldn't be my first recommendation. The quality and taste are great tho! Also a great location.

DISCLAIMER: This is more of a letter than a review. 


Dear Ashley,

I speak for my entire family when I say, THANK YOU!

I get wild notions in my head sometimes and although for the most part I am a planner at my core, I am also helplessly impulsive. I want what I want when I want it and nothing can hold me back when I've made my mind up on something. 

I seriously had no intention of any vacations for the remainder of the year. I made an announcement to our family early in the year that family time will be limited to nearby weekend getaways. Tampa was not in the cards until one day I was watching a Hallmark movie with my wife and got the notion stuck in my head that I would like a family photo with my mother and sisters. After all, we hadn't had a professional picture done since we were kids. 

So I called them, and suddenly the entire family was excited with the prospect of a beach photo shoot, including my grumpy but lovable brother-in-law who only likes to visit two places: His sofa and the golf range. I decided a family vacation was in order sooner than later since mom is getting up in age and Thanksgiving week gave us the best opportunity. Enter Ashley Izquierdo Photography. 


[ THE EXPERIENCE ]

After trying to schedule a session with another photographer, but never receiving a call back, I discovered your page on yelp and liked what I saw. I was surprised that you didn't realize you had any reviews on yelp, but at the time all three reviews were 5 stars. 

Never having worked with a professional before, I was surprised by a few requirements, such as paying in full for my session up front and the minimum guarantee of 45 good photos, but you worked with me to ease my mind and I appreciated you efforts. So many bad stories of prepaying a business for services that are never rendered was a stressful thought for me. I also REALLY, REALLY appreciated how you were lightening fast in responding to my texts as we kept in touch for nearly a month prior to our session. Many times I could see you were typing just seconds after I sent a message. That comforted my anxiety about paying upfront without knowing you (more than you can imagine). 

Also I appreciate your being on time for our session and the extra effort you made in taking specific photos I requested. While you said our session would be available in your gallery in about 2 to 3 weeks, I was delighted they were ready in just a matter of days. I know I called worried because I had trouble opening the files on my moms archaic computer... but once I was back home in Atlanta, viewing them was a snap. 


[ FINAL THOUGHTS ] 

My entire family (including those whom saw the pictures but were not there for the session) LOVED your work! At first I thought $350 was pricey since I am good with a camera and could have done the session myself with a tripod, but it was money well spent and I'm so happy to have made your acquaintance. 

My only suggestion is don't take things to heart so easily. Some people (such as myself) calling to hire you don't know protocol or procedure when it comes to professional photography. Therefore, sometimes a question is just a question... not an attack that you must defend. I truly wish you much success in your future! You are very good at what you do and deserve all the business Yelp can send your way. While we were just a simple 1 hour photo session, your wedding & engagement pics in your online gallery are STUNNING, and your reviews on sites like The Knot & Wedding Wire speak volumes about your talent and professionalism. 

I hope you enjoyed working with us as much as we did with you! Happy to be your first Yelp sale! 


Thanks again,
Richard & Family


2019/8

There is always a line, but it moves quickly.  The courtyard is pretty. The beignets were good, as was the coffee.  Good alternative to a three hour wait for Cafe du Monde. 

There are often coupons available online.

Not sure why it took me six months to get in here (maybe will-power?), but I'll be back, over and over, again. Without a doubt, one of the finest, most unique, ice cream parlors, anywhere!  

Flavors like: Almond Flan, Almond Toffee, Anise Cookie, Apple Berry, Apricot-Grand Marnier, Avocado & Cream, Balsamic Strawberry, Banana Cream Daiquiri, Blackberry Mojito, Blue Cheese Walnut, Blueberry w/ Mint & Orange, Buttered Lemon & Pine Nut, Candied Bacon & Cinnamon, Cantaloupe, Caramel Fudge Brownie, Cayenne Lime Butter, Coffee & Sambuca Cheesecake, Coconut Lemongrass, Coffee Pecan Brittle, Dark Chocolate Peppermint Toffee, Fig w/ Honey & Pecan, Ginger Peach, Gorgonzola & Toasted Walnut
Grand Marnier Cheesecake, Green Tea w/ Jasmine
Green Tea w/Honey, Honey Almond Eggnog, Juniper & Raspberry, Mexican Hot Chocolate, Mint Julep, Peach w/Champagne & Mint, Poblano Lime, Red Velvet, Roasted Red Pepper & Pineapple, Rosemary-Mint, Saffron Pistachio, Salted Caramel, Smoked Gouda, Strawberry Jalapeno Cheesecake, Sweet Corn w/ Cracked Pepper & Raspberry, Sweet Curry, Toffee Chip, Triple Shot Mochaccino, Wasabi - Pistachio & White Chocolate Caramel Toffee, just to name a few! 

Oh yeah, free samples, too... Just don't be a "sample hog". Seriously?

Good experience tonight. We got an email blast that they were featuring 8$ dinners for three specific entrees. 6 ounce sirloin, blackened tilapia, & Chicken Bella were the choices, we both ordered the sirloin medium and it came with two sides. I got mashed potatoes and a side garden salad. Husband had grilled zucchini & mashed potatoes. 

We ordered a happy hour spinach dip for 4$ on the special Happy Hour menu.  I figured they would short portion it, but the serving was quite generous. Husband tried the 3$ margarita and upgraded to a large mai tai and he reports both drinks were excellent. That's high praise from a bartender with 35 years experience. Happy Hour runs from 4-6 and we sat at the bar- I'm not sure if you could get those drink prices at the table. 

The food was very enjoyable. My only suggestion would be not to serve a small sirloin on a mammoth plate, because it makes it look even smaller. I felt the mashed potatoes could have been served hotter, but they were tasty. Silverware was sparkling clean.

BLAZE AND COMPANY BURGER ARE BUSTLING
I hadn't had lunch at Blaze in about a year and was curious as to it's staying power in this de novo neighborhood. Blaze and Company Burger were quite busy around noon on a Monday with about 3/4 or more of their seating occupied.

WILLA JEAN & MAGASIN KITCHEN WERE QUIET
After getting take-out at Blaze I stuck my head into these two restaurants and they had maybe 1/4 of their seats taken. It's no surprise to me, while Blaze offers an affordable quick lunch alternative, both Willa Jean and Magasin are over-priced for uneven quality. Maybe they depend on dinner business.

NEW RESTAURANTS ARE COMING!
It will be interesting to see how this experiment shakes out.

We went for an anniversary dinner on a Thursday night.  We were happy that the restaurant was full and just loud enough that we could have our own conversation without others being able to eavesdrop despite the small dining room.

The service was attentive, which is a huge factor in the overall enjoyment of a meal out.  The wait staff was personal and informative.
 
We ordered two of the special small plates, sardines and calamari with gnocchi.  The sardines had a bit of the flavor of the gas grill, but the calarmari was unbelievable as were our other dishes.  The sausage was excellent with a lot of flavor and a huge portion.  The pasta was cooked to perfection and the pesto had just the right amount of texture.  We also loved out whole fish.  Delicious!

While we are not generally dessert eaters, the waiter brought over some zeppolis on the house.  They were hot, vanilla flavored and delicisous.  As a matter of fact, all of our food was piping hot, which is another key factor to an excellent meal.

One cannot get food like this anywhere else in South Jersey.  Zeppoli is a treasure!

Kim's is good for Northeast Philly. Came for a friend's birthday with a group of 6. Two of them are frequenters of Kim's so we followed their lead. We got seafood pancake, soondubu, two orders of kalbi, cow tongue, and pork belly. I've had better seafood pancake and soondubu elsewhere, so my recommendation is stick with the BBQ meat! For 2 orders of kalbi, it ran about $56. It isn't the typical thick meat I was use to, but rather more like bulgogi thin slices (unless they got our order messed up, not sure). The flavor was good though. The pork belly was eh, I had better elsewhere. I do however highly recommend the cow tongue! It doesn't sound very good, but if you don't think about what you are eating, it is actually surprisingly VERY GOOD!! I don't think it is a very popular option, so if you are ever at Kim's.. order it!! 

They give you free ice cream which you scoop yourself. That was an interesting concept. Be prepared to smell like smoke because the second you walk in, you will get a whiff of it. They have a small parking lot, but more likely than not, it will be full, but there is plenty of nearby street parking. If you are in the mood for soondubu, go to the other tofu place nearby (forgot the name, sorry!)

This is not the Winn Dixie of my child hood. That is for sure! This South Tampa location looks clean and stylish and has many offerings that compete with local favorites like Publix. Their seafood options are well priced(sales on Salmon and mahi mahi for example were less than $9/lb), and they'll cook it for you as well for free. Their prepared foods were also well priced - bourbon salmon for around $4 a piece. They now have a prepared food storefront inside that has chopped barbecue and cooked food items. They also have a gelato station, a coffee shop, and mini donuts! They even dry age meats!

Staff were friendly and incredibly helpful.

Amazing! We hadn't been back to check out this cafe since it was renovated and boy were we impressed. The vibe when you first walk in is charming and yet high energy. The local pottery art for sale on the walls gives it a uniqueness that feels like home; the cool feature walls give it an artistic modern feel; and the outdoor seating creates a welcoming presence. But enough to about the decor. 
The food totally blew us away!  sitting down we took a look around and saw what other people were ordering and we ended up ordering the same dishes as the gals next to us. We had the pho with extra veggies- well worth it to get more veg. The lentil loaf with amazing mashed potatoes and apple chia sauce- this one was surprisingly a favourite and voted top at our table of all the things we tried. As well we ordered the raw zucchini pasta- it was super savoury and the only thing I'll make note of is to ask for a little less sauce. 
Drinks! We had a super delightful peppermint cocao latte- such a delight to the eyes and tastebuds. And the matcha latte one of the best we've ever had- we highly recommend it with cashew milk. 
All in all- well worth checking out- make sure you take some time to see their deserts they change everyday and are displayed in a case at the front.

Not really a surprise as this is one of the nicest hotels in Indy.  Grille 39 was a great place to have a quiet lunch with someone special.  They play a special upbeat (but not loud) techno mix instead of the weird stuff you hear places.  Food was excellent and served fast and hot - just the way I like it.  Everything in this hotel, from the mix of stonework and stainless, carpet and leather, electronics and bamboo, feeds into the atmosphere here.

3.5 yelps. So it seems like our experience was not the norm and that's unfortunate for us. Seeing all of the other rave reviews makes me want to head back and see if the Sunday when we dined was just a rare fluke. I feel like we were jipped out of this amazing experience everyone else had. We were so excited to treat my parents to this meal. We were a tad embarrassed about how it turned out....

Right off the bat, ordering was fairly difficult. They did not speak one word of English. Many mistakes were made and any special requests we had were unable to be fulfilled because of the language barrier. We spoke with two individuals, neither understood us. At all. I think that unfortunately set the tone for the meal. 

We had a larger party and below is what everyone had to say. I personally can only comment on the mushroom tofu soup which I actually really loved and am totally craving right now after looking over my photos. The scallion pancakes were a tad soggy and lacking in flavor for me and the dumplings were just ok. I've had better. A tad too slippery and slimy for my taste. The plain rice was so delicious for some reason. Piping hot. Yum. 

3 yelps Beef soup. Not enough beef. Banchan Sides were good. Ribs were good. Chicken was just alright. 

3 yelps seafood tofu soup just two shrimp (one with eyeballs) Barely any seafood. "Floating yuck". Beef was really good. Chicken was just ok. "$12 for a bowl of tofu?"  Dumplings were good. A little mushy. 

2 yelps they don't have anything for kids. 

4 yelps Excellent rice plains and simple. 

3 yelps mushroom tofu soup was very good. Beef was the best out of everything. Chicken was average. 

3.5 yelps Chicken was not BBQ as stated. 
Scallion pancakes weren't crisp, were too greasy and a tad bland. 

Tons of food so think twice when ordering. Don't forget about all of the side that come first. The place was pretty cute. A nice find for the area. I think everyone could appreciate the authenticity of the meal for example the raw egg to place in our soon du bu, but Something just wasn't happening the way we had hoped and the way it seemed to for others.

This review is for drinks only. 

While walking through the Marigny, I heard some sweet sounds of a piano from Three Muses and decided to walk in. It was a Saturday afternoon so the door was open and the sun was shining in. It was pretty much the perfect New Orleans afternoon. 

I sat down and ordered the Lavender Lace from their signature cocktails menu. The Lavender Lace is a Champagne Cocktail with Housemade Lavender Bitters and it is fresh and flavorful, and clearly got the job done after two or three of them. The place is sort of divey but has a flair to it too. 

Bart Ramsey was the musician during my visit. He is a local jazz musician with his own music, and of course, did some covers. The crowd was all relaxed, taking in some cocktails and jazz. Some were grabbing a bite, but just drinks for me, so I can't review the food. 

I'm not sure if it traps tourists, but it didn't seem to be one of those places. It was sort of down from all of the touristy stuff on Frenchmen. I dug it and if you visit, you will too!

Great location on Ashley street in downtown tampa. Parking garage right next door, view of the water. Tampa university looks pretty all lot up at night. Yes it can get crowded during events but that is what brings the masses to downtown. Ice skating was a bit pricey at $10 pp but that included skate rentals and 90 min session. Lots of happy skaters of all ages made for a good time.

I've tried them a couple times. And I can say there are a few things here that I truly enjoy. 

Their fried chicken is quite good. It's big and crispy. It's definitely the pressure cooked kind and not just some frozen parts thrown into a deep fryer. I think it's a well-kept secret. 

I also liked the pizza rolls and cheese sticks. My son enjoys the burgers. 

I'm not crazy about everything they make. Some of their food is more average. In fact that's exactly how I feel about their wings. 

But they do a few things well and I appreciate that.

Sure it's one small step away from a s&!%hole but the staff is friendly and the patrons entertaining. The important thing to remember is you're here for the pie. And that can take a while.
 
Looking like you're normal, neighborhood dive on the outside, your expectations will be met on the inside. It's dark and weathered on the inside with years of bar smoke yellowing the blinds lett you know, "we've been around the block" and it looks it. A bar that seats around 15 a table and some booths in the main room that looks into a very small kitchen (partially explanes the long wait times). The second room seats more and adds some attractions, Ms. PAC-MAN, Air Hockey and shuffleboard which unfortunately was ocupado. 

We placed out order in the proper order, beer then pizza. Mac was supper helpful in the kitchen. When quoted 45min for our two pies, she proclaimed "I'm fast. It won't be that long" and it was not. With the game room filled with all 21 and up, thank you, we grabbed stools at the bar and began chatting up the Norms. About 30 minutes later we were out the door with one Chicago and one thin together with a large salad for around $40. Not bad when you consider the amount of food in one of the ChiTown delights. Four of us finished of 1 round with another sitting in the fridge for breakfast. 

The bottom line is I liked the pizza but not enough to spend all night in the Black Thorn Pub. That's not because of it's appearance, I'm totally down with a dive but I did not get the cool, dive vibe. Maybe it's better on the weekend when it's packed to the walls. For now, I'll keep coming in, ordering out and chill'n at the bar with some suds until bell rings.

I have always ADORED this location and this building.  Even when it was Liberties, I have always found the interior absolutely gorgeous.  The bar, the floors, the walls, ceilings, lighting, fixtures - everything - this interior has always deserved better.

Better management, better clientele (a loyal one at that), a good menu, a good concept.   The whole time that B&B was Liberties, I came to the place only a handful of times.  The reason?  Not quite sure, except that I felt that for all the beauty the place had, it didn't have much of a heart or a personality, or that something that would make me want to come back.  In a neighborhood, filled with places that are neighborhood places with a loyal clientele and a certain je-ne-sais-quoi-, this place never seemed to get its footing or become the place that it could (should?) be.

Even now, I stil feel like B&B might be overzealous and overambitious in its approach. First, the menu is WAY too big - wayyy too many items on there. There are a bunch of sandwiches, home-y, comfort food, plates and pizzas, too?  That is way too much.  I understand the intent, a menu to please all palates and offer all things, but a menu can't always be everything to everyone, and when it does that, it will always fall short in its execution.   I always find the smaller the menu options, the better the kitchen, and usually the better the food.  The end.

I didn't experiment with the cocktails, although I wanted to, Michelle C. wisely steered me away.  I stuck to a whiskey as I thought I should, and the bartender suggested one for my bourbon/whiskey neophyte self.  The selection, even at a one ounce pour was expensive, but smooth and went down easy.  Lots of nice beers on tap too, which is a must in this neighborhood.  The food as expected wasn't bad, but it wasn't great and pretty boring too.

A pork belly bahn mi sliders were just okay, too much bread, or too little pork belly - and the big slice of jalapeno seemed to overwhelm the small sliders.  The portions for the big plates, are HUGE - massive really - totally generous, but really, I think, too big.  The shepherd pie was ho-hum, much like all others, except that there was one huge briney olive in the lamb stew mix (which I wasn't sure was intended or not) and the fish and chips was nice, flakey but both nothing to write home about.  

I find it promising that B&B is trying to find and create its own niche and with live music upstairs that might prove to be key - If the menu was revised to be smaller, more cohesive and more appealing I could be tempted to return and because I want businesses to succeed in my neighborhood, I will return - I just hope the whole place revisits its approach, menu and concept cocktails.  The place deserves it.

Lunch special 3 rolls for $13 and a soup/salad - not bad. Standard rolls A +. They have large pieces of fish and avocado in them. I've been twice and just have gotten some rolls, and they were all to my liking. My partner got chirashi one time, which was nice. It's right next to another sushi place, which is also good. The waiter we had yesterday was a little odd and seemed to rush us, even though we were the only ones in the restaurant. However, I'll be returning for lunch sometime!

Lunch here is pretty good - for less than $10 for the entree, you can choose from Beef or Lamb Kabobs, Shawarma, Gyro, Falafel, etc. I've had the Lamb Kabob lunch both times I've been here and I've been very happy with the dish - the meat is well-seasoned and juicy (the 2nd time was better, the first time it was a little overdone), their hummus is really good, and the rice is buttery (i.e. yummy). Very simple, pretty quick lunch spot for me. It's never been busy, but I can't speak of how dinner time or weekends can be.

I haven't ever actually be inside, but I've ordered through a food delivery service multiple times.  And, while this might not sound important (what I'm about to say) but it is because when ordering takeout Sushi, these points have been the complete opposite for other restuarants: Their rolls are always so fresh and never have eaten something I disliked, their tight and don't fall apart.  Anything exra you request (spicy mayo, ginger, etc) they always provide.  Never disappointed.

I went here today since it was right next door to auto zone and I was waiting for auto zone to recharge my battery which takes an hour.

Village Inn has wifi so it was very convenient to kill time here and have a nice lunch.  It really was a nice yummy lunch a lot better than I thought. My waitress was so very helpful as well.

I also came here a few weeks later, and guess what I learned. Wednesdays from 10am -close, you can purchase anything and get free pie. Oh yea that was wonderful. We loved it so much, and our soup was so good and the pie afterwards was even better.

The manager walked around and greeted everyone and he was soo funny!  Will be back, maybe even more on Wednesdays for that yummy bonus!

The Wu Xi Dumplings were very good (the shrimp & pork soup dumplings just okay.)
I would be willing to try them again - but need to be more adventurous in what I try because some of their sauces seemed very bland to me, and there are too many ridiculously good places around to stick with bland...
Their white rice was probably perfect however- the best for eating with chopsticks and that perfect slightly sticky texture I haven't had in ages!
Staff was friendly and food came out pretty quickly, which along with decent prices made it a good spot for lunch hour during the week.

Soup dumplings in Philly!!! Check out this spot. They are super friendly and welcoming. 

We visited a but late but they were welcoming and quick to get our good out. 

I have had soup dumplings in various cities and I can say without a doubt these are not only larger than all others but the soup inside is plentiful and a very good amount. 

Yum!!!

I had high hopes for Monsu after reading the Yelp reviews, but was disappointed.  First, the service was very inattentive so that we felt neglected as we slowly pined away without water refills or air in the corner of the overheating restaurant.  Secondly, the food was very salty.

We started with the Zucchini/Escargot special (which we thought was just a Zucchini dish...so we had a little unexpected protein).  The dish really ended up having more cheese than vegetable, so it was like a gourmet mozzarella stick.  

Half-sized portions of pasta are available (but not as an entree), so I sampled the Gnocchi with crab meat - it was in a tasty sauce that overhwelmed the flavor of the crab.

For my entree, I ordered "Goat in the Style of a Horse", which was a completely unenlightening description, but had come highly recommended.  This was a good dish with tender meat, but it also had too much salt (especially with no water in my glass...)

Really good!  I'm definitely coming back here, but I can't help but complain a little about the price... It is overpriced, but in my mind, it's totally worth it.  The interior is very unique and the food was delicious.  Aside from the price, I guess, my main complaints were that the waitress was a bit slow at first, the parking is tight, and the exterior certainly doesn't let you know that this was a very classy restaurant.  The pros outweigh the cons though. Great food and chill place to go on a date or have a meeting. It's very relaxed. I like this place a lot.  If it weren't overpriced, I would be here everyday, but since it is, I will just have to settle for a few times a month :P

I got the Fuji gyoza, miso soup, and cheek dancer maki roll.  My brother got the spicy tuna maki roll, brown rice, and a chicken terriyaki skewer appetizer.  For this simple dinner, it was $48. I guess, it wasn't too expensive, but I think Samurai would have been a bit lower.  Especially if I got salmon teriyaki, which was maybe $10 more than at Samurai.  Its on par with the quality food with Azie on Main but the restaurant isnt as chic which is why its slightly lower in price from Azie on Main by a few bucks. The prices aren't too too bad, just a tad higher than I figured it should be.  The sushi was very fresh and worth it...

The area around Frenchmen St. reminds me a little bit of Little Five Points in Atlanta. You definitely get that eclectic, hipster vibe. Just walking down the street was an amazing experience where every single restaurant had a different jazz band playing. Everyone's doors are open so you can peek in and listen to the music of Nola for a few moments as you pass by.

The food was delicious, although the fries were nothing special. I particularly enjoyed the Scallops dish as they were perfectly cooked, and you can't go wrong with the Pork Belly. Service was great; our waiter was attentive, really sweet, and definitely laid back. 

Although we were limited to our table for 1.5 hours, my dad and I easily transitioned to the bar to enjoy the rest of the jazz lineup. The evening I was at Three Muses, they had 3 local bands, the first one starting at 5 PM. Chris Peters opened for the first hour. I'd say the genre was folk-indie. It was AWESOME. You get to eat and watch local singer-songwriters play right in front of you. The second group, Hot Club of New Orleans (jazz genre), well...these guys, they were AMAZING. They played for a couple of hours, and I wish I had stayed for the 9 PM performance, but I had other things planned by then. Honestly, it was the music that made everything better.

The wife and I have been many times and I've never had a bad slice here. Sure sometimes there may be a wait due to the crowd, but you'll still be fed. Good beer selections, good sides, great pizza. What more do you want? (Try some of their more unusual cheeses on your pie. You won't be disappointed!)

IMO, the beignets here are no worse than Cafe du Monde's, with the added benefit of short lines, live entertainment, and a nice little oasis of a park to take a timeout from the Bourbon street bacchanal in the morning.

They have reasonably priced breakfast dishes other than beignets, too (try the seafood omelet). The music, even at this family-friendly tourist spot, manages to still be excellent. Thank you, New Orleans.

The key has been turned, the motor is purring and the wheels are starting to roll.  Cannot wait to see what kind of ride this place ends up offering.  
Updates will be forthcoming, but for now, the Mercado San Augustin is "officially" open.  
Some permanent stores are now in place--I came home with some good local, straight-from-the-hive honey ($10/pint or 3 for $25)--goodbye allergies!!  
There's a shared kitchen area, but the details, including availability, are still not so known to me.
Check back around August (2011) for the opening of a food market (with pizza takeout) as well as a restaurant (details are still a secret) and hip bar.  Don't know about you, but I'm looking forward to seeing what they end up offering.
The courtyard is wonderful.  The location is great (I can only hope this is the beginning of hip, cool offerings slowly creeping westward in this town!).  The shop owners seem friendly and happy to be here.  And hopefully this will only get better with the inclusion of the restaurant/tavern and the promised farmer's market (with a twist!).  I sure hope everything comes up roses.... er... saguaro blooms!

This store reminds me of a Whole Foods but the name sounds fancier! 

Bought a container of gumbo file here (cheaper than at Walgreens) and, whaddayanno, they do up to $100 cash back on debit purchases. ($80 more than allowed at Walgreens)-USEFUL since I was not able to find any of my bank's ATM around. 

This particular location is crammed but they were able to pack so much wares here, including an impressive selection of chilled beverages, non-alcohol/ alcohol types, snack foods, and loads of ice cream.

I have been dying to try 3 Muses for the past year. I went in with a tourist friend of mine late last year only to run out very quickly when my guest decided it was appropriate to pull out a Bud Light lime from her bag and pop the top. Luckily I was afforded the opportunity to go back last weekend and enjoy dinner with a friend who does not carry her own bar in her handbag. As we sat down, a waitress came over and told us that we were to order at the bar. I knew this was the policy but found it funny that during the course of the night she never let us actually order at the bar. She always came to our table to see if we wanted anything. This was probably because we were in early before the music started. I'm sure they are more strict about the bar ordering policy when it is crowded later during the evening. They had six beers on tap, including two NOLA brewery and two Abita beers which was a major plus. I had an Old-Fashioned and while it wasn't the best I've ever had, it certainly held its own. We ordered lamb sliders, feta fries, rosemary cashews, and goat enchiladas. I loved the fries and the slider, which after eating I found I was too full to eat anything else. Overall, Three Muses is a great place to enjoy a more sophisticated night on Frenchmen Street. I'm holding out my fifth star until I try the Mac and Cheese.

I finally went in here and BOUGHT something after years of just admiring their window displays from the outside.... they are located next to the cheesecake factory in the STL galleria, for those who might not be from here or live here and are wanting to locate it quickly.

The prices are expensive. Yes. I felt that needed to be said. But don't let that discourage you because they have an awesome sale section. It's pretty effing huge. The only downside is  that I almost never find anything I want in the sale rack. I'd made a trip in here a couple of times with my roommate but never bought anything, just browsed the sale section. 

I really REALLY love the customer service. When I tried on my dress, they wrote my name in erasable ink on a little oval mirror/plaque outside of my dressing room and they referred to me by my name the whole time. It was a little unusual at first because I am not used to being called by my name while trying on clothes by people I don't know, but I think that's what's so great about it. No other store (that I know of) does it, at least not in the US. 

Finally, I decided to buy my first item there and they gave me a card to fill out that allows for easier returns and I think on your birthday you get some kind of discount... (?) And all the while I was talking to the woman at the register about how to coordinate the dress and she said for me to come back sometime soon so they can see my outfit. :) The only other place where I've been told that was at a Japanese brand store in Sapporo when I was living over there. I like it when employees show interest in their customers' coordinates. :D

Finally, I must mention the quality....it's pretty darn good! The dress I got is very soft but also thick and very well tailored. The tag says made in China, yes, but it's still very well constructed. Don't let it bother you! I've ordered garments custom made from select factories in China and they have all done stellar work. (TaoBao, for anyone who is wondering.)  Also Anthropologie carries a pretty wide variety of "brands" in the store so there's usually something for everyone. 

I don't see many 20-something-year-olds shopping in here. It's a shame. Their quality is far better than stores like Hollister and the customer service is great too. I get that the prices can be a bit much but if you restrict yourself to sale areas you can get stuff for $20!!!!

Also I must say the comment on here about the store having a smaller selection than the website is kind of out of date....because the store is HUGE and there is by far WAY more stuff in the store than on the website!

I had no idea what frozen custard is before coming here. I just remember being confused and not knowing what to get. 

The first time I came here was a week into arriving in St. Louis. I remember thinking there were way too many people gathered around the funny looking building. I remember worrying if I can find parking. I remember not knowing if I even LIKED custard. My roommate and I stood in line and stretched our necks to read the menu. I don't remember what I got; I just remember how good it was -- smooth and cold -- as it ran down my throat. It was a fairly warm day. The frozen custard made me very happy.

Since then I've come here a few times. I now know their Reese's concrete is really good and so is anything with raspberry, chocolate, or pistachio... or maybe I'm just extremely fond of those things. I know my favorite flavors are their pies and cakes. Their apple pie concrete is divine as is the pumpkin pie one. (Do yourself a favor and don't try to drink pumpkin beer after eating their pumpkin concrete. Your taste buds will be confused.)  I also love how they serve carrot cake flavored concrete around easter time.

I know so many people who leave New Orleans after eating on Bourbon Street come away disappointed. You have to be careful where you eat in this tourist town. The gumbo shop is the real deal. I lived in Louisiana and know what the food should look and taste like. 

The gumbo shop give you a great selection to choose from with many different combination meals, and yes, the gumbo is good.
