The only two negatives are that they do not have good hurricanes and service is slow, but you are going to get slow service everywhere in this laid back city, so it is worth the wait.

I arrived here a bit ahead of the party that I was joining. The host seated me promptly, and offered to open the bottle of Malbec I'd brought with me. I thanked him and poured myself a glass while I waited.

And then my dates arrived. All 16 of them. Just kidding, though I was in fact the only guy at the table - thank you, ballet class. Wine gets poured, orders are taken - soup of the day and calamari - and all the usual comings and goings of a restaurant occur thereafter.

I know complimentary bread with olive oil is a standard thing, but I still find it to be delicious, so that was pleasant.

The food came out, and I thoroughly I enjoyed their mushroom soup. Their grilled calamari was also good - nice charred flavoring, while at the same time retaining a moist, springy-but-not-chewy texture.

Service was quick and efficient, if not overly familial. Suggestions came out quickly, along with answers to any questions we had. Bottles were opened when they needed to be, water was poured when it was empty, nd empty bottles were taken away.

All in all, this place is nice - cozy and quaint. Nothing I'd write home about, but definitely worth a visit. You may love it.

Also, I like that it's a BYO. Though, I may want to hit it on less busy nights.

Pro-tip: Be prepared to be around a lot of college aged folks. Meaning you may make guest appearances in lots of Facebook pictures. Also, this place is cash only!

So one of my favorite movies growing up was Waterboy starring Adam Sandler and I was always curious about that swamp life, haha! The swamp tour was such a unique experience - we got to see alligators, wild boars, and lots of other animals and hear all about the Louisiana bayou. A little pricey (almost $60/pp) but very different!

I swear I've written a review for Roxy's long ago after having been here a hundred times.  Do they get deleted after a certain amount of time?  Who knows.  

All I really have to say is wow, so glad we decided to eat here for our after Christmas 2019 celebration dinner.  We brought our own bottle of wine and and come to find out it's $25 for the corkage fee!  Yikes.  After debating whether or not to purchase one of their bottles of wine, order wine by the glass, or swallow the fee, I decided to talk with the Manager, Jeff.  I let him know that we decided to eat at Roxy's because it had been a while and that I work for a wine bar in Reno where I purchased the wine we brought and asked if the fee could be lowered and he gladly waived it, since it was the holiday's and he's known my boss for quite a while.  Score!  What a nice guy, he was nothing but attentive the whole time, said he's worked there for 26 years.  

Our meals were absolutely delicious.  As you can see in the photos, we had the filet and scallops.  I'm not really a fan of them having a bread server, they can just leave a basket of bread for the table, it's a little awkward.  Before dinner, we sat in the piano lounge and ordered a couple cocktails from the signature menu.

Not sure how my GPS got me here but it worked and sent me through the back. I was almost frightened since the rear entrance was nestled in a hotel of some kind.

Yelp has steered me correctly once more, this time in my quest for some tasty Indian food. We only got take out but everything was well prepared, properly spiced and well served. They did give me chicken vindaloo instead of lamb but I was not about to hike back down Marlton Pike to have it corrected, talk about a jacked up road. Car suspension preservation is greater than lamb cravings.

The chicken makhani, garlic naan, rice, samosas and accompanying sauces were all on point. I look forward to the dining in version for sho! Hands down the best take out I have had since moving here 2 weeks ago.

The Rusty Pelican has a beautiful view of Tampa Bay. We sat at a window seat and looked out at the water. It was very peaceful. The interior is nicely decorated with ornate furniture and table linens.  You can eat at the bar or in the restaurant. There is a banquet hall for large events as well.

The service was professional and attentive. The atmosphere was tranquil. The food..... Wellll, leaves a lot to be desired.

We went for Sunday Brunch. You know us ladies Love Brunchin' on a Sunday! TheÂ  shrimp pasta left a lot to be desired with its overcooked shrimp. The ceviche lacked flavor and seasoning. Here are some of the highlights for me.Â  The Asian slaw - pretty good. The cheese grits - nice and cheesy and delicious. The sausage on the buffet - yummy. The waffles - delicious with that warm syrup and whiskey butter. My first cup of coffee was served with milk that curdled when you poured it in the hot coffee. They redeemed it with a fresh cup of coffee with fresh cream. It was a pretty good cup of coffee. You get limitless mimosas with the brunch. There is Not an option to deduct it from the price. You're gonna pay for it whether you want it or not so ya might as well drink up. Prepare to the pay $50 per person.Â  Honestly, I've had better brunches. Go for the view, the atmosphere, and the service not for the brunch..maybe lunch or dinner.

I hate writing these kind of reviews, because I do not want to come off as a jerk, but I really need to share this.

My husband and I have eaten at the Italian Barrel on several occasions. The last being our wedding anniversary. The place is cute, the atmosphere is romantic, and the food is AMAZING. We're both vegetarians, so it's hard to find delicious food in the quarter that isn't Mediterranean or pizza. My husband can't stop raving  about the porcini and truffle ravioli, and I am fairly obsessed with their orange Grand Marnier sorbetto. Their cheese plates go on for days and are very different from any of the other ones offered in the city. 

"Why, my dear are you giving this place only three stars, Andrea?" you may be asking. Here's why: My husband and I feel that we get worse service than other customers. The place is tiny, so it's pretty obvious.  We are both tattooed but always wear really nice clothes (it was our anniversary!!) and tip very well (usually 20-35 percent, depending on how many cocktails we have had). Our waiter on 2 occasions did not give us the same quality of service as the other (older and ritzier) patrons. We were not read the specials, my questions were answered curtly, and we were not checked on often. It was pretty irritating, considering we were spending almost 80 bucks on a dinner, and it is one of our favorite places to eat. Maybe we came on a bad night? Maybe our table was for someone coming in soon? I will probably keep going here because the food is so delicious, but it's upsetting, nonetheless.

Great way to end a biz trip?  $5 martinis!

Thanks to the suggestion of locals, we were so happy to hear that Roxy offered a pretty great happy hour - $5 martinis from 5 - 6:30.  Awesome!  The bar is tucked in a back corner of the casino (it seemed that way anyway).  We were greeted by the lively piano singer and super friendly bartenders.

The martini selection is intense.  There are soooo many flavors/combinations - birthday cake, pomegranate, martinis made with tequila.  It was great to just look through the menu!  I was torn between a gin/Campari mix and a Makers martini (aka Kentucky), but the bartender ultimately swayed me to get the Makers one.  Can't go wrong with that, right?

They also serve up the full restaurant menu, so you don't need to move to the restaurant if you're just looking for something chill.  We settled on some apps - the duck spring rolls (yum!) and the calamari.  All delish and awesome prices.  (Reno, you are amazing for having some low food prices!)

If I'm ever back in Reno, I will definitely be sure to return for another lovely Kentucky martini.
Tried the chocolate shake...it was great.  Burgers & fries were equally delish.  Charcoals is two for two.

We go here for a pizza night as group 1x per month. I LOVE PIZZA, and BLVD PIZZA is totally UNIQUE. The most important aspect to any restaurant when I find something I love to eat is CONSISTENCY. CHUCK's takes the CROWN, hand's down! Next for pizza, I appreciate TOPPINGS, TOPPINGS, and did I say TOPPINGS? Seriously this pizza is packed to the GILLS, with more toppings than I ever seen put on a pizza, thin crispy crust, and delicious combinations. My PERSONAL FAVORITE is CHUCK's SPECIAL. Prices are higher, but the VALUE is there, because you get some SERIOUS HEAVYWEIGHT CONTENDER food that is ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS! The Potatoes are good, super greasy, but great. Chicken wings average. If you read this review and check it out, let me know how much you love the Chuck's Special! =)

The vibes here are fantastic.  Right in the heart of Bourbon Street.  Loud, good, local music on the weekend.  Drinks and food everywhere. Maybe a good place to have a few drinks and get a little rowdy.  Would definitely never eat here again.

Disorganized line that wrapped into the dining area and took at least half an hour.  You get plenty of time to decide what you'd want to eat by the time you get there, but half the items on the menu weren't marked 'out' once it was finally time to place an order.

Had to try a Po Boy, Gumbo, and Beignets since I hadn't ever had the 'authentic' stuff.  Of all the places to try authenticity - this should easily be one of those places right?

Terrible po-boy.  Stale bread, no sauce whatsoever, way overfried shrimp.  The gumbo was completely under-seasoned.  No utensils provided in a to-go order.  Some of the most disappointing Creole/Cajun food I've ever had and absolutely not worth the wait.

Swing by here for a few drinks and get a little rowdy / listen to some tunes / have some fun.  Don't bother eating here.

I live within walking distance of this place and I wish I had never discovered it... Because I'm hooked! Strong and relatively inexpensive margaritas, friendly staff, and the food was deliciouso! Coming from Arizona, I love me some authentic Mexican food and this is the place to get it. 

The atmosphere is a little different but they also have an outdoor patio. Ready to go back!

Super cute and cozy spot for a nice dinner! 

We loved the Caesar salad, cacio pepe and fiano wine! I would pass on the broccolini because it was super bitter and the spicy crab pasta was a bit oily, but not too bad.

This will have to be my now 2nd or 3rd favorite place to eat in tampa.  The decor is a little drabby, but who really cares when the food is delicious!  Instead of the ordinary bread to start, they serve homemade chips with some delicious sauce to dip.  The I fried pickle chips are also pretty awesome.  And their buffalo wings were pretty close to home.  Our server was fast & friendly and the cost of our meal was pretty reasonable.  You definitely have to try.

This rouses is newer than many in the area and pretty nice. The bakery, meat area, dairy and wine sections are the nicest. I find the workers are hi or miss. Sometimes they are super friendly and helpful, and sometimes they continue to have their own conversations and ignore that you are standing right there. I would only give it 3 stars if it wasn't for the nicer facilities.
its not as many seats as its sister location in metairie behind izzo's.  same decor, same amount of options.  located by sake cafe

Sahara Grill is a charming middle eastern restaurant offering delicious cuisine at affordable prices. Prepare for a feast for the senses, as you enjoy tasty and wonderfully-spiced meat, veggies, salads, hummus, and more. The kebab dinners were very good, as was the cauliflower appetizer. The restaurant owner was friendly, always hopping around to help people out. And the restaurant interior was cozy and welcoming. Overall a great neighborhood restaurant that I'd be happy to visit again!

This beautiful green space in the right ventricle of downtown Tampa is the perfect place to hang out and have a picnic on a beautiful Florida day. You know those days that come about once in a while that remind us exactly why we live in Florida. They don't happen often, but when they do, they should definitely be spent outside. 

With the surrounding museums and the beautiful architecture of UT as a backdrop, there's definitely a lot to look at. For those with kids - two-legged or four-legged - there's lots of space to run around and tucker them out. Bring a yoga mat, do some Tai Chi, or relax and have a picnic; your choice!

While I have yet to attend a specific happening in this park, I can see how it would be a great space for anything and looking forward to enjoying more of it on future visits to Tampa.

This place was rather empty for a weekend lunch time, with only 2 other tables occupied aside from ours. We came for the dimsum. No carts here, just a la carte ordering, and the food comes out as prepared.

The food overall was okay. I liked the chive empanada (don't remember exact name, but it literally translates to "chive box"). The xiao long bao and dan dan noodles were decent. Our group preferred the regular scallion pancakes to the beef ones, as the latter comes with some sauce that was a bit too sweet. We had a vegetarian - the veggie dumplings and veggie soup were meh.

I walked in here looking for some summer clothes.  Tops, shoes, bathing suit. I like BGC because it's kind of a one stop shop. One thing I hate is having to shop at multiple stores all the time. 

I don't know what it is about BGC, but the just can't seem to ever have enough cashiers at any given time.  The lines are always extremely long and very discouraging to a shopper like myself.  I don't expect to zoom through the line all the time, but dammit do I really want to spend 15-20 minutes waiting? Nope. 

This particular day the line was wrapped around the rails and almost to the clothing racks.  I put everything back and rolled on to the next store.  Pissed because I really wanted the things I was going to purchase. 

Note to manager from another retail manager in the biz ::: note your peak times and ensure you have adequate staffing to handle the customer volume.

I really enjoyed this new pho spot on Fairmount. It's walking distance to bars, ice cream parlors and the Eastern State Penitentiary. It is a friendly and quaint neighborhood spot to meet friends or family for a filling lunch or dinner. I loved the 2 walls that had Vietnamese hats and the other wall had a painting mural of a bamboo forest. 

The prices are so reasonable and the pho bowls range from Small-Large ($7-10).  I got the large but should have gotten a small or medium because it's SO MUCH food! ONE Large bowl is good enough for 2 people to share. This pho is way better than spots in DC because it flavorful and not just a bland chicken or beef broth that was poured into a bowl with noodles and meats. I ordered the #32. I will definitely try it again on my next visit to Philly.

During my time in Philly, I've gone out to Fuji Mountain a couple of times to grab some sushi. Being a huge sushi fan and having eaten high-quality sushi in big cities, I was a bit wary of seeing how this would  stack up against what I'd had in the past. But my girlfriend vouched for the quality of their sushi, and no doubt - this isn't your standard generic sushi restaurant with less-than-fresh fish. All of the nigiri is fresh, and the rolls themselves are delicious as well. In particular, I was a big fan of the Cheek Dance roll; it doesn't try to stuff too many different fish and sauces in it, and it has two of my favorites (eel and yellowtail) in it as well. The only downside is that, as with many sushi spots I visit, they rolls have a bit too much rice in them for my liking. The first time we came here, we ended up getting completely stuffed because we overestimated the size of the rolls we ordered.

The interior atmosphere is very nice; you have high wooden ceilings and lots of traditional decor around. The service is very good, and you get your food in a timely fashion. Whenever we've gone on a weekend evening, it's never been terribly crowded...it's definitely a nice spot to hit up in the suburbs if you're looking for a relaxed dinner setting. And good sushi!

Time for Sunday morning Breakfast at the Diner. We have been coming here for years.  A friendly greeting, seated as soon as we walked in. 
No wait for coffee. I had the Western Omelette. The wife had her usual.
The creamed chipped beef over home fires. Fast friendly service, good diner breakfast. Price wise, A good value. If you live in the area you have to dine here. They have been here for 30 years, we dine here often. Have to review dinner next time were in.

I wish this were a Yogurtology, I like the actual yogurt better there but for the $5.00 Happy Hour, I'll gladly hit up this You Say When!!
Lots of toppings and about 8 flavors typically to choose from, the $5 deal from 5-7pm M-F is a no brainer.

While I've happily embraced all of the culinary delights NOLA has to offer, my body immediately began feeling the burden of everything blackened, fried, and sugar-dusted. So it was onward to Rouses for some detox items and fresh produce to snack on in between conference sessions. 

Yay: selection of fruity bolthouse varieties, organic and local fruits, grind-your-own almond butter, and aloe juice
Nay: weak salad bar, not very many *healthy* grab-n-go options... where's my quinoa and kale at? 
 
Plus, my pre-cut carrots were moldy!!! That's right-- I'd looked forward to my prepared package of celery and carrots only to find that it was all a facade. The entire bottom layer was covered in a slimy white growth. Eck. 

Call me a grocery snob since I'm used to shopping at the mega Whole Foods in Chicago, but Rouses worked in a pinch and helped put my body in a place where I could live another day to indulge on more blackened, fried, and sugar-dusted goodies!

I am not generally a fan of Meijer.  I am definitely more of a Target fan.  However, if this location was closer to my house, they might win me over.  This store was extremely clean and when we went on Black Friday, they had some fantastic deals.  I was very impressed with how nice and professional everyone was.

I tend to find myself coming here when I have friends and family wanting to try a boil but still play tourist and explore main sites around the city such as Magazine Street. Food is solid and I've never had any issues. The menu has a wide array of other food options. A solid location that hits a few checkmarks.

Pretty horrible all around.

The best part of my experience here was the $4.99 margarita. Your choice of frozen or on the rocks. They give you a nice pour for 5 bucks, so no complaints there.

Burrito del mar was an interesting take. There needs to be some sort of law against serving imitation crab in a burrito. No self-respecting Mexican I know would allow this atrocity to happen. Then on top, it's covered with this weird white queso sauce that tastes more processed than an imaginary Lunchables/Handi-Snacks hybrid cheese I might have eaten when I was a kid.

The service was fair, but not great.

Regardless of how far north we are, in a landlocked state, I'm certain there are better Mexican options to be found.

We have been enjoying Steak Out takeout (my rhymes are fire) every month or so since we moved to the area last fall.

Our favorites include the cheesesteak hoagie, the Hawaiian pizza, the cheese fries and the Italian stromboli.

Orders are always ready on time and the staff is really nice!

Found the quesadilla we got to be a bit on the oily side, but otherwise, we've enjoyed our food, and everything's been great.

We did also dine in once, and the banter between the servers and the regulars is great.

We will be back! Thanks Steak Out!

(4.5) ~ Very Good ~ Overall (Food & Service)  NOTES: There's plenty of Parking in the back and they do take Credit Cards(MC & Visa).  It's VERY CASUAL with Styrofoam Cups & Plastic Spoons, but it's worth it, b/k the food is VERY GOOD.  Many of the patrons are Indians, which is a good sign of the authenticity of the food.  The TV's are always showing Bollywood Programs too:-)

DINING NOTES: This is Southern Indian Cuisine, which emphasizes more Vegetarian Items than the more common Northern Indian Cuisine.  Don't worry "Carnivores" they still serve MEAT dishes;-)  The Lamb Biriyani is a very good substitute for Lamb Vindaloo fans and I actually think it tastes better:-)

MENU
** Mango Lassi = (4.5) Very Good
** Lamb Biriyani = (4.5) Very Good
** Rasmalai (dessert) = (4.5) Very Good
** Onion/Chilli Uthappam = (4) very good; came with (3) sauces
* Onion Dosa = (3.5) good; came with (3) sauces.
* Indian Chai = (3.5) good

Happy hour is all day on Sunday, which means $1 PBR and $6 margs (they're gigantic and strong, and had my roomie all a-tipsy).  I got the flying burrito, which was definitely tasty.  The burrito was solid, but not remarkable, but I would definitely eat it again.

One super pro about this restaurant is that there are tons of vegetarian options that won't make veggies feel like they're missing out.  My vegetarian friend tried his first enchilada with rice and beans here and thought it was delicious.  Definitely a great choice in lieu of a traditional Sunday brunch place

Endless Summer is one of the top dinner locations I suggest whenever I have family, friends, and other Yelpers visiting in town. It it right on the harbor so you can check out the boats, see some sea life, and enjoy the ocean views. The decor is insanely representational of Santa Barbara culture. And the food options are well diverse, somewhat affordable, and extremely delicious. 

I have been coming here for years, but my most recent visit was the best and most memorable of them all. My housemates and I stopped by for dinner and drinks on the night of my birthday and it was packed. While wait staff were running around frantically helping all the guests the hostess was trying to touch base with all them while also cleaning newly vacant tables and seating guests, we thought maybe another restaurant would be a better choice. After maybe 90 seconds of standing there, though, the hostess ran up to us and kindly offered to seat us right then apologizing for the chaos.

We got our seats, grabbed some popcorn while we waited, ordered drinks and food, and went to play pool on the deck while our food was being made. Pool did cost a little bit but with the free popcorn and decently priced Happy Hour drinks it was well worth the experience. The sunset over the water was gorgeous and we were loving the active crowd. 

About 25 minutes later we hear our names over the loud speaker and find out we have to go pick up our food at the window.. not sure if it is always like this, because we were not at our table, or it was super busy but none the less we picked it up and went to our seats no problem. I ordered the Seafood Louie Salad and it was probably the best/biggest salad I have ever had. I am not a Huge seafood person either but I was won over by this one for sure.

After we finished we grabbed boxes because their portions are so generous and then they came out with a massive mud pie topped with lit candles for my birthday surprise dessert. Best. Birthday. Dessert. Ever. It was massive too! Our table went to town on it thanking our waitress over and over again. The bill came shortly after and full tummies we stumbled out saying many thanks to all the hard working staff.

That's just one of the many situations here where the staff have been over worked yet extremely kind and on the ball. The food is always delicious as well and the portions will have you full for days. If you're not looking for a meal, come here Happy Hour and enjoy the harbor views. I'll definitely be back for that soon!

As a person new to Philly I had to ofc find myself a good cheese steak, and to my surprise cheese whiz is a vital ingredient for a bomb cheese steak. 

Sonny has the greasy, cheesy, heart attack filled cheese steak that you're looking for. None of that fancy five star quality high grade BS. Their lines move fast and the sandwich is moderately sized. Enough for one or to share for two!

Date of visit 04-24-2019:

I stopped into this Starbucks for a drink after driving out to Tampa for dinner celebrating my birthday.  I usually try to skip & forget that one day of the year that references to my age and that time waits for no one.

I walked into this location and was immediately greeted by 2 or 3 employees with a friendly "Welcome to Starbucks", which I have never experienced at none of the other locations! It was around 11pm and coffee shop was moderately busy and most of the seats were taken by folks actually drinking their coffee and talking to each other and not distracted by some form of electronic device.

I walked to the counter and explained to the employee  (I think it was Amy) that it was my birthday and I wanted to place an order for a Java Chip Frap. She wished me a happy birthday with a smile, asked for my favorite Starbucks Gold card. Other employee's heard her and also made a point to stop what they were doing and say happy birthday! I think its the most happy birthdays that I have ever got in one day :) ! It only took the employee a few minutes to get right on my drink making it and in my hands with another "I hope you have a wonderful birthday", which I really appreciated!

The store was very neat and the floors looked like they were just mopped, hard to believe with the amount of traffic that was in the store. The counters were stocked and everything was in place. If I didnt live 30 minutes away I would make this my new favorite Starbuck (Store cleanliness 5 stars). The Ambiance was really nice and laid back, there wasn't any loud music and the other customers didnt have to yell to talk to each other. I got the vibe that I could sit and just chill which I will make a point to do next time I pass by! Thanks for the great experience.

Dosa Hut & Chat House is a bit of a conundrum. On one hand the food is excellent. Supremely fresh and with a variety of Indian dishes that you may not find elsewhere. If you grow tired of chicken tikka, butter chicken, and other items you'll find en masse at other Indian restaurants, Dosa Hut is a great place to visit. Given the name, you'd expect that the dosas, utappams, and chats are prepared quite well and indeed they are. You really won't go wrong with any of them. The curries are also consistently tasty, but not the best I've ever had. For what you get, I think the pricing is a tad high but is not unreasonable.

Where I have trouble giving DH&CH 5 stars is the service and environment. On a Friday, during lunch--which you'd imagine is the busiest period during the entire week--they had ONE employee staffing the entire dining room of 40 or so patrons. With the entire dining room filled up (so much so that we actually shared a table with other people) and other patrons waiting outside for a seat to open up, with one guy waiting on the entire room made it difficult to get any service. Speaking of the dining room, it consists of high stainless steel tables, swivel chairs probably from a discount hotel furniture store, and styrofoam/plastic dining ware.

I think I'd peg DH&CH at 3.5 stars.... the food really is excellent and I have no reservations about heading back frequently, but they really need to bring the other aspects of the experience up to the same level as the cuisine. That being said, my official Yelp ranking will be 4 because it's great to have tasty and different Indian food in the area.

Good wings.  Wednesday is wing day 70cents per wing. Not a bad deal. 

The shrimp and corn chowder was good. Got that to go. The portion size was rather small for a bowl. Got the fish tacos to go as well. Didn't care for them or the macaroni and cheese.

Is dunkin' donuts fancy? No. Can they even really get my order right 1/2 the time? No. You know what it is though? DD is extremely quick, extremely cheap, extremely large in quantity and offers extreme variety. Dude, so extreme.

$1 medium sized iced coffee keeps me coming back. I occasionally go twice a day iffin' I'm in the right vicinities. Most locations offer drive thru's that aren't 6 miles long (cough, Starbucks, cough). That's good enough for this gal. I actually singlehandedly owe them my iota of sanity in the first 4 months of my daughters life. 

Most of the time I drink a big ole' black iced coffee with one cream - if you ask them to add cream you get cream with a side of coffee. But if I'm feeling sweet; man! The flavored sicky sweet drinks are good. SO GOOD.

The food is obviously reheat and eat, its not amazing, but they have options for hangovers or an 'on-the-run' meal for a reasonable amount of calories - covered and covered.

Went here on a recommendation.Got a cup of mother's gumbo and the seafood platter.It had fried  catfish, fried oysters and fried shrimp with french fries. It actually turned out pretty good.oysters were decent sized and the catfish was nice and flakey and delicious! Total meal cost about $32.

A classic place to visit while in St. Louis! I ordered The Christy while is a frosted brownie and the Ted Drewes classic vanilla custard. The brownie was hot so it started to melt quickly which forced me to eat it rather quickly. It was pretty crowded but we still got our order really fast!

Excellent service but underwhelming food for the price, Fleming's is only average when I was expecting extraordinary.

In the past, I used to be pretty skeptical of steakhouses, as I never thought the quality of the food offered justified the cost. Turns out, I was just going to the wrong places, and now I'm more than willing to spend a pretty penny on a great steak. This chain steakhouse in Radnor is located in what appears to be the first floor of an office building. They have complimentary valet parking or you can just park anywhere in the lot next door. The interior is absolutely massive, easily seating several hundred people, and the dress code is more formal than casual (otherwise you my get some looks). 

My girlfriend and I ordered the Newport Filet Mignon (6oz) with Fleming's potatoes, the Certified Angus Beef Block-Cut Craftsman Ribeye (11oz), and the Chipotle Cheddar Mac & Cheese. If you're wondering on prices, the steaks run $45-$55 apiece and the mac & cheese is close to $20. Overall, I wasn't too impressed with the steaks we had. Despite ordering them medium, the steaks came out closer to medium-well, not enough to send back but enough to notice. The outside of the steaks were also a bit too charred for my taste, resulting in a chewy steak. The Filet Mignon was definitely the better of the two. The Ribeye was a leaner cut of meat than your usual Ribeye (something the waitress pointed out to her credit), so if you're a fan of a traditional Ribeye you may be disappointed. It wasn't bad for a leaner cut of meat, but still suffered from the previous ailments mentioned. The Mac & Cheese was the most disappointing. They attempted that baked breaded top, which just dried out the top layer of pasta, and the actual cheese, instead of being creamy and smooth, was clumpy and watery.

Overall, Fleming's unfortunately seems to confirm my past suspicions. From my experiences, the food is not nearly at the quality it should be for a nearly $200 meal. I will say the service was spectacular, as our waitress was extremely knowledgeable about the menu, and honestly saves this place from two star territory. There are better steakhouses for your money.

--- Short Synopsis ---

Good lunch buffet with nice, light, complimentary naan bread!!! My favorites were the chicken tikka masala, tandoori chicken, the methi matar goshi, and the rice pudding out of the available items. The first three went great with rice or naan bread. 

Also, there is a great ambiance to the restaurant with the decor and bollywood music playing in the background!! I will come back here when I crave more Indian cuisine!!

--- Detailed Review ---

I came here for the lunch buffet and enjoyed my experience here.

The complimentary naan bread was thinner than I am use to, but still good and goes well with many of the buffet choices available. I did have to ask the waiter for the naan refills, so be prepared to do that if you'd like more.  

The chicken tikka masala had a nice subtle sweet coconut taste along with chunks of chicken that made it delectable. The methi matar goshi also had a subtle sweet, nutty flavor that I really enjoyed. These two items, the chicken tikka masala and methi matar goshi, were my two favorite items offered at the buffet. The tandoori chicken was good as well.

To spice things up, they have a hot chili pepper sauce available along with a yogurt sauce, sweet n sour sauce, and onion chutney. These were located near the plates and sauce plates at the buffet table.

The buffet style and layout of choices allow you to create your own dish of what you like. Oh, the countless combinations you can make! This means you can try a little of everything on your first go around and then get what you really enjoy. With two types of rice and the naan bread, you have some options as far as what to put the other goods on.

For the ambiance, they have bollywood style music playing in the background along with nice Indian looking decor around the dining areas. These provide for a nice setting to enjoy Indian cuisine. They also have TV's that showed music videos, although the videos were a tad strange to me coming from a different culture. 

As it currently stands, it is $11 per person for the lunch buffet and it is worth it for the food and ambiance you receive.

I recommend this place and will come back to satisfy my Indian cravings.

SERVER REVIEW  only at a belated birthday celebration (Thurs night with a $10 coupon in hand). 

Wow, Carol was NOT a good server.  Probably one of the worst I've had, and I dine out A LOT!    This was the general consensus of our whole table of four.

The first thing I noticed was her impatience when our last party hadn't arrived yet (after 15 minutes).   I told her that my friend was on her way, but I knew what she wanted.  My request was to please give her five more minutes.  

We all ordered then, including our missing party's order.

Our meals came out in a timely manner.   Our last party member arrived in perfect timing!  

When I asked Carol to take a picture of us, she responded "okay, but it'll have to be quick because that table is waiting to place their order."  REALLY?  In my opinion, she could have thought that, but didn't have to SAY it!  RUDE! 

Our food was plentiful and absolutely delicious AS ALWAYS.  The darling little older man visited our tables, as most (probably all) others.  We complimented him on our food and chatted a bit.  

My one friend wanted to place a take out order for her children, as she told Carol earlier on.

She placed it, no problem.

As Carol came over to our table again (we saw her coming towards us, with how our chairs were turned), she ROLLED HER EYES (two of us caught that) when (the ordering) one friend turned a certain way and Carol accidentally hit her shoulder. 

No apology or anything.    WOWEE!!!!!!   

Her very small tip reflected our thoughts.  I have never posted, nor name dropped a server until now.     

If you can't stand the heat, literally get out of the kitchen!

Food tastes good, service is not bad and decor is simple. It is nothing fancy. However, it is quite pricey for what they are offering. But I have found out that with most Korean Restaurants they are pricey in general. I came here twice with friends. The kalbi seemed overcooked when we had it. And when we cooked our own, it tasted better. I like that they give free ice cream after your meal. 

They are quite popular. Each time I came we had to wait for tables, because it was super crowded. Places like this, it is good to go with a group of people.

I have been eating here for years upon years. When I cannot get off campus to Shere-E-Punjab, this is my go-to spot. 

And since the renovation of last year or so, the space and -- somehow -- the service have improved substantially. My favorite about the new space: gorgeous windows that let in natural, bright light, and I've developed quite the affinity for the bright green chairs there. 

What to know? 

This is a small, super casual and speedy restaurant. And, after placing your order, you can be sure that your food will be prepped and ready to go within 10 minutes or so. 

My favorite is the saag. Doesn't matter if you have it with chicken, paneer or whatever else, the dish always carries a lovely flavor, with a hint of mustard seed. Nice. 

But where are the issues? 

The place can get crammed very quickly during the lunch rush. That makes for too many awkward situations. 

Also, the veggie samosas and the tikka masala are strangely flat on the flavor. Just...not interesting at all. 

I hear the tikka masala is the most popular dish. How?! There is SO MUCH MORE going on with the menu offerings, I cannot believe the tikka is the go-to item here. The tomato sauce flavor is strong with this one. 

The bonuses?

I've had great luck with the curry and korma. The aloo matar and the biryani are also quite nice. 

And the Q-roll -- brilliant addition! It's yummy, spice-enduced flavor wrapped in a thin bread-like tortilla with crisp lettuce and this glorious sauce. Seriously?! Perfect for lunch. Try the lamb and haryali rolls. Yum-yum. 

Also important to note: You have the option of mild, medium or spicy. I tend to go with medium, but find that I often wish I had gone a bit more spicy than that. I was raised in Los Angeles. Tobasco sauce is a fun flavor additive. Dave's Insanity offers just an enjoyable rise. ("Give me the habanero, I say, or give me death!") So, for me, the spice often runs mild and dry at Kababeque. 

What else is important to mention? The favorite and enjoyable naan!

You have the option of plain naan, or a whole selection of flavorings, like cheese, japapeno, lamb, aloo and other naans. Seems the garlic naan is pretty popular here. I have not tried anything other than the plain naan. It's pretty amazing. The size of two adult faces for a little more than $2. Nice pricing there. 

So, yes, highly recommended, especially if you are on campus or visiting campus.

came here for valentines day and had a wonderful meal!

we didn't get the combo but ordered a la carte since i only wanted the beef orders. we got the kimchi pancake, egg souffle, doenjang jigae, bibimnaengmyun, pork belly, boneless beef ribs, beef sirloin, and prime rib

the kimchi pancake was good, nothing special and same with the egg souffle. the banchans i was a little bit disappointed in, they were mostly vegetables or pickled vegetables; very simple. i really appreciate the variety of banchans at seorabol since they contain meats or protein 

the meats came out and we began to grill! all of the beef and pork was so delicious! no complaints at all. service was a bit spotty but it was v day! luckily i'm not rookie in the korean bbq game so i don't mind cooking and cutting my own meats.

the bibim naengmyun was good but something was missing to me, maybe something in the sauce or maybe i wanted the noodles to be chewier? but compared to seorabol i would say they're on the same level

the doenjang jigae was a surprise hero; it was spicy, good pork flavors and i really enjoyed it! 

all in all, it's good to have another korean bbq option in the area and i'm a fan! welcome to the neighborhood!

UPDATE: Realized I wrote my review for the wrong location, but Yelp won't let me delete this one. Apparently this location is a bit more of an "evening spot" and doesnt have the same charm as their location on Royal Street. Would recommend the other location for breakfast and sitting and this one to go.

------

Looking for a beignet fix without the wait?  Cafe Beignet serves 'em up hot for a great price in a beautiful setting.  Find a spot in the courtyard and enjoy your food under the shade of the Louisiana State Courthouse. Or take your food to go as you stroll around town! 

All of their menu items are less than $10 but some are a little ridiculously priced - $9 for a cup of gumbo? I mean it's delicious and I want it and I will absolutely still buy it, but i could buy 12 beignets for that price! They serve a great standard breakfast (think bagels, waffles, omlettes, etc.) on top of authentic Nawlins specials like red beans and rice, jamablaya, gumbo, and muffalettas.  

I've come here every time I've been to New Orleans, and I'm always pleased. Even in the busiest seasons, they have friendly and fast service, and their food maintains its quality.  Definitely worth visiting if you're looking for something off the beaten path.

Mafiaoza's is a pretty big place, but the outdoor patio, which is covered by a red tent hung with jumbo christmas lights, was pretty packed on a Wed. night during the summer.  The inside, on the other had, was almost empty.  I couldn't quite put my finger on the customer demographic at Mafiaoza's - there were a lot of young professional types, but also a few families and lone old dudes nursing a beer at the bar.  My party of 5 was seated right away at one of the high tables outside.  

The fried ravioli seemed to me like glorified mozzarella sticks, but the bruschette was great - thick slices of crusty break topped with ripe tomatoes, really fresh shredded basil, and parmesan.  The pizzas come in 2 sizes - the 12" "capone" and the 18" "don" (all the dishes have cheesy mafia names like "the greek" and "the associate.")  The greek pizza was generously topped with feta, tomatoes, green peppers, and onions.  It was pretty good, but as a former professional pizza artist, I have a few complaints: the crust was thin but a little soggy, it seemed like there was barely any tomato sauce on the pizza, and the toppings weren't evenly distributed.  

We skipped the list of 120 different wines and went for the happy hour 2 for 1 draft Yazoo served in little jars.  The service was friendly, and we didn't have to wait long for our food.

First things first,  Brio is a beautiful restaurant with it's nice marble accents,  draped fabric,  and large floral arrangements. It is spacious, lavish, and has a nice patio.  Their entrees are decent but they have an awesome happy hour! Anytime i can get a good buzz and get full for under $20, it's a win! They have large, tasty appetizers and cocktails apart of the happy hour that start at $4. The burger is good, flatbreads, and shrimp are good.  Remember, it's only available in the bar area and patio. Some of the dishes are kind of salty but they still taste great.

Brand new elegant steakhouse situated inside the Bacara Resort in Santa Barbara. Executive Chef Vincent comes from a background of having worked at 3-Star Michelin restaurants in France. Would highly recommend the two hour trek to get here from L.A. for the food alone + Breathtaking views from the patio and a menu that delivers real Certified Kobe Beef from Japan at $20 an ounce (3 oz minimum order). Never have I tasted beef that oozes of juiciness and melts in your mouth like that Kobe. 

It is a steakhouse after all in which I recommend sticking to as many meat products as possible such as the super fresh Beef Tartare as a starter served with potato crisp, black garlic, egg yolk, spinach. Or the Roasted Bone Marrow - oxtail marmalade, pistachio gremolata, herbs, grilled sourdough, better than any other version of marrow.

Their steaks come with optional SAUCES: bÃ©arnaise, red wine sauce, assorted peppercorn sauce, horseradish crÃ¨me fraÃ®che, beurre blanc, Angel Oak steak sauce similar to A1.

HOUSE BUTTER: coriander-lime-espelette, or truffle and herb.

Each main dish could be enhanced with the addition of : lobster tail, pan seared foie gras, shaved black truffle, or Alaskan king crab.

The food, drinks, service and views blew us all away. Cannot wait to return ASAP to get another fix of their mine meals and that KOBE!!!

We only tried a large cheese pie and garlic knots.  The pie was on the smaller side compared to other places in the area.  The crust was a bit too thick for my taste and not crispy.  The sauce was very good.  I would go back to try the food and will write that review but as for the pizza I don't think I'll be getting it here in the near future.

Needless to say I think our park is bomb, even though I'm the first to admit I've gotten lost trying to get Out of it. The trails all throughout are awesome for running and I love all the bridges and ponds. I ran through a little natural habitat today I'd never seen and realized how huge this park is (and how diverse!)
 
 I love what is encompassed here as well: The Muny, the (free!) Zoo, the Boathouse (paddle boating!), the History & Art museums (and Art Hill!), etc...it's amazing how they've created such an "escape from the city" right in the heart of it all. 
   
 It's incredibly well kept and is patrolled frequently--I never feel like I'm unsafe or unprotected, even when I go alone. It's the perfect place to go play a friendly game of football, attempt rollerblading (don't do it down the history museum hill, you'll have battle wounds--trust me), go for Twilight Tuesdays, or a cool event like Shakespeare in the Park that just wrapped up--there's Always something unique and fun to do here!

GOOD MEAT. I've only had the cheesesteak here but they have good steak. The sandwich isn't ovewhelmingly humongous so that's nice. And the staff is awesome. This is the place I always suggest to visitors. Cash only though.

Trish found a Groupon for this place so we decided to give it a try. Located in a small strip mall, the interior was average and clean with about 15 or so tables. Fusion restaurants are kind of a gamble, with trying to cook several types of cuisine, inevitably some come out better than others. This was in fact our experience here as well. 

Our specialty roll( can't recall name) was very good, it was a pimped out  shrimp tempura but with avo and spicy tuna added to the top. In hindsight we should have just stuck with sushi. But Trish craved Udon, and I some Mu Shu. We both selected chicken as the protein and both regretted it. While the rest of our dishes were average, the meat was below that. Funky texture and taste and detracted from the overall taste. I like my Mu Shu with pepper oil, and this one was excellent, pancakes however were a bit stale and did not roll very well. 

Our servers were friendly and funny, and for the savings( $15 for $30 worth of food) we might return for an all sushi feast.

I feel like I could be a secret shopper at Walgreens. I love that all of their stores are truly laid out in the same pattern. I have never had a rude or impatient worker at Walgreens. I stop at a Walgreens every week. Their sale ad is the first thing I read in my weekend paper.

Monsu was very good.
There was a complimentary bite of blowfish and sweet berries on a cracker that was interesting. Couldn't taste any fish though and a bit sweet for an appetizer.
The snail appetizer was very delicious. Great sauce. Highly recommend trying it.
Gnocchi was delicious. I like the bit of pistachio crumbs that gave it a nice crunch.
Tagliatelle was very nice. Mushrooms were delicious. Pasta was fresh.
Serving sizes were not large but actually perfect if you don't want to be stuffed since pasta can be heavy.
Friendly service- The waitress was very warm but it was hard to hear the laundry list of specials. Cash only and BYO.
Overall a good place to try out.

Nada hit the spot for a fantastic Saturday brunch on a recent visit to Indianapolis. 

Although staying in the trendy Fletcher Place neighborhood, my friend and I found that the brunch spots in that area proved to be painfully overrun on a Saturday morning. After searching the Yelp app for "brunch", Nada popped up as a top pick. It was a short trip to downtown, and we found ourselves in the hippest brunch spot imaginable. 

Nada has a vibe that's a mesh of swanky Latin American restaurant, cozy lounge, and trendy bar, all wrapped into one. We were able to be seated immediately and started out the meal with a coffee. Even black, it had all the right flavor and smoothness to be satisfying. 

For brunch, we both decided on the Eggs Benedicto; it's the Eggs Eenedict that you know and love but with a little Latin flare as well. Flaky crab instead of Canadian Bacon, and Hollandaise sauce that has just the right amount of picante added to it. After questioning the server I learned that it's thanks to just a touch of sriracha. Duly noted, and my own adventures in attempting to replicate it can begin soon!  

Speaking of the server, despite the place filling up throughout our meal, he was just the right amount of attentive while we ate. He never lost his upbeat attitude even with the frenzy of high school cheerleaders that filled the place up (apparently they were in town for a convention and all decided to eat at Nada). 

I hope that I'll be back soon to experience another meal at Nada, but in the meantime it's one spot that you don't want to miss for a perfect weekend brunch!

Decent wings - sauce seems to hang on outside of wing as a posed to saturating it though.  Frefer the latter.

Decent beer prices, but tall special didn't start until after 9pm when I went :(.  Great sports atmosphere, And a trivia contest was in full swing when I arrived. Looked fun!

When I saw that Ritz East was a Landmark theater I knew I was in good hands. I've been a huge fan of their Tivoli and Plaza Frontenac locations in St. Louis for years, so I know they are pretty much synonymous with quality independent and foreign films in a nice atmosphere. 

As far as I know they are the only theater showing Moonrise Kingdom anywhere in the city, which is a major plus. The ticket prices, too, are extremely reasonable for the location--$9.50 for Saturday evening shows, $6.50 for shows on Wednesdays, and $7.25 for matinees are pretty stellar prices if you ask me. 

My only advice, which is less of a downside and more of a peak-time reality, is to show up a bit early on weekends. When we went for our 8:45 p.m. show yesterday (Saturday) the theater did get very crowded, and a sign posted said that the 7:45 p.m. show had actually sold out. We ended up buying our tickets about half an hour early and walking around for a bit beforehand, which worked out really well because when we came back the ticket line had gotten really long and the theater was starting to fill up. So, be prepared to come early if you want your pick of seats.

I've come here a few times since my last review (which I still stand behind) and I have tried a variety of things on the menu that I really enjoyed. For me, this place is all about location (I can walk here from my house) and ambiance (I am 'outdoorsy' in that I like to drink on patios). 

I LOVE sitting on the patio and enjoying the margaritas by the carafe (the best deal in the house) on a nice day with the breeze blowing. On my last visit, my friends and I really enjoyed the empanadas & the mussels, and thought that the ceviche & the tamale were just O.K. (No melted cheese should be ON a tamale, it should be IN the tamale, right?)

They serve Sunday brunch which has some gluten-free options and cheap mimosas (if you like your orange juice with just a splash of bubbly).

My new favorite Mexican place!! I recently moved from out of state and it's been so long since I've had good Mexican. This place was a godsend. 

We started with the staple mexican app - guac. Like most people do when dining at Mexican, I ate about a days worth of calories in chips, salsa and guacamole. Totally worth it! The guac had thinner consistency but was still tasty. 

I couldn't make a decision on my entree and then I saw a picture of the Molcajete on the menu and convinced my husband we had to order it. Pictures get me every time! This magnificent dish is plenty to share for 2 people. It comes with literally everything you could want - chorizo, chicken, steak, shrimp, veggies, rice, beans and tortillas. It is served in one of those hot pot lava dishes and it will be insanely hot so do not touch it! Every bite was absolutely amazing but the chorizo and shrimp were my fave. It was the perfect way to get a little of everything. Can't wait to come back here!

I was pretty pumped when I saw a Dunkin' Donuts being built on 5th street. Granted, I usually take 370 to get to work, not 70, but I figured I'd take a brief detour once every so often to grab me some donuts and iced coffee. (Plus they finally reopened the 70 bridge..fuck yeah, MoDOT!)

I went on the grand opening day....(oddly enough, I had a dream before it opened that I went there on the grand opening and there was a gigantic tray of donuts in the middle of the store and people could eat as much as they wanted--wtflol)....and it was CROWDED as balls. Not surprised though! They had people dressed up as gigantic donut and gigantic coffee which was pretty silly..can't help myself not to honk at 'em when I drive past. And also funny b/c the McDonald's across the street felt the urge to 'compete' or more like join in on the ridiculousness that is people in giant food costumes in the hottest month of the summer, lol.

Clearly they have some kinks to work out. Lots of fresh employees who have clearly never worked in fast food before (is this considered fast food? I guess if you consider starbucks fast food, then yeah?) and lots of newbie mistakes made but hey that's okay. I didn't mind that they spilled someone's iced coffee all the hell over dodge....I was just glad I wasn't the first person in line when it happened...that person got a little bit splattered, lol. They worked really hard to clean it up, though, and were cheerful about it, not angry.

The people who work here are SUPER nice and super excited which is refreshing but I can't help but wonder how long that will last, lol. They have little pieces of paper with all the donuts on them (sans seasonal I think) which makes it way easier to order when you're getting a dozen for your coworkers...I wish other places had thought of that sooner! Plus you can take those back to your office and maybe survey which kinds ppl like so no donuts get wasted on your next order. ;) 

The only downside so far is that the iced coffee is never consistent. The first time I got it, I couldn't decide if I wanted cream and sugar or not b/c I'd actually never had one before and I was worried it would be too sweet so they did half for me and it was close-ish to being just right for my tastes, but the second time I asked for full cream and sugar and it was too creamy and not sugary enough....maybe I am just a n00b to DD myself, but I don't get why they don't just let people put their own in like at starbucks? Maybe they did have some but I didn't see it. IDK. I'd probably go back when I am not running late to work and have more time and figure out the correct proportions to suit my tastes for future reference.

Anyway! I haven't tried their breakfast food yet but I suspect it's deliciously greasy and amazingly bad for me yet tasty. DD is a BFD here apparently b/c there used to only be just the two in the airport but I heard the dude who owns those (Indian guy, I think? and his fam?) opted to open more DD's up, so there should be at least one or two more coming to the area....St. Peter's, mebbe?

Go get yo sugar fix!

We tried Verde during Devour last month - it's always a gamble trying a place out that's a 30+ minute drive but this was totally worth it! Street parking was all full but there is a lot behind the restaurant designated for the shops and restaurants that Verde belongs to.
This was one of the most "bang for your bucks" places on the devour menu this winter - for $30 a person I was able to get their queso fundido, an order of quesadillas with rice and salad on the side, a full size margarita, and churros with dipping sauces. I definitely was not able to finish neither my drink nor my dessert but I thoroughly enjoyed the app and entrÃ©e. I think the portions are big enough that even on the regular menu I would be satisfied with an entrÃ©e for the price. I definitely want to come back for more of their entrees - they have a pretty hefty menu! They also have 2 other locations in Fishers and Ironworks for those who can't make it to Carmel!

After starting out at Ruth's Chris steak House we decided instead on the Roxy.
We were happy we did.
The food was delicious and plenty of it. Our server was very hospitable and patient with the party of 10.
The price point is below Ruth's Chris but still in keeping with fine dining. We were very pleased.

OK. I Always attend their buffet when In Cherry Hill. It's Consistently Very Good. Service is STILL SPOT ON! My Place for Indian lunch In Cherry Hill. A great selection of Indian Foods, Fresh Naan, Chutney's and Dessert. A GREAT place to try for the first time, you'll keep coming back.
Very nice and welcoming. Parking is easy. Selection of products is diversified and fresh. Friendly staff. Can't make groceries without running into people I know.

Fear not, my carb fearing friends, these carbs will make your calories worth it!

Yep, I'm that friend who is always ordering protein style burgers and sandwiches not necessarily because I'm trying to cut back on calories, but because half of the time, the buns completely overwhelms the star of the show and acts as less of a supporting actor.  

When I order a burger/sandwich, like a properly raised gentleman, I'm mostly interested in whats on the inside, rather than what's covering the outside.  Thus my reason for normally omitting the buns.  

To be fair, whenever I am visiting a restaurant for the first time, I always give the buns a try to determine what category the bread falls into for next time; pass or stay.  

Rockfire Grill, you won my bread discriminating heart with your soft savory flatbread!  After having the pleasure of consuming my meal, I wondered, why aren't more places using flatbread?!  My feeling is that before long, more places will....if they like seeing extra $$$ flowing into their registers.

As I mentioned before, what's on the outside matters little if what's on the inside is repulsive, but I can happily report that we are looking at an evenly attractive and juicy burger no matter which angle you take.  Great roasted veggies, unique sauces, juicy meat, and soft and savory flatbread.  Fries are crispy and every table is set with 4 squeeze bottles of sauces.  

I'm coming back for you Rockfire, and next time I'm going after the pizzas!

UPDATED REVIEW:

I have been on again, off again on this diet (I follow it loosely when I don't eat their prepackaged meals). I was doing the auto delivery plans after purchasing gift cards from Costco where you get $100 worth of food for $60 which is a bargain. Yes, you supplement the breakfast,lunch, and dinner with additional items like vegetables, eggs, dairy, etc which I figured and didn't mind. The snacks were actually good value compared to individually packaged things from the grocery store. 

My problem is that they are dishonest in their advertising and deliberately omit information that they should legally have to list. 

I got an email earlier tonight that there was a 50% off sale on all a la carte entrees due to President's Day. No mention in the ad regarding when it expires. Their website listed the ad as well and likewise, no mention on when the promo ends (this might not sound like a big deal to most people but when you are in California, the time difference can make the difference in getting a promo or not getting a promo). Right when I selected my entrees, the promo changed to just getting free shipping!!! I couldn't believe it. Anytime I have seen promos like this for different companies they list the date and time that things expire. Not South Beach. 

I canceled my auto delivery and have like $250 left over in gift cards. If South Beach doesn't try to make this right (I messaged them about this), they lost me as a customer and I will just sell my gift cards on Ebay or Craigslist. In any case the diet itself is easy enough to recreate doing yourself (it was convenient for me, but the pissed me off to the point where I'm done). Want to do your own South Beach without dealing with them? Here you go:

Breakfast- 2 eggs with veggies and a little cheese

Snack- Low carb/low sugar protein shake (I like Atkins and I get the ready made shakes off Amazon for a good price)

Lunch- small garden salad and a protein bar or shake (usually I do a Think Thin bar which I can often get for $1 on sale at Ralphs)

Snack- plain lowfat Greek yogurt with a little fruit

Dinner- tuna salad with a few whole grain crackers

Snack-Cucumber slices and pistachio nuts

The only silver lining from this was that it was convenient, I never felt like I was starving, and (the main one), they give you a little purse size book which you keep track of your exercise and what you ate for the day (I ever did this), but the listed about serving sizes and recommended ways to eat when you don't order their food. 

It's a shame that that the cons with this company were really bad as this could have easily been a lot better. If you see gift cards on Ebay and you think it's me, ask for the Yelp Special LOL.

This is only a review for the pecan pie. 

My hubby says it's the best pecan piece he's ever had in his life. He's histrionic though, so take that how you will. Haha. 

Our sever was a really funny guy and made jokes about us just poppin' in for dessert. I liked him. Everyone else who was there was going to town on their meals. We got a couple of drinks that were serviceable. Food looked pretty good. 

The pie was really good! It has a much chunkier texture than what I am used to - I feel like most pecan pies blend up the nuts too much. I liked that there were more whole nuts in this pie. Perfect with a scoop of ice cream on top!

--- HAPPY HOUR EXPERIENCE ----
First of all, this place has a solid happy hour menu and prices. $5-6 drinks and their appetizers are at $7- not bad for a steak place. 

The hostess who sat us down was kind of rude and wasn't super welcoming but we dismissed it because we really wanted to try the happy hour. 

Friend and I ordered: Kobe beef sliders, spicy crab and artichoke dip, and potato skins plus blueberry lemon drop and blood orange margarita for drinks. 

Kobe beef sliders: ok they only gave two sliders but it was DELICIOUS. Perfectly grilled. No complaints. 5/5

Spicy crab and artichoke dip: I'm happy to find out it wasn't drenched in cheese but it wasn't spicy enough. It was okay...overall. The real winner were the pita chips of this dish. 3/5

Potato skins: 4 pieces, it was good and crispy but not my thing. 3/5

The drinks were a bit sweet but very good. Luckily our service improved when we met our actual waitress. She was awesome. I had to take a few stars off for the unwelcoming atmosphere and a few mediocre appetizers. 

I will be back to eat all of the Kobe beef tho.

Cavan is a new addition to the Magazine restaurant scene and after hearing raves, I couldn't wait to try it.

We made reservations a few days before and we were only able to get in at 9:30, so make your reservations early. When we arrived we were immediately seated at a lovely table in the downstairs area. The restaurant is in a house that has been renovated and I like that it still has the feel of being in an old house. You sit in lovely chairs with an antique feel and there are even a couple of sofas with tables where you can eat. The upholstery is a rich red and the decor of the rest of the space makes for a romantic feel.

As for the food, we started with the fried oysters and the raw oysters. The fried oysters came lightly fried on a nice toast. They had a lot of flavor and I enjoyed them. The raw oysters were amazing. I don't know what it is, but these are the most unique raw oysters I have ever had. They weren't as salty or big as some other oysters I've had, but they were extremely juicy and the cocktail sauce they were served with complimented them perfectly.

For my entree, I had the seared gulf fish that came with shaved fennel and white bean salad. The portion was nice and the fish was perfectly cooked, but not so much that it lost the flavor. It was a little cool in the middle, which I liked. The white bean salad was served cold and provided a crisp balance to the entire dish.

For dessert we decided to get a couple of Irish coffees, which was some of the best Irish coffee I have ever had in my life. It was real Irish coffee and not some overly sweet concoction that some bars might serve. It was a great end to the meal.

I loved my experience here and I would absolutely return. The wait staff was attentive and kept our drinks poured and made sure that we had everything that we needed and that we were satisfied.

I fell for the hype. I'm a big fan of unusual ice cream flavors, and this place advertised tons of them, so on our trip to NOLa, after eating at Commanders, we made the short extra trolley trek out here to try this ice cream, which I thought would be just as impressive as all the various other amazing ice cream shops I've been to. It was... decent ice cream. Pretty good, even. I'd give it 4 stars instead of 3 because it's pretty cheap - but I could also tell the difference in quality between a place like this, and a place that can get away with charging 5 bucks for a cup instead of 3. And they didn't have that many exotic flavors when I was there, either. I don't even remember which flavors I ended up getting, and it's only been a couple weeks. Granted, it's been a *crazy* couple weeks, but still.

Wow! I have driven past this place for years and every time said to myself "I need to try that place!" And tonight we finally did! I am a HUGE fan of all things hot chicken, fried chicken, chicken tenders, etc. and this place did not disappoint. 

I got the jumbo tenders (3 large tenders on top of a piece of toast and topped with a pickle) and a side of the mac & cheese and Parmesan fries. I highly recommend this meal if you're unsure what to try! The fries are a very generous portion and they go great with the hot honey dipping sauce. My fiancÃ© got the chicken sandwich with the mashed potatoes which were also very good! 

As far as spice level, we both tried the "Tweener" which was a 4/6 on the spice chart. This was a great choice if you like hot, but don't like runny nose/crying hot. We both think we could probably handle the "hot" which is the next level up next time we go.

I love going to Fresh Thyme! 
Their loss leader buys on meat and produce on the front of the circular can't be beat! Excellent buy on all natural chicken breasts, raw shrimp and sausage! When they have their bacon on sale, BUY IT! They have THE BEST BACON! They have 3 different bacons available at the deli counter- thick cut, applewood and peppered! Buy all 3! I love using the peppered bacon with roasted Brussels sprouts and with appetizers that call for bacon. The pepper gives it a kick. The applewood is phenomenal and the thick cut is perfect or sandwiches. Also don't pass up their sausage when it is on sale for $1.99 per pound. They have a lot of great choices for chicken sausage and pork sausage and if you don't see it, pre-order CHORIZO SAUSAGE HERE! Do not pass it up if you see it in their deli case and if sausage is on sale, request at least a couple pounds of it because it is SO much better than the pre-packed chorizo. Their chorizo is highly seasoned and flavorful, but doesn't cook down with a lot of oil floating in the meat. The pork and chicken chorizo sausage Is good. 

They also have excellent buys in shrimp that are either $4.99 or $5.99 per pound and they are big and deveined and delicious! 

As much as I wish their was a Trader Joe's on this side of the river, fresh thyme has become my health conscious go to store when I am looking for all natural, "clean" or organic Products.

This family run business really take their business to heart! Their passion to create and unique tasting spirit really reflect their craftsmanship towards a high quality product! You will not believe what goes on behind their door until you take a tour in their distillery. This is local New Orleans flavor at their finest! 

We booked our tour through Groupon (best deal ever)! 

Gus aka Joey developed his passion abre 10 years ago to put New Orleans on the radar for distilleries.  His family, his wife and brother Edward were very nice and down to earth! 

I never though I would like sampling those Cajun spirits, but they were awesome!  You will be so surprised what aromas and flavors you can taste!

I have toured many distilleries and by far I have enjoy this tour so much! Not only because it's local but you can tell the family are proud of their product. 

I truly recommend y'all to experience this!

Was invited to a seminar sponsored by MSC cruise lines.  Have only been to the Rusty Pelican once years ago for a Mother's Day brunch and hadn't been back since. 

This is located off the Courtney Campbell causeway at the end of Rocky Pt rd. Being right on the bay, this waterfront restaurant has amazing views and is a perfect place for special occasions, corporate events or weddings.   A perfect setting for date nights. 

As we entered the Grand Ballroom, we knew we were in for a great start to a great buffet style meal. With lots of veggie options, I was a happy camper. Not sure if this would be same as their menu offerings, but everything I tried (except the key lime pie) was delicious. Salads and green beans, pasta salad and mashed potatoes as well as mahi mahi were well prepared. No complaints at our table at all. 

I grabbed what I thought was cheesecake and it was key lime that was so very tart I couldn't eat it. As there were about 150 people, they had run out of the cheesecake. A very nice server went back to the kitchen and brought me a piece and it was great!  

Only complaint was the temp of the room. It was freezing. Maybe because they didn't want us to snooze during the one hour long presentation.  It worked! 

Beautiful outdoor fireplace helped warm me up before frostbite set in. 

Wasn't real impressed on that Mother's Day brunch I went to but will def check this place out again in the near future.

I will update this review but I felt it was necessary to start in the midst of my fatigue...

Today, the spices and herbs in the food were prominent. I had a subpar experience here over a year ago. The food this time erased that experience. I was really amazed at how well prepared the food was. I took someone here who'd never had Indian food and she really enjoyed it. The resturant is very large and almost reminds me of an event hall/ older cruise ship. It's nice, I don't mind going here every so often. 

One tragic flaw.......there was a speck of lipstick on my drinking glass and the water pitcher glass was foggy so I dined without drinking anything.

While waiting for the "Book of Mormon" lottery the past few days we have been watching them put the finishing touches on this new burger joint. R told me it was open and I was craving a burger so off we went. 

We ordered fries and rings. The onion rings were delicious, but the fries were mushy and not crisp or crunchy. The sauces and the ketchup weren't our cup of tea. The smoke sauce is best, but smuggle in your own Heinz. I also think it's sort of weird that they don't have a soda fountain or gun. It's all bottled soda. With fries/burgers I always want something carbonated and generally a troth of it. I am American after all! So, the burgers come. The buns are bigger than the burger. The buns have these weird seeds on them. Flax? Uncertain. My beef burger doesn't even taste like ground beef. The texture is bizarre. I ate half. I just didn't feel like complaining or I would have. The pickles however are delicious! I had a side of sweet pickles and dill pickles on my burger. The stout onions were good as well. 

R had the bean burger and said it had no taste or seasonings. The guac on it she said tasted heavily of raw onion. She was not impressed. She also ordered a vanilla milkshake, but said it was lackluster. 

Our bill was 44! Ridiculous we didn't even have cocktails or a dessert. Definitely not returning and hope you will get your burger on elsewhere!

The foods so nice we had it twice. 

So when you first come in here you're thinking, wow cool effing bar. But, the best is yet to come... 

As you make your way thru the bar and thru some slot machines as a nuance.. behold the goldmine. The killer poboys indeed. 

We had some poboys the night before at what seemed like a food chain type of place we were on the hunt for what this city was known for; POBOYS! And here we were. One shrimp poboy coming up. It was soooo fresh and delicious, we had another one. Partially because it was the best one we've ever had and also because we may never have another one like it. 

Job well done boys. I have you on my must have lost without a doubt.

I finally made out to Black Thorn Pub with some friends for dinner on a Friday night. I was so excited to finally make it out and try Black Thorns famous Chicago style pizza. For some reason I pictured some old pub but this place is a total dive bar right in the middle of a neighborhood. Even though it's not what I expected, it's still fun and unique. 

They have really cheap beer including a small craft selection from Schlafly.  If you want to eat dinner, you need to get here about an hour to an hour and a half before you want to eat. That's how long it takes to cook your pizza...I was aware of the wait but for some reason I thought it would be more like 45 minutes...not double that (it might be shorter if you are the first pizza order in). The other thing to note is seating....

Since this is pretty much a dive bar seating is a free for all. You have to be fairly aggressive with getting a seat. I had to wait about 30-45 minutes before we could get a table and it really wasn't that packed. Between the slow cooked pizzas and limited spots, it can take a while. You can put your order in before you get a seat which is nice. 

The pizza was good but I think I liked it more because I was STARVING and 2 beers deep. The sauce is limited and kind of spicy. My understanding is that there are two kinds of Chicago style pizza, one cheese heavy and one sauce heavy. This one falls under the cheese heavy category. 

Two pieces will fill you up and three will make you feel like you are going to explode. Of course I made the mistake of eating three...no regrets.

I don't know if I'll be back to Black Thorn anytime soon but it was a fun experience! If I lived within walking distance it would be a fun place to hit up every now and again. 

Remember...arrive early!

Forgot how much I love this place for lunch.  It's excellent.  A little more pricey than other lunch options, but not off the charts by any stretch of the imagination.  

I had the soup special--shrimp bisque--and MAN ALIVE was it good!  So it was not the low-fat option I went in saying I was going to get, but it was completely worth it.  If they have a bisque at all--lobster, shrimp, or otherwise--please try it if you like that sort of thing.  You won't be disappointed!  I also had the portabello mushroom burger.  Didn't really eat the bread (but it was on French bread--different and good) but the mushroom was tasty and was topped with feta and roasted red peppers.  All delish.  

Service here is great.  They are just attentive enough--I always had a fresh Diet Coke (add a star for that!) but the waiters aren't annoying either.  Dinner here is equally good, and they have a great wine list.  It's hard not to leave here totally stuffed though--so make sure you have time for an afternoon nap in your cubicle, or after-dinner lounging on the couch.  You'll need it!  Fat and happy...

I did advise the waitress of my gluten allergy and she gave me what appeared to be a makeshift gluten free menu exclaiming half of the stuff on it is no longer being offered so I have to pick what I want and she will tell me if they still make it. I went for a very simple option grilled catfish- no fries. It came out with fries. I had to explain that the fries cant be removed and just give back the catfish as she wanted to do because the catfish was already in contact with the fries which were not gluten free. She said she understood and would have it remade completely. She came back with the "new plate" and unbenounced to her I have a gluten tester and the food tested positive for gluten up to 20 parts per million. She said she didn't know why. The manager came and she also didn't know why and said its just grilled and seasoned. I did ask what seasoning they use (Tony's) and that does contain wheat which they were unaware that seasonings could contain wheat. My hubs tasted a piece of the Catfish and he said it was great (it looked great), but I couldn't eat it. We had the chargrilled oysters which were great and that was it for me. They couldn't guarantee anything except salad was gluten free so I passed and ate dinner at another restaurant. My husband had the crab Ceasar which he said was alright, nothing to write home about. The restaurant is kind of dark, dated and old looking. The furniture looks worn and frayed. I honestly was shocked this was a hotel restaurant for how run down it looked and for the nice area it was in. I skipped drinks also because I could see them making drinks in the kitchen bar area and it did not look clean at all. There was junk piled up everywhere. We left spending very little $$$ and I was glad.

This place has a large selection of smoothies and I think they're at a pretty good price point compared to other smoothie joints. They also have a super cheap make your own option. I recommend their tropical mango smoothie! 

A separate paragraph for their CUPS! They have such a cool design where they don't condensate?? Like what the heck??? Crazy cool technology in a seemingly paper cup. Awesome sauce.

Really torn in my review for the Rusty Pelican. The experience was mixed, but I am leaning more towards below average. I came with a coworker after work and we were seated next to the window that overlooked the bay. It was really cool to see so many pelicans diving into the water and catching fish (hence the name of the restaurant) and we even saw a dolphin! 

The food and service however, was not what was expected. We started with the blackened scallops ($15). I was horrified when they were brought out to us (see the picture). The dish was a complete mess. The scallops were butchered; all different sizes, cut unevenly. They were WAY too seasoned and over cooked. Scallops are supposed to be refreshing and succulent; but not these poor fellas. Also the presentation with the sauces looked like slop & runny grease. I'm not sure how this dish made it past the kitchen and serving crew to our table without being questioned. 

For my meal, I got the lemon garlic shrimp risotto ($29). The dish was tasty, a little oily and garlicky, but it was fine. 

For dessert, we ordered the rum coated creme brÃ»lÃ©e. This was by far the highlight of the meal. They light it on fire for presentation, which was pretty neat. 

I wouldn't recommend to friends, but the restaurant had major hype and potential.... oh well.
