We went on a night when it was completely empty, and not close to closing time. The restaurant itself is very attractive, with a large fireplace, piano, and it sits right on the water.
Other service was also really good, and our server was prompt and very friendly.
Stick to the seafood here, if you do make a visit. My sis-in-law ordered a fish dish with veggies on the side, and it was really good. I gt my son the lobster risotto appetizer, which did not get eaten. It was pretty salty, and more risotto rice than meat.

Hubby and I split the filet mignon with a side of baked potato, and the mashed potatoes. The steak was to be cooked medium, and it came out rare to medium rare. The baked potato was still hard, somewhat uncooked in the middle. Hubby asked server to cook steak to medium, and he took it back. But, it came back well done. Usually, at upscale restaurants, when a sensitive, and small portion of steak such as a filet isnt cooked right, they will cook a fresh steak to compensate, instead of destroying the first piece. They didn't do that here. This pretty much ruined our dinner.
The mashed potatoes were ok. Kind of more mushy than mashed. No excuse for crappy food when the restaurant is completely empty. 

Our drinks were good, and that's the only reason I would ever return.

To some, joy may be found in dining at a fancy restaurant with ordinary service and food for a steep price. To me, bliss is discovering a jewel in the rough where the service and food is indeed extraordinary for less than $10! I've always wondered but now I understand why Mood CafÃ© is rated the best restaurant in the city of Philadelphia.

1. First of all, the food here reflects the owner's philosophies. Made with love and care, the intricate blend of ingredients is truly magical. Each flavor is bright, distinct, and amazing. I cannot recommend a specific lassi or chaat because if you choose from any of the literally hundreds of possible combinations, you will not be disappointed. Although Hassan always says kindly that you can have your money back anytime if you do not approve, no one has ever done so.

2. From the wildly popular rose lassi to the many fruits in the chaats, every single food item on the menu is made fresh from scratch. It makes you wonder if he is actually hiding a huge secret elaborate garden somewhere?! 

3. Vegan, lactose-intolerant, and can't eat spicy? No worries fellow patrons. At Mood CafÃ©, it's all about you, the valuable customer. And amazingly, it doesn't matter what you prefer, because you'll find out it all will taste oh so delicious!

4. Hassan personifies what all business owners should strive to become: friendly, accommodating, down to earth, and funny. When you leave Mood CafÃ©, you'll have both your stomach and heart content with incredible food and genuine love. 

I honestly wish Mood Cafe was more common in the world. People like Hassan working hard to make the best food with the best service possible, not the cash that comes with it. Simplicity and perfection at every level. Bravo!

I would come here just for the charbroiled oysters here, definitely!! Whenever I crave oysters, I want to come to Drago's. The raw oysters are a great deal. For just a few bucks more, you can get them charbroiled. They are salty, cheesey, garlicky, tasty. Don't forget to load them up with lemon too! The bread it's served with is nice, thick, and crusty (get your mind out the gutter). Overall, really like Drago's. I would say it's a must do while in New Orleans.

After realizing this place didn't have signage and was in the back of the bar I headed in.   The place is a dive and there are maybe 3 stools and 3 tables.  Pretty tiny.  The mural gives you something to look at if your friend received her poboy (banh mi) after you. 

I ordered a coriander lime shrimp poboy with marinated veggies and some type of sauce.   It was good, but not quite the poboy edge I was looking for.  Honestly if this wasn't New Orleans I would have called this a creative take on a Banh Mi. It also had entirely too much sauce. 

Would I come back?  Probably not.  I give the chef kudos for trying to make an interesting product in New Orleans though.

Like a nice casual summer fling with that sorta cute girl that's visiting your neighbor for a weekend... and goes away forever, leaving behind an 'ok' memory, but nothing to really brag about.

Nice, pub-ish type of atmosphere, with tons of "Endless Summer" memorabilia from the movie, which I remember from yesteryear, back from my college days in the late 80's, so it's hanging on to a relic theme of the past. 

Service was friendly enough, so I didn't mind visiting with family. The food though, was so-so. The halibut tacos was a WINNAH! Awesome, succulent, like the best kiss you've had in a long time.

The caesar salad was 'meh', something you'll find comparable to a highschool cafeteria... so skip it.

Clam chowder is advertised as the 'best in Santa Barbara', but came up short to this Bostonian. Was like clam-flavored cream, and mom HATED it.

Fish and chips was ok. My son, who isn't the greatest fan of fish that isn't fish fingers, actually ate the whole thing. That's a plus for any of you out there with kids that are picky eaters.

Fried calamari was blah. I've been in tons of dive pubs that serve better calamari than this.

Now, I did try the oyster shooter, which I normally dig at sushi places. This place had an interesting take on it, and I will admit I liked it. Doesn't have the sushi-ponzu flavor I'm used to in LA, but has a nice radish-cocktail sauce kick to it, and I will definately order it again if I ever stop by this place again..... but sadly.... I don't think that will happen of my own choice.

I recently attended a work Christmas luncheon at Cocoa's, and it was pretty good! Even a little better than my previous brunch there with my girlfriends once.

They had a private eating area for corporate parties, sectioned off from the main dining lounge, with enough space for about four large tables. The buffet was located in the hall right inside the entrance. I was very impressed with the service, as the staff greeted us as we arrived and showed us to our tables. They were on top of things throughout the lunch, filling empty water glasses, clearing away empty plates, and asking people if they wanted more coffee. Excellent service!

The buffet consisted of a table of warm comfort foods, another of salads and fruits, and another of all desserts. The red snapper in sun-dried tomato sauce was my favorite! Simply delicious -- soft and moist, and popping with tart flavor from the sauce. I wanted more, but was saving myself for dessert!

They had several kinds of cheesecake and mousse cakes for dessert. I decided to go for the yummy-looking raspberry mousse cake, and did not regret it at all. Sweet and creamy, the cake has an outer layer of raspberry gel while the inside is all mousse. Mmm ...

Needless to say, I was stuffed by the end of the lunch. Cocoa's is not only great for a weekend brunch with your friends, but a corporate outing too!

This is our local Boston Market, and we probably go 3-4 times a year, when that craving for comfort food hits! I've always been pretty pleased with this location. Friendly service and they greet you when you walk in, helpful at the counter, and (mostly) clean ... lets face it, since you don't dispose of your own trash anymore, sometimes there are cluttered tables.

The food is good. Consistent with other Boston Markets. I'm a creature of habit here and normally get the 3 piece dark meal with creamer spinach and corn. However, sometimes I'll get wild and crazy and go with a Carver Sandwich and sweet potatoes.  I'm seriously too wild for words. Lol

My daughter could eat their Macaroni and Cheese for the rest of her life. Seriously. Every meal. And I've tasted it before ... cheese, al dente, spiral noodles. It's the stuff kid dreams are made of!

It is rare for me to visit a diner, and even rarer for me to say that I'm a fan. But I will acquiesce to Pat's. This spot has been in operation in this same location for at least 70 years. Truly an achievement in this day and age. I have probably only dined here 3 times,today being the most recent. Each time I left satisfied and bewildered as to how the prices can be so low. Today for example, a 3 course lunch was $8 and change, non alcoholic beverage included. Portion size was large, so much so that my senior dining companion took half of his home. We both had different fish dishes, and both were easily worth the cost. It is easy to see how this restaurant makes and keeps loyal customers. My next visit here will probably be for a breakfast, and I am sure that after the meal I will still be a fan.

Such good Chinese! The General Tso Chicken was my choice--for $5.50, the lunch special included a generous portion of chicken, laced with crispy chili peppers and a subtle Tso sauce, as well as an egg roll and delicious fried rice. 
The lunch portion was so large, I had leftovers! The staff does not speak English well, but it did not seem to matter...food is made fresh in front of you as you wait...quickly done, and soo yummy! Simple decor, with pretty Asian models on calendars, very clean tables. A real winner! 
A good value, friendly service, clean and delicious.

This is probably the most comprehensive grocery store in the entire French Quarter while most of the other options are more convenience stores with limited grocery items.  This Rouse's is surprisingly larger than you would think it was from the outside but still smaller than most other Rouse's locations.  They pack in a lot of items for the space and it is a well stocked grocery for the Quarter.  There are frequently gutter punks that hang out in the area that will hassle you but if you ignore them they usually leave you alone.

Hubby and I were in Santa Barbara and were staying at the Bacara Resort and Spa for a Company event ...... luv those!  The first night we had a romantic dinner at the Angel Oak At Bacara restaurant.  The restaurant is modern, inviting and has a chill atmosphere.  We were greeted with smiles even though we had no reservations .... very nice.  We were seated at one of the lovely booths and ordered:

(1)  Drinks
I ordered my Cosmopolitan which was made perfectly and Hubby had a Dirty Martini.  A great start to our evening.

(2)  Complimentary Bread and Seasoned Butter
OMG, the bread was house made, warm  and was so delish.   After you add the butter you will find heaven.

(3)  Blue Crab Cake
Pan seared, celery root and apple remoulade, caviar.  I had a taste of Hubby's crab cake which was mostly crab, fresh and perfectly seasoned.

(4)  Pancetta Wrapped Dates
Lamb, pickled cucumber, house made yogurt dip.  The lamb was so tender and served with pancetta made it a perfect appetizer.  Very tasty!

(5)  Roasted Bone Marrow
Bone Marrow with Oxtail marmalade, pistachio gremolata, herbs, grilled sourdough.  OMG, this is a signature dish.  Bone marrow and oxtail meat?  What?  Total genius because it was so rich and full of flavor.  Please order this!

(6)  Lobster Bisque
Saffron rouille, pumpernickel, lobster.  My bisque had lil chunks of lobster ..... luv that!  It was seasoned well and prepared perfectly.

(7)  Caesar Salad
Pecorino romano, boquerones, radishes, herbs.  Hubby's salad was a lil underwhelming.  He didn't like his lettuce shredded.

(8)  Bone In Ribeye
18oz., USDA Prime.  I wanted the AAAAA Kobe Certified Steak but they ran out for the night =(.  So, hubby and I decided to share the Ribeye and add a lobster tail.  The Ribeye was perfectly cooked to medium rare and was SO juicy.  The lobster tail was tender and was the perfect match for our steak.

(9)  Lobster and House Made Gnocchi Gratin w/ local lemons
Our lovely server recommended the Gnocchi to accompany our Ribeye.  OMG, the dish was so DELICIOUS.  The Gnocchi was creamy and the dish was full of lobster pieces.  I could had ordered this dish as my main entree ....... yes, that good!  Order this!

(10)  Candy Bar
Dark chocolate cremeaux, peanut butter crunch, salted caramel ice cream.  If you luv chocolate and a decadent dessert, the Candy Bar is for you.  This dessert will definitely make your palate dance.

(11)  De-Caf Coffee
The restaurant's coffee was perfect with my dessert.

I had a romantic dinner with Hubby at the Angel Oak at Bacara.  Their food is delicious and the service was attentive and very friendly.  5 Stars!

I was a Starvin' Marvin! I wanted pizza! I wanted GOOOOOD pizza. Something that I could really sink my teeth into. Deep dish would fit the bill. I've had a hankering to try Rocco's, read all the great reviews, even bookmarked in Yelp.

Well, like Yelp says when you hover over the 2 stars, "Meh. I've experienced better."

We ordered the Kitchen Sink (pepperoni, sausage, green pepper, mushroom, red onion). To be brief, you get a hefty pizza, they put a lot into it. But it is too much and too rich. Too much cheese. Yes, too much. Too much garlic. And I'm not afraid of garlic. Not enough tomato flavor in the sauce because it was overpowered by the garlic. We were not that enamored with the pizza. One slice will probably do you in. Even so, I'm not anticipating eating the leftovers like I usually do if there's leftover pizza. I'll eat it because I paid (a lot) for it and because it's there, but not because I loved it. First disappointment.

Also had the chicken wings because of the reviews. The wings are crispy fried. I've had better. These wings are chewy. My favorite part of the wing is the wingette. When they are this crispy fried, you have more of the crispy and less of the meat. The meat is dried out. Very chewy, too. Can't break the wingette apart. They are OK, but not great. Medium was plenty hot. I've had crispy wings where the skin was still thin, but crispy, and you still had plenty of juicy meat. Second disappointment.

I originally ordered the stuffed pizza. I paid for it, but didn't get it. I called them up. After some polite run-around, I spoke to the manager who promptly said he would send the refund in the mail. Not a lot ($2) but we'll see if they are good for their word. I'm sure they are. Third disappointment.

I'll leave on a good note: they had good service. I called it in, they said it would be ready in 35 minutes. I came in at 35 minutes and it was ready.

***Update: The owner called, apologized, sent me my $2 AND a $10 gift certificate to use next time I visit. A truly good business handles missteps well as things will happen. Good job.

I've got mad, mad love for the Rouses chain in general. My grandmother worked and retired from the very first one opened in Houma. I have so many fond memories of visiting her while she was working behind that bakery counter. That store to this very day is still my favorite one. This location is giving it a run for it's money though.

This Rouses is super cool! Oh my goodness. I was surprised seeing it in the Quarter and was in awe walking in. It looks tiny but it's not. It's got everything you'd find in your neighborhood Rouses. I love the narrow aisles and the liquor behind the counter. It feels like an old timey drugstore. I love it!

This would be the perfect place for all the ingredients you need for a fabulous Bloody Mary. Or dinner. :)

Well, I was wavering.  You see, I like diners ... Places where almost any combination of foods especially if fried can end up on a plate in front of you

Every diner has purchased the same water glasses.  Every diner has a long list of lunch or dinner specials.  And, every diner has food items you can't find at any reputable restaurant like stewed tomatoes and beets just beets.

So I found myself unexpectedly in front of the Harrison House, a diner whose sign boldly proclaims "best of" so like a piece of cheap tin pulled in by a powerful magnet I was seated before I knew it.

Lots of choices ... Lots of specials and that all too familiar glassware.

Navy bean soup, a diner staple, was my option choice to go along with a crabcake sandwich with fries and coleslaw.

The soup did not disappoint.  It tasted like a decent version of diner navy bean.  The beans had a good texture and the broth was flavorful.

Before I could finish the soup my lunch was delivered.  Fries HOT - Crabcake HOT; coleslaw in a little plastic cup & tartar sauce runny.

The fries were crisp on the outside and hot fluffiness inside.  My crabcake had a nice crisp exterior and the interior of this overly breaded "crab"cake met diner expectations.  Actually an overly breaded crab cake is what diners make; never expect the taste of crab to grab you.  The tartar sauce was surprisingly tasty and the slaw .... Well it was served diner-style in a plastic cup would you really expect a lot from it.

The diner is clean but it does smell like a diner and if you have eaten in your share of diners you will recognize the scent (Perhaps that's what happens when your kitchen presents such a variety of foods.).

I decided to hang around a little because there was one unique phenomenon at the Harrison House that I picked up on immediately and remained consistent during my entire time in my booth.  All of the employees lips are permanently turned downwards.  Not a single person working here smoked except when greeting a customer (if then) but the smiles vanish when they again contemplate their place of employment.  A no smile reality is not a good sign of what happens behind the scenes

So if you are in the neighborhood wanting diner food this place is ok but definitely not worth a long trip down the highway.

And, why no rice pudding with my special??

This place isn't bad. Since writing a review for a grocery store could take me all day, I will try to summarize:

(1) Decent seafood section, although I will say that only 3 out of the 11 clams I got the other day actually opened up when I cooked them in my stew. Not sure if that was my fault or what... but it made me feel like I wasted my $5. The seafood woman is super sweet though, and she's always willing to help me with my crazy requests.

(2) They do not stock my favorite cereal, or dried cranberries, or my favorite red wine (Cavit Pinot Noir) in a "normal" size--they only have a HUGE size so I feel bad buying it because it's like $15 or more and I end up wasting 3/4 of the bottle because no one in my apt drinks except for me and I can't finish a whole bottle alone!

(3) Produce is generally fresh and also decent selection which I appreciate. They usually have a full stock of fresh herbs which is a pretty big deal for me, hehe.

(4) Friendly and knowledgeable employees and staff, always willing to help out be it a cashier, manager, dept worker, or shelf-stock-er.

(5) Location. Right near TJ's, Target, Walmart, and Whole Foods so if I DO need something that this location does not have, chances are the thing(s) I need are only a 5 minute drive away! Also it's right off highway 64/40 so that's convenient too. About an 8 minute or so drive from my apartment if it's not super rush-hour-y.

That's about it.

Oh and PS: If you download the App "aisle411" on your phone, you can easily and quickly locate the items on your shopping list!! :D
Great appetizers and a wide range of beer. Fun spot to sit outside (despite being on a SEPTA route), and people watch.

Pretty good gluten free pizza.  The crust is just a smidge too thin, but that's just me quibbling.  

Definitely order online 45 minutes ahead during lunch.  The service was friendly and it's a pretty good value.  Love that toppings don't cost extra.

Good service, but you can tell that the staff are still working out a few kinks.

I love this place, the food is good and the drinks are even better. I never make it beyond the bar area.  I always end up eating at the bar so I can not speak of the table service. 

I hate to make this call out, but anyone who goes here for Happy Hour or anytime for that matter knows it is a true "meat market" and it does not matter which team you play for. So this makes for a very fun and festive night.

April 4, Miss C. and I met for lunch. She ate from the fabulous and generous breadbasket. I looked at it.

Food selection was rather tough, as there were so many tantalizing dishes.

Sarah was our server, and she was quite friendly and at-the-ready with water refills.

Miss C. got penne a la vodka and added grilled chicken ($21.45).

I got a grilled steak salad (medium rare) ($15.95), which included mixed greens, tomatoes, Gorgonzola, crimini mushrooms and spicy pecans with balsamic dressing. There was also a creamy horseradish served on the side, which was a lovely addition.

We both liked our dishes heartily, and both took a lot home. My take-home lasted two more meals.

If you've never dined at The Farm and Fisherman, then please drop what you're doing and go immediately. If you are a regular, you may have one last time to lineup, and get a seat in their superb and lovely dining room. Sorry, had to do it, as The Farm and Fisherman will be closing its doors very soon. 

After a long, busy, and stressful night at work, I felt I didn't want to spend another tough occasion home alone (it was  Mother's Day.) I was tired and stressed; all what I needed was s a gift that doesn't need to be wrapped. I booked a lonely table just for one, and I survived my awesome brunch, thanks to Rachel, my awesome waitress. She made my visit very enjoyable. 

As soon as I saw the innovative brunch menu, I was torn between ordering two small plates and a dessert, or one main dish and a desert. Rachel gave me her opinion on different items on the menu, and I literally wanted to order everything. I decided not to contain myself and get one main dish: Chicken Roasted in Hay (brilliant & delicious,) and a dessert ( was something with strawberry & mascarpone whipped cream.) After enjoying few sips of my first coffee of the day, Rachel returned to my table with a small plate of Ricotta Crostini as a compliments of the chef. (Astonishing, I know!)

How many times have you gotten psyched about some delicious farm-to-table food, that you just couldn't forget the tasty difference?!
Farm and Fisherman, even when you close down, you'll always be one of my favorites.

Four and half Yelps.

Gumbo is one of Louisiana's signature dishes so in New Orleans there's a version on almost every restaurant menu.  That said, the Gumbo Shop serves up some of the best gumbo we've had in the city.

We ordered bowls of Seafood Okra and Chicken Andouille Gumbo.  Both were tasty but the chicken sausage gumbo edged out the seafood gumbo as the better of the two.  The roux was a deep, rich brown and was flavorful without being too salty or too spicy.  There were meat in every spoonful and I thought the ratio of rice to gumbo was perfect.

Our seats in the courtyard were comfortable even if we needed a few more inches of space between our table and our neighbors.  Tim, our server, brought our drinks and food without delay so we were in and out in less than 30 minutes.  We got to the restaurant just after the lunch rush so we didn't have to wait for a table.

With 1,983 reviews, this one is a drop in the bucket but I wanted to add my voice to the chorus of satisfied diners.
I wish they had Blenders in LA...I loved the seasonal pumpkin pie smoothie they had around Thanksgiving time! And I'm not even a smoothie person, but I loved theirs.

I had a chance to enjoy me some Creole Creamery on a late Saturday afternoon. It wasn't overly packed, you should be able to find a table for 3 to 4 people to enjoy your deliciousness inside. Very nice family atmosphere to share some family time!

The staff is very friendly and helpful. They even let you try some flavors so you can make the best yummy choice. I went with a Rose Ice Cream that was yummy!!!! A little hint of wine and ice cream is what dreams are made of on a sugar cone, which was only 3 bucks. That's a big deal, these days you get ice cream in New Orleans you lucky some something less than $7.

Its surrounded by a coffee shop/cafe, restaurants etc. So you can do a few things in the area before enjoying your ice cream.

Make sure too bring case because it's cash only. Street parking area but you can find something within the 2 block radius.

Oh yum!

Had a great experience here on a Thursday night.  We were a group of 8 and showed up around 6 PM.  Not surprisingly, given the size of our group, there was quite a wait for a table.  No problem - we were able to sit outside (it was chilly, but there were heaters) and order drinks while we waited.  Most of us had spiked milkshakes.  YUM!!  I had the bananas foster one and it was fantastic.  I would order it again in a heartbeat.  Only problem was that it was very filling, but that's not really such a problem!

Once we were seated (at the world's deepest booth) we ordered our burgers.  It was great that everything could be done with a veggie patty, as we had a number of people in our group with dietary restrictions.  My burger and tater tots were super tasty.  Judging by the silence as we ate,  and the table full of clean plates, everyone else seemed to enjoy their food as well.

Service was a bit slow, but overall great.  We had the same server outside for our drinks and inside for our meal, which was great.  He offered to do separate checks (which was especially complicated since we had all moved seats), which was much appreciated.

Overall a great experience and I look forward to returning!

Heres the Scoop: This Burger King is right off of the highway. Perfect for a quick snack or the bathroom. The staff is very friendly and give quick service. The dinning area is clean and has lots of flatscreen tvs. The soda area is clean and filled with condiments. Big family diningroom size tables here as well. If you want sweet tea you must ask because its behind the counter. Floors are clean not sticky aas are the tbles thats a pleasure. so if youre in the area check out this Burger King.

#MyLongestReviewToDate
Room 315 overlooked the pool, the beach, and the corner edge of the hotel building to the right. The saving grace from the partial view was the nice sized balcony with two chairs and a small plastic table. The room was a king with balcony (pool  and gulf view), but the actual sight line of the pool was blocked by a tree. The shuffle board court was quite visible. If I actually cared to see the pool from the room, this would bother me since it was part of the description for the room. What did bother me in the room was the lack of art (photo of room art posted), very low water pressure for the shower, no light at the table (a small reading lamp would be nice), no bars or hooks in the shower to hang clothes on (not even a retractable clothes line), and only one three drawer short chest of drawers and two night stand for clothes (the chest was slightly taller than the night stands and perfect height for the tv). These are the things that bothered me, yet I gave them 4 stars (before since other things were discovered by the Mister). So, as of checkout, the pros don't necessarily outweigh the cons for me. The concerns that we have cannot be resolved before my check out date and are not one room specific (that has changed since we found a dusty black sports bra under the bed while checking the room to make sure we didn't leave any if our things behind). Cleanliness would cause me to not stay here again.
I really liked having a full kitchen with electric stove, although I didn't cook (I like having choices). The kitchen was stocked with the basics including dishes, glassware, utensils, towels, coffee maker. We found two unclean knives in the drawer (see photos by Carl O.) Free wi-fi is always good (even if you've unplugged you will need to check into your flight home, or maybe watch something streaming). There is a grocery store about a mile walking west and a Publix close by to the east (go to the Publix, you'll thank me later), John's Pass and Boardwalk is about a mile west and great for all types of entertainment in case you need more than a relaxing time by the beach. There are very good to decent restaurants about a quarter of a mile walk con the resort (great recommendations from the front desk). The lobby is very small, just enough to handle business, including a few seats for waiting so there were no hustle bustle attitude workers (everyone that I encountered was very helpful). There is a rack of pamphlets for local activities and offerings and a shelf of DVD movies and board games (free for hotel guests to check out).
We greatly enjoyed the pool. It's my most favorite amenity. The heated pool was clean and ranged from 3 ft 4 in to 8 ft. No life guard on duty. Several tables and chairs with umbrellas, and loners at the pool and just before the beach entry. Clear skies, flying birds...pure serenity.
Free parking on-site, a great plus compared to other local resorts charging $20 or so daily for parking. Free daily continental breakfast included packets of oatmeal, coffee, cinnamon rolls, fruit, nut bars and 4oz juice cold rounds (the kind you get for middle school lunch). Ok, that's not so impressive but for a quick bite it will do (coffee and a cinnamon roll made the top of the list). 
Overall, this hotel is clean, but the room had some issues as noted, quiet (until I heard a crying kid across the balcony area, called the front desk and was told that the owners family may be visiting with kids - INSERT BLACK STARE #That'sNotAdultsOnly #That'sNotWhatIPaidToSeeOrHear #NowThat'sEnoughToMakeMeNotReturn #IFlewALongWayForAnAdultsExclusiveStay). They can be add cut add they want to be, and it doesn't matter how big they were, they were present, seen, and heard, and apparently live in the penthouse (said someone at the front desk as he showed us the family pictures upon check out). Nevertheless, our stay was slow and quiet. We were able to enjoy the beach and just plain get a mental break from a busy life, which was the goal. 
I should also mention that the hotel does not offer canopied beach chairs for the beach, but rather they are available to rent for $20 a day from a local vendor who has set up this option on the free access beach section that is directly in front of the hotel. You can buy a chair umbrella across the street for under $15, a worthy purchase even if you throw it away after checkout, in case you can't take it on the plane. Technically, you can honestly get more amenities in most other resorts, but we knew that before booking and didn't come here for that. Worth noting again, the heated pool is great and relaxing and it is greatly encouraged daily.
***Yes, I love children so take this adult face value... an adults exclusive resort should be just that. Since the owners live in the penthouse and have children know that this claim is not ever possible at the Shoreline Island Resort - Adults Exclusive.***
IJS

I've never been to the actual restaurant, but I have had delicious delivery.

yes they deliver all the way to my hood ( rittenhouse area) which is amazing.

it's pricey but fresh!

the roasted vegetables are awesome

This is an AWESOME beach bar. 

The location is great. Watching the sunset while sipping a drink is so relaxing. Just another reminder of how wonderful Florida living is. 

Added to it are relatively good servers. They're not insanely nice, but they are attentive and efficient. Even during Spring Break madness, they keep it together. 

This bar also has volleyball courts set up and a few bars to choose from. There's a man that occasionally sets up his amazing BBQ food stand in the parking lot which is always a plus when he appears. 

My only real complaint is the parking. It's a hot damn mess, and half the time, parking in the public lot is your best bet. 

But otherwise, all good.

fast and friendly service.

for the indecisive (read: me), there's a nifty little mini four scoop sampler option for $4. win.

there's a old-fashioned feeling when you walk in, and it's quite spacious. at 10PM on a friday night, it was hoppin'. they have the regular flavors, but that's not why i ventured all the way there. it's all about the specialty flavors!

my mini four scoop sampler was:: steen's molasses oatmeal cookie, brown butter pecan, red velvet, and lavender honey. everything was so rich and creamy, and i wasn't disappointed. i was apprehensive about the lavender honey, but it ended up being my favorite. i'm not the biggest red velvet lover, either, but the ice cream made me a believer. the molasses oatmeal cookie really tasted like a cookie in ice cream form, and i'm a little sad to report that the brown butter pecan was just okay--not disappointing, but not unique, either.

i also had the pleasure of trying the skyscraper: cookies and cream, chocolate, and vanilla ice cream layered with caramel, hot fudge, and crushed oreo cookies. served with whipped cream and a cherry on top. its name comes from the fact that it's creole creamery's tallest creation..and, i'd argue, probably one of the most delicious.

My husband and I were looking for a new place to try for a late lunch. It was his turn to pick, and he chose Mexican. We filtered our search on the Yelp app, and Macho Tequilas came up.

The Place: 
The restaurant was colorful and full of decorations. They had pinatas hanging from the roof, paintings, and all kind of stuff.
They have a bar and table seating. The tables might remind you like your dining table at home. We got a big table just for the two of us.

The Food:
The server brought us chips & salsa and took our drink and food order. I got a Margarita (of course), and my husband had a corona. We got some guacamole for the chips and green and red sauce. The green sauce was SPICY, but I could not stop eating it!

For lunch, I had the "Carne Asada" no tortillas and white rice and husband got a chicken "Wet Burrito."  We were happy with the food. My carne asada was delicious! It tasted really good. I loved the rice and beans. 
The chicken burrito was enchilada style. The sauces and seasoning were very authentic. We were greatly surprised by the food at this place. We had no idea about it.
 

The Service:
A nice lady took good care of us during our visit. She made sure we had enough chips, waters, and drinks. The food came out in promptly and our check too. 

Yes, I will be coming back. Sometimes, I feel we have so many Mexican places in Reno, but they are all the same. So I am glad to find something a little bit more different finally.

I have driven PAST Blake's in Deming, NM on my way out of Hatch so many times and always thought to myself, "Huh, I really should try them out." But I never do because I just want to get home to Tucson and to be honest, 9 times out of 10 I just put a Sparky's green chile cheeseburger in my belly so I wasn't hungry. When Blake's came to Tucson, I was really excited!!!

Don't believe the hype. The green chile cheeseburger at Blake's is a mediocre burger overall with the saving grace being the green chile. The green chile is delicious but not very hot, at least for my taste but that's not where I find fault with this burger. The actual burger is greasy and just a whatever burger. Mine was thrown together so sloppily that I had more onions and tomatoes off the bun than on it. I literally had to put my burger back together before I could eat it. And then the grease started dripping off my hands. Honestly, I would compare the "burger" part of my sandwich to any old fast food place but priced much higher. We also had seasoned fries which were good and onion rings which were not. The size of the order of onion rings for the price was NOT a bargain at all.

So I'm glad I finally tried Blake's but I really don't think I'll be back. Especially when the green chile double cheeseburger I had at Whataburger was actually better but then again, my judgement on that one may have been clouded by a hangover.

What bro doesn't like to visit B-DUBS once in a blue moon??

Visited on 4/9/17 around 7:30 PM and it was a "seat yourself" kinda situation in the dining room which I kinda like.  $36.66 got us a snack size order of wings, a side caesar salad, a kid's meal, a chicken wrap with fries, a cocktail, and a sweet tea.  

I don't give a flying rat's arse about sports but they got about a million TV's in this place if that's your thing.  Beers are cold and the wait staff are nothing but friendly and attentive every time I go.  

For some reason the wings always take about 30 minutes here but they're always fresh so I don't mind waitin'.  I like to get the buffalo dry rub on mine cuz' I like my wings crunchy and spicy.  They have the best carrots and celery here (I've heard they soak them in Evian but I dunno really why they're so good).  Their ranch is so-so but adequate.  

While we were there I was eavesdropping on an Indian couple (the dot kind, not the feather kind) and they were having the most intense argument ever.   Nothing like dinner and a show. 

Solid B-dubs location.  9/10 would do again.

Hubby and I visited about a month ago, long enough for their Grand Opening kinks to have gotten worked out.  (Not that I know of any, but just in case).

Our wait on a Saturday morning at 9 AM was only about 5 minutes, and we were greeted and served quite promptly.

It's a standard ihop experience, hot coffee, loads of condiments on the table to choose from, and pancakes.  Our experience was pleasant, and most everyone around us seemed to be experiencing the same.  Nothing especially significant to report, other than the yelper who was presented a dirty glass, etc. - we didn't see any of that, and I was trying to look around to find a flaw.

I enjoyed the multi-grain pancakes variey with granola, very good.  Hubby went the opposite spectrum and ordered the cinammon bun pancakes, thankfully with the "goo" on the side.  It was a sweet hot mess, but he enjoyed himself.

So don't overthink it, go get yourself some pancakes already.  They're open.

Dropped by here on our one day tour of Philadelphia. I can't say I've had many cheese steaks in my life so no judgements on whether it's the best cheesesteak ever here. 

There's quite a lot going on in their menu - you can get chicken or steak, and they have a good number of sides (all of the deep fried or bacon variety) in case you're extra hungry. They've also got grilled cheese if that's your jam, and some more creative sandwiches - including one that resembles a pizza melt.

They have five different cheeses that you can choose from - cheez whiz, american, mozzarella, provolone, and bleu, if I remember correctly. Some toppings (fried onions and hot peppers) come free, while others (bacony bacon) cost extra. They have these delicious picked hot peppers in a jar behind the hot sauce. 

I got a bacon cheese steak with cheez whiz and it was exactly the sodium, grease explosion I was expecting. The meat is sliced thinly and is quite tender, and the whole deal is absolutely saturated with cheese. The cheez fries are way more filing than they look, and they come with maybe half as much fries as you want given the cheese ratio - you'll most likely end up with globs of leftover cheez whiz unless you like eating that stuff with a spoon. 

Staff is friendly but it's mostly self serve after you get your sandwich. Overall, pretty awesome experience, would definitely drop by again if I'm ever in town.

Way up North off SR 54 is Wesley Chapel District Park. This park houses fields for various sports, including, lacrosse, soccer and softball. There is even a basketball court. My son plays lacrosse here and during practice I can get a good workout in on the 16 mile trail that is there. Although I haven't made it a full 16 miles the running, jogging and walking a few miles is fine for me.

Food is pretty standard at this wing place, but a great place to gather for some sports games to watch on one of their HUGE screen tvs!  Tuesday nights are 40 cent wings (must order at least 6). monday nights are bogo burgers and wednesday nights are kids nights.
I recommend sitting at the bar and exchanging niceties w/ Jeff - he's really great waiter. They also have a great trivia game that you can play associated w/ Buzztime.  The questions can be so hard, but fun ---- especially if you're really not into all the sports games going on around u.

Awesome theater!  Had a great time seeing Hobo With a Shotgun on Friday night...tickets were like $9.75 which is a gd steal these days!
Friendly customer service, nice crowd, clean bathrooms.  I can dig!

Big fan of big, public grassy parks situated in downtowns. This one offers a view of downtown buildings and the peaceful river and is located next to museums. Nothing too exciting as far as parks go, but it is worth visiting for a stroll. I could see myself reading here. Saw a family in the middle of a photo shoot.

Really glad that events are held here, even though I wasn't able to catch any while I was in town. I hope they get a good community gathering.

This is a welcoming mission style hotel...in a residential neighborhood.  I didn't really know where I was and was pleasantly surprised at discovering some previously unknown areas of Santa Barbara.  A few blocks from the Beach, a few blocks from the wharf, a few blocks from State st.  Great location for a weekend stay.  
The room was ok, but what I appreciated the most is the front desk adjusted my room to a 1st floor room.  I wasn't traveling light and wouldn't have been able to get my luggage up the stairs.  Turns out the room was handicap friendly.  I was impressed with the accommodations level of user friendly touches. The microwave & fridge were placed at easy wheelchair level, as well as a secondary lower peep hole.  Since I have loved ones who use those services, I was impressed.  They also had safety measures in bathroom.
-nice cooked breakfast delivered to the room.
-additional order of chocolate dipped strawberries- nice touch of yummy.
All in all...the star of the show was the general customer service..this started with the late night reservation I made.  This noteworthy service continues with staff reaching out before arrival checking in on anything needed before arrival, during stay...and when leaving.  That was A++ .
Thank you to all the staff
Warm regards,
Sharine

Clean..Bright lights inside..Nice and cool.. a Large place..Very friendly and polite staff,and 17 flavors with a variety of topping and syrups,it was very busy but the line was moving,one of the staff was keeping the dip tray clean from the spilled yogurt he was replaceing all the  trays,try the pistachio,strawberry,pistachio its awesome.

we just had fries, but one order filled the large cup &  into the bottom of the sack they came in, feed 4 of us esily for $4.39 plus tax
everyone was friendly, the place was clean

I don't know what's wrong with the Tampa Bay Boston Markets. This one always does something wrong when I roll through the drive thru.

Once I came home to find raw chicken in my bag.

This time I ordered a side and an extra side of Sweet Potato casserole. I never ordered the mac n cheese, but in the place of sweet potato casserole, mac n cheese is what I got. Why not tell me you ran out? Why have me go home to disappointment?

I just don't get it. This is a franchise with specifics! Get it right!

Really enjoyed my breakfast here.  Husband and I took Teen 1 here for a big breakfast.  She had eggs, bacon, hash browns, and chocolate chip pancakes.  

Our waitress let me order from the geezer menu since I was not starving and most of their meals would feed a lumberjack.  I had B & G with hash browns and one scrambled egg.  I asked for the hash browns extra crispy.

I ate the egg first, which was a rookie mistake because it was by far the worst thing on the plate and took up some valuable hash brown room in my stomach.  Not inherently bad, but I like a hard scramble and it was still a little too wet for my taste.  The hash browns came out exactly like i like them, and the B&G was delicious as well.  Fluffy biscuits with a sausagy ( I know its not a word, but work with me here) gravy that was delicious.  

Its also important to note that Teen does not like powdered sugar and they dusted her pancakes in it.  What this means is that Husband and I got to eat the top one.  I took a bite just as a curiosity because I was already full...OMG!!! Those pancakes were SO delicious we were on that thing like piranhas on a cow until there was nothing left on the plate.  And that was after they sat for awhile, because they were the last thing she got around to eating.  

Everything here was good, but if you like pancakes they are a must-try!

No complaints about waiting or service that I saw in some of the other reviews.  Our waitress was a pro!

I wouldn't say their beignets are better than Cafe Du Monde's but they are pretty good. It might really be the open courtyard ambiance and live music playing day and night that attracts many here. I admit, that was the allure for us. Dining al fresco under some shade with fans blowing was a nice retreat from the busy Bourbon St. All that, plus a cup of CAFE AU LAIT ($2.99/sm) and an order of delightful BEIGNETS ($3.99), I felt right with the world. I can't say I'm not a fan.

We've been fans of Burger Republic since 2013, and we also love their location in the Gulch!  I felt like it was worth mentioning here, because it's still good. The service has always been consistent, as well as the food, so we have zero complaints.  I always get the tater tots over fries. We prefer Burger Republic over The Pharmacy and Burger Up in general.

This bistro recently opened not too long ago  (the building previously housed Kenmac Flowers). The name, Knights Bistro pays homage to the philanthropic Knight's family of Collingswood.

After driving by this place a few times, we decided to stop-in. This bistro has its own parking lot (fairly large).  We were very disappointed & had  totally different expectations of this place. The inside decor has a nice bistro feel to it with a casual environment. However, the food was nothing more than a mediocre pizzeria/ sandwich shop with a few entrees thrown into the mix. 

With a bistro concept, we honestly expected to see the likes of Portabella burgers, homemade soups, Pommes Frites, gourmet salads, bison burgers, Charcuterie/Salumi, Roasted eggplant, Hummus platters, etc. on the menu (you get the point)........Instead, they serve your typical Mozzarella sticks, Salads, Pizza, Calzones/Sromboli's, a few pasta dishes, wraps, etc.  blah blah blah.  

I tried the 'Panini Italiano', it was completely flavorless. Each individual ingredient was lackluster. The spinach tasted like it was thawed from a frozen box (they could of at least sauteed  it in maybe some garlic, olive oil, etc.). The chicken was dry. The prosciutto was rubbery. The Foccocia bread wasn't too bad, it had a nice crunch and the inside ingredients were warmed up enough (I hate when places don't cook the panini  under the press long enough). I was then insulted with a small bag of boring Lay's potato chips?  I thought they would of at least served some house made potato chips or skin-on french fries, etc.............   Kate had the Cheese Steak Wrap, it was flavorless..... no amount of ketchup could of saved that wrap. 

I would rather pay a few extra dollars more and eat the Panini's at the Kitchen Consigliere Cafe down the street (the difference in quality is like night and day....those panini's are made with love &  come with a small mix green salad AND sweet potato fries). In this day and age, even the bars/taverns are kickin' out some gourmet'ish food, you have to step up to the plate. 

On a positive note, the restaurant server was nice/friendly/proficient. 

On the way out the door, I noticed a pizza tomato pie that looked good. I don't know. Maybe other people will have a differing opinion of this place. I'll try to check back on this site for new Yelp reviews to see what others think, I am curious......  scratching my head about this one. This place has potential.... I think.

Great eat-in pizza place with a large array of salads, apps, and pastas.  Great, attentive service. Their strawberry walnut salad was very tasty and the thin crust  pizza was just right. Always busy with patrons which is a good sign.

Hmmm, well I came here on a pregnancy craving. I never been there before and I really liked it. Not too crazy about the prices. I had a lot of food and I eat it all too, the baby made me do it . I can't say that now unfortunately. 

I had doughnuts holes, a shake, a burger with tots and yes, me and the baby ate it all. I wouldn't pay the extra money again for the upgrade Parmesan truffle aioli, it's not really that flavorful and the cheese doesn't melt so it's hard to eat.

The atmosphere it's cool and the service we had was good. The price range is average high so I'm not too crazy about the place to say I will come often so it wouldn't be my 1st choice if I want a burger. I've been in cheaper places with awesome burgers and when you ask to load the tots or fries they mean loaded. 

Definitely go check them out if you're in the area.

After living abroad for months, all I wanted was a delicious burrito. Last week I went to Chipotle at the King of Prussia mall, and it was terrible. I was SO grumpy that my triumphant return to burritos was lackluster.

After a long day of running errands, my husband (who also was abroad for even longer, and had yet to have his first burrito) and I decided to stop at the Marlton Chipotle. Boy, we are glad we did.

We WENT for it. I'm usually a burrito bowl kinda girl, but not this day. Burrito. Sofritos. Sour Cream. Guac. All of it, in my belly. Staff was friendly and attentive, and they made me one heck of a burrito. We grabbed a bag of chips, and sat in silence for ten minutes as we devoured our burritos. 

They were delicious and it was a very satisfying experience! All I could keep saying was... I'm so happy we came here.

Between a wedding and a reception, how does one kill the time? With a famous bite of custard, that's how. No really, my group saw a wedding party having their photos taken while ordering. It really is worth it to blow time between the two parts. ;)

I liked that the custard was cool and creamy; it definitely tasted better than whatever you pull from a grocery store freezer! I was also impressed with the brownie underneath of mine. I couldn't even finish my entire sundae, but man whatever I made it through was delicious.

One should note that even the smallest size is huuuuuuuuuuuuuuge. My ice cream/custard loving guy couldn't finish it... Worth a share if you're not too hungry, but regardless it's worth a drive over.

I ate my first 5 Guys burger in Columbia SC several years ago during a visit to Daughter #1 who was in college at USC. Five guys is the rage, Dad. We have to go. So go we did. It was the rage for a reason. I really loved the burgers, the peanuts, and the vibe which was pretty cool for a fast food place. I googled 5 guys when I returned home and loved the story of a Dad and his 4 sons opening up a burger place. And the rest is history. 

So I was super excited when I read that 5 Guys was coming to NOLA. An educated guess is they were in tune with the recent NOLA burger craze and decided to cash in. So D #1, who has since returned to her beloved New Orleans, and I headed to the concreteness that is Clearview Pkwy for a nostalgia burger. 

They did a good job of getting the restaurant to have the same feel as the ones in SC. It was packed at lunchtime on a Tuesday, but the bustle didn't bother me for some reason. I consider the burgers to be the best of the fast food class, pretty close in flavor and texture to Camellia Grill. The fries can stand up to some of the best in NOLA no doubt. One disappointment was the amount of fries per order. In SC I remember ordering a medium fry and getting enough for a family of 4. These orders are tiny and rather pricey. Overall cost is more than your typical fast food jernt but well worth the extra 3 bucks or so for a lunch for two.

So we look online and see that they are open until 11 and we pull up at 9:30 Pm ( they are open until 11) online and the window. There's no one in but the reviews on the food are good and we've been talking about trying it for a month. We walk in, the waitress just looks at us and I say "are you open still? She looks annoyed and says "I will see if we are still open" She walks by us and into another room and mumbles under her breath that she was just about to leave and go home. On purpose so we heard her.  Now it's 9:30 and the sign says they close at 11. So we stand there for 5 minutes waiting for her to come back and let us know if there open and she never comes back. So we left. And we will never go back. So all she had to say was. The kitchens closed. We've all heard that

My friend Steve is a funny dude. I had offered to drive he and his wife to the airport from Malvern last year. A few days before he sent me a Facebook post that said,
 " I'm thinking around 9am for our Taco run"

I replied that maybe 9am was a little early for Mexican food but I'm not one to pass up a Taco run. He soon answered back with a mea culpa that autocorrect changed " Taxi" to "Taco" and we gad a good laugh about it. I mean, how often is the guy typing "taco"?!

After successfully getting him to the airport, Steve cleverly rewarded me with a gift card to Chipolte. Thoughtful and funny but I couldn't for he life of me think of one near me or my work. 

" We'll there's one right near me" offered Steve 

That's great , buddy, but Malvern is about 45 minutes away. No taco is that good!

Luckily, I discovered that this one in Havertown had just opened. Still not totally convenient but near enough. The gift card was for $30, which came out to 3 visits. 
Here is what I learned in these 3 experiences.

It's a huge parking lot, but I've yet to be able to park anywhere nearby. Pretty much all of Havertown that isn't wedged into the Manoa lot is here. I opt to park by Lowes and walk over. It's less stress.

An order of Tacos is about $7 it's pretty reasonable and you get full from them. I have to say, the steak they use is only slightly better quality than Taco Bell. Pretty much every other bite is chewy and gristly. I'd stick to the pork or chicken. 

In a few cases I would have been happier with 2 tacos. I almost suffered through a third one. I wish there were more options to get more or less than 3. 
 
I could take or leave almost everything here. It's not bad it's just average. They have tabasco at the counter but  Siracha  as an option would be a game changer. I know it's technically Asian and not Mexican but I think most fans would be willing to overlook it.

The big draw for me here is their guacamole . It's fresh and delicious. I always get the chips and guacamole along with my tacos and now that my gift card is used up, I may just return only for the C&G.

The place is relatively clean and the staff is always friendly and helpful. I consider my rating a 3.5. Whether you are on a taxi run or a Taco run, Chipolte could always be a valid option.

I've been to the Fermentaria and Cafe a ton, so when they opened up a location in Fishtown, I was there opening weekend. It's a pretty simple setup--picnic tables and bales of hay everywhere, and two trucks loaded with taps of Tired Hands' beer.

The taps were really good. Everything is only available in a 16oz plastic cup, which was kind of disappointing given the different sizes at the brewery. Tap list was excellent, if a little pricey. I saw some dogs the first time I went but now they have a pretty strict "no puppers" policy. There's very little food--just some chips and beef jerky. You're free to bring food in.

Staff, as usual, was awesome. No restrictions on tasting beer and they really know their stuff. I loved Zenaissance, and Alien Church is always a winner. 

I'd suggest bringing the prices down a buck each and also getting some food trucks to pull up! Regardless, I'll be back for more.

Sonny's transformed my understanding of why the Philly Cheese Steak is an iconic regional specialty. I was predisposed to enjoy Sonny's because my friend who is a chef told me it is the place serving up his favorite Cheese Steak. He advised me to order it as a Beef Whiz Wid to get the most traditional style, though he prefers American cheese for melt and flavor. The Wid means "with onions" which you either already know or learn through any Google search for a list of best places in town.

The first bite was the bliss that I experience whenever I encounter a truly outstanding dish. It was heavenly. The second and third bites held the quality and flavor. I'm leaving Philadelphia the same day I found this glorious sandwich and I'll be taking my craving with me!

Well, it was nice and something different to do. I had not gone mini golfing in forever. The nice thing was they did not care that our dog was with us. We have a little shih Tzu. He was not walking just in his carrier. don't know if they would care if it were a bigger dog.  
The holes were okay, no big deal, nothing fancy. It was just nice with the big ship and the water fall, but nothing so spectacular. Glad we did something different. I don't know what other prices elsewhere are for mini golf but ours was 9.95 a person, is that pricey. I guess to me initially it was. it ended up being fun, super humid then ending up pouring down on us so we were refreshed at the end. Do this if you are looking for something different to do that you have not done in forever, but not in July when it is super steamy out.

Large arena that is well maintained.
Snack bar is very affordable - Thanks.
Watch the Roller Derby gals - the Copper Queens. Such lovely gals and super athletic. They have a great attitude as did the gals on the other team.
It was so much fun. 
I had a personal guide on my left teaching me about the sport. Saweettttt.
Live music ........ hello.

This is a good value for people who are starved for sushi but don't want to spend a lot of cash.
At $65 for 2 people for a stomach bursting amount of food, you cannot complain.

The problem with AYCE in Edmonton is that it's gotten a bad reputation for poor service and crappy quality food.

I can honestly say that Zen is both good value , and solid quality. It's not the best  for sushi lovers, but if you have a friend who hasn't eaten a lot of sushi or japanese food you can easily take them here.

Lots of cooked items for non raw fish eaters, complimented by insanely quick service makes Zen well worth going to.

Pros
Great service
Good Value
Free Parking

Cons
Atmosphere is odd. Their music choice literally plays broadway musicals, michael jackson and KPop

Today at Brio Tuscan Grille I felt lunch was just so-so.  We always come here before we go to the cinema at Plaza Frontenac and for some reason I just felt that Brio did not live up to my expectations.  

They have a large bar so of course we sat there.  There is  a selection on the menu that is 650 calories or less.  I did not choose from that.   I ordered the shrimp and crab cakes, and Majordomo order chicken under the brick.  We did not have to wait that long for our lunch to appear.  Both dishes were served with mixed vegetables and Major's came with mashed potatoes.  His chicken was tasty along with his sides.  My cakes were tasty also but I did not care for the vegetable medley.  There were also a few potato slices mixed in with the veggies.  Since everything was tasty, but nothing really blew me away like last time, I have to take away one star.

Would I come back here?  Yes, of course.  They have a very large menu.
Baskin Robbins always cures the "I had a disappointing dinner" blues. I just went for it! Chocolate Chip and Pralines & Cream. There's nothing better!

I'm always unsure if what I am eating is as good as I think it is after a couple of beers. Make that four beers, and I am even less sure. Or was it five? Hell, I lost track. And, I got hungry. What better than some late night pizza to take that beer flavor out of your mouth? Yeah, so I slapped a slice down my pipes. It was pretty good, I think?

I've always been a fan of The Ritz movie theaters for the cleanliness of the theaters, the films they show and just the convenience to nearby hot spots.

The Ritz at the Bourse is no different, but for some reason I end up there less often than their other theaters. It may be their best.

I always remembered this theater for having no cell reception on the bottom level, impossible to call/text to meet up with friends. That problem has now been alleviated as it seems it's possible to get a reception down there (at least with AT&T). So, if you're looking to crosspost across several social media services to tell people about the moving you're seeing or checking in on several checkin services (like Yelp!) you're in luck. Just be sure to turn your phone off or on silent for the actual film :)

Good place to stop in for a sundae, their hot fudge is good and their pecans are crisp and tasty. Culvers dairy dessert isn't ice cream by the way, it's actually custard, so it's very smooth.

Clean dining room and good service, hard to complain!

I went here with some friends while visiting for the weekend, I am extremely pleased with everything about this place. From the decor, vibe, music (DJ was playing old soul music and R&B that hit every chord in the right way). The portions were grand, I feel like there are often many spots that don't get it right or overcharge for basics, not here. I loved everyone else's dishes too (literally since the place settings are a mixture of types / designs of plates). Their biscuits are SOOOOOO good, make SURE you get them. I had the cheesy grits with shrimp hands down awesome & prepared the right way (and I'm picky since I go to ATL a lot), they get it right here! Absolutely coming back here for my next brunch when I'm in town!

This has been my neighborhood grocery store for about a year now so I guess that it is high time that I review it. 
I have found the produce and meat to be between average and good in quality, and I can usually find other things that I need. I can not speak about how their prices compare to other stores because I rarely go to other stores. 
In my experience the staff has been polite and helpful. There has been several times that they went to the back to look for items for me.
I try to do most of my shopping when they have the Pick 5 For $25 sale going on. If you get more than 5 of those items they are $5 more for each package. Sometimes the meat is not cut evenly or is oddly shaped, but that is okay with me , because I split it up anyway. 
Yesterday I spent $35 on the Pick 5 sale and I got enough meat and fish for 20 meals! That made me pretty happy.

Captain Bill's was a surprise. The king crab legs caught my attention and I will say the food all-around was very good and better yet, a good value. Started off with some char grilled oysters - very good. The grouper cheek basket was OK - nothing to write home about but the Crab Legs were terrific and char grilled is the way to go! A solid pound and a half that is nicely seasoned and not too greasy with plenty of sweet crab meat. Comes with two sides but with the crab, who cares about the little red potatoes or coleslaw that had too much mayo.

The other big win at Captain Bill's is definitely the drink specials - $3.50 for red or white sangria and $4.50 for a rum runner - I think that's a good deal! Also $4.99 for a pomegranate martini - let's have a couple to go with the crab legs! Next time you're in Treasure Island, make sure to stop by Captain Bill's for some good seafood and the live music wasn't bad or too loud either. Service was good and accommodating. Parking in the lot can be tricky during busy times but it was late enough that we parked down by the bank that was closed and had a very short walk.

My kid loves this place. I think it's attached to her memories of when we would take long bike rides and then stop here before we headed home. The interior is really cute...rustic and kind of kitchy. The food is a-okay. Tonight , with our dark chicken order I found the chicken being on the edge of under cooked. I don't want any question of well done-ness when it comes to chicken. Our Mac n cheese was the last of the pan. I should have waited to ask for the fresh batch. I like their shady, outdoor seating. The craft sodas are kind of cool too.

"Blenders in the Grass" makes me think of lawnmowers or something of the sort, but having been there, I now think of delicious smoothies! 

I had the mocha blend, which was made with non-fat milk, coffee, chocolate, ice milk, and banana! Yummie! It was so smooth and creamy without being overwhelmingly thick or sweet! The banana added a nice touch too. I also tried some of the Red Banana, which was really tasty too. No need to even compare it to Jamba or other places because this is on another level! You can also add supplements to your drink, and they have a wide selection to choose from. Each drink runs about $5, but they're huge! More than enough to split with a friend. :)

Meh. I had heard several recommendations for Sonnys by locals.  Several people said it was the best in the area.  It wasn't bad, but there was a lack of consistency.  My cheese steak had considerably less meat than my son's did.  Coincidentally, his tasted a lot better.  It was alright, but honestly I have had better cheese steak in other places.

I hate the setup of this cosi... It's really confusing because you have to give your order at one end (not where the cash registers are) and then you have to walk around to the other side and repeat your order to whoever is at the cash register.. the setup is not systematic, it is jumbled and confusing and the employees don't really assist with directing traffic because they expect you to know the process (which i think is unreasonable considering no other cosi i've ever been to is set up in this manner)

In addition, I was 1 of 2 customers waiting on an order and i watched my hot beverage through to completion and it took FAR too long for me to be serviced. I'm usually relatively patient with this kind of stuff and I would have been in this situation had the employee making my drink 1. known what she was doing and 2. not had three different conversations with other employees in the meantime.

Disappointed and probably won't be returning to this location.

After several visits to Bertha Miranda's, I have to upgrade this amazing Mexican restaurant to 5 stars.  Every time we come in here (and we love to bring our out-of-town guests), we are treated to amazing food and service.  When it's just my husband and me, we love to sit in the bar.  Relaxed atmosphere, and great top-shelf margaritas.  The last two times, I've ordered chili Colorado, and wow, WOW, the flavor is so spot-on, and the homemade tortillas are to die for.  We chose Bertha Miranda's for our Cinco de Mayo dinner, tequila line, great food, I'd probably eat here every day if I could!

Waited a long time to try Dragos and I have to say it didn't disappoint. The Charbroiled Oysters were simply awesome. Any Oyster lover can appreciate the quality of this dish. For my taste the only Oyster dish I'd prefer would be the  Rockerfeller Oysters dish from Bourbon House. but that's not to take anything away from Dragos, that's just a personal preference. I enjoyed the service, waiter was very attentive and offered good suggestions. The shrimp and grits was very good indeed, not the best I've ever had, a place called the fish house in Pensacola takes that award. Still, you can't go wrong with ordering the shrimp and grits here. Also tried the BBQ Shrimp, (at least Drago's version) again, very good dish, not the best. These were not the typical BBQ Shrimp you get at any Brennan's restaurant in NOLA, these had a nice kick to them though. The ambiance topped it off, good for just about any occasion. Glad to finally make the visit.

Sometimes you find yourself on vacation and say to yourself, "I really want store bought packaged soup."

I would never say such blasphemy, but to each their own. 

Whatever you would get at a convenience store while you're on vacation.......... beer, liquor, wine. Yeah that pretty much wraps it up. You can get it at Rouses. 

Located in the middle of The French Quarter, this place is a gem. 

It's pretty large and has a vast selection of food items you may need, especially if you're trying to do NOLA on the cheap. Are you a college kid tying to be thrifty? Did you lose all your money at the Casino? Did you fall in love with a stripper? Rouses has what you need! 

It's like your local grocery store, if it was surrounded by a bunch of belligerent people, the homeless and scantly clad women. 

If you're staying in the French Quarter, Rouses can take care of all your shopping needs.

So I have been looking for other choices for breakfast since I don't like 5e white cheese they are using for the egg white delight at McDs now.  This is the only Hardee's around so here I go!

First time through was pretty quick and the frisco ham breakfast sandwich was tasty. However I am giving 3 stars based on my second visit the other day.  

First off it was very slow then when I got my chick biscuit meal it was nasty.  I worked in fast food as a fry cook in a past life and I know when old oil is bing used,  the oil was very old and gross.  All the fried food tasted bad.  

In general I like Hardee's food and will go back but the manger should have did a little QC this morning and change the frier oil!

I had high hopes...  darn it. Seems like half the reviews like the place, and the other half say they are overpriced for what they offer. I had to side with the "Overpriced" group.

I love seafood, and am a little picky, especially when the price starts moving up the scale. Being  a damn good cook myself, I am probably harder to please than a lot of people.

We walked in the door... and there was no hostess, maitre d', headwaiter, etc... or anyone to greet us or seat us. After a minute or so, a waitress showed up and explained they don't have a hostess on the weekdays. She seemed a little grumpy, but maybe that was just my perception. 

She seated us... and gave us the full alcohol spiel. I explained that my girlfriend is allergic to alcohol, and I don't drink when I am driving. We ordered water... as that really is my preference. She delivered the water... and we ordered some Conch Fritters. We also  ordered the main courses... I chose blackened shrimp with a Caesar salad... GF got the Fish and Chips.

Conch Fritters were meh.. crispy outside, but mush inside, and the conch was tough.

Blackened shrimp were the 60 to a pound size, and I got two skewers.. maybe 20 to 24 shrimp. SMALL shrimp! Blackening was mostly cayenne, and it did not have the complexity I expect from good blackening spices. Cajuns blacken with a ton of butter... that did not happen either (maybe trying to be healthy?), and it does add a lot of flavor. Salad was ok... but the dressing was out of a bottle.

Girlfriend said her Fish and Chips was good, but she only ate the fish, only had three of the fries (and she loves fries)... and barely touched the Slaw (and yes, she loves good slaw). So what does that say?

And the waitress never did seem very happy to be there either! 

I usually tip well... and I think I only did about 18% here.. instead of my usual 20-25%... because if it is that hard to be there, someone needs to look for a different job. 

We did not do dessert...  

Maybe my expectations are too high? If I want Red Lobster, I will go there... and that is what I feel I got (and no, I don't consider Red Lobster to be good seafood!)  lol!

Definitely overpriced for what they offer.  I guess all the TV's scattered all over the place, and the emphasis on Alcohol should have clued me in... but like I said above.. I had high hopes.

It's a grocery store . Wasn't too busy at this time. Very tidy. Staff was nice. I got a turkey hoagie and watermelon juice.  Staff was young and very helpful at the register. The hoagie area had older staff that was also nice and helpful. My sandwich seemed fresh and good.

Delicious, huge portions of tasty food and fresh ingredients. Thanks to Yelp, we ended up here after a hike and ate ourselves into food comas.  I had the Taco combo which was a great mix of chicken and all sorts of veggies...I love that there was celery in there! I did not eat the tortillas so it was relatively healthy...who knows, it was worth it!!!
 I wish we had Mexican food this good in San Francisco!

Decided to write my first review on a soft tofu restaurant (typical Korean I am) because I go here about once a month and also because I am doing NOTHING at work today.

I think this place has the best soft tofu in the PA/NJ/NY area. I've had BCD and Seoul Garden in NY and So Gong Dong in Palisades Park, NJ. 

Like all soft tofu/Korean restaurants, you get side dishes (banchan) but the pickled dishes here are great. For $10, you get sides, rice in a stone pot, and soon doo boo (soft tofu) in a stone pot as well. 

I usually get the "More Spicy" when I go, and for some reason, this level is spicier when I go with fellow Asians than non-Asians (judging..maybe?). This just might be me, though. I really would get some level of spicyness because the non-spicy soup is just meh and looks too pale. 

The table bell to grab waiters are a plus, too.

Wish this place was in the city.

Delicious! I finally made it to Cheu after months of hearing about its greatness from my friends. 

Went for lunch and even at 1:00 on a weekday, the place was saturated with hungry lunch-goers. If you're not too concerned about where you sit, belly-up to the bar and make friends with the chef. Watch as he effortlessly prepares each dish fresh. Ask him for recommendations and then take him up on it!

To start, we had the broccoli/pork appetizer. It was solid and now has me wondering how I can re-create it at home (eating more veggies and all). For my entreÃ© I had the cold green curry noodles. Look, I'm not a huge fan of tofu, but I absolutely loved this dish. Perfect for a humid day when the thought of hot broth makes your mouth sweat.

The chef/bartender gave us some corn rangoons to test and they were somewhat spicy and definitely something I would order with a round of drinks at happy hour (which they have, M-F 5-6:30).

I've heard dinner can be super packed, so make reservations if you're a party of 4 or less and decide to hit up the joint on a weeknight between 5-6; otherwise, just waltz in.

I haven't ever reviewed a super market and so I am willing to give this a try. Do I like Schnucks? No. Do I shop there? Yes. Why? Because STL doesn't have a Publix! I wish they had a Publix! 

This Schnucks is the most convenient to where I live and so I go here. It is always busy and it is always loud. I go in to get what I need and I leave. I have never interacted with the employees. They hardly ever say hi and I can't even remember if I have ever been approached while walking around looking lost. Publix employees always had a smile and said "hello". Maybe Schnucks can learn something by taking a customer service class? Also, when I go to check out, the cashiers are hardly ever attentive and most the time they are talking with the baggers about weekend plans or asking if it is time to go yet! Honestly, all I need a simple "hello" and a smile every once in a while. That's all I ask for. 

As for the set-up of this location! I hate it. It is the MOST confusing and doesn't make sense. It irritates me when I can't find what I am looking for. Instead, I have to waste my time walking up and down every aisle since NO ONE is ever around to help! Get it together Schnucks. 

I will ONLY go back because I need groceries and unfortunately for me there isn't a closer location. You win by default.

I came to Nashville wanting to try places that I couldn't try back at home. I am SO glad there is a Mafiaoza's in Birmingham as well! This is by far the best pizza I've ever had. We were gonna start off ordering a capone (12") each until the waitress told us how big it was. Thinking back, an individual slice would have been plenty! I almost had to force myself to eat two slices because it was so delicious. I ordered black olives and buffalo chicken on my half which had just the right amount of meat and cheese, but the dough is what made everything just perfect. We couldn't even finish half the pizza cause it was just so huge. They offer the biggest slices to where u have to actually fold it to be able to eat it. The table next to us ordered the 18" which is definitely what I'm gonna try at the one in Birmingham.
IT was just ok.  I ordered a chicken sandwich, but the sandwich looked like something I could have made at home.  I will have to try the desserts next time and write a follow up review.

this place used to be great. growing up in barclay farm it was the take-out option of choice for my family,
i stopped in recently for some takeout and was sorely disappointed. wonton soup - meh. not so good. stir fried vegetables - oily & bland, and they all came out of a can. the place was empty & slow at lunchtime. 
sadly i think the glory days are over for this place.

We were craving some Taiwanese food and decided to give this place a try.  

What we ordered were:
1) Shanghai steamed pork soup dumplings - $5.99 as of 7/2019.  
Soup broth here was very flavorful as was the meat filling.  Just wish there was more broth in the dumplings!

2) Beef scallion pancakes - $5.99 as of 7/2019. 
Also a hit.  The scallion pancakes were extremely crisp yet tender on the inside and there was enough beef and hoisin sauce to really bring the dish together.  Highly recommended.

3) Garlic watercress - $12.99 as of 7/2019.  Whenever I eat at a Taiwanese restaurant I make it a point to get this as it's delightfully crunchy and light in flavor.  A must have for vegetable lovers.

4) Szechuan Style Tofu (aka Mapo tofu) - $12.99.
Holy balls this was spicy.  Most of the mapo tofu i've had has been fairly mild but let me tell you that they should really emphasize the Szechuan text as it has the classic numbing spice that ma la dishes have.  If you like tofu AND spice then look no further than this!

Overall the food was good though service could be better (took a while to clear away dishes).

If you're in the area and have the same cravings I did then check this place out!

My family was visiting from out of town and wanted to go to an upscale seafood restaurant for dinner, so we chose Rusty Pelican. The environment here is very cozy with all the wood and the fireplaces. The view absolutely cannot be beat. We sat at a table by the water and we were literally "on the water" meaning we looked over the edge of our table and could see the bay below us. Now THAT's what I call "Florida Dining". Even though the weather wasn't too spectacular it was still very enjoyable and i imagine it's even nicer on a clear day or an early morning. 

We arrived around 6 PM and it was fairly empty in the restaurant, so our waitress was able to greet us promptly. We are serious eaters, especially when it comes to seafood, so we started off with ordering about half of the appetizer menu. We got the seafood ceviche, oysters rockefeller, oysters on the shell, escargot and seafood risotte. Everything was really tasty, but my favorites were the escargot (which I was surprised to have found it sooo tasty) and the seafood risotte. The raw oysters on the shell were also extremely fresh and tasty, some of the best I've ever had.
