After that, our server made the mistake of asking if we wanted to order entrees or if we were just having apps. HA! Clearly she did not see us coming. Of course we were not done. 

Next we all ordered up our dinners. I chose the stuffed gulf grouper with mashed potatoes. My family got the tuna tartare, grouper and cioppino exquisite. We were all very satisfied with our meal. I thought mine was very fresh as far as the grouper goes and the mashed potatoes were just alright. My only complaint in regards to the menu is it was a bit limited in my opinion. For example, it seemed to be lacking key items like crab legs. I would have killed to see crab legs on the menu last night! Also would be nice if they had a few more raw bar options for those who are there for the seafood more than the steak. However everything was good overall. 

Finally, we finished up with key lime pie and coffee for dessert and our server continued to check up on us throughout our whole experience. Even though we were there for over 3 hours, she did not make us feel rushed or unwelcomed. I have heard great things about the brunch here and now that i have experienced their dinner, I would likely return for brunch on a special occasion. Definitely worth checking out rusty pelican if you are looking for an upscale experience in a seafood and steak restaurant with a view.

Last year I tried out one Cafe Beignet location, this year I decided to try out this location.

I actually did not get the beignets here. That WAS the plan, however, we saw they had a pretty impressive breakfast menu so being that it was 9AM on Bourbon (unheard of) we decided to get an actual breakfast instead.

The French toast I ordered was made with French bread (no plain old sliced bread here) and came with fresh fruit on the side. It was delicious, as well as filling since the portion was huge. One person in our group ordered an omelet and we were all surprised by how small it was. Maybe 1 1/12 eggs? He said the flavor was decent but it was definitely not filling. My cafe mocha was perfect and not overly sweet. It also gave me that caffeine I so desperately needed and got me up and running for the day ahead. 

This location has a big courtyard area with additional seating (and restrooms) upstairs. There is usually live music, which is nice. The counter where you order your food is small but you're only there for a moment or two since they bring your food to your table.
Easy parking, modern exterior with great patio sitting, friendly staff and decent iced coffee. Near the airport if you have time before a flight but want to be in the area. No issues.

I've ordered delivery and also ate in the restaurant. 

The food is good, the aesthetic is alright. Service in the restaurant is quick and friendly. Delivery can be hit or miss. Sometimes they're really delayed in delivering my order? But then they send extra naan or something. 

If you have to get one dish, I'd say get the butter chicken.

What has and F and a Z in it and takes you back to a simpler time?  Frank Zappa comes to mind.  In this case, I'm talking about Fazoli's.  I had every intention of eating Vegan here (which they do have options), but "The Closer I Got" to the restaurant, that idea faded.  After a crazy stressful month and skipping breakfast to get out the door, I caved and went all out!

I was perusing the menu for a few minutes when the nice cashier girl suggested the sampler which I could get baked.  I think I said "Yes" before she could finish the sentence.  The sampler was a mix of their fettuccini alfredo, spaghetti and meatball (singular), and lasagna which also comes with unlimited breadsticks.  After a long drive, I opted to make it a meal so I added a drink and a slice of pizza.  Gotta love that option for a combo!

For a fast-casual Italian joint, it's surprisingly delicious.  And at 2:30p on a Sunday afternoon, it was like Sunday Supper in Little Italy with a mix of patrons cramming carbs into their bodies like.  I tackled the Fettuccini first and the sauce was creamy and the noodles were al dente.  Then onto the spaghetti where the sauce was flavorful and I made sure I mopped it up with a garlicky breadstick.  The meatball was good, not fall apart tender like a hand crafted meatball, but a firm texture.  The lasagna was done exactly how I like it with an ample amount of ricotta and meat sauce.  It held together when cutting and was delicious.  

"A cow don't make ham" as they say, but a cow does make the beefy goodness that helped flavor their options.  The breadsticks that I cleaned my plate with were light and airy.  They gave me 2 to start and when I went back for a refill, they loaded 4 on my plate.  I didn't plan on eating them all but eating a fresh one was like a savory fresh warm Krispy Kreme in texture and just went down so smoothly.  I knew I'd regret it later, but I was living in the moment.

I'm glad there aren't more of these around as I'd be tempted to visit much more often.  This location between Tampa and Orlando is a must stop for any fast food junkie or anyone who likes Pasta dishes.

OK, so the space is SO beautiful, but I have to say, the food fell flat. I had the chips and salsa and pork belly tacos. Everything was a hard OK... it definitely didn't live up to the hype. The pork belly was good, and the one I ordered with an egg was definitely the best, but it definitely didn't wow me. I would like the option to order ala-cart. I get the sharing plates shtick, but when eating dinner with co-workers, this isn't the easiest route. 

The spicy mango cocktail was good, probably priced about right. Overall I spent about $40 and came out feeling underwhelmed. I'll try again, but it's hard to stomach that price for just the atmosphere when there are so many other amazing taco joints right down the street on Mass Ave or in Fountain Square.

I remember the first time I tried Chipotle...I hated it.  Haha.  And then I went back...and again...and again...and again...and then I worked for them...and quit...and went back...a million times.

It's a guilty pleasure...your boujie wannabe Mexican food...and I love it.

This location though...fell short.  The rice was not seasoned enough.  The meat portion was fine.  The fajitas were super overcooked and limp.  

They did a great job with their guac but the chips also weren't seasoned enough with lime and salt.  

Overall, it was a mediocre experience.  I'd still pick chipotle over their Q competitors anyday.

3 stars.

This was easily the best diner I've ever been to! A dessert case filled of big, beautiful desserts greets you when you first walk in! It was spacious and clean, the service was great, and the food was amazing. They were able to make a Turkey Gobbler Sandwich for me with a side of cranberry sauce even though it is no longer on the menu. It was a generous portion of perfectly cooked comfort food! The long roll that held the stuffing, turkey, gravy, and cranberry sauce was evidently from a local bakery. So fresh and homemade tasting! For dessert, I chose to take a chocolate covered cheesecake to-go. All in all, my meal came to $18. Not bad! I'd happily return to try the club and more of the tempting desserts!

Decent Chipotle. They know how to wrap a burrito! The energy is nice too because they greet people as they enter...at least during the lunch hour. Later in the day it's kind of busy.

I would recommend coming here over La Cumbre if possible. La Cumbre location has some issues but see the Yelp page.

Sometimes there's lively service, but this time our order was taken by a timid individual that never even greeted us. We just received a look upon approaching the register. We chose to order our Cali Burritos as bowls (love that option!) The Big Cali Bowl was full of fresh ingredients, despite them forgetting Guacamole in mine :( Oh yes, I went to the counter and asked for it, wouldnt you? No biggie, a server brought it out soon after and the feast began. Yes, I do mean feast! The bowls are huge and I can eat a lot! The cilantro-lime rice was cooked well and the tortillas fresh crunch compliment the other textures in the bowl. I didnt get any of the hot sauces (15+ to choose from), but theres no shortage. If Taco Bell is your thing, you need to step up your game!

Excellent food, inconsistent service, creative atmosphere, and cool seating options.

Will return.

We have been coming to Reno and have always stayed at peppermill since 2012 and this was our first time trying out this place. What a treat Oceano!!! We are definitely going to keep coming back for more if we are staying over at peppermill. I could've ordered the AYCE sushi ($23 for lunch) but the sashimi and special rolls aren't included.

*****| Sashimi platter, $16.50.. not going to lie I was skeptical at first but when the plate came out (omg yay me). For the price this was so worth getting and some!!!! Best looking fish I've had in a while (and in Reno). 

*****| Pacifica sandwich, $13. Dungeness crab and shrimp tossed in some delicious mayo dressing with melted cheese and perfectly toasted sourdough bread - Y U M M Y! Where else can you find a Dungeness crab sandwich for $13? This was also served with either regular fries or sweet potato fries. We opted w some yummy sweet potato fries. I highly recommend this and the serving is huge so you can definitely share this dish.

Oceano, thank you for an awesome meal! And Peppermill thank you for the comp dollars!

I've only been here once, and my experience was pleasant.  The service was fast, friendly and the food was beyond good.  Was it expensive?  You bet your sweet ass it was, and that's why I've only been once.  It's hard to justify slapping down $65 on a filet when my total weekly grocery bill is usually $75.  But on those rare occasions where you want to do something glutenous and American like spend $120+ for 2 people to eat, it's cool.  

I ordered my steak medium well and it came out cooked perfectly. No knife needed, cut throught it with my fork alone!  The taste was up there with the likes of Bern's, but not quite as good.  Also, we had the mac-n-cheese, which I highly recommend.  It is a la cart, so you're going to have to pay extra for it, but it's totally worth it.

If you go here, you have to order the lava cake when you order your meal and give it a try.
Yet another tourist trap style shop with lots of gifts.  Things seemed a bit pricey to me, but I guess no more so than other similar places.

Capdeville is a great spot to grab some food and drinks if you are in the CBD.  I always stop here on my visits back to New Orleans.  A perfect grown up gastropub for the grown up me.

I'm a sucker for yummy cocktails and the cocktail menu here does not disappoint.  The food is quite tasty as well.  On my last visit, we dropped in for drinks and some snacks to fill our bellies.

For drinks, I had the Pirate's Alley (perfect since a few in my party were dressed as pirates) and New Jack City.

Being a founding member of the Fritter Fan Club, I had to order the Fried Red Beans and Rice as well as the Jalapeno Cheddar Sweet Corn Fritter.  Yeah.  Good stuff.   Don't tell anyone, but I'm not the biggest fan of red beans and rice.  This shows that you can fry anything and I'll eat it.  

We also got an order of fries with chorizo and manchego.  Another really good item.  I think we would have ordered a few more plates of this if we didn't have somewhere to be shortly after our visit here.

Capdeville is kind of hidden out of the way if you don't know that it's there.  Go visit and partake in some great food and drinks.

We stopped here for their famous Charbroiled Oysters.  This location is inside the Hilton and the restaurant is quite large.  We actually went on the day of a LSU game, so the place was packed with red shirts.

I'm not sure if I went on an off day or what, but the Charbroiled Oysters were just okay.  I mean they were good and the cheesy garlicky butter sauce was perfect for sopping up with the bread, but overall they were way way too salty .  I also ordered some Raw Oysters, but they weren't as fresh as others I've had in NOLA.

I'll probably give them another try the next time I visit, so hopefully they'll be better then.

Decent place to get coffee at 8pm at night. Nothing too much to write home about. I ordered my coffee from my
Phone. It was waiting for me when I got there. 

Only one person was working, see greeted me as I walked in to use the bathroom and once again said hello while picking up my coffee. I appreciated the acknowledgement. 

The Starbucks baristas don't make eye contact with me while I'm picking up my mobile order.

There are plenty of old-fashioned diners to choose from everywhere.  Some have actually been in business a long time like this one.  Unfortunately, much of the food tastes like it has been lying in their freezer a long time.

Our service was very brusque, but many restaurants are famous for that, so I expected it, and it didn't bother me.  There's a restaurant in Boston called Durgin Park where they yell at you and the customers love it.  Our waitress was however, very efficient and came around a couple times to check on us.

We ordered what we thought would be the safest items possible, an open-faced reuben and an open-faced hot turkey sandwich.  I feel really sorry for those who have been brave enough to order fish.  Yikes.  

Anyways the corn beef was fine, cheese was fine, rye bread was soggy and had muted flavor, it was probably mass-produced and bland on purpose.  They put cardboard-tasting cole slaw in the sandwich, and on the side.  This stuff was seriously awful.  The fries were only slightly below average, a little dry, not greasy.  

The turkey gravy was impressively house-made, but tasteless.  How did we know?  It was lumpy!  A side of mashed potatoes, couldn't tell if they were powdered.  Asparagus so large it looked almost like green carrots.  And of course, overcooked and mushy.

This place survives I think because most of its customers have grown old along with it.

Today was something called "National Cheeseburger Day" and I received an Email from Fleming's mid-afternoon saying they were going to celebrate it all night long.

On select occasions, Fleming's offers their 5 for $6 "Til 7 PM Menu until close. That includes five different cocktails, five different wines, five different appetizers AND one really "prime" cheeseburger WITH fries all for just $6 each. (And if you look closely, you can even find a nice featured bottled beer on that same menu for only $3.)

Sold!

Yes, Fleming's is on the higher end of the spectrum when it comes to most of their food and drink, but this is one of the better Happy Hour menus out there and you have to love when they cut it loose for an entire evening.

Sure, I've had a fantastic steak here on a previous visit and delicious crab cakes with a bottle of wine on another.

Any excuse to visit this Fleming's is a worthy one, especially when the service is consistently good as it was again this evening. (Thank you, Matt)

Now, who actually decides when it is National Cheeseburger Day in the first place?
Great, Standard Starbucks.  Always consistent. Drive through line is a little tight but they keep it moving.

Flemings has all the markings of a high end steakhouse, including the dark wood paneling, soft lighting, nice long bar with a very good beer & wine list, etc.

The service certainly lives up to expectations. I was with a group of people and we could not have asked for more accommodating servers -- going about their tasks quickly and quietly. All very polite. So far, so good, right?

Then the food came. The shrimp cocktail was pretty good, with the expected jumbo shrimp, well cooked and chilled. However the cocktail sauce was very bland and really tasted almost like pure ketchup. 

There were four of us at dinner, all ordering steaks. 
I ordered medium rib eye, but my steak came out extra rare and was so laden with fat it was inedible. The server quickly took it away and replaced it with a better steak, properly cooked , but it was a little surprising given the high prices here, that a really bad piece of meat like that got through he kitchen. 

My replacement steak was cooked perfectly but the flavor was just okay. The mashed potatoes were nice and silky with a light butter flavor, but the asparagus was barely cooked before it hit the grill. So although the spears looked quite nice, they were almost raw inside (and yes I like my veggies al dente too). 
I did not partake in dessert but my dining companions did and they did like the carrot cake.
I was the only person in my group who finished their steak ( incl two filets) and the steaks were not huge -- so what does this tell you? When our server asked my companions if they'd like to take the rest of their steak home, all said "no thanks".

So despite the nice ambiance and great service at Flemings, I cannot really recommend it, except for perhaps drinks at the bar. The price point here is just much too high to put up with a very average steak dinner. 
Some chains like this have replaced real chefs with 'cooks' to save a lot of money. I don't know if that's the case here, but someone running the kitchen is asleep at the switch.

Loco Pez is loco-good. From walking through the doors and casting on eyes on the cautionary message: "Cash only, bitches. Si, putos, tengo ATM!," I knew we were in for an irreverent good time. (Though it's worth noting that I probably would go 5 stars if it weren't for the cash-only thing....putos!)

I was immediately struck, after being seated, by two positives: 1) the menu offers a handful of great choices that are very inexpensive, and 2) our waitress was unbelievably nice. It's amazing how much an upbeat server who appears to like his/her job can make a restaurant experience. 

I got the volcano burrito, which was very good. A small critique is that, if it's possible for a dish to have too much cheese, and I'm not sure that it is, this burrito may have been near that threshold. Also, it wasn't that hot, but they give you a ton of delicious sauces, some of them homemade, to spicy it up. I also got the diablo black beans, which were awesome. The guacamole was also fantastic. 

I hereby dedicate this paragraph to the bloody mary. It was one of the best ones I've had in a long time. It is quite spicy, which I love, and they accent it with cumin and chili powder to give it a Mexican feel. Highly recommend it.

Bonus: they had a pinball machine in the back that somehow had 3 free plays loaded up. So each of us played a round on our trips to the bathroom. 

I can't wait to come back here and try the brunch.

A DD inside a gas station.  They have a drive-thru too, which is handy if you've got dogs or no legs (I guess).

Everything is consistently the same as every other Dunkin around.  It's generally good enough and fast enough.  But as I'm writing this, I keep clicking between 2 stars and three stars.  

Two stars - the donut upselling.  I go in for three, and the cashier tells me "It's cheaper if you get 4."  It's cheaper PER DONUT, but you're still always paying more.  There's a serious distinction between those two concepts, and that attempted upsell happens every time I go in.

Three stars - dog treats (or a couple stale donut holes) for the corgi when I bring her through the drive-thru.  They don't have to do anything like that, but it is very kind of them (and Stella loves it).  

Three stars wins out, since my dog is staring at me, probably thinking about squirrels or food or tennis balls - whatever corgis think about.

Updating this review:  Went for a second visit this weekend - there was a gulash special, which was yummy. Really enjoyed the Fischer Hefeweizen too. The staff were friendly as previously, but could have been more attentive, which is only reason I changed the stars on this review. I really like this place. I really like the beers. I would just like a tad more attention from the other side of the counter. :)
________________________________

I should probably try more food than just the wings before I write a review, but the brewed beers were very good. Was fortunate enough to be there with someone that knew the owner and we got our group got our own little private beer tasting. 

Service was quick. Food was hot and fresh. Was quite pleased with the heat on my wings. Don't think there was really a bad beer in the bunch.

All I can remember is that the Magnum 44 is the best stuff ever. Hurry - somebody get me a growler of this stuff - stat!!

We visited Eats! during Creative Loafing's Tampa Bay Burger Week to try their $5 Juicy Lucy Burger. This Wednesday evening was fairly busy, but we quickly found a table with a view of the World Series game on several televisions. But because this is a small restaurant, I imagine it does fill up at busier times.

Having enjoyed their Mac-N-Cheese at the annual Yelp event in April, I was delighted we could substitute that for fries on one of our orders at no additional charge. Because the burgers were delicious. I'll rave about them first. Mine was cooked more than my requested medium well, but was simply so good that I was able to completely ignore the overcooking. The fries were also very delicious. But the highlight of my meal was that homemade Mac-N-Cheese! The bowl was huge - more than plenty to share between the two of us. Piping-hot creamy pasta, covered with bacon & a thick layer of cheese - glorious. Sooo good!

Our server was very attentive but not over-bearing. She was friendly & helpful, sharing her opinion of a couple dishes that had caught our eye for future visits. But, we also appreciated that she wasn't terribly chatty. Later in the evening, we saw a sign on the ad board about 70Â¢ wings on Wednesdays, and hubs almost ordered a few to take home for his lunch, due to our server raving about them. Even though he ultimately didn't order any (only because he wasn't able to finish his burger), we are definitely returning for those wings, as well as a few other entrees... And that amazing Mac-N-Cheese.

If there was a 12 step program for ice cream addictions, this place would probably distract me from completing the course... Anyplace that still serves Richman's Ice Cream has my business whenever I can get there. Although I never have tried any, there's a menu full of good from the fryer and grill. The cheese fries must be a favorite since I saw a few orders being eaten on my way in. 
The ice cream prices are a bargain, and the serving size is enough to make you stuffed and looking forward to your next visit. 
They've been around for awhile, so its good to see a quality business still in the area.

Pho is my favorite hangover cure, but definitely not when it's from Pho Bistro.

Straight to the point: overpriced and awful. 

The pho was just plain bad. As the only pho place in Isla Vista, my theory is that there's no pressure from competition for them to cook up quality food for a good price. The broth (which has a pretty dominant influence on your meal, and my favorite part) was extremely greasy. Gross.

I've never tried anything else here but I noticed a lot of others were getting the fried rice. I came here to fix my pho craving, but my recommendation is to just wait until you can get your hands on something better.

Really just a miss for me. The ambiance is a lot like Panera but the food is far from it. They specialize in all things flatbread, with soup, salads, flatbread sandwiches, and flatbread pizza. I dont really think flatbread is something to base a whole restaurant off of, as it's really not that popular in general?

Anyway the staff was really nice, but I cannot recommend the food. The Chicken Pasta soup had no chicken in it, and the pasta was more like couscous.

Probably will not be returning.

What a hidden gem  you step out of the elevator and into a different time. It is updated yet has enough of the charm from long ago. 

Reservations on Resy - Easy Peasy

All the wait staff -super friendly! 

I love the menu has a simplicity to it. 
My steak was cooked to perfection 

The biscuits were delicious (berry jam so I could not partake) 

Love the drink menu very unique flavors. 
The Pacific Prince was my choice they light the rosemary so it gives it a smoky vibe! 

Cannot wait to go back and check out the beautiful outdoor area. 

They offer love music and events!

The smell of cajun crab boil from the antique bubbling cauldron right in the front window will overwhelm you as you pass by this place on Decatur Street.   

Very casual, and although it's not that clean and a little too brighly lit,  it is still an authentic Cajun dining experience.

Crawfish were out of season, but  the chargrilled oysters with parmesan, crab risotto and fried seafood were very good.

Whoopsies, apparently the Publix and Tsunami Sushi are not related. My bad. I still enjoy many other places better than this one though, my sister orders takeout from there every once in awhile and it doesn't seem to have changed much since my last visits.

Went with a group of 5 for a light, late dinner. While the restaurant is pricey, I think it's fair because the menu really is very unique. Each of the items came in small servings, and we tried a variety of items including beets, eggplant, Brussels sprouts, octopus (you have to eat octopus given the name of the restaurant), steak tartare, and broccoli. The only thing I wasn't too fond of was the Brussels sprout. The broccoli was also a bit dry. But the preparation and presentation of each item was different than anything I've had. It's a fun place to go for tasting, but I wouldn't recommend going there if you are really hungry. 

Our server was lovely; she offered many suggestions and even comped one of the dishes because one of our choice dishes was not available.

We were at the museum and wanted a great Italian meal.  The reviews for Little Nonna's were very good-however in my opinion, 5 stars were not enough.  Hanna the Host was extremely nice and scored us two seats at the Chef's table right in front of the kitchen.  We had a bird's eye view of the delectable meals coming out.  

The restaurant was cozy and very intimate.  Perfect for a date night with my wife.  Our server Lydia was totally amazing.  We split the Garlic bread and the Spaghetti and meatballs paired with a carafe of Montepulciano d'Abruzzo.  We chatted with the kitchen staff who were very nice and told us what they were preparing.  

Overall, a phenomenal experience.  I highly recommend Little Nonna's!!!

4.5

Cheu Noodle Bar is a quaint, yet eccentric little spot serving up soul-warming ramen & other asian small dishes. Happy hour is Monday-Friday from 5-6:30, which is when I came to catch up with two friends over drinks and ramen. 

There's limited seating, and you can't sit at the bar while waiting for a table to open up, as it is reserved for sit-down eating. No problem - we grabbed a drink and waited standing up! However, the one downside: there is very limited standing room. The three of us were against the wall, and had to dodge around waitresses every so often when they came out with new dishes. While waiting for ~40 minutes, this became a little irritating, and the reason I knocked the rating down. 

The drinks were good! My favorite was the TEEN SPIRIT (tequila, aperol, lychee, & lime). 

While waiting, the kitchen accidentally made an extra order of the mojo dumplings, and we were lucky enough to be treated to those - which helped soothe our rumbling bellies. SCORE!

Food: 
MOJO PORK DUMPLINGS ($7) // five dumplings filled with pork, and sitting in a flavorful, sweet & spicy sauce. I;m not sure what it was, but there was definitely a spice in the sauce that gave it its MOJO!

BLACK GARLIC WINGS ($10) // Crispy coated wings bursting with flavors - there's cilantro, there's garlic, there's sesame. The wings are full of juicy & flavorful meat.

MISO RAMEN ($14) // A classic take on Ramen. A warm bowl of broth & noodles, with shredded pork shoulder, a soy egg, black garlic, & mustard greens. The noodles were perfectly cooked without getting soggy, and the pork was tender. Definitely a good & hearty bowl of ramen perfect for a cold winter's eve.

BRISKET RAMEN ($14) // Japanese food meets Jewish food, and births Jewanese ramen. This was a unique take on the classic dish - there were traditional ramen falvors (kimchi, sesame red chili broth), and then some unusual ones - brisket ramen & a large matzo ball. It was fun to see this twist on Ramen! 

Overall, the food was incredible. Cheu packs in plenty of flavor into each of their dishes. I'll definitely be back, but will probably go at a less popular time - to avoid the small waiting area!

We r in the land of Fazoli's. It's dinner time and got off the road for some good fast food Italian. When my baked Spag with meat sauce came it was pretty sad looking! I have never had it this small of an amount and hardly any sauce on top!! Noodles were exposed and dry looking. I spread them a bit for the pix. The taste was good but I have to say this is the WORST looking dish I have ever had at Fazoli's. 
   Bf had the chicken carbonara and it was good. He ordered a side salad and drink for add on. Thank god for the breadsticks.  I use my app for $ back too. I now have $5 on for next time! I needed one dollar to score my points which I did this visit.

First time here and wanted some chicken for a fast lunch. Enter the restaurant and was greeted by Tasha.   Who was working the register and waiting on another customer.  She gave me that wow experience.   She was very pleasant and cheerful when waiting on my brother and I.  She was so sweet and kind to everyone who walked through the door.   As other guest left the restaurant she made a point of thanking them for stopping by.   The manager Brittany was working the line and just as friendly and professional.  I tried the chicken little combo.  It was fast.   Fresh and had plenty of flavor.  The potato wedge where crispy and hot.  Because of Tasha and Brittany we will definitely come back.  We will be working right down the street all next week. Will have to come back for lunch.  I would recommend this place.  Thank you Tasha and Brittany for a wow experience.

Although the revolving circular door in front is a costly bit of nonsense that I cannot fathom, McMahons has an old school dark-paneled bar room that is a fine venue for happy hour or dinner. I have had many steaks here in the past and have never been overly impressed with their quality, but the ambience almost makes up for it. On Fridays, McMahons  packs in the Foothills hoi paloi with a sweet happy hour on their twinkly adobe brick patio, and rarely can so much Elaine Benis-style, rhythm-free body movement be witnessed in one place. The cigar selection is outrageous, and tobacco aficionados are revered here, another rarity. The old school movers and shakers certainly still shake it up at McMahons, for better or worse.

I must say that I found out about this place using Yelp. I used to live in NO but left about 8 years ago when this "restaurant" was not there. As previously described this restaurant is in the back of the Erin Rose bar on Conti next to Bourbon in the Quarter. You go through the small bar to go to the even smaller restaurant. They only offer maybe 5-6 versions of po boys at a time so it is a limited menu. I had the pork belly po boy and also ordered the potato salad for a side. Total with tax was $13.  

The po boy is a 7" which seems a little small. However, it was very, very good. I like their bread (it comes from a Vietnamese bakery in NO East) too. The potato salad was also very tasty. 

The "restaurant" has one high table for 4 people. The other seating options are along a bar that adjoins the wall. This place is small. If you want a drink you have to go get it in the bar and pay separately. Also the restaurant only accepts cash.

The chef uses all homemade ingredients...this is NOT your typical po boy shop. It is actually a high end product that you can taste the difference. My favorite po boy is still at The Cajun Stop in Houston however this place comes close.

I highly recommend the pork belly po boy. I am sure the others are equally good too.

Complete creole dinner made for an awesome meal for me and my boyfriend to share- from our waiter it sounds like it was made for one though. Not too big a fan of their seafood and okra gumbo as it was too slimy for me. Love love lovee their crawfish etouffee!! Flavor was amazing and it was filled with crawfish. Their bread pudding was also super delicious, but a little too sweet for me. Went around 6pm on a weekday and we didn't have a wait at all.

This is a review of Cajun Encounters City Tour.  It covered the whole city, gave lots of anecdotal history with quite a bit of humor, Renee was our magical mystery tour bus guide and guru.  Renee let us wander around on our own at the cemetery, told us to be back at the bus bus in ten minutes...don't worry if you're late because they'll come back and pick you up...tomorrow.  One lady didn't show up on time, he made sure she saw us slowly pull away..she turned into a world class sprinter and provided entertainment for the group.  We rode through every part of the city and saw and heard lots of interesting, and some morbid, things.  This may be the best thing we did in New Orleans, actually pronounced Nawlins by the locals...one of the interesting tidbits Mr. Renee shared with us.  Covered a lot of stuff about the storm, what the city, state, and people have and are doing to bring this city back from a watery grave.  Everybody heard a lot of news coverage, but listening to someone that lived through the experience and is very knowledgeable really brings  this disaster to life.  Well worth the price of admission!

Solid NOLA eats. Come for the chargrilled oysters! Stay for some of their various other famous Cajun/Creole eats. We also had the chance to taste/share  the gator bites. Tastes like a chewy fried chicken. 

For my main I had a crawfish Ã©touffe. Lightly spicy but the serving was not huge! Service was quick and efficient for our huge group. Overall a good above average experience for our first night in the Big easy! There are so many places to eat in this town. A solid 3.5/5 that I will kindly round up as it was good! Thanks. Peace

Who'da thunk that the simple grilled cheese sandwich could morph into a 21 Century restaurant chain centered on this basic food group? Bread and cheese becomes delicious fast casual cuisine. Born in New York, the brainchild of a twenty something selling hot sammies from a window operation, it now extends as far west as Minnesota. The Newtown store is the second in PA; the first in King of Prussia Mall. 

I caught it on its first day. It seemed the entire staff was on hand to help out. They wore black T's with the Melt Shop logo on the back, and ball caps similarly adorned. The place was crowded with assorted families and kids just out of Council Rock North's last week of school. The music system played on a rock loop that made for a very noisy atmosphere that was unnecessary given that it just interfered with conversation and made ordering a shouting contest. 

Just turn off the sound system, please! 

The food was very good. I went with the Maple Bacon Grilled Cheese (maple cured thick bacon, cheddar/American slices) within decent bread slices, and Shop Tots (tater tots sprinkled with grated cheese and mild spices). Plenty of chewy flavor inside the hot grilled pain, and well deep fried crisped tots. Liked them both alot. Drank a bottle of their signature water from GIVN, an outfit that brings clean H2O to communities in need. 

Prices add up quickly, so if you want a shake with that, lunch reaches $15 in a hurry. 

Melt Shop also does variations with fried chicken and burgers, both of which looked good on other tables. Will make it back to check them out. I'll give them a while to figure things out first.

Shout out to Davide, one of the managers, with whom I had an informative discussion about the store.

Enjoyed my meal at Dragos. They were pretty empty as we went on off lunch hours so we were seated immediately. I didn't get too much of the menu here but we did get their staple Chargrilled oysters which were delish. I definitely could have eaten more of just these. Our server was friendly during the short time we were there. They are located near the outlet so a good spot to visit while shopping.

Ultimately, Sweet Alley is a very forgettable establishment in Isla Vista. It's kind of cool that we have our own fro-yo and candy shop, but considering that I went like, once three years ago and just recently mustered up the courage to try it again, there isn't much to say about this place.

With their "re-opening" a year ago, management has introduced several Asian desserts to the menu, including the beloved egg waffle. Emily L., my significant other, and I each ordered one of their egg waffle sundaes, which comes with a large scoop of ice cream, fruit, and chocolate wafer roll. And so did the 20 people in front of and behind us.

The one aspect that was clear from the start was how understaffed this place is. There was one student at the front taking orders and making desserts, and on a Sunday night, with about 20 people out the door, that really piles up. After a 10-minute wait, another girl walked in (perhaps she was on her break with an hour left before closing?) and lazily began refilling the DIY fro-yo toppings bar. Hey, your co-worker is wildly swamped at the front and there's no one in line for chocolate chips. Start making egg waffles, or something!

That being said, the sweet blonde girl running the shop really did an excellent job of staying on task and keeping it cool. There were several things out of her control that this place really has to improve on if they care about making their customers happier. The staffing issue is one. Another was that the scooped ice cream was super icy. I'm talking "finding ice pockets in the cream" icy. Fro-yo might be a better bet, so stay away if you don't want to shock your molars every time you chomp down. Management should also consider paring down the menu (cold brew nitro coffee! Egg waffles! Sago soup! Acai bowls! Sour cherry gummy coke bottles!) to maintain quality control.

All that said, the egg waffle was just okay. Too dense for my liking. It wasn't strawberry season, so the fresh sliced ones on top of my sundae were kind of sour, but the presentation was pretty. What else can ya say for $5.95?

Was looking for other cheesesteak places besides the popular pats and genos and found sonny's. Parking was pretty hard to find on a sunday but we got lucky after circling around for some time. The line was out the door and there were a good amount of seats (though they fill up quickly). I recommend one person in your group line up and order while the others occupy a seat! My boyfriend and I got the loaded cheesesteak meal (fries & a drink). Fries were decent and drink was fountain soda. The cheesesteak itself was really good! I am craving it as I type this! 

They also take card which is a plus!

I love when a place has non-dairy/vegan options. Their coconut sorbet was creamy as any dairy ice cream out there. Waffle cones were crispy and fresh as if they were just made. I like that. Hubby had two scoops of two different chocolate ice creams that he raved about for two days. The line is long, but worth every minute of your wait time. This is in a fairly pedestrian area - but watch for traffic as the cars move quickly. BTW - so does the line, so don't be deterred when you see how long it is!

I go to this Whole Foods pretty often since it's only a 3 minute drive away from my home and it has most of the normal shelf items but because this is one of the older and smaller Whole Foods store, it's lacking a full food/restaurant area that's becoming more normal in the larger, newer stores. So because it's lacking that full "food court" section, this gets a solid "A-OK". So, it has a pretty great sandwich and sushi bar but it's lacking 2/3 of the menu from the larger stores like my favorite, the vegetarian burger.

The staff is very helpful, friendly, and patient.

There is a Trader Joe's right across the street and I love TJ's but the feeling I get from every visit to any TJ's is a sense of urgency and mayhem. It's always busy and people are frantic everywhere. Like Black Friday at a Walmart. And though I'll also shop at TJ's, I tend to pop in and leave as soon as I can. Whole Foods is just another type of experience and I like the toned down vibe where I can stand in one spot for a bit while I read all of the ingredients and weigh my options.

The staff keeps telling me that this Whole Foods will close down and reopen a few miles south in a larger location to accommodate more items and I don't know if it'll ever happen since it's been years since they said this and honestly, I'm ok if they don't move just because they're so close.

Parking: Large shared lot
Price: Whole Foods in general is more expensive than any grocery store

Hooray for GC, which looks nicer than your average grimy Chinese take-out joint, but is your average grimy Chinese take-out joint at heart.  You can sit inside if you like and take in the ambiance of crazy purple neon lights along the windows.  They look radioactive.  I think there's a TV in there, too.

How's the food?  It tastes how the food always tastes at a Chinese place with industrial tile flooring and strange glowing photographs of anonymous plates of food above the counter.  I think they even sell those giant plastic containers of iced tea/lemonade.  That's just nasty, but their food is fine--you know how it is.  If have $5 and you want some, go get it!

I'm a sucker for an old-timey soda fountain/candy store, especially when there's homemade ice cream. The place was PACKED on a Friday night--not surprising with the summer weather. I got the homemade strawberry ice cream. SO GOOD! You can really taste the difference between ice cream made on the premises and stuff you get at the store. Sitting outside, eating your ice cream, you'll feel like you're in a Norman Rockwell painting. Very quaint.
Also, this is a "high risk" store meaning they don't carry certain thing and also cannot take returns from non high risk stores. It's ridiculous.

This place got very good pizza buffet.  Customers wear  gloves  to pick up the food from Buffet station. There were chicken soup, pasta with two different sauces,  various topping pizza, desserts including brownie, Cinnamon ban and apple Pizza, Boston cream pizza. I loved the personal Pizza. Customer can choose the bread, the sauce and 4 Topping. They baked it fresh for you. Mine was  pizza bread, spinach alfredo sauce, anchovy, beef, sausage, and chicken topping. It was so delicious and fresh! The soup and salad were decent. The cinnamon ban was my top favorite. They were so buttery, soft, general creamy icing on the top and sprinkle of the cinnamon power-very very good. The sitting area was clean with some arcade game machines along the wall. With Christmas music playing at the background, carton showing on TV, the ambience was happy and layback.  The employee were very friendly and helpful and the pricing was excellent- All day all you can eat buffet for 6.99 per adult, where can you beat this in Tampa?

Unfortunately this review will be very narrow and pointed. I only came for the oysters! They are so good they did not stay on the plate long enough for me to photograph them. You must come to Drago's and order the chargrilled oysters. It is one of life's best experiences. My life has been dramatically altered by indulging in the great Delicacies. I won't even take a star off when it took me an hour and 15 minutes to be seated and then another 45 minutes for my oysters to reach my table. The oysters are nice and medium-sized. When they arrive to your table they are encrusted with Parmesan cheese garlic and dripping in butter. And just in case you need help stopping up all the butter and the Chardon is on your platter, they bring you a loaf of fresh French bread. This is not diet friendly nor would I want it to be. Every voice turkey was delicious. They were nicely shocked and I never found a piece of shell in the Oyster. It is now my go-to spot when I'm in New Orleans after I get off the airplane to go stand in line for Drago's.

I have been to the other Ritz theaters in the city and enjoyed this one just as much. The layout to this Ritz is a little funky where you have to ride an escalator down to the concessions. Honestly, the glitz of the Ritz sign just made me more excited to be there! 

I went to the first showing of The Little Hours last Saturday. They offer a little bit of savings if you go to the first showing of the day. Also, keep in mind you can avoid the online convenience fee if you buy the tickets at the theater. The largest popcorn was $7 and they had a bunch of other treats you could choose from. The seats themselves were all on one level and reclined.   Seats and aisles were clean when I arrived and there were no issues with the movie showing (see my other movie reviews to the horrors of theaters I have encountered). I'd definitely see another movie here and look forward to my next chance to visit.

Delicious! Cute little place in downtown Tarpon. I had the coconut latte and some of their cookies and their grilled cheese. Everything was so tasty and it was such a cute and calming place. I would definitely come back.

Probably the best sushi I've had in Nashville.

What looks like a small storefront from the outside is a really large restaurant inside, with a mixture of regular and hibachi tables.  We were here with a large group (15+) and they gave us a private room, which was perfect, because it meant that we could have loud cross-table conversations without bothering anyone else.  Service was a little uneven, but that could have been due to the enormous size of our table.  

Overall, a great experience and I will be back.

This used to be my favorite "chain" restaurant in the city and I still love their corn grits, and would go back any day and just eat those.

Unfortunately, I am sorry to report that the last two times I ate here I got sick.  Yes, SICK.  Both times I ordered the trout Lafite (my favorite).  I thought the first time was a fluke and I was just coming down with something, but when I returned about 6 months later and ate the same thing, once again, I got sick.  It was terrible.

I have never had this issue at the Westbank or Elmwood locations, just this one.  It's sad, because I like supporting uptown businesses, but I will never go to this Zea's again.

i came here a few times since my conference was located at the hilton.. service was always slow.. whether it was at the bar or at a table.. 

the charbroiled oysters were decent.. nothing mind blowing.. i figure if you put enough butter and cheese on anything.. it'll taste good.. you don't really taste any oysters as it's overpowered by everything else.. 

the oysters in the half shell were gigantic.. but poorly cleaned.. there was plenty of grit.. i also prefer east coast oysters since they tend to be more briny.. 

i also had a the shrimp po boy and the catfish po boy.. both were flavorless and the fries soggy

Greeting- yes
Vibe- hotel lobby
Price- nice
Service- very good
Wine list- some good buys
Parking- hotel lot
Food
All I ever eat here are the char grilled oysters.  About $15 dozen. Delicious with a glass of white wine. Sit by the grill and watch the show! 

WIGB? Yes

I was visiting Indy and made a brunch reservation based on the number of good reviews. I was pleased with the service and delicious food. I wish there was a nada closer to me because I'd go back in a heartbeat. 

We had a table of 6 and our waiter handled all of our questions, orders and checks flawlessly. We started with the trio salsas and build your own queso. Both were perfect for sharing. We got the pork belly mixed in the queso and it was so amazing. The 3 different salsas were all really good too.

For my brunch I got the eggs benedicto. I really liked the avocado, egg and cream sauce combination. Something new compared to your standard eggs Benedict. My husband got the enchiladas and another friend got the fish tacos. Both were excellent! Only one person didn't like their dish and it was the geotta sausage Benedict. If you're not familiar goetta is a grain based sausage so the texture and flavors are a bit odd.

My first time here... and it reminded me of Moe's..
I had an hour lunch today, don't get that very often...my co workers wanted Taco Bell, but I wanted something more!!!
So I thought what? what? what? I was driving in the Vandy area and saw Chipotle ...never been so I swung my van into the  parking lot and went in. The line wasn't too long, gave me enough time to check out the overhead menu.

I opted for the chicken burrito bowl with brown rice, and black beans, with corn relish, pico, guac, fajita veggies and cheese...then I also got chips and salsa to go with a side of two different salsa...right at $10 not bad...

this was to go back to my work cube...so by the time I got there, it was cold..not their fault
wish I had eaten there, would have been much better served hot

I would go again! Reminded me of Moe's...

This is my son's favorite pizza. The owners are so charming and friendly. A shout out to Mike!! Thanks for always being so friendly and outgoing!! We have had several events here with the Level Up gaming trailer. 

I love their lunch buffet $6.49 comes with salad and a drink. I love the choices a buffet gives you. They have so many varieties and choices it makes it fun to try new things all the time. 

I like the crust. It is then with a thick crust to it. I like to dip my crust into ranch but they do have honey if that is what you like. Love the weekly specials they run too. 

This is a great place for gluten free pizza.  The gluten free come in two sizes medium or small. Be sure to sign up for their emails as they send you coupons from time to time.

Piccolo Trattoria is a local success story, and it is well deserved.  Its growth to 3 shops is testament to the hard work and persistence of its creator.  While I have only frequented the Newtown location, I hear great things about Flowers Mill and Pennington.  

Take out pizza is an almost weekly order for us.  Friday or Saturday night would not be complete with a regular or Brooklyn Pie and a Spring Mix Salad.  The kitchen is a factory operation which you can watch as you wait at the register to pick up your food.  It is a beehive. 

The pizza is very good and the Brooklyn Pie an excellent version of Sicilian with semi-sweet sauce, basil leaves, and copious mozzarella.  The Spring Mix is loaded with Green Apple slices, Walnuts, Feta, and first class Balsamic. The times I have eaten in house, everything has been well presented, tasty, and in abundance.  Most of the menu is traditional Italian American fare, so if you have a more adventurous palate, you may want to try Vecchia Osteria., or travel a bit farther afield to Philly or NYC. 

Otherwise, you can't go wrong with Piccolo.

Came here for dinner on Friday with the family.  The service was lightning fast, we had our food in just a few minutes.  

The Buffalo wings I ordered as an appetizer were delicious and the pizzas were fantastic.  My husband and I got a large, 4 cheese thin crust pizza and our kids each got a child's pepperoni pizza.  All of our pizzas were really good: great crust, flavorful sauce and a good melt on the generous serving of cheese.  

My only complaint would be that our waiter never offered to refill the adult's drinks, only the children's drinks.

(Extra credit for them having a vintage Ministry album on the wall with the other dÃ©cor.)

A very decent BWW over in Tampa.

Stopped over at BWW in Tampa with some friends for lunch a couple weeks ago. The restaurant was decently clean. The waiter was nice, but he disappeared for long stretches and took a while to get our checks (a pet peeve of mine). The food and drinks were in line with normal BWW food in terms of quality.

Overall, if you are looking to go to a BWW in Tampa, this won't blow your socks off or anything, but it is a fine location.

The food is straight up salty. It's frustrating but most of the food in the Casinos just seem to be laden with salt.

The restaurant is nice and is  on the cheaper side of fine dining. I had lobster bisque ($12) and the cedar salmon ($27). In comparison to other restaurants that are in the fine dining ranging it's affordable. 

BUT IT'S SO DAMN SALTY! I seriously stop eating my soup because I felt like I was  getting closer and closer to having hypertension. Don't get me wrong  it's flavorful and there where bits of lobster that tasted fine but I just couldn't get over how much water I was taking in to feel hydrated again.

Moving onto the salmon, what the heck is wrong with people? Must you ruin a dish by bathing it in salt? For shame. Salmon was fine, it's the crap underneath it that I had issues with. My vegetables we swimming in this salty sauce. The vegetables just killed it for me. I 'm not coming back.

******WARNING!! As of November 2016, the VAST MAJORITY of the 267 reviews found on this page are NOT for this Rouses Market (i.e., the one on Royal St. in the French Quarter), but for the Rouses Market on Baronne St. in the Central Business District/Warehouse District.******

This review is for the Rouses Market located at 701 Royal St. in the French Quarter. It ranks a solid 3 stars in my book because of the following factors;
1) It is essentially the only real grocery store located in the French Quarter.
2) Its product line leans toward natural products. In many ways, the Rouses chain tries to compete not only with supermarkets, but with Whole Foods as well.
3) It is open for long hours each day, and in fact, is open until 1 AM.

Having said that, I will admit, as others have noted, that the store is incredibly small, and that it has only one small set of doors, located at a front corner of the store, through which all customers, and also all deliveries and tradespeople, must all somehow manage to pass.

Because of the small size of the store, the selection and range of items offered is rather limited. For example, I recently spent five minutes trying to locate the section that stocks nutritional supplements, and, having failed at that task, I asked a grocery clerk for the location of the nutritional supplements section. When he confessed that he had never heard of nutritional supplements, I gave him  some examples, citing products such as "vitamin C, or calcium tablets". He searched in vain for five minutes, and then gave up  He and I then went to the front desk, where I asked  a woman (who identified herself as a manager) the same question. Much as happened with the clerk earlier, she confessed that she had never heard of such a product, and, thus I shared with her the examples (cited above) that I had shared with the clerk. Looking  at me blankly, she vaguely pointed me toward a spot in a specific aisle that, of course  bore no  trace of  nutritional supplements. A conversation with another manager later confirmed that they do not carry nutritional supplements.

I had much the same experience days earlier in trying to locate Dr. Bronner's liquid soaps, a line of natural and organic soaps which are, and have been, a staple of natural foods stores for over 60 years. The manager had never heard of such a product line, and admitted that he did not carry it. In contrast, even the tiniest and shabbiest Whole Foods store, even a one-star rated one, always offers a wide selection of this staple product line. 

Now it is time to get back to the header paragraph of my review: The sad reality is that as of Nov. 2016, the VAST MAJORITY of the 267 reviews found on this page are NOT for this Rouses Market, but rather for the Rouses Market on Baronne St. in the Central Business District/Warehouse District. In fact, a quick survey that I conducted yesterday of all 267 reviews indicates that at least 85% of them, particularly the 5 star reviews, are for the vastly larger Rouses Market located in the warehouse district. 

So, if you should see on this page a review (and there are many of them) that claims that this store sports any of the following features:
-- tons of free parking
-- an outdoor open-air dining area with garden
-- a rooftop herb garden (some reviewers have called it "aerophonic", whatever that is...) where you can prance happily through the aisles of herbs
-- a burrito bar
-- a coffee bar
-- rooftop overflow parking
-- a fresh pizza bar/counter
-- a huge selection of single-bottle beers
-- a sushi bar/counter
-- never a line at the "many checkout registers"
-- wide aisles
-- an amazing and wide selection of foods and other natural products
-- a fresh seafood counter
-- a fresh meat counter

....well, those reviews are TOTALLY WRONG!!! None of those things listed above are true for this store, but they are true for the Baronne St. store, which is about ten thousand times larger than the French Quarter (FQ) store.

However, the FQ store does have a deli counter, albeit a very small one, and the staffers there are very friendly.

Some pluses about the admittedly very tiny FQ store: 
-- It does carry a good selection of yogurt and kefir products.
-- The refrigerated products section offers a limited array of  pre-packaged sushi products made at its larger sister store. 
-- It often carries bottles of  egg nog in the dairy section.
-- Most of the staffers try very hard to be helpful.

Lastly, let us address the question that has been burning in my mind for the past week: How could it possibly be that over 80% of the reviews found on this page are really for the much larger store on Baronne Street in the Warehouse district? How could so many reviewers possibly make the same mistake? After hard deliberation, I feel  that these gross errors must be chalked up to the fact that there is a very high rate of consumption, and abuse, of alcohol and drugs in the FQ, and in all of New Orleans, and thus...!

Most recent observation is all the hard liquor is in limited selection and quantity and only behind the counter UNLIKE the Tchoup location.  Which frankly is a little frustrating given they have ample floor space and showcase wines in a fashion that begs why then not do the same for high grade liquor?  Or even low grade for that matter.  They have the space.  Use it!  And be consistent with the other stores.

a great find in the far back of the truly dumpy Erin rose bar.  don't let the front bar fool you, there are serious po boys of the highest order.  the bread is Vietnamese style and crispy like a cracker.  I had the meatloaf which is tasty and spicy. my wife had the shrimp which is one of the best iterations of that, that we have ever had. a simple place, but doing it right. I believe they have another location too.

This place is a hidden gem. I can't believe it took me this long to find them and they're so close by! So far we've had the tacos, burritos, taco salad, quesadilla, Chili relleno and enchiladas. We've come here a lot since we found them.

If I had to pick ONE favorite item, it'd have to be the carnitas crispy tacos. So dang good. The meat is crispy and all of the ingredients are fresh and delicious. Crisp lettuce, ripe red tomatoes, freshly grated cheese. It's evident a lot of love goes into their dishes.

They do a great job with takeout but we also enjoy eating there. Oh! Great margaritas and beer selection, too.

If you have a craving for really good Mexican food, you really can't go wrong with anything at Macho Tequilas. Oh- and I'm writing this as I'm waiting for my tacos. I may have a problem...

What the heck??? I have been shopping here bi-weekly and I never knew this place existed?? I always thought it was more space for people to eat their purchased prepared food! It is for that but they also have a full bar and a menu in there. Friendly bartender yesterday greeted us and we enjoyed our pizza here while drinking some delicious beers.
There is also a Tap Room menu. So many great options! Great prices on everything. Wine, Beer and the food. We will be back!

This one time a month or so ago I agreed to run in Saint Louis track club's road series. I agreed because a friend has been asking me to do some type of official running with him for quite some time. I drank a tall can of Pabst Blue Ribbon before I went, not purposefully. When I showed up to the Visitor's Center I had to pin a number on my shirt and all of this other serious stuff. Gazelles were everywhere. Litheputians from the land of Liltheput and shit. 

What happened after the fear and anxiety in my PBR laden mindbelly clenched itself in sweaty agony is a strange tale to tell. Yet I can relay you this much. I ran my first F'Real Race and it was 6 miles of my consciousness inhabiting a place in my soulbrain that I still suffer some remnants of PTSD. Thank you shamanfriend for leading me into the desert known as "There are some big ass hills in Forest Park that you didn't know existed but in conquering them you will live."

Forest Park contains many great memories for many great people. Weddings, Golfing, Softball, Public Sex, Fishing. For me, Forest Park now carries that time I ran, I ran up a hill, I thought only of some goddamned red shoes bouncing in front of me and I won. 

I won.

The End.

Located right next to the Hilton, this place is good for one thing; char broiler oysters.  Big and full of flavor, they are sure to please. I will say that they seem more cheesy and more competing flavors than at acme or Frank's; keep that preference in mind.

Somewhat out of the way to get to unless you are at the casino or going to the outlets.  Otherwise, items on the menu seem pricey compared to other nearby options.

A dessert place with a long line can mean two things. One, it is an Instagram photo-worthy hype. Two, the dessert tastes really amazing. Of course, it can also be a combination of both factors, but for Ted Drewes, it is simply the latter option. The dessert served here is solely vanilla custard, and you can play around and customize it by adding some sauces or toppings or by making it a concrete, shake, malt, or a few other variations. Choose from one of the menu options, or get creative and make your own flavor combination. Either way, whatever you do, the custard remains the star of the show, and what makes it so good is that it is high quality while staying simple and unpretentious. It is super creamy and looks, feels, and tastes homemade. 

There really is not anything fancy in appearances about the storefront or the custard at all, but the lack of disguise is what makes it so charming. You order at a window and either eat your custard outside or take it to-go with you somewhere. The line may be long, but it moves fast. I placed my order and then received my dessert almost instantaneously. If you want to avoid the line completely, go on a day when the weather is terrible and people do not want to be outside.

There are plenty of ice cream places in any town so I will give you a fact that might convince you to make a visit like it convinced me to. According to SoolNua's 2016 annual World ICECREAM Index, Ted Drewes was rated as the world's best ice cream. I am no connoisseur and have no idea how prestigious SoolNua's World ICECREAM Index is, but it sounds pretty cool. I do not know if Ted Drewes is the best custard in the world, but I can say that the custard is pretty darn good and worth a visit.

Ok location. It has the Coke machine serving all those flavors that's a plus- I come here for my biscuit cravings- it's no fine dining. It's Popeyes! 
Ppl are generally nice

I was shocked to have a terrible meal from this establishment.  They have really gone downhill.  Used to be my go-to, and as a guy who works in a thai restaurant and has traveled to thailand, that says a lot.  I ordered beef salad and green curry.  Two Thai staples...both were all but inedible.  Oversalted is an understatement.  The green curry tasted salty and had virtually no coconut flavor - I have seen some Thai places use cream to cut cost on curry, but this seemed like pure heavy cream and no coconut milk at all...and soooo salty.  The beef salad had uncooked beef to start, and was even saltier than the green curry...could hardly get it down.  even the white rice  (which was sushi rice and not jasmine rice) was very salty, which I just don't understand. My wife (from Thailand) agreed 100% and said that she couldn't eat it either.

Sorry to say, but I will never go here again.  Too bad.

** Low Ratings?? They Are Reviews 1+ Yr Old. One is 4 Yrs Old. Why Did I Ck?? I'm Not Driving. Behind the Wheel? I would PEEK QUICKLY/SAFE @ THE HINTS. Sorry, Now their hiding behind "The Reviews:("

I have Zero complaints about this StarB location. Convenient next to I-4 W. Exit 19. It's spotless clean. Seems like it's had a nice Reno. Modern, lots of seating w/WiFi charging access. Configured into different sections. Even, for the non-techies. Wanting to relax for a bit. Or, come in w/a colleague or bestie. Seating for business meet/greets. 
Most important. "Bean Talk" from placing an order w/Armando at the Register. Great people skills. 
The Baristas are polite. Fast efficient service. I ordered the A Grande Mocha Soy Frappuccino. Needed a chocolate Jolt. 
I must say. ##WOW!! If Chocolate is an aphrodisiac or wake up your senses. 
I feel like dancing. 
Yes, I do miss the Hints On Yelp. Though :-( "Yelp. Pls, Bring your Hints back.*** NO OTHER W.SITE HAS THE HINTS.*** We're feeling lost out here. 
Lots Road Warriors.

Might be a little biased because the only films I've seen here are all knockout emotional rollercoasters... that also happen to be Taika Waititi movies but whatever.

This is a charming little theater tucked away near Headhouse square with all the things you need to enjoy a great indie/limited distribution/arthouse/absurdist Hitlerjugendfilme film, like refrigerated junior mints, giant pop corns and sodas, and a bathroom that is actually clean.

Kick back, relax, watch a couple of flicks, and drink in the area. Everyone should be so fortunate to be able to partake in simple pleasures like the Ritz East.

Dining at the Prime Rib restaurant, which is located inside the Warwick Hotel in the affluent Rittenhouse Square area is not as wonderful as it used to be.  It was once a place where you would feel like you were walking into the middle of the past century and beyond to find Don Draper and his mad men croonies, ah times change and everything else along with it, but this time it was a sin.
 
We were early for our reservations and were going to have a seat at the bar, but decided to check in with the host and he offered to seat us right away, seeing we were famished, we took him up on his generous offer, Food! Our server immediately greeted us and offered us drinks, hubby had a coke and I had an excellent dry martini, served in a rather large cocktail glass, well chilled and made to perfection.
 
On the Prime Rib page of reviews on Yelp, it says to mention Yelp and you and anyone else at your table will receive a complimentary appetizer and so I did, which he was not at all enthusiastic about and it clearly showed. Then I pulled a rabbit out of my hat or rather a printed certificate from an Open Table offer that they and the Prime Rib had made publicly, to pay $25.00 up front to receive $50.00 off your bill when all was said and done. 
 
This really did not thrill him and he was very obvious about his distaste in our lack of class ( in his mind ) to take the Prime Rib up on their own offers. Not only this but several times our server and a group of other staff members were nearby our table, talking about us and looking right at us, like how could we?! Even over at the service area for the bar, they turned and stared at us, laughing and talking. I'm serious folks, it was down right rude, made me feel like a clown and was the beginning of the most absurd service I have ever experienced.
 
We sat at least 20-30 minutes waiting for menus, while hubby stewed watching others being serviced and finally received our Yelp appetizer which was one large ( Diver, I'm assuming ) scallop each, wrapped in practically raw bacon on a small bed of baby spinach leaves. The scallop was cooked perfectly, I gave hubby my bacon, but he and I both agreed it was too raw to eat and then we were handed menus, which was a good forty minutes after we had been seated.
 
We shared the most bland bowl of lobster bisque that was served in a cool tureen style crock, absolutely no hint of sherry and I used to love their bisque, our waiter brought us a hot pepper sherry sauce in a bottle, but we passed, as it was very hot and the sherry did not even attempt to shine through.
 
The large oyster Rockefeller were outstanding, the escargot were tender and swimming in a garlic sauce with baby mushroom caps and a thick slice of grilled bread to dip into the sauce. The jumbo lump crab cake was large and pure but very un-adventurous other than that and was served with a lousy cocktail sauce. I had to giggle silently as the table next to us commented on their choice of sauce to serve with a lump crab cake. I myself had asked for the mustard sauce that was previously mentioned in their crab claw appetizer and it worked to help.
 
When our meals came our server finally grabbed my hubby's longtime empty coke glass and refilled it and asked if I would like anything else. I asked what chardonnay they had by the glass, he offered several, not mentioning the names but the regions and I chose a Sonoma, when he brought it he had the label totally covered and poured me a sip, I asked to see the label and I was thrilled to see that it was Sonoma Cutre, one of my favorites and then he was about to walk away when I said excuse me, can you please pour my glass of wine? Oops.
 
Hubby was served a huge roast of Prime rib and he was kind enough to cut the bones off first to save for my onion soup for Christmas, his meat was cooked to perfection, tender, flavorful and juicy, however my filet was a big let down and we had already spent so much time there and just wanted to leave. I had ordered it medium rare and when I cut into the first third of it, the first cut was medium well, no pink or red whatsoever, but the center of the steak was barely pink.
 
I was not going to say anything, but for a dry, flavorless piece of meat at $38.00 and the thinnest, un-flavorful bearnaise sauce I have ever been served, I thought this is so wrong, class or not speak up. I did and he argued with me! He said well the outer edges will be well done, I had cut one third into my steak, come on buddy this is not the first place I have had a steak is what I wanted to say, but instead I showed him the center and said it is barely a hint of pink and even the top and bottom of that was well done!
 
To be continued in another update, this is how upsetting this dining experience was.

Soon to be one of stops along the the long awaited Modern Streetcar, Mercado San Agustin really is quite charming not just because I live here! All of the merchants here are LOCAL and could use some extra visitors. Ever heard of a little bakery called La Estrella? yep....they have a little shop here and it's delightful. I can get my pan dulce fix any time I want! Ever heard of a little place called Taqueria El Pueblito? Yep..that's here too, and although it's somewhat Americanized, I can't get enough of their breakfast burrito...and they serve b-fast ALL day! How about Sonoran Sno Cones? You can find that too. Plus Brasserie with it's chic bar is the perfect place to throw back a few walk home. But it's not just about the food my friends! You can also get a massage here and by antiques and colonial Mexican furniture. And you can also find pretty much all of Tucson's food-trucks in the commissary kitchen where they all come and cook their culinary delights. And every Thursday, there's a farmers market! TALK ABOUT LOCAL! Love this place. Why wait for the modern street car? You peeps have cars! The bus stops here too.

Solid spot at the airport in terms of airport food options. Everything is made fresh and they pretty much have their full menu. They have it marked clearly that this location is not gluten-free friendly.

My food was made fresh and I still got the delicious crunch from their cheese fries. I've had their burgers and open-faced hot dogs. Both were delicious and every bite had me wanting more.

There isn't a sign that shows the location but it's near Dylan's Candy Bar.

I really don't get the hype about chargrilled oysters. If you like oysters, eat them raw. Chargrilled just makes them taste like grilled breadcrumbs covered in butter. 

But my preference for raw stuff aside, I found the food to be over priced and over rated. I ate here twice because my friends are vegetarian so they don't care where they get their lettuce and it was raining and apparently they melt in the rain. 

This was just a typical restaurant tourist trap conveniently stuffed into a huge hotel. The salad was meh. Lunch specials are ok in price. The poached oyster pasta was pretty good, but the Alfredo was nothing special.The stuffed crab special was extremely salty and the collard greens that came with it were watery. 

Walk away from the casino/hotel area and get real food.
Great ice cream/yogurt spot to stop by on the way to the beach. Very clean, different flavors all the time, and broad selection of toppings.

Fast food- Chinese style
Cheap, fast & not the greatest
$5.60 for ALL during ALL open hours
Crab Rangoon- surprisingly nicely stuffed, but taken from a heat tray for speed
Hot & Sour Soup- tasted OK, but only about 8oz
Garlic Sauce Shrimp- the sauce was closer to gravy & not much garlic plus very tiny shrimp

It is as advertised - Express.

What is not to love at Chipotle. I have never had a bad experience at this location - food is fresh, perfectly made, and I always return to this location.

They are open everyday until 10pm.

Highly recommend: Burrito with brown rice, pinto beans, chicken, mild salsa, corn salsa, guacamole, lettuce, cheese and sourcream = my usual.

Enjoy!

Once I heard about this place from my brother, I wanted to come here quickly.  This place isn't as good as the Korean BBQ place in K.C..  But, this will suffice my cravings until I go back to KC.  The side dishes were plentiful & okay.  The grill is brought out to you instead of having a grill built into the table with a fume hood over it.  Not good in my book.  The meat was okay.  The service was fast, & the staff were nice & helpful.  There are cables clearly seen running through the entire place.  The bathroom was a bit nasty & kind of reminded me of the bathrooms on airplanes.  Just with a bit more space than the ones on planes.

Key things to know: 
* Open till 1 am. 
* In the quarter
* decent selections
* Bottled Alcohol is cheaper as compared to other places
* Definitely on the expensive side but again, no other place in the quarter that is cheap for groceries / staples in comparison
* Check for expiration dates before buying (unless under the influence - high probability!)
* Deli section is the most iffy part
* Very courteous staff - its south for sure!

We have passed by the entrance of this park quite a few times in the past so we finally decided to check this park out  this afternoon. I was not able to find a lot of detailed info about this park and could not find a trail map on the internet.

When you first enter this park  it has a real concrete/golf course'ish feel to it. (sucks but it gets better, see below).  The main park is sectioned/labeled by lots (lots A - J ??).  It is a mecca for children/families. We encountered at least 5 different baseball/softball fields, numerous soccer fields, playgrounds,  large sand volleyball courts, a small skateboard park and a basketball court. Throughout the park is roofed pavilions/gazebos with picnic tables and  large BBQ grills (quite large grills, very nice). They also have a large concession stand/building  (was closed today) that has a eating area with built-in tabletop checkers/chess games. The park has a large amphitheater (2200 square foot stage)  that hosts summer movies and summer concert series. You bring your own lawn chairs,  the lawn will hold approximately 4,500 people with unobstructed sight and sound according to what  I have read. Not too far from the amphitheater is a retention pond that is stocked with fish (no fishing allowed). Some of the fish were huge (probably well fed by humans?),  they were practically jumping out the water. (they looked like golden and yellow carp?). 

Around the perimeter of the park is a interconnecting asphalt paths for walking/jogging/running. Sections of the paths intertwine into wooded areas that also have more picnic tables. The park has outdoor  'fitness stations' scattered throughout the park with equipment for doing pull-ups/chin-ups, push-ups, ab leg lifts, monkey bar, etc. 

We happened to park at lot 'E". At the edge of that  lot we found a trail head that goes deep into the woods. We were pleasantly surprised. We found numerous trails. Some of the trails were 'groomed' (covered in wood chips), this is excellent for trail running (it was seriously comfortable on the feet).  Other sections of the trail have wooden boardwalk sections that cross over  huge wildflowers/fern like plants (I wish I knew what the plant species is called).  We also walked on less groomed/unmarked trails. We encountered a cedar lake for fishing (need a permit) and a wildlife/wetlands area. We also found a small hill with some dried-up creek beds/streams that had the exposed tree roots that we walked up on, very cool.

We liked this park and are looking forward to checking out some of the other trails.

I love KFC, but this particular location isn't all that great.  They routinely get my order wrong and I don't find out until I get home.  Employees here aren't exactly loving life and it shows.  Nobody is outright rude, but they're not friendly either.

With a recent large catering order the containers were so flimsy that I ended up spilling both green bean juice and coleslaw liquid all over my car.

We came here on our philly layover. Im Not sure why people are crazy over "philly cheese steak" subs. They are boring and plain and nothing like the ones we have in New York. My boyfriend had one from here and never having a true Philly cheese steak sub. He was disappointed. It was basically all meat, dry meat. Minimal onions, no peppers and it came with a side of cheese whiz. Gross. There was of course no cheese on the sub. I tried a bite of it and was thankful that I didn't order from there. There was NO flavor. The ones in New York are sloppy and delicious with loads of cheese, onions, and peppers) next time we go to Philadelphia we will be sure to steer clear of the original sub. Maybe  ours was just bad but I doubt it. Glad we tried it though so now we know.

heck yea i'm a fan! 

they may have a limited menu~ but what i really enjoy about this place is the service.  the staff always attend to their customers with a smile~ and they always make you feel very welcome.

the food is solid! the seafood pajun is done very well! and free refills on the side dishes! i only wish they extend the lunch specials to the weekend too...
