i have yet to try the kalbi but the portion looks mighty generous! that and the soodobu sound like the perfect winter grub combo.  looking forward to it! yummm

On the second day of our trip to NOLA, we ventured out to find a place where we could sample a different type of po'boy. After reading a couple of reviews, we settled on Killer Po'boys which happen to be right around the block from our rental. Upon entering the restaurant, we were pleased to see its low key atmosphere that was both inviting and aesthetically pleasing. The woman at the counter was a doll, eagerly helping us order while asking questions and making recommendations of what we might like. I decided on breakfast style po'boy with house made chorizo and egg while my fried opted for a curried goat variation of the popular New Orleans dish. While waiting on our food, we took in the restaurant decor which was a nice mix of local flair. We even had the chance to read a few articles about the "new age po'boy movement" and how restaurants like this were changing the concept of what a po'boy is. It didn't take long for us to receive our order. I was surprised at how large the po'boy was, especially since it was rather inexpensive. After taking that first bite, I don't think I can ever go back to the original po'boy again. The chorizo was flavorful but not too spicy and the egg was perfectly cooked. I had a chance to sample my friend's curried goat and was surprised at how much I enjoyed it. The goat was braised perfectly and the curry seasoning took much of the gamines out of the meat. This place will definitely be one that I frequent every time I'm in the New Orleans area.

nice clean family, locals, travelers friendly place.  Some kind of connection to The Dairy Cottage.  I'm not rushing back for the cheesesteak but if you have a group of people/family and everyone wants something different including a cheesesteak then this is your place.

Okay, I'm not impressed with this Indian food. Huge price tag on mediocre food. Indian food is known to be on the pricy side, but this place doesn't live up to their price. I had the vindaloo and chicken Biryani.

Looking for a low key seafood place with great staff and food?  This place delivers.  We were ready to enjoy a lazy evening grazing on food and drinks.  We started with the grilled oysters, shrimp trio (coconut, buffalo and firecracker), frog legs and seafood gumbo.

Luckily the beautiful char grilled taste of the oysters made up for the fact that they spent too much time on the heat.  Even cooked oysters need to have a blast of juice when you take a bite.  The shrimp, for the most part, were very well executed, crispy, flavorful and not over cooked.  The buffalo's were jumbo sized and had the right amount of buttery hot sauce heat and crunch, the firecracker were smaller but also crisped and expertly coated with sauce.  I didn't taste the coconut coated crustaceans, but the verdict was they tasted like they came out of a Sysco bag.  So a miss.  The frog legs were super plump, lightly coated and fried perfectly.  The meat was so tender and fresh, but it was missing seasoning.  A side of melted salted butter with garlic would have been the perfect accompaniment and the right fix for the lack of salt and flavor punch the legs needed.

Next came another order of firecracker shrimp (they were one diner's Achilles heel), seared ahi tuna and a cup of the seafood bisque.  Tuna was deemed quite excellent, but the sweet drizzle was said to overwhelm the dish. More heat less sugar was the preference.  The soup had potential, but upon arriving, it had all the signs of coagulation from not being stirred before serving.  Roux based soups require a careful eye and don't have the best longevity.  In the end, it loosened up and was decent, but not a favorite.  The man and woman duo providing the live music that evening were fantastic.  Their song choices that included James Taylor, Neil Young, and Santana provided the perfect back drop for a great evening.  Mini hiccups, but overall great food, music, drinks and company.

This new and used bookstore has been a UPenn staple for ages. This place is great if you are looking for a hard to find or out of print book or just want to browse the recent bestsellers. They have shelves and shelves of used books as well. The whole place is very neat and categorized, which is a plus. 

The owner does have a few cats that roam the store but other wise, it is a great place to sit and read for an hour or two.

We waited about two hours for our delivery on Sunday night. Good thing we ordered fairly early in the evening or I would have been one hangry lady. After a call to the restaurant, someone assured us that the driver was nearby. We had our order about five minutes later. 

Rather than going for Indian, we tried some of the "Indo Chinese" selections instead. I'd say they were very similar to some of Han Dynasty's offerings, with just a hint of Indian spices. The two dishes we tried were both good (chicken in hot garlic sauce and chicken in kung pao sauce). We ordered one mild and one medium and I thought both were pretty spicy, especially for my weakling palate. We received two containers of basmati rice along with the order. 

While I might try Tiffin again, I probably won't go the delivery route.

I'm generally a huge fan of Whole Foods for the quality organic produce and dry goods selection, and usually stop here for a sushi dinner or some fruit to get me through evening classes.  Though the selection is more limited, this location often brings in unique gourmet things (like Jeni's ice cream) that other locations don't.  It can get pretty crowded at times in the aisles since the space is smaller, so be prepared to rub some elbows and swerve around carts.

Downside is the parking lot, which shares space with the Philadelphia Sports Club and can turn into a war zone on busy afternoons and weekends.

SO many options of ice cream!!! And the portions are great- and prices are cheap. You can also split ice cream flavors in any size. My go to is always coconut when on vacation and theirs doesn't disappoint - plus with over 50 flavors, can you really go wrong?

I finally made it! Arrived at 11:15 as rumors of the city shutting down for Coronavirus were swirling and snagged 2 seats at the bar. Tried the egg roll, cucumbers, Dan Dan noodles, and hot chicken. I appreciated the freshness of the egg roll and it was perfectly crispy. The cucumbers were the perfect combination of spicy and cool and crunchy. The Dan dan noodles were absolute perfection. I have been searching for noodles like these since having them at various places in NYC and have not found them until now. Luvi has them, and I love that restaurant, but the noodles are not what I've been searching for. I am still thinking about the Dan dan noodles from Blue Giant. I saw all the rave reviews about the hot chicken and my husband devoured it enthusiastically-  I didn't love it as much as he did - I don't know why - it was very good though! I can't wait to try every single thing at this awesome place. Hooray Blue Giant!!!!

The worst mexican food I've ever had in my life. I am from San Diego, I'm visiting Tennessee and was craving mexican food. Mexican food here is nothing compared to San Diego mexican food. 

The chips and salsa were good, the guacamole was very bland. Margaritas were great and a good price for the pitcher. 

The food was terrible. The chicken in the crunchy taco had absolutely no flavor and tasted old. The taco itself was tiny, it hardly had any toppings on it and the shell was not crunchy. The cheese enchilada was very bland and the sauce they used was tasteless. The chilie relleno was odd, normally they have cheese in them but this one had chicken. Even though I did not order that. The chille itself was not bad but like I said the chicken here is flavorless. Surprisingly the rice and beans were the worst thing on the plate. The beans had such an odd flavor that I couldn't even take 2 bites of it. The flavor completely ruined my appetite. 

Overall, I'm sure if you're from the south this food might be authentic to you. If you're from San Diego or anywhere where they have authentic delicious mexican food you will not like this.

I'm not a huge fan of frozen yogurt, but I must say that Yogurtland really delivers where it counts (at least what is most important to me).  Good selection of flavors.  Good taste.  Texture is not too soft.  Good variety of toppings.  Decent syrups.  And very reasonably priced ($0.30 per ounce).

This Yogurtland, located on State Street in Santa Barbara, is not much different than other Yogurtlands out there.  I tried their pistachio flavor, which was good.  I also tried their lychee flavor--I definitely could taste the lychee; decent but maybe not for me.

They have a lot of toppings and I went with some Fruity Pebbles, Cap'n Crunch and bananas.  They had a lot of other stuff you would come to expect such as other kinds of fresh fruit, candy bars, cheesecake bites, chocolate chips, and so on.  They had nice big Ghirardelli syrup dispensers.  I tried the caramel and it was good.

I went a little bigger than I usually do and my total was in the $3 range.  Usually, I'm in the $2.50 range at Yogurtland.  Service was pretty quick.  There was a little bit of a line, which is often the case at Yogurtland shops.  It can be a little frustrating because I worry that my frozen yogurt is going to melt.

Of the self-serve frozen yogurt places I've tried, I would have to put Yogurtland at the top (though I could not really tell you what makes one frozen yogurt better than another one so the affordability of Yogurtland is weighing heavily here).  Cherry On Top has a lot of toppings, but their frozen yogurt is too soft.  Menchies has a lot of toppings too and their frozen yogurt has a nice texture, but they are too expensive.  There are other frozen yogurt places out there, but for me at least they don't seem to provide a significant advantage over Yogurtland.

Parking is available on the street (though hard to find); parking is also available at a nearby lot that is free for the first 75 minutes.

Y'all gotta try the fries! 

Excellent live music ambience. I felt very comfortable here, almost like I didn't want to leave. Great food, very tasty. You can tell they care about the food they make. 

Make sure you have your ID because they check that. Idk if its 18+ or 21+ but if you're old enough try it out!!

Short summary: Go here. Go here and eat here. Then do it again, and again, and again.

Juan's has an extensive list of food options, with plenty of veggie friendly options to go with that.  However, who wants to start with the meal? Let's start with the location.

You are about 2 minutes from Anne Rice's house, and in a very hipster/indie area - far enough from the French Quarter to be away from the crowd, but not too far to walk or drive to places like Cochon or the aforementioned Ex- Anne Rice's house (she sold it). There are all sorts of cool little shops, and parking by meter on the street is simple enough (and plentiful).

One thing you must get from Juan's is the Chips, Salsa, Guac and Queso. Not only is it delicious, but it's easily large enough for 4 people. Guac was nice and fresh, queso was nice and hot and dip-friendly.  I got the flying enchiladas to go with that, which was one of the few times I didn't eat something exclusively vegetarian. I was however, provided awesome black beans and rice to go with that. 

On the vegetarian front, the sweet & green is delicious, and very large for it's size. Really, the issue here is what Eddie C mentions - there is simply way too much food to eat in a sitting. You're going to have to come here multiple times if you want to have enough room to eat their food. The red & green sauces provided at the table are predictably awesome, and should be generously applied to your personal preference with whatever you order.

I am a guy who can eat for two, and between the appetizer and the flying enchiladas, I was pretty well stuffed here.  Do come here with an empty stomach.

Had a really great dinner here! First of all, from the unimpressive front of the building, I didn't expect this place to be classy at all. The inside was surprisingly nice--it had stone walls with nice lighting and comfortable booths and chairs.

They are getting 5 stars for the food, service, and ambiance. Our waitress was very friendly, cleared plates quickly, and didn't give us any attitude when we gave her our Groupon (I hate when servers do that!). The food was excellent! Everything tasted very fresh, and the salmon and avocado, eel, and spicy tuna were all great. We also ordered the New York roll which had salmon, lobster, and avocado in it. So good! The $40 for the groupon went a long way, and on top of the free edamame we got for checking in on Yelp, I basically had to waddle home. My boyfriend and I really liked this place and will definitely be back!

FYI: It's BYO, and there's a Wine and Spirits shop only a block away, so if you forget to come prepared, no big deal.

I ordered the smoked trout Benedict with potatoes and it was the worst Benedict I have ever had.  In my lifetime I have enjoyed Benedict dishes in seven U.S. states from the west coast to the east coast and Bourbon & Branch managed to really ruin a potential good meal.  The potatoes were hard as a rock, they seemed as though they had been sitting out for three days.  The trout was over-salted, the sauce had no flavor and the bread (not English muffin) was horrible.  The eggs were under-cooked and also over-salted.

I then tried my friend's hummus and pita, also quite bad.  The pita bread was wet (with water) and the hummus was flavorless AND over-salted.  I am able to prepare better hummus and pita whilst in a coma.

My husband ordered the chicken and biscuits, the bacon n'beer mac and the branch brined wings.  ALL were over-salted.  The "food" was not edible.

Burbon and Branch is apparently for people who are too drunk to notice (or care) if they have been served proper food or not.  PATHETIC.

I run into this Dierberg's once in a while when I'm in this area eating lunch. It isn't as great as one of their bigger stores like Brentwood but it has all the basics plus a nice selection. It's very convenient that they have a UPS store in the front of the store and it's in the same shopping center as Target, World Market, and lots of restaurants. Very convenient!

I mentioned to a good friend that I didn't like Ted Drew's because of some I had at a job function. He said well it probably was a flavor you didn't like. I was like your right, I hate lemon. He said give another  a flavor a try....... and one beautiful summer night I did. ........And the vanilla custard was good. I like the atmosphere of this location during the summer .... very lively

I've been coming to Tampa regularly for over 25 years and this was the first time I ever decided to explore the downtown area.  I honestly can't explain to you why, other than I didn't think there was much to see here... but I was truly mistaken.

Tampa has created a walk along the Hillsborough River that stretches from Water Works Park (near gorgeous Ulele restaurant) all the way to Cotanchobee Fort Brooke Park 2 miles away. The entire walk is truly spectacular with so many things to see such as The Florida Museum of Photographic Arts on one end, The Florida Aquarium at the other end and Curtis Hixon Waterfront Park somewhere in the middle.

The park is home to concerts and festivals in the summer and ice skating in the winter. The park encompasses 8 acres and includes a "Great Lawn" for concerts and other performances as well as leisurely picnics, kite flying and frisbee throwing. There is a dog run, plenty of paved trails, restrooms, and two interactive fountains. One of which we watched as children and parents alike found great joy in the simplicity of water sprouting from the ground!

You can truly make a full day of it here. Just across the river via the Kennedy Blvd bridge is Plant Park, part of the grounds for the beautiful and historic University of Tampa. Directly next to the park on one side is Kiley Garden and on the other is Glazer Children's Museum. Also nearby is the must see Sacred Hearts Catholic Church. If you are interested in beautiful architecture, you won't want to miss it.

The playground @ Curtis Hixon Waterfront Park is designed to fight childhood obesity by combining video games with exercise. How cool is that!!!


FINAL THOUGHTS

Aside from being a really amazing place to just hang out, it is also responsible and environmentally friendly. The sprinkler system uses reclaimed water and LED lighting is installed throughout the park. The views are spectacular and the overall feeling you get from just being here is one of serenity and peace. If I lived in Tampa, I'd find myself here more often than not. Some might even question if I had a home at all because my visits to this park would be so frequent and lasting. LOL



2016/50

I was slightly concerned before my first visit to the Wild Hare because of some less than amazing reviews, but I have to say I had a great experience!

For lunch I wanted something lighter so I went with the grilled veggie farmer salad with the green goddess dressing and my BF had the cheeseburger. My salad was AWESOME. That damn green goddess dressing is so good and the salad was fresh and delicious! The cheeseburger was also great and I probably devoured more than half of his french fries. Oops. 

The service was ok, and the interior feels a bit divey, but overall it was a perfect lunch and just what I wanted! The pizzas look pretty amazing, so I will have to stop back in to check them out!

Can't believe I haven't reviewed this fine place after 3 or 4 times eating here in the past few months. I usually pop by for lunch with my dad and we're in and I"m back to work all in an hour. My dad and I have split a cheese crisp, and there's plenty of chips and salsa to snack on. Good strong ice tea. I wind up getting a taco salad and leave very stuffed. The last time out, I had a chimichanga (I think I just did plain beans, and what good beans they are!). Nice friendly service, hot food and quick, it's a deal and they have great lunch specials.

This place is huge.  HUGE.
Conveniently, that means they usually have a place for you, even at prime time hours.

It had been a long day, so I was eager for some tasty food.  The hostess was less than friendly, but she showed us directly to a table, so I didn't mind.  Of course, we were there for the oysters.  I decided to go all out and in addition to the dozen charbroiled oysters to start, I opted for the oyster po'boy served with fries.

The sheer volume of customers and oysters for this place is staggering.  You don't come here unless you're getting them.  Tray after tray went by, making my mouth water.  Finally it was our turn.

The were quite good.  Not the best oysters I've ever had, but I'm glad that I ate them.  The seasoning was nice, particularly the garlic flavor. If you don't like the slimy taste of raw oysters, this would be a good option since the charbroiling takes out much of the juice.

We each downed our 6 pretty quickly and then waited for our po'boys.  We should've just had more oysters.  The po'boys were a lot of bread, served with a lot of fries, and none of it had much flavor.  My fried oysters were bland and dry.  They definitely needed some sauce or dressing or something, and the cup of tartar sauce on the side just didn't cut it.

Now that I've crossed it off my list, I probably won't be back.

Been craving for their lavender flavor ice cream so we head over here after our brunch. I got the lavender and salted caramel ice cream, so delish. They only thing I have a complaint about was that our server didn't wear gloves when scooping our ice cream. When he was grabbing a spoon for my ice cream, the spoon slide from the ice cream and touch his hand that was holding my ice cream cup and he still handed to me without asking if I'm ok with it or he can replace it. At a time like this, we all should be taking precaution to stop the spread of Covid.

I came back here because I enjoyed the fresh guacamole. I saw a sign promoting the birria tacos. Keep in mind that this restaurant is not related to Mi Pueblito truck that makes awesome birria tacos.

I was greeted by super friendly lady, very welcoming. 

Birria tacos: the broth was salty, not too much flavor. I would rather wait an hour outside for the truck.

Al pastor: small pieces of pork, missing the pineapple pieces, not too much flavor. It's a little bit salty for my taste.

Forest Park was one of those places that I wished I lived closer to and could have spent more time here.  I loved going to the zoo and just wandering around the grounds on a sunny day. 

The administration of the park was also very friendly to the community.  My university was shooting a commercial for a student advertising class, and they graciously granted us permission to shoot the night scenes here.

On the second day of our family trip in New Orleans, we had plans to get to the aquarium but since it was pouring and freezing outside, we didn't want to go to any local hotspot that would have us waiting outside for too long. Since I came to New Orleans before, I knew that Drago's is a fairly large restaurant that would probably be able to seat a party of 7 fairly quickly. So we hopped in the taxi and were seated almost immediately. It was fun to see all the waiters wearing Saints jerseys on gameday as the diners were completely focused on the game around the bar. The po-boys were big enough that in retrospect I would want to share a plate with someone. The shrimp alfredo was pretty good too. 

Previously, we tried the chargrilled and raw oysters here and they weren't as good as Acme Oyster House but they were fine. Come here for convenience.

DO NOT COME HERE!  Go to the original Dragos!

"These are not the Oysters you're looking for."

...  It really might be worth the drive to Metarie!  I'm a big big fan of the original Dragos. Their oysters can not be beat. 

HOWEVER the quality that is the original has not translated to the location in the Hilton. 

At least for the char grilled oysters. Which is 99% of why you'd come here. 

That and the ambiance feels like you're in the Harrahs casino crossed with a cafeteria. Big and sterile. 

#disappointed

Located in St. Louis on historic Route 66 Ted Drewes has been selling frozen custard (and occasionally Christmas Trees) since 1929. Frozen custard is mixture of butterfat and egg yolks.  It's very smooth and creamy.  I love Ted Drewes andI have never been disappointed by anything I have ordered there.  I visit the Chippewa location every time I visit St. Louis no matter the time of year (as long as they're open) or what the temperature is outside.  The staff is always friendly and helpful.  Once I wanted to bring some frozen custard home with me to California and they packed my order in dry ice so it would fit on a small cooler I could pack in my suite case.  They did such a good job of it that it made it home completely in tact. On my most recent visit on 12/11/2013 it was 21Âº outside and there was still of a line of people waiting to purchase there frozen custard.  You a place that serves ice cold desert is popular when people line up sub freezing temperatures to enjoy it.  If you never tried frozen custard you should where ever you can get it.  If you're in St. Louis you should expend any effort necessary to get yourself to Ted Drewes.

This was my first Indo experience but it certainly won't be my last. I picked up a curbside order about ten days ago and I have thought about the Khao Soi every day since. I ordered the Palm Sugar Ribs and the Short Rib Khao Soi. When I got home and unpacked everything it smelled and looked perfect. They packed the soup for travel. The broth in one container, the crispy noodles in a container, and the protein, noodles, and veg in another container. I assembled it in a large bowl. The short rib was tasty and very tender. I prefer this to chicken in the dish. The noodles were well cooked but still had a nice chew. The red onions were fresh. There was a nice briny flavor from the pickled cabbage. Then there was the broth. It's creamy, spicy, bright and acidic from the lime, and so so good. You should sell it by the gallon. I'd buy it! The Palm Sugar Ribs were really good too. Tender, sweet, and a little sticky. I had to save them for another meal though. I totally over ordered. Dude, can I give you hug? I eat out a lot and it takes a lot for me to get this worked up. I'll be back and I'll be ordering the Khao Soi!
Great food, specular view but the service was not that impressive. Definitely worth checking out if you're in Santa Barbara. The ribeye with seared foie gras was my favorite!

I am enjoying the food for years maybe 30 years. I always went there late night after playing ice hockey. Go over there give it a try to place is been redone it looks really nice. I remember back when they had karaoke it was really fun I wish they'd bring that back.

It's my opinion that you can really tell the quality of a diner by its lunch and dinner offerings, not breakfast.  Breakfast is difficult (though not impossible) to screw up.  My friend and I came late one Saturday night, around 12:30 am.  The hostess and waitress were cheerful and attentive.  The facilities are updated and clean.

Just remarkable.  I can't believe I haven't written a review yet for one of my favorite locations in all of St. Louis: Ted Drewes Frozen Custard!

All I can do is echo some of the other reviewers:

1. The "All Shook Up" concrete is the best (it's banana and Reese's cup).  Heath or Hawaiian-flavored concretes are also great.

2. This place sells CHRISTMAS TREES in December.  Great service and great value (except for the whoppingly-expensive 'Dottie Trees').

3. Ted's is closed from about January 15 - February 15.

4. Avoid it here after Cardinals games!  Alternatively, come after Cards games for the real experience!

5. They sell gift cards!

6. They close when they're out of customers, more or less.  We showed up at 12:15a the other night and barely made it in, to give you an idea.

7. Don't be fazed by long lines.  Those many counters make for a well-oiled MACHINE.

Bottom line is, though, if you haven't been to Ted's, it's high time.
The Mex'orean fried chicken, sangria roja, guacamole, and fish tacos made my tummy very happy! Love this place

I really like this neighborhood grocery store. Every time we stay in New Orleans, I stock up on the Rouses coffee. Great stuff. Be sure to get a loaf of the fresh french bread. The staff is very friendly.

Made a reservation  here for my boyfriend's birthday dinner since I had heard such good things about the restaurant from others. 

Ambiance is very, very homey and comfortable. Both the indoor and outdoor decor is deliberate and thoughtful in its play on a classic Italian eating place. The outdoor sunroof and flowers were especially pleasing to the eye. 

We started with the wild mushroom arancini, which was placed in a truffle oil base. This was by far our favorite dish of the night. The outsides were perfectly crisp and firm, while the inside was decadently gooey and cheesy. The bright sharp cheese with the mushrooms paired extremely well with the savory pervasive flavor of the truffle oil. 

The spaghetti and meatballs were sadly a miss for me- the meatballs had a strong taste ofblack licorice and the tomato sauce was extremely tangy. We had to specially request grated cheese, which mildly improved the dish. 

The gnocchi unfortunately followed suit. The truffle oil strong armed all the vegetables and gnocchi pieces into unwanted submission. 

Overall, even though the decor is highly appealing, our food was slightly disappointing as a whole.

Couldn't find alcohol in this area, went to rite aid, wawa and 7-11. This is the only place I'm aware of near Logan curio that sells beer. Also sells fresh fruits if u want to grab some for your hotel room etc

I was pleasantly surprised with this little eatery on University!  Stopped in a little before the lunch rush and found myself first in line for ordering.  I had the Shahi Kofta while the wife had the chicken Biryani.  Both were well made and quite delicious.  Both were spiced to "medium", which was adequate for a lunch.  Quite spicy but not over the top by any means.  Truly a delicious option if looking for some Indian food near campus.  
Decor certainly felt Indian more than like an American restaurant that serves Indian.  By this I mean it felt like somewhere you might find along a street in Delhi (think how a pizza parlor in NYC feels if you know what I mean).  Ballywood on the tv, little booths done in a decidedly fun way, ... .  Still, it appeared that most of the customers came to order and pickup.  Glad I spent the time eating there, watching the wonderful tv show.  Just fun!
The only real downside, and frankly, it didn't bother me in the slightest, was that it took a bit of time for the food to come out.  Whatever, I'm willing to wait if the food is excellent.  And excellent it was!

I rolled in to Misconduct around 6 PM on Valentine's Day, dying for a nice place to sit and sip a glass of wine before heading off to the Avenue of the Arts for a show. Since it was V-Day, we had been wandering for a while and just wanted to find somewhere with a seat and a decent happy hour. After using Yelp and a variety of happy hour apps to no avail (damn you, Valentine's Day!), we were waiting for a stoplight and I happened to look to my right and saw this bar's sign. I convinced the boyfriend to go in because I had recent;y heard about this place, and we were encouraged by the half off happy hour that continued until 7 PM. To be honest, I wish that we could have stayed longer.

I loved the atmosphere inside the bar. It was completely nautical-themed, with sailcloth panels in the ceiling and dark wood reminiscent of the deck of a ship. We even had to climb up a small set of steep steps, which made me feel even more like I was on a ship. The bartender was friendly and joked around with us while he checked our IDs-- a little friendliness goes a long way-- and he proved to be helpful in specifying what was included in the happy hour (i.e., what wine was on special). In addition to the bartender being friendly, I also felt at home with the clientele (who were all a little older than I). A news show was on and the sound was muted, so I asked the couple next to us what was going on and that morphed into a pleasant conversation for a few minutes.

After the friendly and inviting welcome of what could be a forbidding establishment, I am excited to return to Misconduct at some point, perhaps to try some of the food (which looked really tasty). Plus, the bathrooms are quite nice (private rooms and an ample amount of them); it's hard to find good bar bathrooms.

Culver's is what it is.   Kind of the red-headed step/lovechild of a fast food burger joint and an ice cream shoppe.   If you're really craving a quick burger, this is not the first place that would come to mind.   If you're looking for ice cream (excuse me....custard), this is not the first place that would come to mind.   However, if you're looking for a place that offers fast food burgers and custard, then this is one of the few places that can do it.   Average burgers and average custard.

This isn't a criticism of this particular location, but of all Culver's in general...$1.20 extra for nuts on a sundae, but the candy toppings are free?

Due to the prime location right off 465 on 67/Kentucky Avenue, it's usually pretty busy.

FUN FUN FUN!!!!!!!!!

They picked us up in front of our hotel. The bus ride was amusing because the driver sounded like Chris Rock and would narrate where we would drive through- swamp areas, hunting places, marshes, a bridge on the hwy that led to nowhere, abandoned communities, and an empty Six Flags affected by Katrina- this was the sad part of our trip. Once we got to the Cajun Encounters location we paid for our tour (it's $50 so be prepared to spend $$$ to see a swamp) and waited for our color wrist band to be called out. 

The tour itself is serene, relaxing, and a totally different part of New Orleans than the French Quarter. You'll see lots of trees, turtles, a few gators, and we saw a family of raccoons. They take you to the open parts of the river with houses lining the shore, some were destroyed from Katrina and left in dilapidated conditions...another sad part of the trip. They also lead you into the narrow parts of the swamp where you can reach out and touch the trees (amazing!!). Our tour guide was super friendly and funny. The best part of this tour was to see how friendly the people were and how high their spirits were even though something as devastating as Katrina affected them all. If you're not into nature, though, I don't recommend this tour for you. It's a whole lot of talking, trees, swamp, and some animals.

After reading good things about the lunch pasta bar, we decided to try it out for dinner. 

Our table of 4 started with the toasted ravioli and the calamari. Nothing special. I am glad I tried the toasted ravioli but I don't know that I would try it again...it didn't live up to my expectation based on what I've heard.

I had the prosciutto wrapped chicken roasted garlic mashed potatoes and asparagus. The portions were okay, I would have preferred more asparagus...you get 5-6 skinny stalks. My sister ordered the smoked chicken and penne, an entree I considered but am glad I didn't...the garlic cream sauce was very thick and didn't look appealing to me (it also didn't reheat well as leftovers, the sauce separated and looked even less appealing). My husband ordered the penne pomodoro, it was good...nothing special. 

We shared 2 apple tarts for dessert. They were served under a scoop of cinnamon or caramel flavored ice cream, we agreed it was a nice twist from plain vanilla or vanilla bean. The common agreement was the tart didn't have much apple in it. It was a flat tart with apple slivers. 

Overall, the food was okay...but nothing special, I felt it was a little over priced for what you got and the overall taste.

One of the best things about a national chain being on one of the more popular shopping areas with high end shops and restaurants all around, the prices (from what I can see) are the same as all of the other locations, which is pretty darn awesome. You can find all of the same services and amenities at this location that you can at any other location in the city. They do have a nice selection of seasonal items. The restrooms were neat, clean and well stocked. Service was quick. The location is a bit far from where I normally hang out, but if I am in the area and need something, it is easy in and out. They do have their own parking lot, which is a plus in this area.

Delicious burgers, excellent customer service, but the worst dine in environment of any place I've ever encountered in my life! It is entirely TOO smoky in there! There's ZERO ventilation, so you see clouds (thick haze and a strong aroma) when you enter the restaurant  and can glide on their floor - in rubber soles! It felt more toxic than the days of dining in a restaurant filled with cigarette smoke if you're a non-smoker. I asked a worker (and so did others if they burned something). We were told it's a known vent issue. In the 5-6 minutes that I waited for my order, my eyes watered and I left smelling like I had a shift as a member of the kitchen staff. To make matters worse, there are no windows to open nor fans in the dining areas. IMO, it's was also odd that there's a lockbox on the front door of the restaurant. Another first. 

As for the food, I ordered a smoke burger (the air quality fit its name) , fries and a cran citrus punch.  All 5/5 with the cran citrus punch being a tart lovers dream. They seriously struck gold with that one. The crinkle fries were hot, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The chopped cherry peppers on the burger made for a great combination. I'd definitely order them all again. 

In sum, delicious offerings - strong fry & juice game, reasonable pricing and great service, Poor ventilation. It's only a matter of time before the health department shuts this location down or someone sues them over it. They've likely gotten away with it attached to the only upscale shopping mall (Louis Vuitton, Sak's Fifth, etc) in Nola because their entrance is separate, meaning you cannot enter from the mall. All I want for the city's Shake Shack location in 2022 is clean air so I can actually dine in!

I was staying in the French Quarter and Killer Poboys was my first meal in New Orleans. Prices were reasonable and the pork belly po boy I got was pretty good too ($12). I appreciated the unique po boys they offered since every other restaurant in the area seems to only have fried seafood versions. Who would've thought I'd end up having one that had pork belly in it! I highly recommend it if you're a fan of pork belly. The cabbage slaw in the po boy goes well with it too.

This particular location is a bit odd since it's located in the back of a bar (Erin Rose) so you probably have to be 21+. It's also very small so there's not much seating. However, they've recently opened another location in the French Quarter that is a standalone spot so you may want to go there if you plan to dine-in (or if you're not 21 yet lol). Overall, I enjoyed their creative takes on po boys and would return if I'm ever in New Orleans again.

The dim sum here is rather delicious. And while I've only ever ordered dim sum here, I do totally recommend it for that. So many wonderful dishes! It's hard not to over order when out for dim sum in general, but this place is good. The menu is varied but really quite good.

I came here on a recommendation of a friend and I'm not disappointed.

I must have passed this place a bunch of times but Lancaster Ave is so busy that it's hard to take in the scenery.

The inside looks like an old diner but cutely decorated.   The bathroom needed remodeling or a good paint job.

The restaurant is small but cozy and the free parking around back is a plus. 

The service was top notch. One waiter but he was on top of everything.  My water glass was never empty.

Hubby loves that there was a pot of hot tea for us at the table.

I had the dinner special which was about $11 and included egg drop soup (yum), pepper steak, brown rice, eggroll and a desert.   It was really tasty and the portions were huge.   I have enough for lunch tomorrow.

We also had veggie dumpling as an appetizer. .  It was ok to me but it was my first time eating them.  Hubby and friend loved it so it must be good.

Hubby had the house fried rice (yum) and the general zao's chicken (double yum).

Friend had chicken and broccoli with sauce on the side (she obviously loved it).

Everything was great, huge portions and reasonably priced.  We both took home plenty for tomorrow.

I will definitely be back.

Yup! This was as good as I expected it to be. I've been wanting to try the pizzas here as I've seen so many great reviews and they were also recently mentioned as one of the top ranking pizza spots in the country. Their online ordering system was easy to navigate and I pulled up for the best curbside pick up experience I've had yet. On time, friendly, and they were very welcoming and grateful for my business. And the pizzas were literally brought to my window! 

Now on to the food... we ordered two pizzas, a house salad and a giant cookie. The pizzas were much larger and more filling than I expected - a welcomed surprise. The pies are really adequate for 2 hungry people - maybe even 3 if you want a lighter meal. The crust is pretty darn delicious. A dense but chewy center and a wonderfully light and crisp but still chewy in the best ways crust. Pretty much pizza perfection. We went with a classic pepperoni to try them on for size and the cherry picker which was loaded with fresh cherry tomatoes and burrata cheese. OMG yummm. That cherry picker was so freaking good that I couldn't stop eating it and didn't even get to the pepperoni! I added some of my own Calabrian chili's which in my opinion made it even that much more delicious (note to the restaurant: I seriously recommend making that a topping option for this pizza). The salad was also fantastic! And the citrus vinaigrette was some kind of wonderful voodoo sauce. My only gripe was that the bacon i added to the salad was less cooked than I prefer. 

Overall this was an excellent meal and we have leftovers for lunch tomorrow. Fully worth the gluten binge! The price is high but the ingredients are top notch and the pizza is truly artisan. Enjoy!

As a review of all the Ritz theaters: this is the only place where you'll have quiet, decent audience members, la-z-boy-esce chairs and more to choose from at the concessions stand that just popcorn and M&Ms (think Jones soda and brownies). Also, instead of watching The Twenty you'll get to see local art and here classic jazz.

But tell me why are there three Ritzes within walking distance of each other? Can't Mr. Ritz just buy one building?

Ordered Dragos carryout to try their famous oysters. The oysters were just OK, but I am not one who enjoys oysters. They were flavored heavy with lots of salt, this could be from all of the butter and cheese on the oysters.  We also ordered the shrimp and corn chowder, the flavor was great but they were very skimpy about the shrimp quantity in our soup. We would have enjoyed it more had there been more shrimp.

Overall I don't see myself going back, there are many options in New Orleans to dine, so unfortunately they wouldn't be my pick.

We don't have any Mexican food place near us... this would be the closest. Super excited it finally opened. 

What can I say... it's chipotle. This is a well know fast food Mexican chain. The food is always consistent here and the service is quick and friendly. Parking can be a challenge when the shopping center gets full. 

The lobby here is a bit smaller than other locations I have been to, but it super clean and the windows allow a ton of light. They also have an outside sitting area to enjoy during the warmer months. 

Since I'm vegan I Always Get the same thing. "Bowl" - white rice, black beans, spicy sauce , little lettuce and double quac! Then I get a Side of chips to make it like nachos. 

This is a quick and easy place to get Your Mexican fix!

Pros: Good food.

Cons: Inexcusably bad service.

We had friends in from out of town for one night and wanted to show them that Philly is a great place to be.  They certainly didn't get that impression from Little Nona.

I guess it was a slow night because the restaurant was nearly empty when we ate here.  The ratio of customers to staff was nearly one to one.  Still, we had to ask for water refills four times throughout the meal.  They never brought an appetizer.  They never brought crab utensils for three of us who ordered crabs.  Entrees arrived 15 minutes apart.  We had to interact with five different waitstaff because nobody ever stopped by more than once to wait on us.  It was really hard to have conversation and a relaxed dining experience when you are constantly in need of something and nobody is waiting on you to help.

The food was good, particularly the ripe heirloom tomatoes, but not good enough to redeem itself from the horrible service.  They eventually brought the appetizer during our meal and comped us for it as they knew they were really not keeping it together.  A free late appetizer was not enough to make up for the debacle of this meal.

I am so glad we tried this restaurant.

We arrived before 7pm and had our choice of tables.  If you arrive after 8, you might not be so lucky.

To start, we shared the fried green tomatoes.  I found the lemon dressing a little overpowering, and the ham wasn't crispy.  

For our entrees, my husband had the pork two ways.  He thought it was pretty good, although he had a hard time finding the pork belly in the hash.  I had the fried chicken.  They serve a half a chicken for $13.  What a deal!  The french fries were light and crispy.  The hush puppies were a tad dry.  The chicken was fragrant, piping hot, and perfectly crispy without being oily.  It was served with honey mustard, but the staff also offered ketchup, and then Mrs. Moran suggested pepper vinegar, which she brought out herself.

They make their own ice cream, and it is fantastic.  Also, if you have reason to try their basil chantilly cream, do yourself the favor.  

The wine list is very moderately priced and very decent for this kind of restaurant. The beer list is great.

All in all, this is a great place, and I'm glad that it's in my neighborhood.

I'm staying 5 minutes away at the Hilton and wanted to see Jojo Rabbit so I walked over there. It's a cute, small theater. Prices for tickets are very reasonable. It's a no thrills theater inside which I don't mind. Went on a Thursday night for a 6pm show and it was empty. Maybe 8 people including myself. Would return if im back in town.

It's a nice diner that I go to with my grandparents every Sunday after church!  I'm a fan of the omelettes, but I've had better breakfast potatoes.  The waffles are sweet and fluffy and the French toast comes in some really tasty flavors as well.  The wait staff is usually very friendly and we always like having Maggie as our waitress.  I would recommend it for a quick bite to have breakfast or brunch!

The Gumbo Shop definitely hits the spot!

Ordering the seafood and okra gumbo and a honeydew daiquiri, I was able to check off 2 items on my "must try in NOLA" list. The gumbo was everything I hoped it would be! Savoury and flavourful, hearty servings of seafood, veggies and rice came with every spoonful.

Conveniently, our daiquiris came in to go cups so we were able to enjoy them even after we left our nice lunch in the courtyard.

Their website notes that they're award winning, and I don't doubt that at all based on the great experience we had.

Haven't been to jimmy johns in a few years. It really did hit the spot. The service was nice and helpful. My sandwich was tasty. I had the number 8 or 9 w roast beef and ham. I added avocado spread which is .75 cents more. If u get a beach club, it is included already but w turkey. This was a good convenient sandwich to bring to the beach.

Anyone that lives in St. Louis is well aware of Ted Drew's. Just as a local is familiar with fried ravioli, this is a staple to the St. Louis history. When you drive up, anytime of they day when they are open you fill find a crowd of people standing around, in line and eating ice cream. 

Don't let the crown make you nervous. Just go get in one of 15 lines and you will have your frozen custard in no time. They staff heavy and they move quickly. 

This is up there with an almost "Must Do" when in St. Louis so don't pass it up.

Oh my chocolate heaven! This custard is the best I've ever had! I have never experienced a soft serve custard before and it just doesn't disappoint on any level.

Ask for a kids cone! It's super cheap and almost the same size as a small :)

I haven't gotten to try anything else because I just keep getting my chocolate heaven.

You HAVE to come here, I promise you will come back again, and again, and again!!

I visit Reno quite frequently and shop here often when I do. I do not always review grocery stores because, well, they are stores. But I had an awesome experience here and want to share it.

Save Mart has home-made multi-colored tortilla chips that are just awesome. I love them and buy them quite often. So I walk in and they are out. My daughter told me they were not making them anymore. So I asked and was told they were in the chip aisle (no). I asked someone else and was told they are in the deli (no). I asked someone else who was stocking shelves. She said they were in the deli. I told her that I couldn't find them there.

This woman (Meredith) put down what she was doing and went back behind the deli counter and asked the person working about the chips. She said that they were in the kitchen waiting to be bagged, fresh. So Meredith comes to the counter and grabs a hair net and some gloves, and goes back into the kitchen and bags up my three bags of chips, that complete the menu for our Christmas Soiree. 

The Chips are awesome and the service this time was awesome. Many times I have heard that places are "out" of things, when they probably are not willing to go the extra mile for the customer.

I always get good service here, but this time was particularly great. Thank you, Meredith.

Given the exceptional experience I had the other CafÃ© Beignet location, I had to check this place out too.  The beignets here seem to not taste as great as the other location and it lacks the cozy cafÃ© feel.  Yes, they're still made to order, but it wasn't as perfect as their other location.  Their seating is mostly outside and that can be a turn off when the weather isn't nice.  The service was slow, yet the beignets were still better than the ones at CafÃ© DuMonde.

Oh, Ted Drewes. This is one of those rare local food obsessions that I feel is actually worth the hype. Having lived in St. Louis for 10+ years, I actually haven't been as frequently as you might think, but every time I go, I love it. The custard is absolute silk, probably the best I've ever had, and their sundaes are hard to resist. I usually go with a Fox Treat or a Cardinal Sin - the tart berries in each are awfully good with the vanilla custard. Plus great butterscotch malts, and they actually know to ask if you want it thin enough to drink (handy for yours truly, driving and thus not able to work a spoon).

I've actually been back more frequently as I drive through the city on vacations than I probably did when I was living here...If you're on your way through, especially if you're on I-44, you owe it to yourself to stop. Just be aware that this place can have some pretty amazing lines. Although, on my last visit, I did discover that going during the middle of Easter dinner was a good option to avoid the rush.

I order takeout from here somewhat regularly, and they always get the order right.  In NOLA, this doesn't always happen.  So they are already on my good side for that.  I've also eaten in here a few times, and the service is always great.  

They have some yummy appetizers.  My two favorites are the duck empanadas and the asian almond shrimp.  During seafood season they have asian sesame oysters-AWESOME.  

I often order a half rack of thai ribs, which is more than enough for one person and comes with two sides.  For $14.  Like everyone has already said, the corn grits are like so effing good.  A while back, Zea posted a recipe for them online which contained something like 4 sticks of butter in one batch.  Why it's hard to live in Louisiana...

I've gotten the tuna steak, also delicious.  The only thing I've had here that I haven't enjoyed was the basil trout.  It was far too salty.  Another Yelper hit the nail on the head: Zea serves a wide range of food ranging from forgettable to quite good.  And everything is reasonably priced.

I really am a fan. Their prices are really cheaper than other places, but be on the prowl for what you are lookig for in terms of prices. Also note season items such as flu medicine in the winter is cheaper than the other bigger stores. Always came here to stock up on stuffs for rental properties and walked out 100's of dollars cheaper than the again the larger department stores. Even their food prices are cheaper in snacks and drinks and soups and spices. 

This particular store has become even better since the first time I came. It is cleaner, the people there are nicer and the furniture has it's own area now. If you don't find what you are looking for, next door has another home good place. 

There are cold goods in freezers and lots of differen foods from different countries. It is an adventure every time one goes. We find lots of unique items randomly, and if you go often, your chances of finding them increase...mathematically speaking. After the holidays,  specials go way down to 90 percent. Have a a ball shopping.

I would give 1200 Chophouse 4.5 actual stars but I rounded up because I'm a "glass half-full" type of girl. The restaurant itself is small and therefore can get loud and crammed--not an issue for me but can be for some. 

On my two visits to 1200 Chophouse on a weeknight I have been pleasantly thrilled with the quality of food, the service, as well as the pacing of the meal. 1200 Chophouse is located amongst hotels, stores, and restaurants on Gulf Drive of St. Pete Beach (Intercoastal side). There is a parking lot on the premises with parking around the side and back of the restaurant.

1200 Chophouse is part of the same ownership and management company as Madfish (which I have not visited). It was created out of a renovated 1940s house and features a 1200-degree searing grill. The meat cuts are aged in-house according to their website. 

The restaurant does not accept reservations and opens at 5pm sharp. This was initially an issue for an older (95 year old) dining companion, however if you arrive before or at 5 there will be a table for you despite the others who wait for the restaurant to open. I was shocked on my visits at the size of two (fairly) large parties who were waiting outside prior to the restaurant opening and who got in just after it opened. I have observed that it gets pretty busy even early on and I think that is an indicator that people enjoy the food and, as I have spoken to other diners to confirm, come back. 

An semi-open kitchen allows you so see the chefs and cooks hustling to prepare the food. Because of this it can be a loud so if you are looking to dine with people who prefer a quieter atmosphere (background noise doesn't bother me) you might want to choose to dine elsewhere. They have a great variety of wine and also serve beer for those of the drinking class (no liquor). 

1200 Chophouse serves up meat and (limited) seafood and does it well. My suggestion if it's something that intrigues you, order the special of the day. I went that way on my first visit with the veal chop with bacon braised brussel sprouts and I wasn't disappointed. From my experience all cuts of meat have been cooked as asked/preferred. My usual dining companion swears by the ribeye. The Tomahawk ribeye is enormous and a spectacle and leaves a nice bone for you to take to your favorite canine. 

You can customize any steak with an additional preparation/sauce ($4) and each entree comes with a nice salad of mixed greens, cheese, dried cranberries and a nice (opaque) balsamic vinaigrette to start. My experience is that the salad is a bit overdressed and to ask for it on the side. Not a huge salad dressing lover myself, I did enjoy the salad dressing. Fresh bread is brought to the table with a honey butter accompaniment. 

One my most recent my dining companions and I had the bruschetta which was flavorful and fresh tasting. A generous portion and thinly cut bread didn't fill me up enough to not enjoy my main course. 

I have also tried the sea bass and I loved the preparation other than the fact I found it to be a bit salty. The only other seafood dish I saw on the menu were mussels as an appetizer so if you are a non-meat eater be conscious of this. 

If you are in the area or want to check out a unique steakhouse then this is your place for a memorable meal. The prices for the entrees can be on the higher end but as the saying goes, "you get what you pay for". Give it a try and let me know how you like it. :)

I went to this Sonic yesterday at the drive-up window. They have a wide selection of two items and drinks it's hard to choose from. So I decided to get a strawberry banana milkshake and tater tots. The person that took my order didn't understand what I was saying I wanted the milkshake extra thick so it wouldn't melt so fast and I wanted hot tater tots. So he kept asking me the same thing over and over I said forget it waited patiently for my items to come out to me. When my items came out my milkshake was watering the tater tots was high but I asked him again I wanted my milkshake thick. He told me because it was so hot out here that the machines was melting the ice cream fast which didn't make sense but I said okay but I don't want this milkshake. He said okay I will take it back and when he came back my milkshake was thick but my tater tots was cold. I love Sonic but I wish they had one near me it would be great for the kids and adults to drive up or just to hang out for some great snacks. And the happy hour is awesome and also the late half price after 8 p.m.

We had a wonderful time at the Tampa Bay Brewing Company. We had landed in Tampa in the late morning on a Friday for a weekend wedding. The wedding was in the Tarpon Springs area and I noticed that this location was toward the direction of Tarpon Springs. I believe that the other location was closer to downtown Tammpa which I would expect to be more crowded. We got there about 12PM or so on a Friday afternoon. The place was fairly empty, but by the time we were leaving, an hour or so later, there were people waiting for tables. We were seated prompted in a booth. The waitress was as nice as could be and thoroughly explained everything to us. We settled on the crabcakes, cider wings, pizza and a flight of beer. The Cider Wings were really good. The pizza was also great as you can see a brick ovn pizza toward the back of the seating area going to work. The crabcakes were a bit disappointing though. I had a flight of beer with 4 ounce pours ranging from $1.50-$2.00 each. I believe My flight was about $7, which included some higher ABV beers. I also noticed that though its a "brewery". it is more like a grill vibe so feel free to bring the kids. There were a good variety of people there including children and older folks as well. Food was good, beer selection was great and very reasonable, and the staff was excellent. I would highly recommend this to anyone in the area. I am not sure if they have a Happy Hour, but that might be a bonus incentive to visit.

Cafe Beignet is a "safe space" on Bourbon Street.  An island to itself right off the Bourbon Street insanity.  This is more of an older adult spot to listen to jazz and enjoy a drink.  Of course you do see kids (during the day) and younger adults as well, but its not a "party" bar.  

Cafe Beignet has live music going most of the day and night.  Place starts shutting down around midnight so not a place to keep partying.  The live music is pretty good.  It's a good place to grab a drink (adult of coffee), listen to some music, and appreciate the open air surroundings of the place.

Just a few quick tips
-  Bring cash with you.  They take cards but the band will expect tips and will walk around with a bucket to collect it.
-  They shut down the upper level sometime around 9ish.  This is important because this also eliminates the upper level restrooms.  It leaves you with a single unisex restroom (1 person at a time) to use later at night.  Lines can get long to the use the restroom at this time.  
- If you need cash, they have an ATM.  Of course you are going to get jacked on the fee.

I had been wanting to try The BAO for a long time and I finally got to last Thursday! We walked in at around 8pm. There were 2 others tables, not super busy. 

What I ordered: I started off with the Thai soup and it was amazing! It was a coconut milk-based soup and it had spices with green onion, mushroom, and tofu that balanced it out perfectly. We also got the crab avocado dip with lotus chips. The ingredients were very fresh. Then we got the shrimp starter. (I can't remember the exact name.) It was friend shrimp with crunchy noodles wrapped around the outside served in a spicy buttermilk sauce. It was very good as well! Then we finished it off with the bao dessert. It tasted like a funnel cake with ice cream.l! My favorite thing was the soup, but everything was amazing

These are rather small portions, but the food is worth it! I would love to go back sometime to try a bao!

This place always has a line or people in the store. I went one time and decided on their White Chocolate Red Berry Crisp ice cream and I haven't had it since. I have been DYING for this flavor to come back.
But every now and then, I will come anyways because it is very good. The store is located uptown with street parking. Warning, the parking lot across the street has patrol watching you so don't get a ticket or boot. 
They only take cash so there are two Chase banks and a drug store across the street for you to get cash out if you don't have any. 

I decided to go with a scoop of the Pear & Balsamic Caramel which was a unique taste but I liked it alot. I tried the Earl Tea flavor was good too. 

They let you taste but don't get too feisty with the taste tests. One scoop is plenty for me!

- unbelievably affordable
- favorite of the locals
- always open
- fast friendly service

Fine place for a meal on a business trip to Indianapolis. Ate at the bar. guacamole appetizer was fresh and came with salsa/chips. The pastor tacos were good. The beer selection had several local options.

I still remember when I dined at Blue Hill in NYC with my family for my birthday. I had specifically requested that restaurant because it was at the forefront of the whole 'farm-to-table' concept, which was relatively new at the time. It was one of the best meals we had had in NYC, so simple and yet the flavors were remarkable. When I heard about The Farm and Fisherman opening up where Paul used to be, and more importantly that the chef was of Blue Hill fame, I really really REALLY wanted to try them out asap.

I mentioned it only once to my bf, and when my birthday approached he announced that dinner reservations were already taken care of and 'it was a surprise.' I love surprises, but I was a little wary - not that he chose a bad place, but I assumed it wasn't The Farm and Fisherman because my own little sleuthing had turned up zero available reservation times there - until 3 weeks later. Imagine my ecstatic surprise when we arrived there.

The interior has been transformed since Paul, and the warm, intimate vibe is perfect for the space. It's very small, which is one reason reservations are hard to get, and perhaps a bit close quarters but the food makes you forget about anything else. And since it's BYO, everyone arrives with their drinks and proceeds to enjoy them as much as they do the food.

It was a tough call, but we started off with their Kirby Cucumber Soup (Buttermilk, sour gherkins, chocolate mint), which was creamy and refreshing, and the Smoked Rainbow Trout (Bacon, pea puree, spicy cress, bachelor's buttons), a dish that we agreed was the best smoked trout we'd ever had (yep, better than Telepan). I'm not a big lamb eater, but my bf really wanted to try the entrÃ©e because it was seasonal and I have to say that the Braised Lamb Shoulder (New potatoes, Poblano pepper, merguez), had wonderful complementary tastes that built in flavor with each bite. I personally preferred two 'second courses' for my entrÃ©e and ordered the Stuffed Quail (Smoked zucchini, apricots, pistachios) and Poached Jennings Farm Egg (Peas, hazelnuts, patty pan squash, pancetta, morels). The quail was fantastic - it's only half of one, but the apricots it's stuffed add a nice sweet-tart flavor to the game hen. My bf initially questioned my choice with the egg, but one bite shut him up. It's the best dish we ordered, and such a wonderful surprise. The poached egg sits in a semi-stew of fresh peas (seriously, the freshest I've ever had EVER), patty pan squash chunks, morels, roasted hazelnuts and the lingering smokiness of pancetta. It's a party on the plate AND in your mouth - the combination of colors, flavors and textures created an absolutely unforgettable dish. I couldn't have asked for more - and almost couldn't finish it! We had a lot of food, so unfortunately dessert was out of the question, but I really didn't care. It was the best dinner I have had all year, and such a perfect way to celebrate my birthday.

I'm slightly obsessed with Henley. After two experiences I am thrilled to give them full stars!! I'm going to focus most of the review on a standard experience, which was a busy Friday night where we had dinner at the bar. They were booked up but we were able to get two seats and the bartenders were extremely busy and seemed short staffed. But we weren't in a hurry so it didn't impact our experience much. We ordered some cocktails which were delightful; the Long Weekend which was a nice vodka cocktail with prosecco and fancy things I can't describe. It was refreshing and delicious. My BF had the Old Belle which was very delicious and more booze heavy; a very nice cocktail. Not gonna lie we had a bit of a struggle ordering because it was so busy, but we ordered the trailer baby crackers and duck hand pies to start. Both appetizers were delicious, but the crackers were fantastic; pimento cheese, gulf crab, and celery which melded together on your palate in a perfect bite. We were so close to ordering a second helping of them they were so good. For entrees we had the squid ink gemelli and skirt steak. The gemelli had shrimp and was pretty salty, but in a good, "straight from the sea" kind of way. The steak was great too and perfectly cooked. We ordered a second round of cocktails and both liked our first ones better. I had the Last Years Crop which was made very well, but it was a mezcal drink which isn't my favorite, but if you are a fan should definitely order it! 
My other visit was a very special one-of-a-kind experience at Henley going to the Rabbit Hole, which is a private, table of 4 in the kitchen with a specially prepared multi-course chef's tasting menu with the optional drink pairings. It's a unique, memorable experience and worth the cost. It is pricey though, so come for a special occasion or prepared to spend some $$. You should definitely come to Henley for a fantastic meal!!

So I have been here a handful of times in the last couple of years. I normally do not enjoy chain restaurants, but I feel that they do this one well. It is basically roasted chicken Portuguese style, so if you don't like that then you should probably skip it. I have a number of things but generally I go with the 1/4 Chicken (Breast) with two sides. Usually it has been tasty. Once in a while I find that the chicken is pretty skimpy. The sides are really good. I enjoy the potato wedges and the salads. One thing I don't like is the amount they charge for fancier sides - for example, 7 dollars for corn on the cob I think is a little much.  They also have family packs that are similar to the ones you find at KFC, but much fresher and healthier. All and all a good experience.

Still a super solid place to meet friends.

Eight moms with babies under the age of one, you wouldn't think hey they should go to TBBC for lunch would you? Well, you'd be wrong because we did and it was great. 

Lunch on a Thursday is pretty light so our huge number of strollers didn't get in anyone's way. Especially since it was cool out so we were able to sit outside! They have umbrellas for each of their tables which is great for blocking the sun.

Our server was super courteous about serving eight moms with eight children. We were all over the map with our dietary restrictions, no dairy, soy, eggs, or nuts right here, and it was all handled with grace. To be on the safe side I got hummus with just vegetables. They just didn't add the soybean oil which normally goes on top.

The hummus was good, nothing fantastic, but it is hummus so I'm not going to judge a place mainly for the hummus. This update is to add that this is a super family friendly place during the day. 

Honestly, once my baby is older and I can eat and drink with abandon, this is going to be our new go to place.

This was the most bizarre delivery experience I had ever had.  They forgot to add tax and the guy refused to use a calculator and did it in his head, which is fine - but I also like to see my charges on a receipt which they do not provide.  I felt like he snapped at me when I offered to use my phone calculator.  

The chicken strips were pretty good.  The sauces were mediocre.  I couldn't taste the lime in the chipotle lime may and the curry was also just all right.  I really cannot describe them, but I wasn't crazy about them.  It's not really worth the 50 cents each.  That was another thing I didn't like about it - having to pay 50 cents per sauce. Usually the first is gratis.  However,  you do have to use sauce with their chicken in my opinion.  Otherwise it would be absolutely tasteless. There does not seem to be any seasoning in the breading.  However, the chicken is very very tender,  so I DID like that part.   The mascarpone mac and cheese was also ok.  You wouldn't be missing out. 

The first not so great impression I had about this place was when I first called in to ask what their deliver fee was.  She says "it' $2.. it says it online."  For some reason the latter portion of that statement pinched a nerve because of it's implications and the tone.  I saw their information on this ad they dispensed at dorms, and nowhere on that ad did it say 1)  you have to make the delivery order on-line and 2) there is a $2 fee so no need to get catty over it.  Next time, write that fee on your flyers before you start abrasively flapping your lips.

Excellent. Authentic home style Greek cooking. Fantastic fresh fish, usual other things but well done, huh quality and friendly staff. Very reasonable Greek Wine by the glass of bottle too. Cut over others here for sure.

So, after a long day at a rained out Busch Gardens, my friends and I decided to stop by a local sushi place to redeem the day!

The sushi at Tsunami is fresh, beautifully presented, and a bit pricey.  Each of their signature rolls is at least $10 and we had ordered their special roll, "Valentine Roll", which was $15.50.  The size of the rolls are average and to be quite honest both the rolls we ordered tasted very similar.

The service was awkwardly out of place as we had a Caucasian male serving us with a Brooklyn accent and very macho-like attitude.  Definitely belonged in a Tony Roma's or something.  He was a little annoying and didn't seem to listen very well.  

Besides that, we all had a good time and would come back if ever in the area again.  The atmosphere is average, food was a little above average, and the service...well, I think we were just unlucky although he was attentive.  Overall, the waves were choppy but definitely not worthy enough to be categorized as a "tsunami"

I love cheese!!!! I prefer Gouda in everything when possible! Everything here was delicious but super rich! I was only able to eat of the big cheesy grilled cheese sandwich! I think all grill cheese sandwich should come with tomato soup or something to cut the fatty richness of the sandwich. Just a small cup.  

My hubby really enjoyed his cheezy melt! I should have gotten this too cause I love meat and cheese. Fries are generic.  Not homemade. They should cut their own fries cause it would be delicious than frozen fries.


Love the creamy Mac and cheese! It's just cream and not as stringy as I would like but overall tasty. It needs like a Panko crust on top for a great crunch!  Will be back soon!

We went here for a professional lunch a while back. Smokin Thighs delivers on one specialty, and it does it extremely well--bbq chicken any way you like it. We actually had a toy dump truck full of wings for each table. That's right: not a bowl, not a tray, not a plate but a dump truck. The wings were absolutely delectable and fittingly served as the seasonings were a bit of a grab-bag combo: jalapeÃ±os, onions, tomatos, cheese sauce, bbq sauce, and more. They were rich, just a bit spicy, and finger-lickin' good. Of the other chicken items that were ordered, I really enjoyed the buffalo chicken dip. Just the right amount of heat followed by a sour tang which marries well with tortilla chips. All of the offerings were delicious, but I imagine ordering just one would satisfying my bbq chicken cravings for at least a week. Heavy, honest-to-goodness bbq.

The bartenders are attentive, kind, and easily some of the best in town. I had absolutely no negative experiences with any of the staff here, and they were all so accommodating to our large party taking up nearly half of their restaurant. Drinks and food were delivered in a timely matter, and no one complained of any thirst or hunger for the hours we frequented the location. 

My only complaint would be parking. Try to avoid rush hours to this location as the lot is a bit small. You can always park across the busy street, but it's difficult to find a crosswalk nearby to make your way back to the restaurant. 

Indulge in the delicious chicken and order a drink from the lovely staff. Smokin' Thighs puts the happy back into hour.

Looking back, I wish I came here hungrier... We had spent a day in the French Quarter eating here and there so by the time we got here, there wasn't much room left to eat more. My local friend said we had to eat the grilled oysters so we split a half dozen. So that was 2 for each of us. I really wished I could have eaten more because it was so good! I am more of a raw oyster kind of gal and my husband prefers oyster Rockefeller, but both of us were in love with these oysters. Full of butter and cheese! What's even better is the sauce on the platter that you can scoop up with the bread they serve... so bad for you (health wise), but so yummy.

Drinks.
I got the swamp water... fun name. It looked like Mountain Dew, but a fun mixed drink to enjoy.

Service.
We spent time at the bar and our bartender was great. I followed his recommendation for my mixed drink and couldn't be happier. 

Overall.
Chargrilled oysters is a NOLA life experience! Please get it and come hungry to fully enjoy. If I'm ever back in this town, I will be sure to get a whole dozen for myself alone.

If you like ice cream, you'll love frozen custard. It reminds me of extremely dense soft serve, but with a rich flavor.  This place is so popular that it hired an armed security guard to keep the patrons in line during the chaos in the parking lot.  If you're visiting St. Louis, it's a must. If you can't make it, they have a vending machine at the airport.

For those not from St. Louis....Forest Park might well be the heart of the city. A massive park right smack in the middle of the city,  with golf courses, tennis centers, Science Center,  Art Museum, Muny, History Museum and one of the best Zoo's in the world, every thing is top notch.....

......and

......it's 

.....ALL

FREE!*

*unless you're a tax payer in St. Louis City or County!

This Publix is tiny for a grocery store, but decently stocked for its size. Definitely smaller than most other Publix locations, I appreciate the ease of finding those couple of items I need quickly, without feeling like I've hiked a great distance. The pharmacy is super convenient, too, though the deli is always very busy. The parking lot is also more intimate; I'm usually able to park very close to the entrance. Cashiers are typically plentiful, though I often forget that most customers aren't doing a big weekly shop here & the express lanes tend to be the longest lines. As a fun perk, though I'm not sure which evenings, I'm delighted to find a wine tasting when I stop by after work.

Came for lunch on a Wednesday and I was very pleased with what I stumbled into! After soon research on simple lunch sandwiches on a weekday, I just ended up walking around on 2nd street and checking out menus on my way, until I found that Bourbon & Branch has vegan cheese options, a weekday brunch menu, and so many options! I only tried two of them today: The cheesesteak and the chicken parmesan (and a side biscuit). 

Wow! The peppers/onions and vegan cheese on the cheesesteak made it one of the best dairy-free options I've had in the city, and the chicken parmesan was perfectly crusted with great sauce and a fresh side salad, just added a bit of salt. Price is not the cheapest, but relatively okay for the size of sandwich and quality. Since it's weekend lunch and a lil slow, the initial service to put in our orders wasn't the quickest, but the bartender walked over when he saw we were ready for a few minutes and made sure we were eating quickly. Looking at the mixed reviews, can't wait to come back and update on the vegan mac n cheese and the brunch menu as well!

It's real whole foods.
Southern dishes with all its charms.
I personally enjoy the waffle and bacon. This is good food with excellent service. I return again & again as I have since 2000.

Great event venue and water front park. Love rock the park on the first Thursday of the month and Community yoga every Sunday night at 6:00. I went the Sunday before Halloween and more than 500 people came out for the costume optional yoga event.  Guys were doing yoga in tutus! It was a great time with great yoga. You never know what cool event will be hosted there any night of the week. Check out the downtown partnership website and email list. It gives you a weekly breakdown of what is happening at the park and all over downtown.

What a great little restaurant! Conveniently located in the heart of Center City, we popped in on a fairly quiet Monday night. Reservations were made for 5:30 PM and we were lucky that we were seated quickly and we could actually hear each other during our conversation. We had a friendly server who was great about getting our drinks and food out to us quickly.

The menu is quite small, and for that reason, you will appreciate it as most of the food was literally in our laps within a few minutes of ordering. I went for the standard $19 spaghetti and meatballs. Huge serving, and I could only attempt to finish half, only because I wanted to also have some dessert. And mama, those were some monstrous meatballs, with a cheesy interior.  I found the gravy to be a tad bit salty, but only because I tend to not salt my food so I notice those things.The pasta was al dente, perfect consistency.

For dessert, we shared a tiramisu cake. Nice and light and fluffy.

now THIS is what i'm talkin about. you haven't lived til you've had really good soondubu (soft tofu soup). and this ish is the real deal.

if jong ka jib sits at 5 stars in my book, then i'd literally have to go back to every center city korean restaurant review i've ever written and downgrade them by one star (at least). that's how much better this place is. it just completely blows all those so-called korean places in center city out of the water.

the interior decoration is about as traditional as korean restaurants get. and the flavors stay true to the korean taste buds.. no diluting spices to placate the westernized palate. of course, you can always ask for your food to be less spicy. ahem *weaksauce* ahem. they also give every customer a huge stone bowl of rice to accompany their meal. L-O-V-E.

the banchan is decent. more fresh than anything i've tasted in the city, but not a very wide selection - only about 5 dishes. however i'll take quality over quantity any day.
